column2: WASHINGTON, July 28-- A more liberal foreign view of United States regulatory policy in the maritime field may result from recent visits abroad by the chairman of the Federal Maritime Commission.

MY previous Caribbean cruise occurred many years ago; that is, in 1929. An old traveler, they say, never admits that anything could possibly be the same as it used to be. And so, having just returned from my second cruise down there, I must say that almost nothing is.
GRANT, Neb., July 28 (AP) --Joe Kumor, a wheat farmer, wiped the sweat of a harvest day from his windblown brow and gazed out across the golden prairie.

DEARTH is not in the lexicon of Dino Di Laurentiis. The Italian producer, here last week to promote both "The Best of Enemies" (due at the Fine Arts on Aug. 6) and "Barabbas" (coming to the De Mille on Oct. 10), revealed enough production plans to accommodate a major studio.
Many squadrons of the Air National Guard now returning from European service during the Berlin crisis, will return to state status as skeletonized units, according to a National Guard analysis.

A DOOR decorated by Gauguin that Somerset Maugham bought in Tahiti for 400 francs was sold not long ago for $37,400. At the same sale, an early Picasso fetched $227,000, one of the highest prices ever paid at auction for the work of a living artist.
A beach house built on sand can last if one or the other of two principles of the Taproot Principle or the Boat Principle are followed.

IN 1939 America's greatest prehistorian, Carl W. Blegen of the University of Cincinnati, revolutionized our knowledge of the Greek second millennium B.C. by his excavation at Homer's Sandy Pylos in southwestern Greece.

Annual Pointers Sometimes petunias are battered by thunderstorms or winds or the plants just become leggy. All is not lost. Petunias can be cut back to within four to six inches from the ground. New growth appears shortly and in another three to four weeks the plants will be as floriferous as before.

The furious post-war officebuilding flurry along Park Avenue may have dulled the public's impression of that avenue as a residential "Gold Coast," but the broad boulevard is still overwhelmingly an avenue of carriage-trade residences.

NOTTINGHAM, England, July 28 (Reuters)--Pakistan's batting failed again today against England's fast bowlers. Bad light stopped play in the fourth test seventy minutes before the scheduled close of the third day.
The average war veteran who bought a home in 1961 was not quite 34 years old, according to an analysis of home buying throughout the country made by the Veterans Administration.

LOS ANGELES, July 28-- Frank Howard continued his phenomenal show of power tonight by driving in four runs with a homer and two singles as the league-leading Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the San Francisco Giants, 8--6.

Yankee deficits have a strong tendency to vanish on the winds in the late innings of baseball games at the Stadium. Such was the case again yesterday in the seventh inning when John Blanchard bashed a pinch-hit homer with two men on base for a 4-3 triumph over the White Sox.
PEOPLE who do not follow dance activities and developments in detail must find it difficult on occa sion to make sense of all that happens in the name of dance.
LIMA, Peru, July 28--United States military attaches have resumed some public contacts with leaders of the Peruvian armed forces.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 28 --Neutral Austria and Sweden presented their case today for admission to the European Economic Community as associate members.

PAGE, Ariz.--The Colorado River and its canyons, first explored by man less than a century ago, are about to undergo a great change. Before 1962 ends, diversion tunnels that now bypass the river's silty waters around the new Glen Canyon Dam will be closed.

THE family room in the American home today is a far cry from the original recreation or "rumpus" room. It is a second, more intimate, living room. No longer a catch-all for odd pieces of furniture, it is keyed, in decoration, to the rest of the house with special care taken to select furnishings that withstand hard wear and are easy to maintain.

The General Electric Company has developed a combined cycle gas and steam turbinegenerator described as 12 to 15 per cent more efficient than comparable steam turbine-generators. The new unit is expected to strengthen G. E.'s bid for business overseas, as well as at home.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 28 (UPI)--Johnny Counts, a speedy rookie halfback who played one season at the University of Illinois, was the offensive standout today in the New York Giants' first "controlled" scrimmage.
HICKSVILLE, L, L, July 28 -The Hicksville School Board decided early today to take no action on a petition for a public referendum on a school prayer.

VIEINTIANE, Laos, July 28 (UPI)-Vice Premier Prince Souphanouvong told the United States Ambassador today that five Americans and a Filipino held by the Pathet Lao forces would be returned here Monday.

MIAMI BEACH, July 28 (UPI)--Mike DeJohn of Miami checked the bull-rushing attack of the Canadian heavyweight champion, Bob Cleroux, with a long-reaching defense tonight and gained a unanimous tenround decision at the Miami Beach Auditorium.

JOAN SUTHERLAND, the coloratura from Australia, will star next season on one of the "Voice of Fire stone" telecasts over the American Broadcasting Company network. The music will be conducted by her husband, Richard Bonygne.
BOSTON, July 28--The 1962 session of the Massachusetts Legislature closed this week. Leaders of both major parties were certain they had manufactured political ammunition for the election campaign.
"An object in motion tends to continue in motion, "Sir Isaac Newton liked to say, "and an object at rest tends to continue at rest."

TIDEWORTH, England, July 27--A series of crude but colorful drawings, all containing the words "welcome to Tidworth," remained fastened today to a wall of the new school for Gurkha army children that opened here this week.

ANYONE who thinks, not without reason, that rural Long Island is being Levit-towned out of ex istence would do well to visit Stony Brook, a North Shore pocket of fierce resistance to the dormitory suburb.
The rebuilding that has changed the face of Third Avenue has been carried over to the side streets on both sides of the thoroughfare from Fortysecond to Fifty-ninth Streets.

The New York man's university club is changing. The day when he could push through leather doors into a world marked "men only" and walk across green carpets through somber wood panelling and up to a heavy oak bar is passing.

In an unusual move to make an independent institution of higher learning available for free adult schooling, Point Park Junior College in Pittsburgh announced last week that it would give adults who have dropped out of school a chance to get their diplomas. Dr. Dorothy

WASHINGTON, July 28-- The problem of wavelength allocations is providing the first critical test of whether the nations of the world are willing to cooperate in establishing a global communications system with satellites.
CHICAGO, July 28 (AP)-- Barbara Hunter's Kootenai splashed through the rain and mud at Arlington Park today to win the $28,375 Beverly Handicap by two and a half lengths.

CLEVELAND, July 28 (UPI) --The Minnesota Twins scored three runs in the ninth inning-- two on a single by Rich Rollins --to defeat the Cleveland Indians, 5--2, today behind Jim Kaat's five-hit pitching.
Resistance to high-rise apartments in the suburbs is really just a rear-guard action, a hopeless battle against the inevitable, a New York architect said last week.
MOSCOW, July 28--The Soviet Union has begun construction of a modernized electric belt railroad around Moscow to ease the capital's heavy traffic.

IT used to be fun to observe, in Moscow, how Tass, the Soviet news agency, handled the news to glorify the Soviet Union and, generally, to depreciate the United States, how it found quotations even in Oshkosh, if necessary, to fit its purposes...

IT is Christmas Eve in the little West German town of Tungerstadt, only a few frozen fields removed from the Iron Curtain. In a cozy living room before a decorated tree, the Fahrenbach family has gathered to celebrate.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 28-- Columbia, the defender of the America's Cup four years ago and a candidate this time to meet the Australian sloop Gretel in September, struck a blow for her cause today as she defeated her three 12-Meter rivals on the New York Yacht Club's squadron run from Block Island to Narragansett Bay.
NEW DELHI, India, July 28 --There were indications this week that India would move closer toward the Soviet Union in the military and economic fields.

GLYNDEBOURNE EACH year the season at Glyndebourne grows longer and the repertory more adventurous. Having begun with a limited number of performances of Mozart in 1934, the festival of opera this season runs from May 21 to Aug. 19, playing invariably to sold-out houses.

BESIDES rubber and tin, the suspense story continues to be one of the most dependable products of the Federation of Malaya. And well it might, for with its rich resources, hardlosing Communist terrorists, racial mixtures, opium traffic and birth pains, the country is a luxuriant seedbed for intrigue.
WASHINGTON, July 28-- The Administration hopes to salvage in Congress at least part of President Kennedy's proposed civil defense program.

ATLANTA, July 25 (AP)-- Robert T. (Bobby) Jones Jr., who won a golf tournament at the age of 9 and retired from active competition at 28 after winning four major tournaments in one year, today was named the 1962 winner of the Walter Hagen Award.

POLYNESIA has fascinated Europeans increasingly dur ing the past two hundred years with its lush islands scattered over coral seas and its handsome people free from the inhibitions of the Puritan tradition.
BUENOS AIRES, July 28-- The Argentine state-owned railway system is hardly operating in high gear, but it has taken a series of measures to shift out of reverse.

AS the motion-picture business changes, so do its theatres. On Thursday, one of Broadway's mid town landmarks--the old Capitol Theatre on Fifty-first Street --will reopen for trade examination, before its public unveiling on Aug. 8, with a new name on its marquee. The Capitol will have become Loew's Cinerama.

BRUGES, Belgium-- Bruges is unique. The medieval and Renaissance world has miraculously survived in this charming Flemish city encircled and intersected by quiet waterways. Here the past has been notably preserved.

WASHINGTON, July 28-- The Administration is not yet satisfied with the Peruvian military junta's moves toward constitutional government, and it plans to hold up diplomatic recognition until further concessions are made.
ALGIERS, July 28--Premier Benyoussef Ben Khedda called today for an immediate meeting of the nationalist movement's parliament to settle the Algerian leadership struggle.
ROME--By driving at least part of the way through Europe, Americans who come over here this summer can enjoy the standard sights for which the Continent is famous.

EVERY writer of science for laymen knows that chemistry is a tough subject to getacross. It is not visual or dramatic. Only a few chemical reactions result in explosions, bad smells, or even changes of color.
LAUGHTER is highly unpredictable, as anyone knows who ever tried to tell his wife a hilariously funny story.

LIMA, Peru, July 28--A new form of militarism has appeared under the Latin-American sun. The armed forces of Argentina and Peru have deposed their constitutional Presidents and taken control of the political life of their countries.
United States exports this year are showing evidence of reaching new high levels in almost all major world markets except one Latin America.

PALERMO, Italy. FROM Montelepre, the mountaintop village where the bandit Giuliano once reigned, to Palermo, the capital of Sicily, the road descends in a series of escarpments until, with a final wrench, it twists and falls, exposing for a few glorious moments a panorama of the golden shell of this ancient city on the Tyrrhenian Sea.

James R. Day, vice president for research and engineering of the Radio Engineering Laboratories, Inc., 29-01 Borden Avenue, Long Island City, (Queens, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital. He was 52 years old and lived at Peconic, L.I.
OCEANPORT, N.J. July 28 --Affectionately ran away with the important money in the $100,440 Sorority Stakes at Monmouth Park today. !

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) --A Food and Drug Administration official revealed today that the agency has been considering changes in its regulations concerning distribution of experimental drugs to reduce hazards from their use.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) --The United States has promised up to $180,000,000 in aid to Tunisia in support of that country's three-year development program, the Agency for International Development (A.I.D.) announced today.
MEXICO CITY, July 25-- Mexico's efforts to expand her navy and merchant marine were highlighted this week by the visit of the United States Secretary of the Navy, Fred Korth.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 28 --Valuable stands of ponderosa pine in California's Sierra Nevada are infected with two varieties of beetles and thousands of the trees are being desroyed.
GLASTONBURY, Conn., July 28--Miss Chelsey Ann Carrier and David Fitch Remington were married this afternoon in the First Church of Christ Congregational, by the Rev. Dr. Russell M. McGown.

LONDON, July 28--Britain is conducting intricate constitutional talks in London aimed at fusing her strategically important Colony of Aden with twenty-three sheikdoms and sultanates in the colony's vast desert hinterland.
The cooperative advertising cauldron is boiling again these days, and there are fears that manufacturers, retailers and ad agencies alike may wind up a bit scalded.

Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Jewish Congress, has canceled representation of the congress at the Vatican Council, which is scheduled to begin in Rome on Oct. 11. The council will consider the entire field of Roman Catholic practice and doctrine.

MIDWAY between July 4 and Labor Day, the im-- minence of autumn is signaled by the first state fairs. Two traditional harbingers of the season--the Delaware State, Fair and the North Dakota State Fair--came and went last week.

WILLIAM GOLDING is something of a publishing phenomenon. His first novel, "Lord of the Flies," was successful in England, the country of his birth, but it appeared here in 1955 to discouraging reviews, sold barely over 2,000 copies and went quickly out of print.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 28 --Henry B. Sprague of the Cedar Point Yacht Club, Westport, won the opening race, then placed second and took a 3 point lead for the Long Island Sound Lightning Class championship today.
ALBANY, Ga., July 28--A Negro lawyer staggered from the courthouse today with blood streaming from his head and accused Sheriff D.C. Campbell of caning him.

ALBANY, July 28--A New York City architect is preparing designs and cost estimates for a shrine where the first of two original drafts of Abraham Lincoln's Emancipation Procclamation will be kept on permanent public display here.
LOS ANGELES, July 28-- Gov. Edmund G. Brown is confronted with another deathsentence dilemma like the Chessman case.

One hundred years ago this month the LandGrant Act provided a grant of 30,000 acres for each Senator and Representative in Congress. The money from the sale of this gift of public land was to be used to establish at least one college in each state to "promote the liberal and practical education of the industrial classes in the several pursuits and professions of life."

FOR light-work gardening and low-upkeep plant collecting, it would be difficult to find two more varied and delightful groups of perennial plants than the sempervivums and sedums. Both are succulents and belong to the orpine or stonecrop family (Crassulaceae), and both include many fascinating species.

HOW good have America's Presidents been? Which ones have left an enduring mark? Who were the failures? Where do the others rank? Seventy-five students of American history, including two in English universities, have undertaken to answer these questions.
President Carlos Julio Arosemena Monroy of Ecuador yesterday inspected two projects in New York State 300 miles apart that reflect accomplishment in the present and confidence in the future.
DUBLIN, July 28--The Irish International Airline reported today a profit for the fiscal year ending March 31.

Mrs. Sarah T. Lusby of Cincinnati has announced here the engagement of her daughter, Miss Lucinda Taylor Lusby, to Randall Malin of New York. It should not be assumed, from the eclat with which Prince Souvanna Phouma has been received in Washington, that he holds the destiny of Laos in his hands. He does not. The neutralist Prime Minister of the Laotian troika Government will be an influential figure in the new regime.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 28-- Republican organization, supporters of Richard M. Nixon for Governor are hopeful of demonstrating next week-end that the party in California is united behind him.

An old Brooklyn neighborhood, rich in tradition but poor in almost every other way, is being rejuvenated by the construction of the Lindsay Park middleincome cooperative apartment development. The first section of the twenty-two-acre project was begun last week.

Howard J. Samuels, a Canandaigua business man who is seeking the Democratic nomination for Governor, proposed yesterday that the party hold a series of regional meetings, instead of a mock convention, to open its campaign early.
Clarence E. Lovejoy will retire this week as boating editor of The New York Times. He has held the post for twentyeight years.

AMARILLO, Tex., July 28 (AP)--A witness at a court of inquiry on Billie Sol Estes testified today that at least some lending companies had a chance to make 80 to 70 per cent interest if the Texan's empire had not collapsed.

LITTLE grown as a house plant, yet delightful for sunny windows or small home greenhouses, is the plume plant or plume flower (Jacobinia carnea). A member of the acanthus family, this native of Brazil is grown for its showy heads of densely clustered rose or crimson-colored flowers.

WASHINGTON, July 28--Americans seem to be vaguely uneasy about the state of labor relations in their country. This sense that all is not well has been articulated in Congress and underlay a question at the Presidential news conference a few days ago. The fact is, however, that the strike appears gradually to be fading away in the United States.

The consumer price index shows a seasonal increase. Apples and watermelons and some other fresh fruits provided bad news for consumers last week. The Government's consumer price index for June showed a rise of one-tenth of 1 per cent, to a record of 105.3, mostly because of a 9 per cent increase in the price of fresh fruits.

Peter and Paul in Fleetwood was the scene here this morning of the marriage of Miss Kathleen Maria Synnott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Boyd Synnott of Mount Vernon, to John Raymond Schoemer 3d. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Schoemer Jr, of North Tarrytown.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 9--A question that obtains among art lovers in Israel, if not so much among the artists themselves, is whether something that could be called typical Israeli art will ever develop.

The largest international congress on cancer research was held in Moscow last week under the auspices of the International Union Against Cancer, an agency composed of eightyseven organizations in sixtytwo countries, including the United States.
STEELTON, Pa., July 28-- At least twenty-two persons were killed and 120 injured in the derailment of a Pennsylvania Railroad excursion train late this afternoon.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 28--St. Paul's Memorial Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Sarah Rutledge Parker to Hunter Holmes Wood.
IT has taken ten years between the idea and the execution, but "The Masculine Principle" is finally set for Broadway. Saint Subber and the Theatre Guild will present the play late in January.
Precautions to be taken in the hurricane season of August, September and October were announced yesterday by Robert E. Condon, director of the New York City Office of Civil Defense.

WATERBURY, Conn., July 28 --The marriage of Miss Margaret Mary Fitzgerald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Fitzgerald, to Arthur John Murphy Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Murphy of New York, took place here this morning.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 28 (UPI)--Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower spent a quiet day sight-seeing in Copenhagen today. He discovered that when the sun shines here autograph hunters are absent.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 28--The first annual Croton Shakespeare Festival of the Recreation Commission and Parent-Teachers Association will open Thursday night in the auditorium of the Croton-Harmon High School.

HAVERFORD, Pa, July 28-- Margaret Smith of Australia today defeated Mrs. Karen Hantze Susman of San Antonio, champion of Wimbledon, in one of the most vital expositions of women's tennis seen in this country in years.

MIAMI, Fla., July 28--A strong weather disturbance last week near the French Antilles, 1,500 miles from Miami, brought the attention of the people of Florida once again to the operations of the United States Weather Bureau in watching for hurricanes.

POPULAR-priced books on several aspects of photography and its techniques have been published re cently. One of these is Patricia Caulfield's "Complete Guide to Kodachrome II" (New York: Amphoto-Universal, 128 pp., $l.95), which is one of the few paperback manuals that really delivers what the title promises.

A psychologist at Washington University in St. Louis concludes, after extensive research, that the proficiency tests in foreign languages required traditionally of most Ph.D. candidates have become "a mere gesture," having little significance as a measure of true learning.

MOUNTAIN TOP, Pa, July 28--Mine Rosemary Neville Shea and Albert Richard Caputo were married here this morning in St. Jude's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Edward J. Nolan, who also celebrated the nuptial mass. A reception was given at the Westmoreland Club in Wilkes-Barre.
A 2,400-home community, the largest planned on Long Island since Levittown was built shortly after World War II, will be erected in Huntington.

A vessel that can float horizontally like a log or vertically like an inverted beer bottle went through its acceptance trials successfully last week in Puget Sound.
ST. LOUIS, July 28--The Mets won their second game in a little over twenty-tour hours tonight. They did it the hard way.

LONDON, July 28--Britain is seriously concerned about the potential dangers developing in the Congo. But her policy is not as outwardly tough as that of the United States.

Prime Minister Macmillan's Cabinet shake-up on July 13 was the political equivalent of a nuclear bomb. The blast rocked Parliament and the whole political structure of Great Britain, and the fall-out has descended on the Conservatives as much as the Laborites and Liberals.
CLEVELAND, July 28-- Great Lakes vessels carried 44,495,778 net tons of iron ore, coal grain from the opening of lakes traffic this spring to the first of this month.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 28 --In Christ Protestant Episcopal Church in Christiana Hundred this afternoon, Miss Ann Brooks Longer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Longer of Oberod, Wilmington, was married to Richard Irwin Gibbons Jones. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Black Jones of Plumly Farm, Westtown, Pa,
ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 27 --Turkey's livestock, vital to the nation's economy, is being threatened by a new type of foot-and-mouth disease known as South African Territory-One (S.A.T.-One).
TOKYO, July 28--The United States and Japan, military partners by treaty, will hold one of their rare official military consultations here next week.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 28--Roger Ginsberg of Riverdale, who plays out of the Harrison Country Club, reached the final of the Westchester amateur golf championship today by scoring two easy victories at the Wykagyl C.C.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 28-- The Kennedy Administration's cautious optimism on the progress of South Vietnam's war against the Communist insurgents is not widely reflected among Americans stationed here to help in that fight.

CINCINNATI, July 28 (UPI) --Jerry Lynch and Gordie Coleman batted in three runs apiece today to give the Cincinnati Reds and Jim O'Toole a 9-3 victory over the Milwaukee Braves. The defeat ended the Braves' longest winning streak of the season at seven games.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., July 28 --The home of her parents was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Judith Ann Campbell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. M. Rudolph Campbell, to Pietro Piussi. The bridegroom is the son of Signor and Signora Ottone Piussi of Udine, Italy.

The re-emergence of the Congo crisis has added to the uneasiness in the United Nations about the trials ahead of the organization between now and next April, when U Thant's term as Acting Secretary General will expire.

Prices of most over-thecounter stocks moved in a narrow range last week in quiet trading. The exceptions were the life insurance, utility and savings and loan groups, which moved ahead on good volume.

LAST week's exchange of live television between the European Continent and North America erad icated time as the airplane conquered distance. That more than 200,000,000 persons between Belgrade, Yugoslavia, and Seattle, Wash., and the Arctic Circle and Florida simultaneously watched the same happening almost defies ready comprehension.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., July 28--Miss Sandra Walcott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Walcott of Newton Center, was married here this afternoon to Henry Eckhardt Jr., son of Mrs. Henry Eckhardt of Bridgehampton, L.I., and the late Mr. Eckhardt.

DETROIT, July 28 (AP)-- Norm Cash, hitting only .237 in defense of his batting crown, strengthened his bid for the home run title with another tape measure shot today as the Detroit Tigers trounced Los Angeles. 6--1.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 28-- Attempts to salvage part of the 34-foot sidewheeler Empire State, now lying in twenty-five feet of water in Bristol, R.I., harbor, are being made by a group headed by Jackson Jenks, director of the New England Naval and Maritime Museum.

Given time--and God willing--I think I can do it."

THE 1963 renewal of the annual Intercollegiate Bridge Tournament may be conducted on a much expanded plan if proposals made at a preliminary meeting in New York last week are adopted. The tournament is conducted by the Association of College Unions, which has just appointed a new tournament chairman, E.J. Ritter of Bradley University in Peoria, Ill.

CINCINNATI, July 29 (UPI) Joey Jay pitched the Cincinnati Reds to a 2-1 victory over the Milwaukee Braves in the second game today after the Reds had moved into third place by winning, 8 6, before 29,515, the season's largest home crowd.

Red Nichols, who plays the cornet, is continuing a romance with the bass saxophone that began thirty-five years ago. It is being conducted at the Metropole Cafe, where he is appearing with his Five Pennies.
LONDON, July 29 The tone of the London stock market improved this week, with stock averages showing a moderate gain.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 29 Roger Ginsberg, a 23-yearold Bronx golfer, today added the Westchester amateur title to the Westchester open crown already in his possession.

Uris, president of the Uris Buildings Corporation, and Mrs. Uris of 941 Park Avenue and Purchase, N.Y. Her husband's parents are Mrs. Lilen Sanger of New York, London and Nassau, the Bahamas, and Dr. Mack Lent of Los Angeles.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 29 William Bond of La Jolla, Calif., today won the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship, the biggest prize that has yet fallen to the tall 20-year-old Southern, California junior.

Two new major features have been booked at first-run midtown theatres. Metro-GoldwynMayer's "Two Weeks in Another Town," an adaptation of Irwin Shaw's novel of modern Rome, will open next at the Paramount. Kirk Douglas, Edward G. Robinson, Cyd Charisse, George Hamilton and Claire Trevor have the leading roles in the color drama. It was directed by Vincente Minnelli and produced by John Houseman.

PARIS, July 29 Fashion circles were still buzzing today with the excitement engendered Friday evening by the fall fashion collection presented by Simonetta and Fabiani. The Italian designers, husband and wife who have until this season maintained separate couture houses in Rome, made their initial venture into French couture a joint success.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 29 Vincent Price has purchased 1,700 works of art to be sold by Sears, Roebuck Co. in ten cities beginning in September. The sale will probably open in Denver.

A Bishop of the Spanish Reformed Church said here yesterday that "there is no freedom for Protestants" in Spain. Protestants, said the Right Rev. Santos M. Molina of Madrid, "are only tolerated" by the Spanish Government.

The panel of fact-finders named to investigate a labor dispute between Canadian and United States seamen will have a preliminary report ready by Wednesday. The panel was appointed by Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg.

The Rev. Dr. Edward Lissman, senior chaplain of the Fire Department and founder and former chief rabbi of the Riverside Synagogue, died yesterday morning at Polyclinic Hospital. He was 92 years old and lived at 180 Riverside Drive.

NORTH HILLS, L.I,, July 29 Bill Tully of Pelham, N.Y., seeded second, upset George Ball of Woodhaven, Queens, seeded first, 6 3, 7 5, today to win the Eastern junior veterans' tennis championship at the Shelter Rock Tennis Club.
PITTSBURGH, July 29 The latest order receipts of steel mills indicate an August shipping rate equal to 55 per cent of capacity or slightly better.

LIMA, Peru, July 29 (AP) Former President Manuel Prado y Ugarteche was freed and transferred today from the ship that has been his prison since July 18 to the estate of a relative. There the national police provided a guard for him.

ST. LOUIS, July 29 Rallies after two out in the eighth inning of the first game and the seventh inning of the second enabled the St. Louis Cardinals to sweep the Mets, 6 5 and 5 1, today before 15,443 fans at Busch Stadium.
BAASTAD, Sweden, July 29 (AP) Sweden gained the Davis Cup interzone tennis finals today, breaking Italy's long dominance in the European Zone with a 4-1 victory.

Congress has again asserted its constitutional authority to "raise and maintain" military forces. A $48,136,247,000 defense appropriation act for the current fiscal year that provides more funds, for two important items, than the Administration had requested, is near final approval. The legislative rebuffs to Secretary of Defense McNamara's program, though tempered, are definite.
DAMASCUS, Syria, July 29 (AP) The Syrian Government asserted today it had foiled an attempt backed by the United Arab Republic to overthrow Syria's regime and reunite the two countries.

GRAND TETON NATIONAL PARK, Wyo., July 29 (AP) A snowstorm struck towering Grand Teton peak as a party of ten mountain climbers neared the top Thursday and one died of exposure before rescuers reached them today.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Monday, July 30 Customs officers in the six European Common Market countries put into effect last midnight a radically new system of handling trade in farm products. Over the years ahead millions of farmers and traders inside and outside of Europe will almost surely feel the effects.
Fur-trimmed coats and double knit wool suits continued to be the most popular sales items last week, as they have been for the past several months, resident buying offices here reported.
STEELTON, Pa., July 29 (AP) A track out of alignment may have caused the derailment yesterday of a Pennsylvania Railroad excursion train into the Susquehanna River, the railroad said today.

The Castro Convertible Corporation, manufacturer of convertible furniture, has leased the corner store containing 6,000 square feet in the building under construction at 1010 Third Avenue, northwest corner of Sixtieth Street.
WASHINGTON, July 29 Defense Department officials called on Congress today not to undermine current civil defense efforts by approving deep cuts in funds.
PITTSBURGH, July 29 The marriage of Miss Donna Rae Berkman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Berkman of Steubenville, Ohio, to Robert Arthur Paul took place tonight.
CHICAGO, July 29 (AP) Except for a show of firmness at midweek, the grain futures market last week was belabored by speculative liquidation and short selling on the Board of Trade.
The state's Democratic county leaders will meet today to decide on a proposal for an early consensus on a candidate for Governor before the Democratic state convention in September.
WASHINGTON, July 29 The United States Chamber of Commerce has given President Kennedy a ten-point program to reduce the flow of dollars out of the country.
LONDON, July 29 New appointments for the top civilservice positions in the Treasury were announced tonight.
Pete McArdle broke a thirtyyear record yesterday in winning the Road Runners Club New York Association ten-mile race at Van Cortlandt Park's quarter-mile cinder track in the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, advised the Kennedy Administration today to wait until it saw "the whites of the eyes of the recession" before asking for a tax cut.
"It is time to speak," a professor at Union Theological Seminary said yesterday. "Has the church nothing to say?"
THE wounds of youth are slow to heal, and a Missouri farm boy who became one of America's great merchant princes recalled recently, at the age of 86, the deprivations of his childhood.

The recovery of $93,500 in negotiable securities stolen in May from Carl M. Loeb, Rhoades Co. was announced yesterday. An anonymous postcard and the cooperation of an underworld informer were credited with a major role in the case.

WASHINGTON, July 29 Administration supporters will be working to salvage some major elements of President Kennedy's legislative program this week as Congress starts what is likely to be the last full month of the session.
BRISTOL, R.I., July 29 (AP) Deck strapping of a Civil War troop ship that burned and sank seventy-five years ago was recovered from thirty feet of water today by divers.

NEW LONDON, Conn., July 29 At her parents' home here today, Miss Renee Stern Dreyfus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Merrill Stern Dreyfus, was married to Arthur A. Greenberg. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Greenberg of New York.
Theodore R. Kupferman, who is seeking the City Council seat of the late Stanley M. Isaacs as a Republican candidate, charged yesterday that Mayor Wagner was dictating to the Council.
A new continuous warning system on births of babies with deformities is being started by the New York State Health Department.

Five New York City teachers continue on suspension without pay. For three of them over six years have passed since they were thus punished, first for refusing to turn informers against other teachers suspected of Communist sympathies and, after the State Education Commissioner and the courts ruled against the Board of Education in their case, for having made false statements in their applications. The remaining also because of misstatements in their personnel files.

OPERA buffs were out indroves at Lewisohn Stadium on Saturday for the annual Italian Night. Jan Peerce, the tenor; Roberta Peters, the soprano; Alfredo Antonini's conducting and the charms of a balmy summer night attracted about 15,000 persons to the City College amphitheatre.

WOODMERE, L. I., July 29-Playing with confidence and poise that belied his age, 20-year-old Ralph Johnston of the Garden City Country Club defeated George H. (Pete) Bostwick Jr. of the Meadowbrook Club, 6 and 5, in the Long Island amateur golf final today at the Woodmere Club.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 29 The iron grip that the 12-Meter yacht Weatherly had established on the Queen's Cup during recent years remained unrelaxed today. The Henry D. Mercer Syndicate's sloop gained the prize for a remarkable fourth successive time on the third racing day of the New York Yacht cruise.

WASHINGTON, July 29 A political impasse that is taking on the proportions of a personal feud has developed between some Democrats in Congress and the Administra tion over filling two vacancies on the Atomic Energy Commission.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 29 Julius Schutzman of 31 Fairview Road, executive head of the Gimbels New York department store and its branches, died today at Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown. He was 46 years old.
New York State's Democratic leadership can begin serious consideration of a candidate for Governor when Mayor Wagner returns on Thursday from a month in Europe.
ALBANY, Ga., July 29 City officials will seek contempt of court citations tomorrow against the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and other Negro leaders in the campaign against segregation here.

TODAY'S teen-agers wield tremendous purchasing pow er. They choose their own clothes, help select the family car, dictate the furnishings in their rooms and sometimes even strongly affect those in the whole house.
MIAMI, July 29 Three freed Cuban prisoners arrived in Miami today after payment by families and friends of a ransom of $175,000 to the Cuban regime.
PARIS, July 29 A leader of the Algerian dissident movement said here today that he expected the new political bureau headed by Vice Premier Ben Bella to assume power in Algeria on Thursday or Friday.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., July 29 Whitney Reed, the No. 1 ranked player in the country, and Mrs. Karen Hantze Susman, the Wimbledon champion, head a field of fifty-six men and thirty-six women in the thirtysixth annual Eastern grass courts tennis championships that open tomorrow at the Orange Lawn T.C.

THE Dutch Defense was long a favorite of the world champion, Mikhail Botvinnik, who used it to win many important victories. It certainly can prove irritating to White, particularly if he is confused about the best way to meet it.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., July 29 The marriage of Miss Jan Spielman, daughter of Mrs. Clement E. Schotland of Short Hills and Joseph Spielman of East Orange, to Dr. William Snyder took place today. The ceremony was performed at the Arch, a restaurant by Rabbi Louis M. Levitsky.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 29 Premier Cyrille Adoula formally proposed today a new Constitution for the Congo that makes significant concessions to demands for provincial self-rule from secessionist Katanga.

WASHINGTON, July 29 The head of the United States Alliance for Progress Program, Teodoro Moscoso, has told his staff here and in Latin-American centers that there will be no "celebration" of the Alliance's first anniversary next month because the results so far do not warrant one. The occasion will be noted without fanfare.

OSAKA, Japan, July 29 (AP) Satoka Tanaka of Japan bettered her world record for the 200-meter back-stroke with a time of 2 minutes 31.6 seconds today as the four-day Japanese swimming championships ended.

THAT was a gay gathering the Yankees assembled in their stadium on Saturday for the latest of their Old-Timers' Day masterpieces. And as usual, some of the most interesting scenes were those enacted under the stands before the old boys gave away their ages on the field.
WASHINGTON, July 29 The Federal Government, author and publisher, soon will show some of its literary products for the consumer-minded in a hundred post offices across the land.
KUMASI, Ghana, July 29 President Kwame Nkrumah opened a congress of his Convention Peoples party today with a stern order to weed out what he called "budget politicians" opponents of his budget.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 29 Eighty-nine teams entered the second session of the Masters' Mixed Team Contest tonight in the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament at the Leamington Hotel here. The tournament will continue through Aug. 7.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 29 (AP) A miniature poodle named Ch. Tedwin's Top Billing, owned by Col. E.E. Furgeson of Hollywood, Calif., won top honors today at the Santa Barbara Kennel Club show.
Eight reporters and editors have been awarded fellowships in Columbia University's Advanced International Reporting Program for the academic year 1962-63.

Every Tuesday, just after noon, a Cabot, a Lowell and a dozen other top New England business leaders sit down to lunch in an elegant wood-paneled suite on the twenty-fifth floor of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Building in Boston.
BONN, July 29 The U.S. Government sticks to the legend that recent command changes in both Washington and Rocquencourt are routine and involve no shift in strategic thinking.
CAIRO, Ill., July 29 (AP) A white integrationist leader and a Negro woman were arrested today and charged with disorderly conduct, the police said.

MOSCOW, July 29 The Soviet Union opened its first international horse fair today, but there were virtually no foreign buyers in evidence. Soviet trade officials, who staged the exhibition together with the Agriculture Ministry, expressed confidence, however, that buyers would arrive before the fair closed in three weeks.
By the end of 1970, perhaps as early as 1967, three Americans will be rocketed on a journey that, until Sputnik I, only a few visionaries believed would ever take place.
Bartenders at some of the Schrafft's restaurants in town have a complaint concerning the new advertising campaign developed for the chain by the McCann-Marschalk Company, Inc.
WASHINGTON, July 29 Maritime legislation has been in the doldrums in this session of Congress, partly as a result of a hold-out attitude attributed to some members over a disputed bill.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 29 Severe frost has caused extensive damage to coffee plantations in northwestern Parana State, the Brazilian Coffee Institute reported today.

LONDON, July 29 A parade in Manchester led by Sir Oswald Mosely, pre-war British Fascist leader and now head of the extremist Union Movement, was broken up by fighting today. Forty-seven persons were arrested.
