CHICAGO, July 29 One yardstick is as good as another for measuring the relative talents of the celebrated participants in tomorrow's all-star baseball game at Wrigley Field. All statistical omens indicate that the National Leaguers will subdue the Americans for the second time this season.
An American philosopher said yesterday he thought it might be a good idea if more Americans started going to jail for their beliefs.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 29 (AP) Alan Paton, the author, reported today he was visited Thursday at his home near Durban by an officer of the South African Government's Security Branch (political police) and questioned about his literary activities and movements.

MONTREAL, July 29 (AP) Ted Kroll, who hadn't won a major tournament since 1956 captured the $30,000 Canadian open golf championship today with a 72-hole total of 278. He won by two strokes over Charlie Sifford of Los Angeles.
BERLIN, July 29 East German guards apparently killed a young man near the West Berlin border today.

The Eighty-seventh Congress is limping toward adjournment in a mood curiously compounded of contentiousness and apathy. It has all but declared its independence of President Kennedy. Forgotten if it ever was heard is the President's declaration in his State of the Union Message last January that "the Constitution makes us not rivals for power but partners for progress."
Two trends more jobs for the skilled, fewer jobs for the unskilled will characterize New York's manpower picture between now and 1970, the city Labor Department said yesterday.
The business expansion, in its seventeenth month, has ground to a halt.

ALGIERS, July 29 Troops of the neutral nationalist military region adjoining Algiers took over the capital without a shot today. Their commanders declared the city open to "all the leaders whose contribution could hasten the resolution of the present crisis."
BUENOS AIRES. The Argentine Government is undertaking a far-ranging program of incentives to help Argentina's buffetted cattle-raising industry and agriculture.
The diversion of passengers from planes to 200-mile-anhour trains on short hauls along the Northeastern Seaboard was suggested yesterday by the Regional Plan Association.
WESTPORT, Conn., July 29 Miss Nancy Morris was married this afternoon to Ensign Robert D. Kaplan of the Navy, son of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Kaplan of Ossining, N.Y.
Several thousand Puerto Ricans gathered on the Central Park Mall yesterday to celebrate the tenth anniversary of the founding of the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico.

The imposing figure of an electronic Big Brother wearing a Treasury badge has struck fear into the tax evaders. The Internal Revenue Department's data processing system that will have everyone's number is scheduled for full operation beginning Jan. 1, 1966.
NAIROBI, Kenya, July 29 The chance that Africa's 200,000,000 people will join together under the banner of "panAfricanism" appears extremely remote.
About 100 Brooklyn detectives checked more than 2,000 Coney Island residences and other buildings yesterday in a search for a 9-year-old Manhattan girl who has been missing since Thursday.
ORAN, Algeria, July 29 Col. Saoutt El Arab, commander of the nationalist military region of Constantine, said here today that he now supported the Ben Bella group.
ST. LOUIS, July 29 (AP) An arbitrator has ordered Federal Barge Lines of St. Louis to reinstate forty employes with full back pay.

VIENNA, July 29 Bulgaria announced today big price increases for farm products, the abolition or reduction of income taxes for peasants and other benefits as incentives to the peasants to increase production and end the agricultural crisis.

THE time is ripe for sweet green peppers. Vegetable stands now are well stocked with freshly picked specimens that are crisp in texture and a burnished green in color. Predominant is the bell-shaped variety that is so good sliced and served raw in salads or stuffed with meats or other vegetables and baked.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 29 Dwight D. Eisenhower surrendered unconditionally to the Swedes today. He took back a remark about Sweden's socialism that caused concern and protest two years ago.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 29 The Communist-supported World Youth Festival opened here tonight with nearly two hours of almost incessant chanting of "peace and friendship."

GLENWOOD LANDING, L.I., July 29 Fire Commissioner Edward Thompson of New York warned Nassau officials today that the county would experience a "catastrophe" within ten years unless responsibility for fire inspection was removed from volunteer fire departments.

How much credit is being used for speculating in the stock market? The answer is that nobody knows. The Federal Reserve Board, which controls stock market credit through its power to set margin requirements, and the ...

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 29 The ninetyfourth Saratoga racing season will begin tomorrow, with the Flash Stakes as the main attraction. The twenty-four-day meeting will be concluded on Aug. 25 with the running of The Hopeful.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 29 Lord Casey said today he was reasonably certain Australian trade would not be appreciably affected if Britain entered the European Common Market. Her entry, he said, was inevitable.

Mrs. Eleanor Jackson Piel, former Legal Aid Society lawyer in Special Sessions court, has sent a letter to a Senate Judiciary subcommittee to rebut a charge by former Chief Justice Irving Ben Cooper that she was a "judge-baiter."
HIGHLAND, N.Y., July 29 Five elderly women and a man were killed in the head-on collision of two cars near here today. Two other persons were injured, one of them critically.

William Gilchrist Anderson, a Negro osteopath who was released on bond from jail in Albany, Ga., on Saturday, declared here last night that demonstrations would continue there "as long as segregation exists in the city of Albany as it does at the present time."

Belenenses of Portugal won the Second-Section championship of the International Soccer League yesterday by beating the Wiener Sport Club of Vienna, 2 1, as the regular-season play ended at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

Samuel Inselbuch, owner of the Inselbuch Press, 137 Hudson Street, and a former publicity and advertising man, died yesterday in Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. His age was 67 and he lived at 800 West End Avenue.

After several seasons that have left critics and audiences grumbling, the uptown appearance of two off-Broadway playwrights suggests that the theatre may return to the exciting activity of the Nineteen Twenties.

The military junta in Peru has won a battle. As soldiers, its members doubtless realize that victory in one battle is not decisive and that the war for democracy and social justice in Peru is far from over.
Net income of General Mills, Inc., in its fiscal year ended May 31, dipped to $10,154,000, or $1.25 a share, from $12,832,000, or $1.63 a share in the preceding year, the company announced yesterday.
The Long Island State Park Commission has agreed to buy two private sportsmen's clubs in Suffolk County and preserve them as wildlife refuges.

WEST MILFORD, N.J., July 29 A helicopter joined forces with week-end hikers today to airlift 1,000 pounds of building materials for a shelter on Bearfort Mountain. Bearfort is a 1,200-foot-high ridge near Greenwood Lake on the New Jersey-New York border.
LINCOLN, R.I., July 29 (AP) Lincoln Downs will introduce night thoroughbred horse racing tomorrow night under its newly installed $500,000 lighting system.

VIENTIANE, Laos, July 29 The American pilot of a plane that crashed in Laos July 22 is presumed dead, a spokesman for Air America announced here today. The private airline carries personnel and cargo in Laos.
MOSCOW, July 29 Premier Khrushchev accused Stalin today of responsibility for high farm production costs because the late Soviet leader opposed an effective rural electrification program.

TEL AVIV, July 29 The Cabinet decided today not to let Dr. Robert A. Soblen back into Israel. By a unanimous decision, the Ministers held that the intrinsic right of any Jew to enter the state as an immigrant did not extend to Soblen, a convicted spy for the Soviet Union.

The proposed mergers of Apex Smelting Company and Kawneer Company into American Metal Climax, Inc., have brought requests for information from the antitrust division of the Department of Justice, it was disclosed over the weekend.
A total of 196 men will be graduated today at the twentyfourth commencement exercise of the United States Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, L.I.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) A few liberal Democrat Senators prepared today to continue their filibuster against a space communications bill. At the same time another liberal accused them of doing irreparable harm to the civil rights cause.

LOS ANGELES, July 29 (UPI) Don Drysdale pitched the Los Angeles Dodgers to an 11-1 victory over the San Francisco Giants today for his ninth straight triumph and nineteenth of the season. The Dodgers increased their league lead to four games.

LAKE GROVE, L.I., July 29 Brenda Felicetti rode her bay gelding, Swing and Sway, to junior working hunter honors today in the Fox Hill Stables horse show, Blue ribbons in the under saddle and women's events gave Miss Felicetti the victory. Reserve honors went to Jane Converse's Playboy.
WASHINGTON, July 29 In its new handbook for overseas volunteers, the Peace Corps deals with a key question; as follows:

Charles Richard Maxwell, a dangerous Sunday driver, made three blatant hit-and-run attacks before 41,883 witnesses at the Stadium yesterday. The victims were young and happily married Yankee pitchers named Ralph Terry and Roland Sheldon.
The Marine Engineers Beneficial Association has asked President Kennedy for an investigation of the use of ship-subsidy funds to fight an engineers' picketing action.

The Kennecott Copper Corporation reported net income of $17,870,246 or $1.62 a share, in the quarter ended June 30. This compared with first-quarter earnings of $18,707,860, or $1.69 a share and 1961 secondquarter earning of $20,121,219, or $1.82 a share.
WASHINGTON, July 29 The Administration plans to reorganize the President's Committee on Equal Employment Opportunity.
NEW LONDON, Conn., July 29 What might be called a Humphrey-Weidman program was presented here last night as the third event in the American Dance Festival at Connecticut College.
IF there had been one, the "help wanted" advertisement might have gone like this:...

ROME, July 29 Gabriele Acacio Cardinal Coussa, Secretary of the Congregation for the Eastern Church, died of peritonitis and pulmonary complications in a hospital a few minutes past midnight. He underwent an appendectomy July 20.

The Eastman Kodak Company attained record sales and earnings in the second quarter. Results for the first half ended June 17 were also the highest in the company's history, according to the report released today by Albert K. Chapman, chairman, and William F. Vaughn, president.

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 29 Clan Kennedy gath ered at nearly full strength in the family's summer enclave here this week-end to celebrate the thirty-third birthday of the dark-haired Bouvier girl who married brother Jack.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota said today a State Department official had given him evidence from its security files on Alger Hiss that President Harry S. Truman would not let House investigators see.

WASHINGTON, July 29 The abstruse and often allegorical political vocabulary with which Communists normally conduct their feuds appears to have been supplemented in Communist China with equally abstruse and allegorical cartoon strips and panels.
The Rev. Thomas P. Leonard of the New York Apostolate Mission Band warned worshipers at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday against "the capital sin of sloth."

After a bad financial year, British European Airways has recruited forty-two salesmen in an attempt to increase passenger and cargo revenue in Europe and Britain by $4,200,000 in the next eight months.
SANTA FE, N.M. July 30 (AP) Boaz W. Long, a former diplomat, died today at his home here. He was 85 years old.
The Cleveland Pipers were refused membership in the National Basketball Association yesterday and the N.B.A. announced it would not expand beyond its current nine-team make-up for the coming season.
The Union Oil Company of California in the first six months of 1962 had the highest net earnings and revenues for any half-year period in its history, A.C. Rubel, president, reported yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 30 Two United Nations investigators reported today that it was "the overwhelming desire" of the African population that the United Nations take over the administration of South-West Africa.

YONKERS, July 30 Next Knight, with Billy Haughton in the sulky, won by a head from Colbywell in the feature mile pace tonight at Yonkers Raceway. A crowd of 27,579 turned out for the next-to-last night of the Yonkers meeting.

PARIS, July 30 There is a general feeling in America that state-supported amateur sports exist only behind the Iron Curtain. But this is not true. They exist in many places in the world, except in the United States, where amateur sports are supported by education.

General Motors Corporation went into Federal Court yesterday to oppose a demand by the Department of Justice for the preservation of a vast number of minutes, reports and other documents that might be needed in an anti-trust investigation of the auto industry.
Two fall productions were in conflict yesterday over a director. The producers involved insisted that Alan Schneider would stage their projects for an October opening.
LONDON, July 30 A new alphabet being used to teach reading has produced excellent results, according to the first evaluations of an experiment conducted in twenty-four English schools.
ALGIERS, July 30 Algerian troops loyal to Deputy Premier Mohammed Ben Bella were reported today to have captured one of his bitterest antagonists.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 30 Arkansas will learn tomorrow whether Gov. Orval E. Faubus remains politically invincible or whether time and circumstance have made him merely formidable.
A major toy advertising insertion in the Nov. 17 issue of TV Guide has been canceled as a result of a dispute between the magazine and the Toy Guidance Council.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 30 (UPI) Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower turned down a drink of 331-year-old rum today during a visit to a salvaged seventeenth century warship and gave his guide a lecture on ancient Swedish military history.
Coffee futures came to life for the first time in many weeks and provided the only spark of real activity on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 30 (UPI)--American officials in South Vietnam said today that patrol action along the Laotian-South Vietnam border was being increased to find out if Communist guerrilla infiltration from Laos was on the increase.
The Continental Vending Machine Corporation is expanding its activities through the acquisition of a group of five vending operations.

WASHINGTON GEORGETOWN is a state of mind as well as one of Washington's best known residential areas. It is a mile west of the White House, and yet it is here, in the Federal-period houses, that much of the New Frontier's chic was established.
LAKE WALES, Fla., July 30 (AP) Burt Shotton Sr., who managed the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1947 and 1949, died of a heart attack last night at his Camp Lester home. He was 77 years old.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 30 Melvyn Douglas dissented recently from the prevailing opinion that the rise of the independent producers in Hollywood has elevated the quality of American movies.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) American candy manufacturers strongly opposed President Kennedy's trade expansion bill today as ruinous to their industry.
Next year the world may share in the awesome experience of looking out of the nose of a space rocket as it plunges into the moon at 6,000 miles an hour.

WASHINGTON, July 30 Ten nations and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced today subscriptions totaling $1,070,000,000 to help India finance the second year of her current five-year plan.
WHEN most people gaze into the window of Charles Co. at 340 Madison Avenue, the sight of so many fine foods usually makes them hungry.

TURIN, Italy, July 30 (AP) An official of Italy's Communist party, one of eighty-two people tried this month for their part in clashes here between striking mealworkers and the police, was sentenced tonight to eighteen months in prison.
Leon J. Davis, head of a union that recently ended an eight-week strike at Beth-El Hospital in Brooklyn, asked yesterday to be purged of contempt of court.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 30 President Joao Goulart is steadily extending his influence over the armed forces for the critical period leading to Brazil's congressional election in October.
A group of New York ministers is planning to go to Washington next Monday to demand White House intervention in behalf of the Negroes in the racial crisis in Albany, Ga.
PARIS, July 30 The prosspects for British entry into the European Economic Community were more uncertain today than at any time since the negotiations began nine months ago.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) The House refused today to approve funds for further Federal construction of fall-out shelters despite warnings that "terrible devastation" could result from its action.
The American Association for the United Nations announced yesterday that Mrs. Harry Schoenfeld of New York City had been elected as chairman of its Southern New York State division.

Despite President Kennedy's firm assertion that the gold price will not be changed, the price of gold coins here has gone up. The uptrend followed the Presidential order July 20 forbidding American ownership of coins abroad effective Jan. 1 and forbidding most imports of gold coins. What makes the matter interesting is that coin dealers do not know what comes next.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 30 Monmouth Park ushered in the last week of its fifty-sixday race meeting this afternoon with a crowd of 23,854. This included more than 5,000 from New York, where the mutuel windows at metropolitan tracks will be closed for a month.

MONTEREY, Calif. THE Friends of the Mountain Lion are becoming the talk of the Monterey Peninsula and points south. They are demanding removal of a $50 Monterey County bounty on the mountain lion, which is sometimes called the cougar or the puma. Many of the cattle and sheep men are resisting the proposal.
MOSCOW, July 30 New Soviet legislation that is being quietly put into force will let local authorities seize private houses and summer homes built or acquired with unearned income.
WASHINGTON, July 30 George Meany, president of the merged labor federation, urged today a cut in individual income taxes concentrated in the lower-income groups.
PARIS, July 30 A veritable land war is building up in France with aroused young peasants blocking roads and attacking the property of persons for whom farming is a sideline.
LONDON, July 30 Two British mountain climbers were killed last week descending Mount Garmo, in the Pamirs, it was reported today. They had been part of an eighteenmember British-Soviet Expedition.

A committee has been formed under the co-chairmanship of Mrs. J. Truman Bidwell, Mrs. Rush H. Kress and Mrs. John Davis Lodge to plan a benefit preview at the Wildenstein Gallery Oct. 24 of Shakespeare in Art.
THE deep, hot pit of midsummer is the time a cool and refreshing hint of fall can be found in the posting of new game laws. The first crop of these is now at hand. More will be coming soon.
HARRISBURG, Pa., July 30 (UPI) A Pennsylvania Railroad official said today the engineer of the line's wrecked "Baseball Special," on which ...
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. July 30 A Belgian source said today that most of the 450 Belgian troops stationed in Burundi had returned to Belgium and that the remainder would leave by tomorrow.

A THOUSAND YEARS from now historians may argue that the American Civil War finally ended in the Nineteen Sixties. Time boundaries are imprecise when elemental issues of conflict persist through several generations.
A crowded playground was the scene of a demonstration yesterday of how to cross streets safely.

The Leon Schinasi estate has sold the last of its realty holdings consisting of five buildings at 142, 146 and 148 East Fourteenth Street; 106 Third Avenue, and 143 East Thirteenth Street. The buyers were clients of Walter Scott Co.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz asked yesterday for the dismissal of the suit brought by Radio Station WMCA to change the method of apportioning the state's legislators.
Andre Roosevelt, explorer, photographer and world adventurer, died last week in Port-auPrince, Haiti. He was 83 years old.

Extracting coal from the earth often leaves a legacy of problems. One is the ugly and eroding landscape left by the strip-mining of shallow deposits. Another is the deadly acid drainage that in many areas flows from both the strip pits and the shaft mines, including thousands of abandoned mines, killing fish and making the streams unfit for human or industrial use.

WASHINGTON, July 30 President Kennedy met with Arthur H. Dean and other disarmament advisers today to map strategy for presenting modifications in United States proposals for a ban on nuclear weapons testing.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 30 The Committee of Seventeen adopted today a resolution calling for the resumption of negotiations "immediately" between Britain and British Guiana to fix a date for the colony's independence.

MOSCOW, July 30 A small car made in the Ukraine appears to be on its way to becoming the most commonly used private car in the Soviet Union despite Premier Khrushchev's criticism of its production by a plant that formerly made agricultural machinery.
Republic Steel Corporation reported yesterday a drop in second-quarter earnings, compared with both first-quarter levels and those of the 1961 period.

The National Casting Company of Cleveland, die casting and plate manufacturing, has leased tower space in the Pan Am Building, 200 Park Avenue, adjoining Grand Central Station, from Grand Central Building, Inc., James D. Landauer, president, the owner of the building.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 30 The first of two final sessions of the masters' mixed team contest began here tonight in the American Contract Bridge League's national championship tournament.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) The United States Conference of Mayors asked Congress today to give the Federal Aviation Agency power to reduce the roar of jet airliners.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 30 Fire Commissioner Edward Thompson of New York was accused today of having sounded a false alarm with his suggestion that Nassau County remove responsibility for fire inspections from volunteer companies.

Whether there is to be a peaceful, negotiated settlement of the Dutch-Indonesian dispute over West New Guinea now seems to depend largely on whether President Sukarno is prepared to modify somewhat the position he has taken publicly that Indonesia must have possession of the territory by the end of this year.

CHICAGO, July 30 Everything the National League did at Wrigley Field today, the American League did much, much better in scoring a 9-4 triumph in this season's second and concluding all-star baseball game.

BONN, Germany, July 30 West German farmers, who for years have complained of getting only the crumbs of the country's economic pie, face difficult readjustments that will force many to move to other jobs, a recent study indicates.

Whatever the economic indicators for July reveal, they will make disappointing reading for the Kennedy Administration. The President's economic report for 1962 had predicted a strong and widespread rise in business activity because last year's recovery "set the stage" for growth.

At 3:50 P.M. on July 9, Washington newsmen received telephone messages from the Federal Reserve Board's public information office that "something of significance" would be in their hands within ten or fifteen minutes.

WASHINGTON, July 30 A closure petition designed to break the Senate filibuster against the satellite communications bill was signed by the required sixteen members today. Leaders declined to confirm this move, but signers disclosed its "secret" circulation.

The best news about the Congo in a long time is that both Premier Cyrille Adoula of the Central Government at Leopoldville and Moise Tshombe, the self-styled President of Katanga, are ready to let experts chosen by the United Nations write a new constitution for the troubled young republic, and that Acting Secretary General Thant is preparing to appoint the necessary committee this week.

PARIS, July 30 For the first time this season, a Paris salon rang with bravos and rattled with repeated applause. Yves St. Laurent, former designer for Christian Dior who showed for the second time under his own name, presented a collection that was alive with ideas and creativity.

Federal authorities made use yesterday of a law enacted last September to arrest a passenger traveling on a foreign plane. The passenger was accused of striking another passenger with an empty wine carafe on an Air France flight from Paris to New York.
ALBANY, Ga., July 30 James Robert Elliott, the Federal judge presiding here today at a hearing on the Negro demonstrations, is a former champion debater, state politician and prominent lawyer.
The Board of Estimate is expected to authorize today the purchase of 47,000 "vandal proof" parking meters from the Duncan Parking Meter Company of Chicago for $2,350,000.

The sudden resignation of Dr. Sterling M. McMurrin as United States Commissioner of Education will inevitably raise questions about why he quit. Although he has initiated valuable projects in support of greater excellence in education, it would be fantasy to say that the job ...
WHY can't pipe smokers do something heroic? On television, that is.
TRIESTE, July 30 A Trieste political party dissolved this week-end, demonstrating the changed position of President Tito of Yugoslavia in the Communist world.

WASHINGTON, July 30 A total of 1,229 physicians in thirty-nine states and the District of Columbia and one in Canada received test samples of thalidomide, a drug blamed for thousands of birth defects in Europe.

NINETY per cent of American homemakers use bleach in laundering, but one-third of them use it incorrectly, according to a recent survey. The result is spotted or discolored fabrics. The poll was conducted by the American Home Laundry Manufacturers' Association.

A Florida bank holding company proposal, which had been endorsed last fall by the Department of Justice and approved by the United States Controller of the Currency earlier this year, was rejected yesterday by the Federal Reserve Board.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 30 The Black Rock Yacht Club crew from Bridgeport, captained by Cindy Sorenson, led the way through the three-race elimination series today in the Long Island Sound girls' sailing championship off Belle Haven Beach Club. Miss Sorenson placed third in the opening race, then won the other two.

REGINA, Sask., July 30 Premier W.S. Lloyd announced today a special session had been called for 10 A.M. Thursday to begin consideration of the Medical Care Act amendments agreed upon between the Saskatchewan Government and the Saskatchewan College of Physicians and Surgeons in the formula that ended the medical care impasse last week.
The Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation reported yesterday highs in operating revenues and net income for the second quarter and year ended June 30.

THE usual hubbub of life in East Harlem was enriched last night by a new sort of sound, that of a symphony orchestra. Joseph Eger took his West Side Symphony east for an outdoor concert in the plaza of Jefferson Houses, a project on 113th Street at Third Avenue.
MOSCOW, July 30 (AP) The leaders of the Russian and Angliean churches embraced heartily today at the Moscow airport at the beginning of a historic visit.
CHICAGO, July 30 (UPI) Corn and oat futures were firm today on the Board of Trade. Other crops were weak.
BOGOTA, Colombia, July 30 (Reuters) Forty persons died and 150 were injured when a shirt factory at Pereira collapsed during an earthquake today, the Governor of Colombia's Caldaus Province reported.
PHOENIX, Ariz., July 30 (AP) Mrs. Robert Finkbine was set back today in her bid for guaranteed immunity from prosecution if she has an abortion. She fears risking the birth of a deformed child.
DETROIT, July 30 (AP) Automobile production will continue declining this week as more assembly plants turn out their last 1962 models.
LONDON, July 30 Czechoslovakia has offered a visa to Dr. Robert A. Soblen, informed sources said here tonight.
LONDON, July 30 (AP) News from Washington brought the manager of the International Tin Council's buffer stock into the London tin market for the first time ...
MATTAPOISETT, Mass., July 30 Only seven of sixty-six starters were able to finish within their time limits today in a New York Yacht Club cruise run disrupted by light wind on Buzzards Bay.

CHICAGO, July 30 (UPI) Paul Crump, a condemned murderer, was alternately pictured today as a man who underwent a "miracle of rehabilitation" in nine years in prison and a clever, convict feigning reform to escape the electric chair.
The average length of time needed to bring cases to trial in state courts of the nation has increased for the fourth straight year, the Institute of Judicial Administration reported yesterday.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., July 30 Whitney Reed had to prove his credentials as the No. 1 tennis player in the nation at the thirty-sixth annual Eastern grass court championships today. The 31-year-old, Alameda (Calif.) player was forced to rally in each set to beat Paul Como of Dallas, 9 7, 11 9, in the opening round at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.
MOSCOW, July 30 The Moscow radio reported today that eleven Americans had been reprimanded at a youth camp in the Crimea for distributing "anti-Soviet pamphlets."
WASHINGTON, July 30 The Treasury's short-term borrowing cost dropped slightly on today's sale of the regular weekly issues.
Stocks scored a good gain yesterday as trading quickened from Friday's pace.

FOR the child who is confronted by an unexpected crisis, help is never further away than a telephone. Early training in the use of the telephone has resulted in children's calls that have saved lives.
The market in high-grade bonds was immobilized by yesterday's one-day subscription period for the Treasury's $8,750,000,000 cash financing operation.
The state's Democratic county chairmen deferred action yesterday on a proposal to hold a preconvention convention in mid-August.

Another possible theft of stock certificates, involving a potential value of $33,000, was reported to the Federal Bureau of Investigation here yesterday by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, July 30 Moise Tshombe, President of secessionist Katanga Province, said today he "had learned with much satisfaction" of Premier Cyrille Adoula's proposed federal constitution for the Congo Republic.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 30 Vicki Holmes of New Canaan, Conn., the No. 1 seeded player, gained the quarter-final round today as the girls' Eastern grass courts tennis championships opened at the Field Club of Greenwich. After drawing a first-round bye, Miss Holmes defeated Nancy Disco of Forest Hills, Queens, 6 0, 6 1.
CHICAGO, July 30 (AP) Mickey Mantle played no baseball today. In fact, he doesn't know when he will be ready to play again.

ALBANY, Ga., July 30 The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and his followers lost the first round today of their legal effort to fend off a court injunction against mass demonstrations against segregation here.
The last day of July never has been widely regarded in these parts as the most auspicious moment of the year for ...
The Transport Workers Union announced yesterday that it would strike Pan American World Airways Friday at midnight, but the airline said such a strike would be illegal.

LINCOLN, R.I., July 30 The long-time feeling that there might be "gold in them than New England nights" was strengthened tonight with the opening of the first major track for after-dark thoroughbred racing.

Within eight years the United States is determined to reach the nearest island in the sea of space around us. So imminent is this journey that jobs are already being outlined for the first men to get there.

Myron McCormick, the actor, died yesterday in Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. His death was attributed to cancer of the esophagus. He was 54 years old and lived at 50 West Sixtyseventh Street.
Steel production last week increased for the third consecutive week, surpassing the level of output that prevailed before the July 4 holiday.
THE Quakers, in their religious practice, in their nonconformity and in their alleviation of human suffering, were the subject of an hour-long television documentary last night over Channel 4.
The Department of Justice accused the bowling industry yesterday of violating the antitrust laws through a conspiracy to prevent construction of new alleys in "overbuilt" areas.
What is the moon made of? Within a decade American instruments and astronauts will land on the moon and give us the answer. Four hundred years ago Rabelais noted that some said the moon

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) Senator John L. McClellan charged today that an expelled union official had demanded a payoff to stop blocking settlement of a strike halting construction of $1,000,000,000 worth of nuclear submarines.

Criminal trials in Kings County will be suspended for the last two weeks of August. But thereafter the new court reorganization program will double the present four trial parts to work on a backlog that now exceeds 1,400 cases.
WINCHESTER, Mass., July 29 There are still 2,277 places open for qualified freshmen at sixty-four New England colleges, the New England Board of Higher Education said today.
SARATOCA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 30 Optimism, the quality that keeps the race-tracker returning to the scene of his speculations through bad times as well as good, pervaded this community today.
Mrs. Bessie Goldstein Gotsfeld, a leader in Jewish refugee aid and social work, died Sunday in Tel Aviv, Israel. She was the widow of Mendel Gotsfeld. Her age was 72.
Columbia University has received a bequest of $8,600,000, the second half of the largest gift to the university in its 208year history.
WASHINGTON, July 30 The prospect for a settlement of the dispute between the Netherlands and Indonesia over Netherlands New Guinea appeared somewhat brighter today.
British broadcasters sent two shows home from New York yesterday by means of the Telstar satellite.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 30 The police hurled teargas bombs and wielded hard rubber truncheons tonight in a three-hour battle with 5,000 demonstrators protesting the holding of the Communist-sponsored World Youth Festival here.
MOSCOW, July 30 The French Embassy announced today that its acting military attach shot himself fatally this morning.

CHICAGO, July 30 With an effort born of despair, the American Leaguers landed a haymaker today. In fact, they landed three as they roundly thrashed the National League in the second and concluding game of the 1962 all-star program.

KINGS POINT, L.I., July 30 President Kennedy told members of the graduating class of the United States Merchant Marine Academy today that they had the "responsibility for keeping our vital peacetime commerce flowing between America's shores and the ports of the world."

For many years a favorite topic of Soviet propaganda has been the New Soviet Man. We have been told he is without blemish, impervious to the temptations that bring about the corruption and downfall of less heroic human beings.
BOSTON, July 30 (AP) Gene Conley, the wandering pitcher, today was fined an estimated $2,000 by the Boston Red Sox. At the same time, the suspended ball player was reinstated.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 30 Coupled with the successive tiers of buried cities dating back possibly 5,000 years, the semidesert of the Jezireh Plain in northeastern Syria contains quantities of groundwater, which promises to revive the former fertility of the region. The area covered is roughly 20,000 square miles.
Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., 113year-old drug and chemical company, showed the highest halfyear sales and earnings in its history in the six months ended June 30.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) The Government ordered proceedings today that could lead to the closing of the tiny San Francisco Mining Exchange, which grew out of the great California gold rush of 1849.
LONDON, July 30 Prices in nearly every industrial section fell on the stock market today. Most losses were less than a shilling (14 cents).
The State Education Department released yesterday a racial census of public-school enrollment as the first step in a planned attack on de facto segregation in the state.

Cautious regularity rather than bold political innovation was the dominant mood of Democratic county leaders as they met on the state chairman's call to decide whether to hold a preconvention party convention in mid-August to choose candidates to run against Governor Rockefeller and Senator Javits. At first blush it seemed to many of the county chairmen a good,

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said yesterday that it would file complaints with the State Education Commissioner charging two Nassau County school districts with de facto segregation.
WASHINGTON, July 31 Anthony J. Celebrezze became "Mr. Secretary" today, with his left hand resting on the Biblical passage:
Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Jewish Congress, has denied a published report that he canceled representation of the congress at the Vatican Council, which is to begin in Rome on Oct. 11.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 31 (UPI) The New York Giants today asked waivers on a substitute quarterback, Lee Grosscup, and also released two rookies who had been signed as free agents.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 31 The Acting Secretary General, U Thant, appealed today to the 104 member countries of the United Nations to help settle the two-year-old Congo crisis without new Security Council action.
WASHINGTON, July 31 Following is the text of an exchange at the White House today between President Kennedy and a group of Brazilian university students:

WASHINGTON, July 31 The Administration announced today tentative plans to extend the nuclear test series in the Pacific in order to conduct two high-altitude explosions delayed by repeated rocket failures.

Will August bring a rally? The record for the last ten years for that hot vacation month is not too reassuring. In the decade, The New York Times combined average has scored six losses from month's start to end and four gains.
TEL AVIV, Israel, July 31 Opposition members of Parliament held up the adoption of the national budget today in retaliation for a Cabinet Minister's refusal to answer their questions.
PARIS, July 31 About half the Eurppean population of Algeria has fled to France since the beginning of the year.
LONDON, July 31 -- Prices moved narrowly in a quiet session on the stock market today. Declines of a few pennies dominated the principal industrial sections.

NAPANOCH, N. Y., July 31 A body believed to be that of 6-year-old Solomon Schwartz was found today in a cesspool at Camp Rav Tov. The boy, reported missing last Monday, has been the object of a widespread search.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) Gen. Lyman L. Lemnitzer said today that he opposed the plan once advocated by Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor to abolish the Joint Chiefs of Staff and replace them with a single, oneman Chief of Staff.
LONDON, July 31 Prime Minister Macmillan said today the Government would contribute the 350,000 [$980,000] necessary to keep in Britain a Leonardo da Vinci drawing of the Virgin and Child.

THERE is a need for a dynamic organization to represent the interests of trout-fishing sportsmen, Good fishing seems to be vanishing or sliding unnecessarily into the "put-and-take" category each year.
Controller Abraham D. Beame urged the fiscal officers of cities throughout the nation yesterday to demand immediate action by Congress to cut income taxes.
Pan American World Airways obtained a temporary restraining order in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday against a Transport Workers Union strike, scheduled to begin at midnight Friday.
RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, July 31 Reliable sources believe Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran is making progress in his efforts to break the deadlock in the dispute between Pakistan and Afghanistan.

THE tie that binds women shoppers from coast to coast and around the world to Sears, Roebuck Co. is not the retailer's catalogue alone. That well-thumbed listing is responsible for $1,000,000,000 in sales annually, but, in addition, Sears' increasing emphasis on services to customers, fashion styling and luxury merchandise has won enthusiastic response from the public.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 31 Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower proposed here today the establishment of an international "school for global understanding" to teach youths "the objective truths" about the issues that divide the world.
There are just too many cooks with a hand in regulating the nation's banking system. The latest instance involves a proposal to form a bank holding company in Florida.
The television performers' union here has moved to establish mimimum pay scales for future stars of Telstar satellite relays.
CHICAGO, July 31 A suit charging the Chicago Board of Education with maintaining a segregated school system was dismissed today by Judge Julius J. Hoffman of Federal District Court.
The New York League for the Hard of Hearing will be the beneficiary of the Nov. 16 performance of the musical "Mr. President" at the St. James Theatre.

Directors of the United States Steel Corporation declared yesterday the usual 75-cent dividend on the common stock, although June-quarter earnings failed to cover it. The company reported that profits in the latest three months were well below those of the March quarter and the 1961 period.
Fundamental Investors, Inc., reported yesterday that its June 30 net-asset value declined in the past three months to $8 a share from $10.30.

LONDON, July 31 Britain announced tonight that agreement had been reached on the establishment of a Federation of Malaysia. It will embrace Malaya and all that remains of the British Empire in Southeast Asia.
Prof. Salomo Rosowsky, and authority on the musical notation system for reading the Bible in Hebrew, died Monday in his home, 600 West 136th Street. He was 85 year's old.

The mass demonstrations by young people in Helsinki for several nights have given vivid evidence of the abhorrence with which many Finnish people view the so-called World Youth Festival. That Communist-sponsored and dominated propaganda jamboree is being held there only because the Finnish Government did not dare to risk the Soviet disapproval that would have been evoked by a prohibition.
CLEVELAND, July 31 (UPI) -Home runs by Willie Kirkland and John Romano and Gary Bell's relief pitching sparked the Cleveland Indians to a 5-3 victory over the Los Angeles Angels tonight.
Victor Arden, orchestra leader and pianist who attained national popularity with his performances on radio and on phonograph records, died here yesterday. He was 69 years old.

A Federal grand jury investigation into the activities of some labor organizations was disclosed yesterday with the indictment of a labor official on charges of mulcting the Veterans Administration of $9,200 in disability benefits.

An underwriting group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will offer $25,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds of the Florida Power and Light Company today. The initial price of 101.25 will provide a yield to the investor of about 4.425 per cent to maturity.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Bill Skowron hit a grand-slam home run in the first inning tonight off Claude Osteen, the Washington Senators' lefthander, and Osteen and his colleagues never recovered from the shock.

New York City charged yesterday that its residents had been cheated of proper legislative representation and state aid for sixty-eight years under the state formula for distributing Senate and Assembly seats.
The following listing includes events that have been selected by New York Times critics. For children of all ages, unless otherwise specified.
RYE, N.Y., July 31 The ninth annual pro-amateur charity tournament at the Apawamis Club became a family golfing affair for some of the contenders today.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 31 Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons' willingness to try a change of pace earned him a winner today in the $10,000 Schenectady Purse at Saratoga
BERLIN, July 31 A Soviet representative warned today that a United States Army helicopter that had flown over East Berlin might be shot down if it continued to do so.

OF all the instrumental soloists who perform in outdoor summer concerts, the violinists probably have it the roughest. The strings tend to sag and respond dully in damp weather, and that can play havoc with pitch.
PHOENIX, Ariz., July 31 (AP) Mrs. Robert L. Finkbine is planning to leave Arizona for an abortion, but when and where she wild go for the operation are being kept secret.
The value of bond offerings to the public here in July sagged to the lowest level this year, but was above the 1961 volume, according to a compilation by The New York Times

PHILADELPHIA, July 31 (AP) Four electrical equipment manufacturing companies involved in the Government antitrust case signed consent decrees today in United States District Court against future violations of antitrust laws

VENICE, Italy, July 31 The Foreign Ministers of Italy and Austria met here today in a "cordial atmosphere" in an effort to end the controversy over the treatment of the Germanspeaking minority in Italy's northern Alto Adige Province.

The recession in ocean freight rates and a world-wide decrease in shipbuilding orders have had only a minor impact on the operations of the American Bureau of Shipping, the organization reported yesterday.
Stock prices rose moderately on average on the New York Stock Exchange in July in fairly active trading. Volume was below the hectic pace of June, but still the largest for any July since 1933.
WASHINGTON, July 31 The United States has quietly suspended most of its economic aid to Haiti.

Mr. and Mrs. John Kempter Thomas of Toronto have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Burnet Thomas, to William Roper Parker. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. William Edgar Parker, also of Toronto.
LONDON, July 31 Postmaster General Reginald Bevins defended Government policy on British television today.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 31 The final session of the masters' mixed team contest began tonight at the Leamington Hotel in the American Contract Bridge League's thirty-fourth annual national tournament. Sidney Silodor of Philadelphia, Mrs. Sylvia Stein of Detroit, Norman Kay of Merchantville, N.J., and Mrs. Margaret Wagar of Atlanta were leading.

A. M. Karagheusian, Inc., has sold its Gulistan carpet plant at 450 Westfield Avenue, Roselle Park, N. J. The buyer was Romerovski Bros., Inc., of New York, one of the world's largest exporters and importers of used clothing.
A child's eye-view of the Berlin wall the grim line of barbed wire and stone between East and West Germany goes on display here today.
Roger M. Blough, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, had some words of advice for the Government yesterday.
Seven Dead Sea scrolls will be brought from Jerusalem to the 1964-65 New York World's Fair, it was disclosed yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Julius Mark, senior rabbi of Temple Emanu-El.

America of Brazil, the winner of the First Section, and Belenenses of Portugal, the SecondSection victor, will begin a twogame series for the International Soccer League championship tonight at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island. The kick-off is scheduled for 6:15 o'clock.
YONKERS, July 31 Yonkers Raceway ended its sixty-twonight summer meeting tonight, with many of the 28,325 fans showing no reservations about taking a bath in public.

Spacemen's Story America's first seven astronauts are associated not only in their efforts to conquer space, but also in writing their own story of the adventure. Simon Schuster is planning publication of their book in November under the title of "We Seven."
CHICAGO, July 31 (AP) --Corn futures received a late moderate flurry of support and were firm today on the Board of Trade. Other grains and soybeans were steady to weak.
ELLSWORTH BUNKER was a business man in the sugar industry before he found himself plunged by President Harry S. Truman in 1951 into the job of United, States Ambassador to Argentina.

The annual theatre party for the benefit of the Child Adoption Service of the State Charities Aid Association will be held at the Nov. 28 performance of "Little Me," a musical scheduled to open here Nov. 17 at the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre.
ALGIERS, Wednesday, Aug. 1 Vice Premier Mohammed Boudiaf has been released by the forces of Vice Premier Mohammed Ben Bella, a spokesman for the Provisional Government announced early today.
CHICAGO, July 31 (AP )The National League approved today another 162-game schedule for 1963 at the same time the league waived for Houston and for next season only a ban on Sunday night baseball.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm product prices advanced four-tenths of 1 per cent during the month ended July 15.

WOODBURY, N.J., July 31 The Bonsal Blues, big and brassy pride of Gloucester County, were making last-minute preparations today for a trip to the Netherlands, where they will compete in an international music contest.
WASHINGTON, July 31 Lieut. Gen. James M. Gavin will resign as United States Ambassador to France in the next few days, qualified sources said today.

IT is probably just as well the weather held up in Chicago for last Monday's second all-star game. RUMSON, N.J., July 31 Althea Gibson, the former United States and Wimbledon tennis champion, began her major-tournament golf career today with a 42, 38-80 at the Rumson Country Club.
The Government bond market backed away a bit yesterday from the subscription prices for the Treasury's two new longterm bond offerings the 4s of 1969 and the 4 of 1992-1987.

President Kennedy is holding top-level conferences with his military and diplomatic advisers to review our disarmament policy. The aim is, if possible, to devise a new strategy, starting with modifications of our stand on a nuclear test ban that is the key to further agreements an actual disarmament and even solution of some cold war burning issues.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 31 Deans at Eastern Seaboard colleges generally favor raising New York's minimum drinking age from 18 to 21, State Senator John J. Marchi, Republican of Staten Island, said today.

STRATFORD, Ont., July 31 Nothing evidently, not even this fiercely realistic age concerned with space flights, Telstar and the horrors of nuclear war, can dull the luminous luster of Edmond Rostand's great nineteenth-century romantic drama, "Cyrano de Bergerac."
ST. JANVIER, Que., July 31 (AP)-Sgt. Harold E. Myers of Lackland Air Force Base, Tex., outlasted four other men in a shoot-off today to win the 28-gauge open event of the world skeet championships.

The "Culligan boom," , which 'some observers had expected to sweep clean at the Curtis Publishing Company by filling key posts from outside the organization, instead has swept three of the company's advertising executives into top jobs at three Curtis magazines.
NADIR ZURTOUT, an 18year-old Lebanese girl who already is an accomplished Red Cross volunteer and linguist, yesterday summed up the hopes of 117 newly arrived young international visitors.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 31 Virginia Kemball-Cook, representing the Noroton (Conn.) Yacht Club, took the lead in the Long Island Sound girls' sailing championship today. She won the first two races of the fiveteam final round-robin off the Belle Haven Beach Club. The starts were one mile south of Great Captain's Island Light.
MOSCOW, July 31 A leading American horsewoman nonchalantly helped drive a troika on a wild ride around Moscow Hippodrome race track today and loved every leap and stride of it.
Cotton futures were 15 cents down to 5 cents a bale up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

Modern educators, including our own, have found that too many pupils who are supposed to be able to read and write cannot do so. This has led them to experiment with new ways of teaching. In twenty-four English schools 1,000 children during the past year have learned a new alphabet called Augmented Roman, or A.R.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 31 A municipal lifeguard, trapped under nine feet of water by the suction of water rushing into a drain in a boardwalk pool here, was saved yesterday after being submerged for eight minutes.

The Department of Justice asked the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday to reject the proposed merger of American Airlines and Eastern Air Lines because such a consolidation would be "inimical to the public interest."
A greater effort to persuade Latin Americans that private enterprise and investment are essential to the success of the alliance for Progress was urged yesterday by the Chase Manhattan Bank.
Arthur J. Lowenstein, president of the Michelin Tire Corporation, died of cancer Monday in his home at 45 East End Avenue. His age was 72.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 31--Gov. Orval E. Faubus apparently was winning tonight the Democratic nomination for a fifth term.
MATTAPOISETT, Mass., July 31 Racing under sail, the main business of the New York Yacht Club cruise, was interrupted for rest today.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 31 Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. DeFuria have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Frances DeFuria, to Brewster L. Doscher. He is the son of State Supreme Court Justice and Mrs. Robert Doscher of West Nyack.

The seventeen-story Volney Hotel, at 23 East Seventy-fourth Street, adjoining the north-west corner of Madison Avenue, has been leased for forty-five years by Adolphe Kramer to the Volney Corporation, a new company. Frank C. Bromber has resigned as general manager of the Stanhope Hotel to become director of the Volney Corporation.
A workman was killed and two others were seriously injured yesterday in two construction accidents.

The Long Island Lighting Company reported yesterday an increase of just below $13,000,000 in revenues for the twelve months ended June 30.
ALBANY, Ga., July 31 Police Chief Laurie Pritchett testified today that the presence of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. here had raised community tensions to the kindling point.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., July 31 Whitney Reed of Alameda, Calif., and Mike Sangster of Britain, the first and second seeded players, moved into the third round of the thirty-sixth annual Eastern grass court tennis championships today though each faced tough opposition.
Sugar, cottonseed oil and coffee stood out in a generally firm but quiet day on the New York commodity exchanges.
For the first time in its twenty-three year history, the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., is conducting a study to determine the financial condition of its 4,800 members.
The Board of Estimate yesterday approved the purchase, without public bidding, of 47,000 "vandal proof" parking meters from the Duncan Parking Meter Company of Chicago for $2,350,000.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., July 31 Education officials have, blocked a plan that sought to correct an alleged racial imbalance in Lincoln School by establishing a central school for fifth-and sixth-grade pupils.
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
Claudia McNeil, the Negro actress, said yesterday that she had found "no evidence" of racial discrimination in Kennebunkport, Me., when she appeared there last month in "A Raisin in the Sun."
The stock market staged a smart rally yesterday in brisk trading. It was the fourth successive advance and, perhaps significantly, volume has increased each day since the latest upturn began.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) The White House press secretary, Pierre Salinger, said today that Malcolm Kilduff, an assistant press secretary, had dictated a White House letter that was addressed to "Edinburgh, England."
The United States will spend more than $200,000,000 this fiscal year for something than will go up like a rocket, come down like a meteor and land like an ordinary light plane.

THE plum fancier who checks a cookbook index for plum recipes will generally be led to a number of concoctions that contain not one single, solitary plum. The reason is that a number of dishes with nothing more plum-like than a plum raisin have earned this title the most obvious example being the plum pudding.
Wilmer (Vinegar Bend) Mizell, a 31-year-old southpaw pitcher, was dropped from the active roster of the last-place New York Mets yesterday.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 31 George D. Widener's Jaipur, the winner of the Belmont Stakes, loomed as a shortpriced favorite for tomorrow's $50,000 added Choice Stakes. Nine outstanding 3-year-olds were named this afternoon for the mile-and-a-sixteenth race at Monmouth Park.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration is looking into possible cases of rigged clinical research in which drugs and other products may have been improperly or inadequately tested before general release.
The members of the Richmond County Country Club are marshaling their forces to battle a proposal that the city take over their 123-acre golf course under the Park Land Acquisition Act of 1960.

PALMYRA, N. Y., July 31 One hundred and thirty-nine years ago, members of the Mormon Church believe the first modern prophet of their faith was directed by an angel to a hill four miles south of this small, upstate New York town. There he found a cairn in which there was a book written on pages of gold leaf.
Home care by public health nurses for selected maternity patients in municipal hospitals here was advised yesterday by the Community Service Society.

WASHINGTON, July 31 Dr. Jerome B. Wiesner, the President's science adviser, took his first trip to Capitol Hill today and laid before Congress the scientific problems, ranging from pay to conflict-of-interest, confronting the Executive Branch.
Union demands for wage increases and improved working conditions made the country's first atomic-powered liner idle at Yorktown, Va., yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) A paint company executive complained today that the Administration's trade expansion bill would give far too much authority to those negotiating for tariff reductions.

The Ashland Oil and Refining Company in the three months ended on June 30, had a net income of $3,149,119, or 41 cents each on the 7,324,472 common shares outstanding, the company reported yesterday. This
ACCORDING to numerous modern philosphers, scores of contemporary novelists and thousands of fictional characters, "There's no sense in anything. Everything happens by chance."
City Administrator Charles H. Tenney is being considered for appointment to the bench of United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, it was learned yesterday.
LEE, Mass., Wednesday, Aug. 1 The sixth week of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, which began last night, offers a program combining fun and seriousness in judicious proportions.
LACONIA, N.H., July 31 The Rev. Dr. George Dahl, Emeritus Professor of Hebrew Language and Literature at the Yale Divinity School, died today at Laconic Hospital. He was 81 years old.
PARIS, July 31 Hot on the heels of Yves St. Laur ent's triumph yesterday came Hubert de Givenchy's today.
AUGUSTA, Ga., July 31 Five young Negroes convicted in the death of a white youth last April received sentences ranging up to ten years here today.
The Department of Health is considering removing eight families from a Brooklyn tenement where a 2-month-old girl was severely bitten by rats Saturday.
Orson Welles' film version of Franz Kafkas "The Trial," which Mr. Welles says is the first film completed "on his own terms" since "Citizen Kane," will be released here in October by Astor Pictures.
WASHINGTON, July 31 The Senate Finance Committee completed action today on a tax revision bill that might cut Treasury receipts as much as $750,000,000 a year.
ALONG with the first Grand Prix of Puerto Rico, to be run in November, another international sports car event, the long-established Nassau Cup races in December, has begun to shape up.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI)--The Civil Aeronautics Board handed down its official verdict today on the crash of an Eastern Air Lines Electra at Boston's Logan International Airport on Oct. 4, 1960, which killed sixty-two of the seventy two persons aboard.
WASHINGTON, July 31 Indonesian and Dutch negotiators have reached agreement on a formula that will give Indonesia administrative control over Netherlands New Guinea next May 1.
BONN, Germany, July 31 The West German stock market held its own today after slumping to a three-year low yesterday.
New orders received by manfacturers fell 2 per cent in June to the lowest level since September, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.
The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has transferred the nation's most dramatic parking problem to the vicinity of the moon.
Despite sharply increased sales, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company reported lower earnings in the quarter and six months ended June. E. J. Thomas, chairman,

MEXICO CITY, July 31 The spirit of camaraderie between athletes of rival countries approaching an international team match has rarely been exemplified as in the good fellowship existing among the Davis Cup players of Mexico and the United States, who meet here Saturday, Sunday and Monday.
BAYONNE, N.J., July 31 This city went without water for nine and a Half hours before noon today after a forty-eightinch main leading to the city burst in the Kearny Meadows.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 31 Prince Souvanna Phouma expressed confidence today that the United States and Communist China would respect the neutrality of Laos under the fourteen-nation agreement signed in Geneva July 23.
A group of former faculty members has presented charges of irregularities against the administration of the Bronx Community College, it became known, last night.

LONDON, July 31 A hostile crowd of East Enders pushed Sir Oswald Mosley, the pre-war fascist leader, to the ground and prevented him from holding a meeting tonight in a workingclass area with a large Jewish population and many colored immigrants.
LONDON, July 31 The Earl of Home, Britain's Foreign Secretary, said today it would be wrong to describe the Common Market negotiations in Brussels as "deadlocked" or at a "crisis stage."

BRUSSELS, July 31 It will now be announced that General Gavin is resigning as Ambassador to France and it will also be stated his departure has nothing to do with policy. Technically this is true, but anyone swearing it is the whole truth might fairly be charged with perjury.
ALBANY, July 31 Robert Thompson Pell of Ticonderoga, N. Y., who withdrew July 19 as the Conservative party's candidate for the United States Senate, disclosed today his complete break with the party.
WASHINGTON, July 31 Mortlock S. Pettit, former president of the butter and egg wholesale firm of Pettit Reed in New York, died yesterday at the age of 75.
The City of New York awarded $43,000,000 of tax anticipation notes yesterday to seventeen banks and trust companies, members of the city's

WASHINGTON, July 31 The Senate leadership failed tonight in an attempt to halt the filibuster against the satellite communications bill. It offered a concession to the minority opposition, but could not get the required unanimous consent.
NAPANOCH, N.Y. Aug. 1-- The State Police continued their investigation today into the death of 6-year-old Solomon Schwartz at Camp Rav Tov near this upstate community.
It appeared likely last night that hundreds of contests for delegate posts throughout the state would force New York Democrats to scrap any plans for a pre-convention convention in mid-August.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) --A Federal grand jury disclosed today that it was investigating the handling of a $180,000,000 Teamsters Union pension fund.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 1--U Thant. Acting Secretary General, has suggested that the Union Miniere du HautKatanga withhold further payments to secessionist Katanga Province until the Congolese constitutional dispute is settled.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1-- President Kennedy said today that he would have another talk with Representative John J. Rooney about increasing the entertainment allowances of United States Ambassadors who had no private fortune.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1-- The Pennsylvania Railroad today blamed an error by a track maintenance crew for the wreck of the "Phillies Baseball Special" in which nineteen persons were killed and 120 injured at Steelton last Saturday.

The Great American Insurance Company of New York showed an operating profit of $2,981,000, or $1 a share, in the first half of this year, as against a loss of $2,931,970, or $1.02 a share in the 1961 period.
LONDON, Aug. 1--British medical scientists reported advances yesterday in their search for a physiological explanation for the symptoms of a number of mental and cerebral illnesses.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1-- The world president of the Seventh-Day Adventist Church today declared the church's quadrennial world conference here to be the wrong forum for a drive for racial integration.
PARIS, Aug. 1--The Paris openings ended in fashion glory today as Balenciaga, master couturier, presented his fall collection.
The merger of the Congregational Christian Churches and the Evangelical and Reformed Church into the United Church of Christ was upheld yesterday by the Circuit Court of Appeals.
America of Rio de Janeiro defeated Belenenses of Lisbon, 2--1, last night in the opener of the two-game total-goal playoff series for the International Soccer League championship.

AN essentially lazy man, but one with obvious good taste, remarked recently that a Californian named Thompson was a saint of sorts because of a miracle he evolved among grapes. The man referred to was William Thompson of Yuba City.

President Kennedy has signed into law the bill authorizing a $4.6 billion foreign aid program for this fiscal year. The law marks a major victory for him in an otherwise frustrating Congressional session. He justly lauded both parties for recognizing the importance of this program as part of free world defense and as a response to the Communist challenge.

Now that most secondquarter corporate profits reports are in, the news is official that first-half results were very good The First National City Bank, which regularly compiles the earnings for some 900 major companies, reports that profits ran 21 per cent above the 1961 level--$7,219,000,000, compared with $5,982,000,000.

Arthur Godfrey, who is under contract to the Columbia Broadcasting System, apparently will not make a scheduled appearance next month as host of the "Tonight" program over the National Broadcasting Company television network.

The stock market snapped a string of four successive advances yesterday and declined in moderate trading. Volume contracted on the downturn, a fairly encouraging development to those who believe the summer rally, such as it has been so far, is not over yet.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--The United States would like to start applying economic sanctions against Katanga within about ten days to force President Tshombe to end his secession.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 1--The West German Government said categorically today that it had not been requested to increase the strength of the Federal armed forces from 500,000 to 750,000.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1 (AP)--George Altman crashed a tenth-inning home run clearing the 410-foot mark in center field today to give the Chicago Cubs a 3-2 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

If Stanley N. Arnold decides one of these days--as he probably will--that a bracing "winter in August" promotion would be just the thing to put some zip in a client's sales drive, he will have easy sledding.
The annual theatre party for the benefit of the Big Sisters, Inc., will be held at the Nov. 19 performance of Irving Berlin's new musical, "Mr. President," at the St. James Theatre.

LONDON, Aug. 1--Britain will refuse admission to about thirty delegates of neo-Nazi organizations, including George Lincoln Rockwell, Nazi leader in the United States, who were invited to attend a conference here.

Civilian soldiers called to active duty during last fall's Berlin crisis began returning to their families and civilian jobs yesterday.
Thomas G. Lanphier Jr., president of the Fairbanks, Morse division of the Fairbanks Whitney Corporation, has submitted his resignation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) --Spokesmen for the coal, poultry, paper, chemical, mirror and braided rug industries asked the Senate Finance Committee today for help against foreign competition.

MISS BEATRICE LILLIE is said to have glanced keenly over the stupendous water-borne acreage of a new trans- Atlantic liner and then asked the captain: "Tell me. When does this place arrive at New York?"

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 1 --Library books are being merchandised in this town just as if they were, well, say coffee percolators or women's hats. The only difference is that they are for lending only, not for sale.

Major department stores in the metropolitan area had a 5 per cent rise in sales in July over the level in July, 1961, a survey by The New York Times disclosed yesterday. For the city, however, the gain over 1961 was only 3 per cent, indicating that suburban outlets contributed more to the overall advance.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1-- President Kennedy announced today that the United States was willing to accept a system of national control posts, subject to international supervision, for monitoring an atomic test ban.
The board of directors of the League of New York Theatres has agreed to union status for stage directors and choreographers.
LONDON, Aug. 1--Britain announced today that a consti tutional committee would be formed soon to bring the Federation of Malaysia into being by the end of August next year.
LONDON, Aug. 1--The Earl of Home, Britain's Foreign Secretary, said today that Britain must join the Common Market or deteriorate into an economic "offshore island."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1-- The State Department has notified the Argentine Government of its "concern" over recent anti-Semitic incidents in that country.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--An Agriculture Department official testified today that Billie Sol Estes had mentioned the death of Henry Marshall in connection with his disputed cotton deals.
