A surge of reassurance buoyed the market for United States Government securities yesterday, bringing an end to the uneasy hesitancy that had both preceded and followed the Treasury's one-day $8,750,000,000 financing.
Trading in domestic sugar was active in an otherwise quiet atmosphere yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges.

LANSING, Mich., Aug. 1-- Delegates to Michigan's constitutional convention gave final approval today to a new state constitution that has already become a major issue in this year's gubernatorial campaign.
THE world has been saved: Instant Worms are here, communiques from an Oakville (Ont.) firm seem to suggest.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 1--The Northern Natural Gas Company of Omaha has purchased the historically significant Maximilian-Bodmer collection of early American paintings and documents to help improve the cultural environment of this area.
NEWARK, Aug. 1--Public Service Coordinated Transport today was granted a zone fare increase of 5 cents, starting with the second zone. The increase will become effective Aug. 12.
MOSCOW, Aug. 1--The Communist party leadership proclaimed a hands-off attitude today in what appears to be a farreaching dispute within the Soviet medical world on an alleged treatment for cancer.
A program to help remedy deficiencies in this country's knowledge of contemporary Latin America will be aided by a $1,000,000 grant announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation.

ALBANY, Aug. 1--The Court of Appeals announced today that the Court on the Judiciary would be convened here Aug. 15 to investigate the conduct of State Supreme Court Justice Louis L. Friedman of Brooklyn.
Government action to plug a "loophole" through which Italian woolen cloth has been entering the American market was urged yesterday by Roger Milliken, president of Deering Millikin, Inc.

The American Express Company, Fugazy Travel Bureaus and major airlines will meet soon to discuss a warning by the carriers on travel sales through two large mail orderretail store organizations, airline spokesmen said yesterday.
A decline of 494,000 barrels in the country's gasoline stocks in the week ended Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1-- President Kennedy angrily denied today the implication that the resignation of Gen. Lauris Norstad as commander of the North Atlantic Treaty forces involved a shift in United States strategy.
A block of 700,000 common shares of Schlumberger, Ltd., with a market value of nearly $44,000,000, was quickly oversubscribed yesterday at $62.75 a share.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--A move by India to buy a large atomic power plant from the United States has confronted the Administration with the troublesome question of whether to demand international controls over the operation of nuclear reactors sold abroad.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 1-- The Common Interest Group, a local committee working to preserve the Mathews Mansion in Veterans Memorial Park here, found last night that the crusader's life is not an easy one.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--The Senate's second filibuster of the year was shelved today without a clear-cut victory for either side. By unanimous consent, the controversial

The Port of New York Authority plants to offer on Aug. 9 $5,475,000 of New York State guaranteed commuter bonds due 1962 to 1966, Proceeds would be used to buy cars for leasing to the Long Island Rail Road.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 1--Ron Fisher, a 22-year-old Texan, upset Whitney Reed, the nation's ranking tennis player, in the Eastern grass court championships today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) --A Senate subcommittee heard testimony today that profits of 1,000 per cent or more had been made on a defense stockpile contract for low grade chromite ore.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--A memorial service will be held tomorrow at 2 P.M. in the Fort Meyer Chapel, Arlington, Va., for Frank Monroe Upton of Boulder, Colo, who won the Medal of Honor on April 17, 1918. Mr. Upton, the operator of a motel in Boulder, died of a heart ailment on June 25 at the age of 66.
Representative Alfred E. Santangelo reported yesterday that he had received a letter from President Kennedy praising him for his support of the Administration's legislative programs in Congress.

ASKED what one thinks of soccer, one cannot help but recall Abraham Lin coln's diplomatic reply when asked his opinion of a band of bagpipers who at the moment were threatening to blow out the windows in the White House, Said Lincoln:
The latest road to defeat for the New York Mets was an exceptionally long one last night but it had the familiar landmarks--unsteady pitching and poor fielding.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) The House of Representatives adopted the $73,000,000 Philippine war damage claims bill today and President Kennedy promptly hailed the action as fulfillment of "a long-standing moral commitment."
ALGIERS, Aug. 1--Algerian leaders failed again today to reach agreement on a solution to their month-old leadership crisis.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended July 25:

MOSCOW, Aug. 1--Soviet sources have not confirmed the arrival of Herr Ulbricht and Herr Stoph, but Western diplomatic sources here at once connected their trip with the Soviet Union's long-heralded plan to sign a separate peace treaty with East Germany declaring West Berlin a demilitarized free city.
WOODS HOLE, Mass., Aug. 1--Weatherly had the kind of wind conditions that seemed to suit her best today for a victory over the other 12-Meter yachts participating in the New York Yacht Club cruise.
SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 1-- Milk from certain areas of northeastern Utah has been diverted from Salt Lake City as a result of a sharp rise in the content of radioactive iodine 131.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--The league-leading New York Yankees kept the lowly Washington Senators in their place tonight by beating them, 6--4 and 5--2, with the second game going eleven innings.
A most critical phase of the lunar journey will be the takeoff of the lunar ferry from the moon to rejoin its "mother" craft in lunar orbit.

City Investigation commissioner Louis I. Kaplan, who announced on Tuesday an investigation into charges of graft and bribery during the state's administration of rent control here, said yesterday that "if we find anything that we think will be useful we will turn it over to the District Attorney."

Work has begun on the first interplanetary travel station-- at least in the Western world. It will bear no resemblance to Grand Central Station or New York International Airport at Idlewild. It will be spread out along twenty-five miles of the Florida coast north of the present missile test center at Cape Canaveral.

The signed agreement between Malaya's Prime Minister, Tunku Abdul Rahman, and the British Government on the formation of a Malaysian Federation formalizes plans for a union of territories that had already been accepted in principle by both parties.
LONDON, Aug, 1 (AP)-- Tennessee Williams said today he was seeking new subjects on which to write--no more mixedup women from the Deep South.

OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 1 --George D. Widener's Jaipur galloped to a four-and-a-halflength victory today in the $56,300 Choice Stakes at Monmouth Park. He showed his heels to the Christiana Stable's Cyane, with the Crimson King Farm's Crimson Satan third.

Gustave G. Rosenberg, chairman of the city's Board ofHigher Education, said yesterday that its executive committee would meet next week to hear allegations of irregularities made by a group of former faculty members against the administration of the Bronx Community College.

SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 1 (Reuters)--Lieut. Gen. Henry Gordon Bennett, commander of Australia's Eighth Division in Malaya in World War II, died here today of a heart attack at the wheel of his car. He was 75 years old.
The Public Service Commission said yesterday that it had been "giving attention" to de-- teriorating conditions at the 125th Street Station of the New York Central Railroad.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) --The Civil Aeronautics Board ruled today that the crash of a Continental Airlines jet in which forty-five persons died near Unionville, Mo., on May 22 resulted from a bomb plot.

The Railway Express Agency (R.E.A.) has leased the vacant blockfront on the west side of Tenth Avenue between Seventeenth and Eighteenth Streets from Irving Maidman, West Side realty investor and developer. The agency plans to use the site to consolidate its Manhattan truck parking facilities.

GRAND MASTER PAL BENKO of New York met an unexpected upset in the an unexpected upset in the second round of the recent New York State Chess Championship Tournament when Jim Warren of Chicago, on the Black side of a Sicilian Defense, held him to a draw.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 1--This could very well be a vintage year for Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons, in contrast to last season, when the 88-yearold trainer didn't have a winner until two days before the end of the Saratoga campaign. Sunny Jim now has saddled two winners in the three days of the current meeting.

The tax revision bill finally cleared by the Senate Finance Committee bears so little resemblance to the Administration's original proposals or the version passed by the House that it is difficult to escape the conclusion that it has been deliberately designed to kill off any chance of passage. According to Congressional sources the committee bill would mean a loss of some $750 million in revenue instead of a net gain.
Mak Fat Yin, a 3-year-old orphan from Hong Kong, yesterday acquired a new family, a home in Hollis, Queens, and the name of Robert Tom. The happy change in his

One swallow does not make a summer, but the news that unemployment fell in July, to its lowest point in over two years, is extremely encouraging. The figures for unemployment and employment, which reached a new record, both indicate that the nation is not in an economic recession even if activity has expanded at a sluggish and disappointing rate.

A disorder in which bottles, bricks and beer cans were hurled from roofs at pedestrians and policemen erupted last night in an upper West Side block. There were no injuries reported, but one man was arrested.

JERUSALM, Aug. 1--Premier David Ben-Gurion's coalition Government survived today its second test of confidence in three weeks arising out of the expulsion of Dr. Robert A. Soblen. The vote was 58 to 40.

TOKYO, Aug. 1--The United States and Japan agreed today to hold high-level military liaison meetings at least twice a year. The decision was taken at a meeting of a joint committee on security problems, which was set up almost two years ago but had met only once before today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--The national rate of unemployment dropped two-tenths of a percentage point from June to July to 5.3 per cent, Labor Secretary Arthur J. Goldberg said today.
MANILA, Thursday, Aug. 2 (AP)--A Navy P5M Marlin seaplane is missing on a night training mission with thirteen men aboard, the Navy reported today.
YONKERS, Aug. 1--Plans for an arterial roadway system to expedite traffic flow in the city of Yonkers were made public today.
DUDLEY, England, Thursday, Aug. 2 (AP)--Racial violence erupted in Dudley last night for the fifth straight night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1-- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg said today that major collective bargaining agreements concluded in the first six months of this year resulted in over-all wage gains which were "clearly noninflationary."
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 1 (UPI)--Rioting broke out in downtown Buenos Aires today. The police used clubs and tear gas twice to disperse strikers trying to hold a street rally.

President Kennedy had the experience the other day of seeing "oursels as ithers see us." Seventy visiting Brazilian students who had been going around the United States for three weeks ended up at the White House. They were not, it seems, complimentary. Mr. Kennedy handled the incident with customary humor, tact and the right amount of seriousness.
NEW HAVEN, Aug. 1--Yale University announced today that three of its leading professors, all occupants of endowed chairs, had retired.
The state's Joint Legislative Committee on Health Insurance Plans will meet here Aug. 9 to consider changes in the Blue Shield program announced last Friday.
ALBANY, Ga., Aug. 1--Mayor Asa D. Kelley said today the city "will never negotiate with outside agitators whose avowed purpose is to create turmoil" in Albany through mass racial demonstrations.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1-- Three men are 400 feet in the air--atop the largest rocket the United States has been able to devise. They are strapped in reclining metal chairs, three in a row, like three men in a twenty-first-century barber shop. But over their faces are complex space...

A new kind of pipeline designed for use under water was put on display yesterday. Its big advantage, its sponsors said, is that it costs a great deal less than conventional liquid-carrying pipes and does not require the expensive maintenance earlier pipelines must have.

MIDDLETOWN N.J. Aug 1--A thirty - three - car parking lot at the Red BankMiddletown interchange on the Garden State Parkway was opened today by the New Jersey Highway Authority in an effort to encourage commuters to use car pools and buses.
A second Federal grand jury yesterday filed criminal charges against Arthur Schatzberg, an alleged union racketeer who on Tuesday was indicted on charges of mulcting the Veterans Administration.

SHETLAND sheepdogs are small animals but the large size of their entries at the shows is attracting a great deal of attention among fanciers. At the Bucks County fixture there were 126 Shelties and at Trenton 112.
A special Federal court yesterday threw out two major points advanced by the city and Radio Station WMCA in their attempt to upset the state's formula for distributing seats in the Legislature.
The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company announced the promotion of seven senior officers to top positions on the bank's official staff.

BERLIN, Aug. 1--Walter Ulbricht, the East German Communist leader, and Acting Premier Willy Stoph flew to Moscow today, stirring predictions that a new drive against the Western position in Berlin was in the making.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 1-- Winners and losers alike among a crowd of 25,102 left the opening program of Roosevelt Raceway's fifty-two-night summer meeting tonight in agreement on one point: The $79,249 Roosevelt Futurity, a mile pace for 2-year-olds, was one of the best horse-and-buggy races in a long time.

MANILA, Aug. 1 (AP)--The world lightweight champion, Carlos Ortiz, gained a ten-round decision tonight over Arthur Persley of Red Cross, ALa., in a nontitle fight. Ortiz weighed 137 pounds, Persley, 136 .

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--Now that the novelty of Telstar has worn off, the best brains of American television will have to apply themselves to the problem of holding the European audience against the competitions of Soho, the Rue Pigalle and the Via Veneto.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 1--The problem that the high altitude of this city poses for the Davis Cup matches this week-end is not confined to the United States team.

Directors of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company cut the quarterly dividend in half yesterday with the declaration of 12 cents a share on the common stock. It is payable Sep. 29 to holders of record of Aug. 31. In preceding quarters, shareholders had received 25 cents a share.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 1-- Jewish leaders here say the Communists are reaping the most benefit from a recent upsurge of anti-Semitic violence in Argentina, although neo-Nazi groups are regarded as the instigators.

MIAMI Aug. 1 (UPI)-- Cuban exile leaders said today that four prisoners were shot down by guards at Principe Prison in Havana last night when they rioted against nearstarvation food rations. One was reported in critical condition.
LONDON, Aug. 1--Peter Thorneycroft, the Minister of Defense, revealed today that the stationing of United States Thor missiles in Britain would end "in the course of next year."

Record sales for the quarter and six months ended with June were reported by the United States Rubber Company. Earnings dipped 1 per cent in the half year as a result of foreign exchange losses, H.E. Humphreys Jr., chairman, and George R. Vila, president, explained to stockholders.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill, Aug. 1 (UPI)--Gov. Otto Kerner spared Paul Crump, a condemned killer, from the electric chair today and ruled that he must spend the rest of his life in prison with no hope of freedom.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes wants $20,000,000 to start building garages on the fringes of mid-Manhattan, with shuttle bus service to the shopping core.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1-- Stronger laws to protect consumers from potentially harmful drugs such as thalidomide were proposed by President Kennedy today.
A little green wagon crammed with "stuff" was unlocked in Brooklyn yesterday, and what spilled out provided games for children on a whole block in a bleak tenement section of Brownsville.

Plans for the Gotham Ball were discussed at a luncheon given at the Cosmopolitan Club yesterday by Mrs. Andrew B. Shea, vice president of The Gothams, for Mrs. William J. O'Shea, chairman of the event, and her aides. The annual debutante ball is traditionally held at the Plaza on Thanksgiving night (Nov. 22) for the benefit of the New York Foundling Hospital.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 1 --The streets of Helsinki were comparatively quiet tonight, after four nights of demonstrations that started even before the opening of the Communistsponsored World Youth Festival.
CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP)-- Bill Monbouquette of the Boston Red Sox pitched the fourth no-hitter of the major league season tonight by allowing only one walk in a 1--0 victory over the Chicago White Sox.

Gov. Orval E. Faubus has won more than half of the Democratic votes in the Arkansas primary for nomination for a fifth term. His early lead of 58 per cent of the votes was squeezed down, but he will avoid a run-off with his leading opponents, Dale Alford and former Gov. Sid McMath.
MIDLAND, Mich., Aug. 1-- Dr. Edgar Clay Britton, president of the American Chemical Society in 1952, died yesterday of a heart attack in Midland Hospital. He was 70 years old.
MOSCOW, Aug. 1--A recent article syndicated by a Soviet press agency discusses various methods the Soviet Union has been considering for sending a man to the moon in the current decade.
TITUSVILLE, Pa., Aug. 1 (UPI)--Ned H. Dearborn, who became president of the National Safety Council, after a long career in education, died today in Titusville Hospital. He was 69 years old.
WASHINGTON, Aug, 1--Enactment of stand-by authority to cut taxes might settle the question of whether to enact an actual tax cut this year, President Kennedy said today.
PARIS, Aug 1--This has been a good season for fashion all over Paris, a fact that may have been overshadowed by the brilliance of the Balenciaga, Givenchy and St. Laurent presentations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1-- Nearly two years ago a new Federal employe, working out of a drab office, received a routine assignment to study a drug application. She had been working for the Government less than a month, and she proceeded cautiously.

PARIS. WHEN Dior and Balmain fashions for fall were transmitted via Telstar, the Chambre Syndicate, the official association of French couturiers, was forced to abolish its usual one-month ban on sketches. The new rule, however, was not clear and it has not been uniformly observed by the couture houses.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) --President Kennedy signed today a bill authorizing $4,672,000,000 to be spent on foreign aid. He said the measure would let this country speak with a stronger voice in world affairs.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 1-- New York players dom- inated the standings in the life masters' pair contest, which ended today in the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament being played here.

The Federal Reserve Board's denial earlier this week of a bank holding company proposal submitted by four Florida banks has touched off explosive reactions in various sections of the nation's banking community.

James W. Walter and two other officers of the Jim Walter Corporation were elected to the eleven-member board of the Celotex Corporation yesterday. The Walter company, a builder of semi-finished houses, recently acquired a 40 per cent interest in Celotex, which makes building materials.
WASHINGTON, Aug, 1--Enactment of stand-by authority to cut taxes might settle the question of whether to enact an actual tax cut this year, President Kennedy said today.
PARIS, Aug 1--This has been a good season for fashion all over Paris, a fact that may have been overshadowed by the brilliance of the Balenciaga, Givenchy and St. Laurent presentations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1-- Nearly two years ago a new Federal employe, working out of a drab office, received a routine assignment to study a drug application. She had been working for the Government less than a month, and she proceeded cautiously.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 1 --Is a man more adult when he sees a movie in an art house than when he sees the same film in any other theatre?

Half-year earnings of the C.I.T. Financial Corporation established a new record for the period and "earnings should continue to be excellent" for the rest of 1962, Henry Ittleson Jr., chairman, and L. Walter Lundell, president, stated yesterday in their report to stockholders.

IT takes years of patience and practice to develop a sense of responsibility in a child, but it should be encouraged early, according to Mrs. Blanche Saia, who was recently named director of the School for Children, Bank Street College of Education.
The nuclear ship Savannah was still at her pier in Yorktown, Va., last night as labor unions and operating management in New York failed to solve a contract tangle.
GENEVA, Aug. 1--Sweden urged the nuclear powers today to agree to a "provisional" treaty to ban all atomic explosions in the atmosphere and in space.

Green tickets that resemble the tabs calling for $15 parking fines will soon be affixed to diplomats' cars if they are illegally parked here. The police hope that the green tabs will serve as an effective "notice of violation."
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 1 --Orval Eugene Faubus, smiling and confident in the unfamiliar role of the middle-of-theroader, remained today the master of Arkansas politics.

TANGLEWOOD, Lenox, Mass., Aug. 1--The common image of Tanglewood--incomparable scenery framing a shrine to the musically familiar--dissipates somewhat between the festive week-ends. Then the audiences are pared down to the truly dedicated, and the musical fare becomes more adventurous.

MIDDLETOWN, R.I., Aug. 1-- Before this department left Washington for a now-expiring holiday amid the cool airs and broad seascapes of this Atlantic coast, a participant in the great affairs of government identified one root of President Kennedy's troubles as follows: "Indecision between hard choices of acts and policy, and an inordinate concern over how commentators will react to things done or contemplated."
Following is the transcript of President Kennedy's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:
ACCRA, Ghana, Aug. 1 (Reuters)--President Kwame Nkrumah escaped unhurt tonight when a bomb was thrown at his car in a village in northern Ghana.

THREE Josephs and one Johannes made a formid- able quadrumvirate at Lewisohn Stadium last night. Joseph Fuchs, violinist, and Joseph Schuster, 'cellist, were the soloists in Johannes Brahms' Double Concerto,
NEW ROCHELLE; N.Y., Aug. 1--Earle Wooldridge Hammons, a pioneer in the motionpicture industry, died yesterday of a heart ailment in his home at 1273 North Avenue. He was 75 years old.

OTTAWA (Canadian Press), Aug. 1--The Canadian, Government is being urged to eliminate the income tax on provincial and municipal bonds to make them more attrac tive to investors. The idea has come up several times in evidence given before the Royal Commission on Banking and Finance.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 1 (AP)-- The Reynolds Aluminum Company reached agreement tonight on a new two-year contract, ending a one-day strike against the nation's two largest aluminum producers.

The George Putnam Fund of Boston reported yesterday June 30 net assets of $248,737,000, equal to $3.11 a share on 18980,000 shares outstanding. This compared with $263,722,000, or $16.49 a share on 15,990,000 shares outstanding one year earlier.
MARION, Mass., Aug. 2 A sparkling day on Buzzards Bay turned up a victory today for Nefertiti in the New York Yacht Club cruise competition for 12-Meter craft.

Astronauts training for lunar flights will be whirled in a three-man centrifuge, deposited on the sea inside capsule models, and sent as high as 5,000 feet atop a delicately balanced jet engine tilted to the vertical.
The market for United States Government securities yesterday scored good gains in a trading session that was the broadest of the last fortnight.

George Pal, whose most ambitious production to date, "The Wonderful World of the Brothers Grimm," is due for a Tuesday night unveiling here, has quietly begun preparations for his next project, "The Circus of Dr. Lao."
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 2 (AP) Billy Williams and Andre Rodgers hit consecutive homers for Chicago with two out in the ninth inning today, but the second-place San Francisco Giants beat the Cubs, 4 3.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Aug. 2 (AP) A Negro noncommissioned officer listed as a deserter from his United States Army missile battalion in West Germany has defected to Communist Czechoslovakia, the Czechs announced today.

A Noroton (Conn.) Yacht Club crew won the Long Island Sound girls' sailing championship today for the second time in the twenty-four-year history of the event. Virginia KemballCook clinched the title as the final race was sailed from Belle Haven Beach Club, off Great Captain's Island.

MIAMI, July 30 A survey of operations in a number of industrial plants in Havana draws a picture of chaos resulting from shortages of raw materials, lack of technicians, machinery in disrepair, mismanagement and absenteeism.

The State of Washington has announced that it will offer to competitive bidding on Aug. 20, bonds valued at $37,000,000. Proceeds are to be used for school and public buildings. The bonds will be secured by motor vehicle fuel tax revenues.

Carmen Capalbo, who won critical acclaim for his imaginative direction of "The Threepenny Opera," will stage "Seidman and Son," which opens Oct. 15 at the Belasco Theatre. Mr. Capalbo, who was last represented on Broadway in 1958 with "The Cave Dwellers," said yesterday:

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 When Tony Kubek rejoins the Yankees here tomorrow after eight months in the Army, he will be handed his old uniform and directed by Manager Ralph Houk to "try this on, but only for size."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 The military revolution in Peru has had at least one good result. It is forcing a re-examination of the U.S. Government's military assistance programs to the Latin-American countries.
LONDON, Aug. 2 The Government declined today to take any immediate steps to ban processions and meetings by fascist and neo-fascist groups. Four such meetings ended in violence last month.

THE PRESIDENT Met with Senators Bartlett and Gruening, Alaska; Representative Rivers, Alaska, and Interior Secretary Udall, R. C.A. officials and Indians and Eskimos training for communications system in...
Stocks resumed their advance in more active trading yesterday after a brief pause on Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2--The Federal Aviation Agency announced today the allocation of $74,283,719 in Federal aid funds to 419 of the nation's airports.
A member of Congress who sponsored construction of the atomic powered liner Savannah has recommended laying up the $50,000,000 vessel or turning it over to the Navy for operation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 Prospects of an income tax cut this year appeared today to have dimmed considerably.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2 (AP) Frank Howard, who has driven in twenty-one runs in his last ten games, broke a seventhinning tie tonight with a tworun single that brought the Los Angeles Dodgers a 5 3 victory over Pittsburgh before 40,722 fans.
Cotton futures were 80 cents a bale down to 25 cents up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
The public has become increasingly wary about tranquilizers, sleeping tablets and sedatives, a spot check here disclosed yesterday.
ALGIERS, Aug. 2 Algeria's month-long leadership crisis ended in a compromise today.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 2 A leading West German newspaper cautioned today that "a United States wish" to increase the strength of West Germany's armed forces to 750,000 from 500,000 "exceeds our possibilities."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2--Stricter controls over drugs tested on humans will be ordered by the Government in the next few days.
J. Vincent Keogh was sentenced yesterday to two years in prison for attempting to fix a Federal court sentence in Brooklyn when he was a State Supreme Court justice.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP)--Several corn, oat and rye contracts reached seasonal lows today in another broad setback on the Board of Trade. August soybeans slumped more than 3 cents a bushel under heavy liquidation.

One hundred members of he Police Department's Tactical Patrol Force were moved last night into an upper West Side neighborhood where bottles and bricks had been hurled from the roofs at policemen and pedestrians on Wednesday night.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 2 El Al has been under Government orders not to accept Soblen from the British authorities.
Brooklyn's long-neglected "hub" section" an inharmonious mixture of proud buildings set among old brownstone tenements and blighted storefronts may get a $150,000,000 facelifting.

OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 2 Ahoy, a well-named son of Sailor and an almost certain betting favorite for the $100,000 guaranteed Sapling Stakes here on Saturday, is an apple in the eye of his owner, Dr. Leon Levy of Philadelphia.

THERE was some more magnificent playing last night in the Brahms cycle that has been going on at Lewisohn Stadium this week. The concert was the third in the series, which Josef Krips is conducting, and the soloist was Gary Graffman, pianist. The long and meaty program included the Variations on a Theme by Haydn, the First Piano Concerto and the Fourth Symphony.
REGINA, Sask., Aug. 2 In a record time of less than eight hours, a special session of the Saskatchewan parliament completed passage tonight of amendments to the medicalcare legislation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 Senate investigators produced evidence today that a high Federal official had opposed interference with Billie Sol Estes' disputed cotton allotments.
OVER in East Stroudsburg, Pa., a group of athletes is training with such zeal that merely looking at them leaves one winded.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 2 A privately financed symphony orchestra consisting of fortysix students from Harvard University and twenty-six from Radcliffe College has been touring Mexico in "an experiment in international living."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 President Kennedy announced today the extension of the Federal food stamp plan to twentyfive areas in eighteen states. The program for needy families is designed to provide better diets.
A landlord whom the city apprehended after three years went on trial in sixteen cases in the Bronx Municipal Term Court yesterday. He had pleaded not guilty in all of them.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 2--The thirty-seventh running of the Test Stakes today produced identical winning times by two successful contestants. There was no dead heat in the seven-furlong race for 3-year-old fillies, though, because the race was run in two divisions.

THE thriving condition of American print making today and the revived interest in human themes as subject-matter are handsomely embodied in the exhibition "American Prints The Figure" at Associated American Artists, 605 Fifth Avenue. Included here are etchings, lithographs and woodcuts by twenty-five contemporary print makers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 The Administration won general support today from the Joint Congressional Atomic Energy Committee for its new approach to a test-ban agreement with the Soviet Union.
WITH any sort of cooperation from the weather this week-end, salt-water anglers should be able to find action somewhere to satisfy their need to feel a kicking rod.

A certain amount of subjective surrealism is necessary at times to fully appreciate the Mets and tell one of their games from another. This means the Polo Grounds scoreboard resolutely must be ignored.

A MOMENT of unhurried reflection came to televi sion last night in the form of a filmed conversation between Mark Van Doren and Archibald MacLeish. Against the restful background of Mr. MacLeish's farm in Conway, Mass., the poets, scholars, Pulitzer Prize winners and friends talked of the power of love, the sanctity of the person and the importance of idealism, among many other things.

DEAL, N.J., Aug. 2 Mary Ann Doctor, 18 years old, of White Beeches, won her first major golf tournament today. She had a 54-hole total of 237 in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Shore tournament.
CHICAGO, Aug. 2 The American Medical Association said today that cholesterol in the blood should be reduced in cases of hardening of the arteries.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 2 The Republican County Committee was accused today of illegally using its funds, personnel and headquarters to promote the candidacy of Ogden R. Reid for the Republican nomination for Representative in the Twenty-sixth Congressional District.

Mayor Wagner breathed some new life last night into the idea of a mass gathering of Democrats from across the state to think about candidates for Governor and Senator before the formal September conventions.
Rocket and satellite observations in recent years have disclosed, at first hand, clouds of dust and gravel coursing through the solar system.
TOMATOES are hard to beat at this season, in quantity, in price (generally 25 cents a pound) and in quality. They are generally as juicy and flavorful as any tomato lover could wish.
TRENTON, Aug. 2 Gov. Richard I. Hughes approved today a $115,629,261 state highway construction program for the current fiscal year. It is about $4,300,000 less than was spent in the previous year.
A Brooklyn lawyer was accused by a Federal grand jury yesterday of participating in a sham-marriage scheme to enable aliens to enter the country illegally.
The Sperry Gyroscope Company has delivered initial production models of a miniature gyroscope that has performed three times more ac- ...

The consolidated net income of the Sun Oil Company in the first half of 1962 was $19,664, 000, or $1.42 a share. This was 18.2 per cent less than the net income of $24,048,000, or $1.84 a share, in the first half of 1961.
LONDON, Aug. 2 Britain refused today to grant political asylum to Dr. Robert A. Soblen and gave instructions to El Al, the Israeli airline, to take him to New York.

Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., celebrated at 5:42 P.M. yesterday its official entry into the atomic power field. At that precise moment, the reactor in its Indian Point power plant at Buchanan on the Hudson River in Westchester County "went critical."
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 2 Cardinal Spellman of New York was sharply critical here tonight of the recent Supreme Court decision banning official prayers in the public schools.
World sugar declined in active trading yesterday. Other commodities traded here were off in slow turnover.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Aug. 2 (AP) An unemployed pipefitter wounded his attorney this morning, then held five persons hostage in a, state office building for twelve hours as he forced a hearing on his disability compensation claim.
TOKYO, Aug. 2 Prince Souvanna Phouma, Premier of neutral Laos, tacitly acknowledged today the presence of North Vietnamese Communists in his country.
Mortgage loans amounting to $16,000,000 have been placed on three buildings on the East Side.
When the launching rockets cut off as the first Apollo spacecraft hurtles toward the moon, three men will be carried into an environment incredible, empty, silent and perilous.
BONN, Aug. 2 (AP) Former President Eisenhower and Chancellor Adenauer had a friendly reunion tonight at the home of Brewster H. Morris, United States Minister.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 The Post Office Department has decided to establish a separate post office for the Bronx.
MOSCOW, Aug. 2 A justice official said today that a statute adopted last week has given the Soviet bar greater independence.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP) The College All-Stars will oppose the Green Bay Packers, champions of the National Football League, tomorrow night in Soldier Field before 75,000. The Packers are favored by three touchdowns.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 2 Frank G. Clement apparently won the nomination for Governor in the Democratic primary today. The nomination normally is equivalent to election in November.
Hugh Gordon Miller, a retired lawyer and for many years historian for the Southern Society here, died Wednesday of a heart ailment in a hospital in Norfolk, Va. He was 87 years old.
The E.L. Bruce Company disclosed yesterday that it had sold 69,200 shares of the Celotex Corporation for $2,076,000 about $400,000 less than it paid earlier this year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI) Millions of veterans of World War II and Korea who have allowed their national service life insurance to lapse would be able to reinstate coverage under a bill approved today by the House Veterans Committee.
Following are excerpts from the statement made by Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld yesterday in sentencing J. Vincent Keogh, Elliott Kahaner and Antonio Corallo:
Seven new tenants, including marketing specialists and textile and luggage manufacturers, have leased space in the Empire State Building. The leases are for three to six years.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 2 A smiling Dwight D. Eisenhower stepped off the Scandinavia-Paris express train at Cologne this morning to a rousing reminder that he was no ordinary tourist. To the obvious joy and surprise of the former President, several thousand people stood waiting for him in the shadow of the city's old cathedral.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 This country's first official effort to attract tourists from abroad is now being tested. The early results are modestly favorable.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 2 U Thant, Acting Secretary General, said today that the United Nations Congo Force would protect the property of the Union Mini re du HautKatanga against reprisals if the huge mining company stopped paying taxes to the Katanga Government.

"ANTICIPATION OF THE NIGHT" is the preten tious title for the longest of the batch of avant-garde films that opened yesterday at the Charles. It might better be called "Gleanings from the Cutting Room Floor."
PARIS, Aug. 2 Manuel Prado y Ugarteche, the deposed Peruvian President, arrived from London today to take up residence in exile here.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 2 The Acting Secretary General, U. Thant, said today that he was "optimistic" about a final settlement this month of the dispute between the Netherlands and Indonesia over Netherlands New Guinea.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 2 (UPI) The first research model of an inflatable space station was unveiled here today at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Lewis Research Center.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 Edgar H. Dixon, president of Middle South Utilities, Inc., and a key figure in the Dixon-Yates power dispute during the Eisenhower Administration, died today of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 57 years old and lived in Tenafly, N.J.

PARIS, Aug. 2--Two former French Army lieutenants and a sergeant major were sentenced to prison terms today by the Court of Military Justice after a trial that revived controversy here over the army's alleged use of torture against Moslems in Algeria.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) Independent oil operators told the Senate Finance Committee today that their industry was in serious trouble. They urged that the Administration's trade expansion bill be amended to bar further increases in oil imports.
A $37,250,000 issued of the Belt Railway Company's 4.625 per cent first-mortgage bonds received a good reception yesterday, when it was marketed at a price to yield the investor 4.57 per cent.
LONDON, Aug. 2 An international campaign against cancer was announced here tonight.
BERLIN, Aug. 2 A United States Army helicopter flew over East Berlin yesterday without incident although there had been a Soviet threat earlier that the craft might be shot down.
THE last word in stuffed toys may be the Klunks. The Klunks is the name of a family that consists of five crazy characters that have a way of convulsing almost everyone who meets them.
A voice that a good part of the nation's radio and television audience hears at least several times each day will earn about $300,000 for its owner this year.
EVER since 70-year-old Harold K. Hochschild retired, he has been terribly busy.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 2 Sporadic violence broke out today on the second day of a forty-eight-hour general strike called by the Argentine General Labor Confederation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) Substantial pay increases for 1,700,000 Federal workers were approved today by a House committee, but in a form that carries the threat of a Presidential veto.
Nonmedical workers at Polyclinic Hospital voted yesterday to be represented by Local 144 of the Building Service Employes International Union.
Space-minded investors put the stocks of Chrysler, Thioko and General Precision Equipment on the most active list yesterday with good reason.
MOSCOW, Aug. 2 (AP) The Archbishop of Canterbury urged the Kremlin today to grant the Russian Orthodox Church more freedom.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 2 Gov. Edmund G. Brown announced today that he would not halt the execution of Mrs. Elizabeth Duncan and the two men she was convicted of hiring to kill her daughter-in-law.
LONDON, Aug. 2 The reserves of gold and convertible currencies held by Britain as central banker for the sterling area fell last month by 185,000,000 ($518,000,000).

O. Roy Chalk, a Washington, D.C. transit operator, who in 1959 unsuccessfully tried to buy the New York City transit system, has made an offer to acquire a 43 per cent voting-stock interest in International Railways of Central America.
The Visit U.S.A. program received its biggest statistical boost yesterday with the arrival of 1,680 tourists on the maiden voyage of Britain's 45,000-ton luxury liner Canberra to New York.
WILLIAM George Hundley puzzled some courtroom observers for a time with the low-pitched, matter-of-fact style in which he prosecuted the case against J. Vincent Keogh and his two co-conspirators.
The United States Treasury gold stock sustained a $60,000,000 loss in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) Treasury officials expressed delight today at unusually heavy investor demand for two new securities offered as part of an $8,800,000,000 cash financing.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 2 (AP) Walter Ryan, the 57year-old unfrocked priest who was the central figure in a $2,300,000 suit against the Roman Catholic Church brought by his wife, sued her for divorce today.
BETHESDA, Md., Aug. 2 Rear Admiral Dennis L. Francis, U.S.N., retired, died of cancer Monday at Bethesda Naval Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived in McLean, Va.

MOSCOW, Aug. 2 The Communist party leadership of a key Soviet farm region has expressed "serious concern" about this year's harvest and has called on farmers for a supreme effort to bring in the crop.

American Metal Climax, Inc., reported yesterday that earnings for the quarter ended June 30 were $9,482,000, or 66 cents a share. This compared with $7,735,000, or 54 cents a share, in the corresponding 1961 period.

A band of architects, including the designers of some of New York's most modern buildings, paraded on Seventh Avenue yesterday to protest the proposed razing of one of of the city's more venerable neo-classic structures, Pennsylvania Station.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Aug. 2 (AP) The Vermont Senate refused today to adopt a Houseapproved reapportionment bill giving Chittenden County one more seat at the expense of Rutland County. The vote was 16-13.

A unit of Army reservists from the metropolitan area, called up last year in the Berlin crisis, returned to the city yesterday in a generally bitter mood. They were the first reservists from the area to return as a group.

William H. McKeon, the Democratic state chairman, urged the state government yesterday to block what he called an "astronomical rate increase" for nearly 3,000,000 Blue Shield medical insurance subscribers.
OTTAWA, Aug. 2 (Canadian Press) A British shipowner thinks that the St. Lawrence Seaway is fraught with dangers to ships. Seaway officials, however, take issue.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Aug. 2 U Thant, Seting Secretary General, said today that he must have the support of a solid majority in the General Assembly before he would accept a full five-year term as Secretary General.

MIDDLETOWN, R.I., Aug. 2 Once more an end has come to a span of loafing on this fortunate shore of the great ocean of the free peoples. The least stringent exaction of the obligation of gratitude is a tribute to this meeting place of sea and land that surely is as gentle as ...
Six Harlem teen-agers and a 21-year-old Brooklyn man were accused yesterday of more than fifty muggings and taxicab holdups since last March.

LONDON, Aug. 2 The Earl of Home, Britain's Foreign Secretary, announced in the House of Lords today that the United Arab Republic had agreed to compensate Britons whose property in Egypt was seized immediately after the invasion of Suez in 1956 by Britain and France.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg fears that a continued high level of unemployment will cause unions to go after a shorter work week in earnest.

The following is a listing of restaurants that are recommended on the basis of varying merits. Such a listing is published every Friday in The New York Times. Unless otherwise indicated, the restaurants are open seven days a week.

As a consequence of the United States Supreme Court decision in Baker v. Carr our legislative representation systems are now undergoing intensive re-examination in more than twenty states, looking to fairer reapportionment of seats. This re-examination is directed, primarily, at the integrity of the existing systems, many of which discriminate flagrantly against those who live in heavily populated areas and in favor of those who live in sparsely populated areas.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 2 Britain and the six members of the Common Market agreed today to offer associate membership in the market to in dependent African and Caribbean countries in the British Commonwealth and to practically all British colonies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) The continuing struggle between the two top officers of the International Union of Electrical Workers, American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations, resulted today in picketing of its headquarters.
The New Haven Railroad reduced its net loss in the first half to $6,843,721 from $11,777,- 063 in the 1961 period, trustees of the road reported yesterday.

MINNEAPOLIS Aug. 2 Play began today in the master men's and women's pair contests in the American Contract Bridge League tournament at the Leamington Hotel here. Each is a threesession event in which the title will be decided Saturday. There are 178 men's pairs and 136 women's pairs.

NEWARK, Aug. 2 New Jersey faces the loss of thousands of dollars annually as a result of a Superior Court decision that interstate buses using the New Jersey Turnpike and the Garden State Parkway need not pay an excise tax.

The Columbia Broadcasting System radio network is informing its affiliated stations that it proposes to drop four more entertainment programs. They are Art Linkletter's "House Party" and "The Bing Crosby-Rosemary Clooney Show," ...
The Board of Elections said yesterday that many voters would have to use paper ballots in the Sept. 6 primary because the city had failed to sign a contract for new voting machines.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 2 Brazil's conservatives spoke with one voice today against President Joao Goulart's campaign for a national plebiscite on the nation's faltering parliamentary system of government.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 Railroad carloadings rose last week 1.6 per cent from the preceding week's total but were 4.1 per cent below the 1961 level.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 2 Jon Douglas and Dennis Ralston waged a punishing two-hour battle today in their rivalry for a singles assignment in the United States' Davis Cup tennis tie with Mexico. The five-match series will start Saturday.
WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 2 A new menace is threatening the safety of motorists and pedestrians in Westchester County, police officials reported today.
HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Aug. 2--The Suffolk Planning Commission endorsed the controversial proposal of Robert Moses for an ocean boulevard on Fire Island here yesterday.
Acting under the direction of Governor Rockefeller, the State Rent Administrator turned over a fifty-pound carton of rentcontrol records to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office yesterday.

Food Fair Stores, Inc., established its twenty-ninth consecutive annual sales record in the fiscal year ended April 28, Samuel Friedland, chairman, and Louis Stein, president, reported yesterday. Usually heavy store opening expenses, intensified competition and costs ininvolving consolidation and expansion were said to have led to the drop in earnings from those of the previous year.

MALVERNE, L.I., Aug. 2--Two Negroes and a white mother started a twenty-four-hour fast and sit-in last night in the office of the Superintendent of Schools here. They were protesting what they called de facto segregation in School District 12.

Seventeen mammoth new salt spreaders with snow plows attached were inspected yesterday before joining the Department of Sanitation's snow-fighting force. Each machine weighs thirteen tons, and has hoppers for fourteen tons of salt or sand.
New York Airways said, yes- terday that it had set a new passenger record in the first month of operating its new turbine-powered helicopters despite some minor mechanical problems with the craft.
WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Aug. 2 (AP) Art Wall Jr., took only twenty-nine putts today as he shot a six-under-par 65 for the first-round lead in the 72-hole $35,000 Insurance City open golf touranment.

Two men who already are implicated in a $123,000 stock theft from Carl M. Loeb, Rhoades Co., and a burglary of an East Side grocery store were accused yesterday in the passing of counterfeit $20 bills.

FOR some, camping with children is a vacation; for others, it is a nightmare. But as heads are counted, it is readily apparent that increasing numbers of families have found that adequate equipment and good planning can carry the day.

Electric Bond and Share Company reported yesterday net asset value of $159,551,000, equal to $30.53 a share, as of June 30. This was 15 per cent below the $187,429,841, or $35.70 a share, reported a year earlier. On March 31, the company showed net assets of $181,623,536, or $34.59 a share.
ALBANY, Ga., Aug. 2 The head of the integrationist Albany Movement said today that his group had never advocated violence in racial protests.

The Statue of Liberty drew 172,052 persons to Liberty Is land in July. This was more than had ever before visited the island in a single month. In July a year ago there were 142,467 visitors.

Most of the 103 men in the crew of the Savannah refused to leave the nuclear ship yesterday after they were discharged at Yorktown, Va.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Saturday, Aug. 4 Britain and the Common Market agreed yesterday on measures to avoid economic damage to India, Pakistan and Ceylon from British entry into the market.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 3 A battle-hardened team of Australian jungle fighters arrived here today to train South Vietnam's forces in the newest anti-guerrilla, tactics.

Paperhangers in Manhattan and the Bronx returned to work yesterday under union orders after a two-day work stoppage over contract demands.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3 (AP) Don Drysdale scored his tenth straight victory and became the season's first twenty-game winner tonight as the league-leading Los Angeles Dodgers defeated Chicago, 8 3, before 29,569 fans.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP) Six 3-year-olds, headed by Ridan, were named today for the fifth-second running of the American Derby at Arlington Park tomorrow. With six starters the race would gross $116,250 and the winner would receive $71,250.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, told the Senate today that President Kennedy's delay in signing the sugar bill had given importers $663,854 in windfall profits.

BOSTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) Run-producing singles by Jim Piersall and Chuck Cottier in the fifth inning tonight and the relief pitching of Jim Hannan gave the Washington Senators a 2-1 victory over the Boston Red Sox.
The Salvation Army Women's Auxiliary will hold its first benefit theatre party at the Nov. 1 performance of "Mr. President." The musical is scheduled to open at the St. James on Oct. 20.

MARLBORO, Vt., Aug. 3 The twelfth season of the Marlboro Music School and Festival is in its fifth week on the tiny campus of Marlboro College. OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 3--Nine of the nation's outstanding 2-year-olds were named today to compete for a bonanza of $108,055 in the seventeenth edition of the Sapling Stakes at Monmouth Park tomorrow. The winner of the six-furlong race will get $64,833.
American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., received yesterday a $2,600,000 down payment on the subsidiary that it agreed to sell to the Government of Colombia, in December, 1961.

Showers or rain fell yesterday in the Middle Atlantic States, the central Appalachians, the upper Mississippi Valley, the Gulf States and the Pacific Northwest. It was warmer from the lower lake region to the Central Plains States and cooler in the upper Midwest and the far West.

VENICE. THE three figures dressed in flowing nun's robes dashed out of a portico and onto St. Mark's Square, sending hundreds of pigeons fluttering into the clear noonday sky. On they ran, drawing surprised stares, until three loud whistles brought them to a halt. Then they're turned to the starting point, dropping, hot and exhausted, into chairs beside the movie camera, as tourists gawked at the impromptu attraction in the already colorful location.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 5 (AP)-- Robin Roberts continued his comeback with the Baltimore Orioles today. He stopped the Los Angeles Angels, 7--2, on five hits for his seventh victory of the season.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 5 --Marilyn Monroe, one of the most famous stars in Hollywood's history, was found dead early today in the bedroom of her home in the Brentwood section of Los Angeles. She was 36 years old.

The United States Census Bureau has made new projections of the country's population in 1975 and 1980. They enable planners in business and other private organizations, as well as in Government, to estimate future requirements for goods, services and capital equipment.

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., Aug. 5--President Kennedy asked the Senate today to strengthen its pending new drug law to insure "safer and better" drugs for the American consumer.

OCEANPORT, N.J. Aug. 5-- Ronald Ferraro, 19 years old and currently the nation's leading apprentice jockey, has two loves--horses and operatic music. He adds that he will have no time for girls until he has made his mark.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 6 --Funeral services for Marilyn Monroe were set today for Wednesday afternoon.

NEWARK, Aug. 6--Federal Court Judge Reynier J. Wortendyka Jr. today adjourned to Sept. 4 a hearing on whether a suit concerning $2,421,850 found in a Jersey City garage should come under the jurisdiction of a Federal or a state court.
NANTUCKET, Mass., Aug. 6 --Whiting W. Willauer, Ambassador to Honduras and Costa Rica during the Eisenhower Administration, died of a heart attack today at his summer home here. He was 55 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP)--A witness at a labor union trial testified today that James R. Hoffa made $500,000 available to a childhood friend to finance a membership raid on the Communications Workers of America.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP)-- Early Wynn was denied the 298th victory of his pitching career when the Baltimore Orioles routed him with a two-run flurry in the ninth inning tonight but the Chicago White Sox won anyway, 5--4, as Floyd Robinson singled across the winning run in the eleventh inning.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 (UPI)--Georgie Benton scored a unanimous decision over Joey Giardello tonight with a closing barrage that had Giardello, the favorite, hanging on the ropes at Convention Hall. Benton weighed 161 pounds, Giardello 161 .

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6-- Mrs. James M. Helm, White House social secretary under the Wilson, Roosevelt and Truman Administrations, died here today at the age of 88. Mrs. Helm made her home at Boyce, Va.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6--Under Secretary of State George W. Ball predicted today that the Soviet Union and its satellite countries would find within a few years that they cannot maintain their "hermetically sealed society."

FREEHOLD, N.J., Aug. 6-- Wagering a record $532,907 for an opening day, a crowd of 8,437 fans witnessed the first program of Freehold Raceway's sixty-day harness meeting here today. It marked the first time in the history of the track that the mutuel play exceeded $500,000 on a weekday.

The Consolidated Natural Gas Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and gas Volume for the six and twelve months ended on June 30. However, net income in both preriods was below the levels of the year earlier.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., Aug. 6--Andrew Mills Jr., former president and board chairman of the Dry Dock Savings Bank in New York, died today at his home on River Road. His age was 86.

BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 8 (AP) --Len Jordan, a 63-year-old former Governor of Idaho, was appointed today as interim United States Senator, filling the vacancy created by the death of Senator Henry C. Dworshak.

Connecticut, Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Rhode Island and Vermont will participate in the 1964-65 New York World's Fair, Robert Moses, president of the fair, announced yesterday.

DETROIT, Aug. 6--Retail sales of new cars in July were the best for the period since the record year of 1955. A month-end surge in purchases lifted sales to 511,679 units of domestically-built autos compared with the 624,100 sold in July, 1955, according to Ward's Automotive Report. The July total this year was 91,653 units above sales for the same month last year.

Cordier is the committee's president pro tem.

Sugar futures advanced in an otherwise dull day on the New York Commodity exchanges. The bank holiday in Britain reduced trading in some items.

BOSTON, Aug 6 (AP)--A Los Angeles right-hander, Dean Chance hurled a six-hitter and Leon Wagner drove in two runs tonight as the Angels defeated Boston 5--2. Sales of the Dow Chemical Company rose to a record in its fiscal year ended May 31, but earnings declined by more than $1,000,000 from the preceding year, the annual report disclosed yesterday. Net earnings came to $63,004,064 after taxes and all charges. This was equivalent to $2.16 each on 29,120,120 common shares outstanding. In the preceding fiscal year the net income was $64,439,878, or $2.23 a share, on 28,862,717 shares then outstanding.
