MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 7--Earl R. Glenn, a retired professor who had been on the faculties of Teachers College of Columbia University and the New Jersey State Teachers College at Montclair, now Montclair State College, died today in Mercy Hospital. He was 75 years old and had lived recently in Key Biscayne.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) --Dr. Frances Oldham Kelsey, who blocked marketing of the drug thalidomide in the United States, pronounced herself "impressed and overwhelmed" today as President Kennedy hung a gold medal around her neck.
SEATTLE, Aug. 7--Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy said today that the nation was indebted to J. Edgar Hoover for his work in controlling Communist espionage.
International lending agencies announced yesterday the granting of three credits aggregating $29,400,000 to India, Guatemala and Venezuela.

QUITE earth-shaking is the hustle and bustle now going on behind the scenes at Roosevelt Raceway. The tremors aren't caused by the stamping of the pacers and trotters in their stalls. It is Al Weil's vast organization putting on the finishing touches for one of the year's outstanding harness racing events.
ROME, Aug. 7--The development of southern Italy is expected to be spurred by a National Programming Commission that went into operation today.
Amid much tapping of toes and snapping of fingers, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced to the world yesterday that it had come up with a new international advertising language.
CHICAGO, Aug. 7--A Federal judge refused today to intervene in the protracted struggle between the railroads and five key unions.
Fifteen sewage-treatment tanks at two city plants will have to be repaired at a cost of $2,000,000 because of suspected defects.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7 --The election of Sidney J. Goldstein, general counsel of the Port of New York Authority, as chairman of the Local Government Law Section of the American Bar Association was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UPI)--Two California officials of the Communications Workers of America were placed on trial today by the union on charges of participating in a secession plot inspired by the Teamsters Union.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) --The House Space Committee approved today a bill to revise space research patent laws. The purpose is to allow private companies to retain title to patents they develop under a Government contract.
BOSTON, Aug. 7 (UPI)--Bob Rodgers' bases-filled single drove in two of three Los Angeles runs in the ninth inning today as the Angels rallied for a 3-1 victory over the Boston Red Sox.
Pressure mounted on Mayor Wagner yesterday for a $1.50 minimum wage law and for improvement in the status of city employes.

A former official of the International Cooperation Administration and a business man were indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday for an alleged kickback scheme in a $3,000,000 aid project in the Philippines.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 7 --When "Oliver," the British hit musical opened here last night, it was an experiment that could make Los Angeles one of the nation's best tryout cities for a Broadway opening.
MOSCOW, Aug. 7--A Soviet provincial newspaper provided tonight at least a partial answer to the mystery surrounding the activities in the Soviet Union of Walter Ulbricht.

Stockholders of the First National City Bank held a special meeting yesterday to vote on the bank's proposed merger with the Richmond County National Bank of Staten Island. The merger was approved, but the business of the meeting took a back seat to other subjects brought up by First National stockholders.
ALGIERS, Aug. 7 (AP)-- In the gleaming white hospital of Beni Messous, on a hill overlooking Algiers, a 13-year-old blind Moslem boy underwent a two-hour operation today for the removal of cataracts.
Eight families have been evacuated from a Brooklyn tenement where a 2-month-old girl was viciously bitten by rats last week, the Department of Health announced yesterday.

Net income of Aluminium, Ltd., in the quarter ended on June 30 advanced to $12,800,000 from $7,700,000 in the corresponding period of last year, the company reported yesterday. It is a leading international producer and distributor of aluminum.

How many broker-dealer firms are there in the country? No one, not even the Securities and Exchange Commission, knows for sure. On June 30, there were 5,870 brokerdealers registered with the S.E.C. But there are a number of firms that don't have to register, including nearly 100 members of the New York Stock Exchange, which do not deal with the public.

SIXTY-TWO cars, one of the largest fields ever to par ticipate in an international rally organized in the United States, were scheduled to leave the Westchester County Airport early this morning on the MG Car Club's tenth annual 1,000-mile event.

Complaints from astrologers that there are too many disreputable soothsayers here will set off a city-wide investigation of crystal-gazers, palmists and tealeaf readers, starting today. But the investigators intend also to peer closely at the complaining star-gazers.
Stocks declined again yesterday in slow trading. The market performance was almost a duplicate of that on Monday.
LONDON, Aug. 7--A general description of last week's European Economic Community talks in Brussels was issued today by Edward Heath, Lord Privy Seal, who serves as Britain's chief negotiator.

Muzz Patrick, the general manager and vice president of the New York Rangers, intimated yesterday that Emile (The Cat) Francis would become coach of the National Hockey League club for the 1962-63 season.
WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 7-- Royal E. Cleveland's Adiosand from Camp Hill, Pa., scored a nose victory in 2:02.1 tonight over Vandyke Hanover in the mile pacing feature before 16,577 at Roosevelt Raceway.

Gov. Nelson Rockefeller of New York must be the only man in America these days who camps out in a penthouse. He has a cozy little place in Manhattan with a spectacular view of Central Park and a choice of vacation houses stretching from Brazil to the Grand Tetons in the West, but his mind is not on vacations but on votes.
Negotiating efforts in the strike of seamen on the Nuclear ship Savannah remained on dead center yesterday.

PARIS, Aug. 7--Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower continued today his round of visits in and near Paris while Mrs. Eisenhower kept to their suite in the Hotel George V with a mild "flu-like virus."

SCHROON LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 7--Governor Rockefeller said today that enforcment of navigation laws and an educational program in boating safety had been major factors in reducing boating fatalities in the last two years.

DALLAS, Tex, Aug. 7 (UPI) --A Federal grand jury subpoenaed the bank records of United States Representative J.T. Rutherford today as a prelude to a new investigation of Billie Sol Estes. The subpoenaed records go back to Jan. 1, 1959.
NOROTON, Conn., Aug. 7-- Bill Smith and the Pequot Yacht Club crew from Southport sailed into a 2-point lead in the Long Island Sound junior championship series off Noroton Yacht Club today.

LEE Mass., Aug. 7--A dancer new to this country and a program that includes only one work ever seen previously in the United States makes the seventh week's offering of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival rather special by anybody's calculations.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 7--The Federal Government will budget for a deficit of 118,000,000 ($259,600,000) in 1962 and 1963, Harold Edward Holt, Australia's Treasurer announced in the House of Representatives tonight.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 7 --Dink Terripleton, noted track and field coach, died of a heart attack today at the age of 65.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell announced yesterday that open hearings "aimed at the entire garment industry" would begin on Friday in the Federal Court House, Foley Square.
"Lolita" and "Bird Man of Alcatraz," two of the most controversial films released within recent months, have been chosen to represent the United States at the Venice Film Festival.

ALBANY, Ga., Aug. 7--The vanguard of what is expected to be a procession of out-ofstate ministers arrived in Albany tonight. They said they were "ready to go" to jail to demonstrate their support of the civil right struggle here.

Mayor Wagner yesterday appointed Joseph M. Leahey, 65 years old, of 35 Emerson Avenue, Staten Island, as a Justice of the Municipal Court, Second Richmond County District, at an annual salary of $19,000.
The price of silver in New York yesterday edged up a quarter of a cent an ounce to $1.05 , a forty-two-year high.

MOSCOW, Aug. 7--Three Japanese students, who described themselves as Communists, complained today of being manhandled by the Soviet police when they demonstrated in Red Square yesterday against Soviet nuclear testing.

LONDON, Aug. 7--The Government ordered today the deportation of George Lincoln Rockwell, the Nazi party leader in the United States, who has been attending an outdoor camp meeting of British Fascists.

BUTTERMILK has a homely, old-fashioned connotation, at least for anyone who remembers the chore of churning butter on the farm. The tart liquid with golden globules of fat floating in it remained after the butter was removed.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Aug. 7 --Vice President Johnson visited today two Jamaican, camps where members of the United, States Peace Corps are stationed. The trip was made in a helicopter sent from the United States Naval Base at Guantanamo, Cuba.
THE time of the large tournaments is at hand. Those who have delayed in making arrangements to participate will find themselves in all sorts of difficulties if they procrastinate much longer.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 7--A cloudburst, not unusual in this salubrious locale at this time of the year, spoiled what might have been a pretty good horse race today.
Heavy trading in world sugar and cocoa were the main interests in a generally quiet and mixed day on the New York Commodity exchanges.

The 12-meter yacht Nefertiti, a strong contender to represent the United States in the America's Cup next month, sustained minor hull damage yesterday after two mooring lines were mysteriously cut at her Newport, R.I., pier.
MOSCOW, Aug. 7--The Government decreed today a gradual abolition of one-family homes in urban communities of the Soviet Union.
Louis A. Novins resigned yesterday as president of the International Telemeter Company, the pay-television division of the Paramount Pictures Corporation.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 7 --Delegates to the eighth World Youth Festival, which closed last night, travelled homeward today amid indications that some new form of international youth meeting might be under consideration.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7-- David Sarnoff called today for creation of a single company to handle all this country's international communications.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7(AP) --Spokesmen for the glass, pottery and glove industries assailed President Kennedy's trade-e ansion bill today before the Senate Finance Committee.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Aug. 7 --Glenn L. Gardiner, a retired vice president and director of the Forstmann Woolen Company of Passaic and an authority on human relations and foremanship in industry, died today in St. Joseph's Hospital in Paterson. He was 66 years old and lived at 396 Knollwood Road.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 7-- Casey Stengel, baseball's little old word-maker, brought the Mets to an emotional pitch tonight before they faced the feared Dodgers at Chavez Ravine. Then, as dutiful as ever, the Mets went out and lost to Walt Alston's league leaders, 7--5.
LONDON, Aug. 7--Stock market prices remained firm today after the long holiday week-end. The demand was selective, and small gains exceeded losses.
DUBLIN, Aug. 7--This city was at its gayest today for the opening of Horse Show Week.
The 1,113 invasion prisoners still held by Cuba have resisted for sixteen months many efforts to persuade them to defect.

EAST STROUDSBURG, Pa. Aug. 7 (AP)--The New York Titans of the American Football League asked waivers today on Jim Furey, a five-year pro center and linebacker, and Jim Ward, a 215-pound defensive halfback from Jamaica, Queens.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 7--"It sounded real good," said Mrs. E.E. Quinn, housewife in suburban Edina.
The Lido Beach Hotel, a fourstory landmark in the Spanish style of architecture on the ocean front in the Lido Beach area of Long Beach, L.I., will be operated on a cooperative basis.
NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 7-- The Norwalk Chamber of Commerce blamed the Norwalk Redevelopment Agency today for a decline in the city's retail sales.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 7-- A United States Embassy spokesman said today that letters had been received from five Americans and a Filipino who have been prisoners of the procommunist Pathet Lao forces for more than a year.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 7 (UPI)--Roger Werksman of Los Angeles, the No. 29 ranking player in the United States, upset sixth-seeded Gordon Forbes of South Africa, today in the second round of the seventyfourth Meadow Club Invitation tennis tournament. The scores were 12--10, 2--6, 6--3.
GENEVA, Aug. 7--The Soviet Union is expected to reject the new United States proposals on a treaty to end nuclear testing when formal negotiations are resumed Thursday.

A standard tactic of Communist propaganda is to stage events that will attract nonCommunists who can be exposed to indoctrination aimed at winning them over to Marxism-Leninism. Every now and then, however, something happens to upset this strategy, and the result is a useful contribution to the education of political innocents.
The Gamble Skogmo Acceptance Corporation announced yesterday the election of J.N. Anderson as president, succeeding L.F. Crews, who resigned as chairman and president last May 31.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UPI)--An American steel company has complained to the Government that steel wire mesh made in Belgium and France has been "dumped" in this country at prices below fair value.

BERLIN, Aug. 7--East Germany's economic troubles are regarded by experts here as stemming from a Soviet-bloc policy of concentrating productive power on new weapons to the detriment of consumer goods and food.
The National Association of Manufacturers, responding to a challenge from George Meany, outlined yesterday its concept of the meaning of profits.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 7-- Chancellor Adenauer's Christian Democratic Union warned neutral nations today not to endorse or sign any separate peace treaty that the Soviet Union might conclude with East Germany.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7--Federal Judge Irving Ben Cooper testified today that human reaction to the misery he saw had sometimes made him "shorttempered" as a city judge.

SAN QUENTIN, Calif., Aug. 7 (UPI)--A United States Supreme Court justice and Federal District Court both denied a stay of execution today, to Mrs. Elizabeth Ann Duncan, who is scheduled to die tomorrow in the San Quentin gas chamber.
ALBANY, Aug. 7--The Conservative party sued today to invalidate an Election Law requirement that, it contends, unduly hobbles the nomination of independent candidates for state-wide office.
CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP)-- Selling pressure continued for grain futures today. Nearly all commodities extended their decline, and about half of the contracts reached season lows on the Board of Trade.

Investment money, indfferent about working for a long-term yield of 4.19 per cent in new Treasury bonds, came out of hiding in a big way yesterday to claim a share of the new $100,000,000 Southwestern Bell Telephone debentures at an offering yield of 4.45 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) --Top officials of the defense Department and the space agency urged speedy action today on the Administration's communications satellite bill.

HAVANA, Aug. 7 (UPI)-- The Castro Government charged the United States today with violations of Cuban air space over the week-end and said that Marines at the Guantanamo Naval Base had fired into Cuba and hurled flammable materials.
Heavy thunderstorms rumbled over wide areas of the metropolitan area yesterday, causing total flooding, two deaths and power failures in many parts of Westchester County.
A field study of the relationship of automobile exhausts to cancer-producing pollutants in the air is being carried on here by a General Motors research team as part of a three-city test.

The United States Chamber of Commerce, which recently broke with its traditional fiscal orthodoxy by advocating a cut in taxes before the budget is balanced, may be asking for further trouble from conservatives in its recommendations for eliminating the deficit in the nation's balance of payments.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) --Civilian exports increased by 5 per cent in June over the May level to the second highest monthly level on record, the Government reported today. The strength in exports has expanded the nation's important trade surplus.
DETROIT, Aug. 7--George Romney, 55-year-old Michigan industrialist, demonstrated his vote-getting potential today as he won the Republican nomination for Governor in the primary election here.

Kentoku, Ltd., a Japanese manufacturing concern with headquarters in Osaka and branches in five other cities, has become associated with Johnson's Wax International, a subsidiary of S.C. Johnson Son, Inc., it was announced yesterday in Racine, Wis., by Howard M. Packard, president of the parent concern.

Life and politics being what they are in Latin America these days, it is news that Colombia has peacefully inaugurated a President after a democratic election and an uninterrupted term of office for his predecessor.

ALGIERS, Aug. 7--The Provisional Government of Premier Benyoussef Ben Khedda formally divested itself of its powers today in favor of the Political Bureau set up by Deputy Premier Mohammed Ben Bella and his followers.
WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 7-- The Town of Harrison won the right today to tax the Harrison portion of the Westchester County Airport on which the county collects rent for private use by industry.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7-- The Eastern team from the New York area eliminated Middle States (Pennsylvania, Delaware, New Jersey), 5--0, in the first round of the United States girls' grass court tennis team championship today at Germantown Cricket Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7-- Anthony J. Celebrezze, the new Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, endorsed today the Administration program of Federal aid to higher education. But he parried a question on his stand on Federal aid to elementary and secondary education.
An unusual amount of turmoil within Democratic and Republican party organizations in New York City was indicated yesterday by primary designating petitions filed with the Board of Elections.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7--The Government reported today that at least 207 pregnant women had taken thalidomide under a testing program conducted by the American maker of the drug, and that none had given birth so far to deformed babies.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7-- President Kennedy's judicial appointments won general praise at the American Bar Association meeting today.

HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 7--Plans were completed today to try to make Marilyn Monroe's funeral tomorrow as simple as possible. Only a small number of persons will be admitted to the funeral chapel and the press has been excluded.

COLUMBUS, N.J., Aug. 7-- An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and two of his daughters were killed this afternoon when their station wagon collided with another car one mile north of here during a rain storm.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 7-- Three teams were left in the contest for the master's team championship as the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament entered its final session tonight after eleven days of play.
The Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company has ordered some $40,000,000 in steel pipe and compressor-station equipment in recent days for a 409-mile gas transmission line expansion across six states.
An 18-year-old youth has confessed that he had killed an architect found stabbed in a Queens apartment last winter, the police said last night.

A team of recording engineers from Mercury Records has just returned from a friendly invasion of Russia exhausted, but with nothing but kind words for the welcome they received. Their junket marked the first time that an American concern had recorded on its own equipment inside the Soviet Union.

MEMORY and imagination usually make sure that there is a special magic in the past. The historical past is always out of proportion. The drama and the color and the celebrated personages always loom larger than life and the monotony, squalor and misery always are swept at least part way under the rug.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 7--Sandy Paine of Rock Spring won the thirty-ninth annual Women's Metropolitan junior girls golf championship today by a three-stroke margin.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Aug. 7 (AP)--Judge Armistead M. Dobie of the United States Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals died here today. He was 81 years old.

BURKS FALLS, Ont., Aug. 7 (AP)--Matt Mann 2d, former United States Olympic swimming coach and coach at the Universities of Michigan and Oklahoma, died at his summer camp last night. He was 77 years old.

Workers on Hudson River piers between Forty-second and Fifty-seventh Street had their busiest day in almost three years yesterday with the arrival between 7 and 8 A.M. of eight ships carrying 7,434 passengers.
The number of traffic injuries in the city last week amounted to 1,028, ninety-nine more than a year ago.

ROME, Aug. 7--For Franco-American relations tomorrow will be a day of preoccupation. General de Gaulle gives a luncheon for General Eisenhower and his family and his Cabinet will meet to give formal endorsement to the new United States Ambassador, Mr. Bohlen.
MADRID, Aug. 7--Press censorship in Spain seems to have been asleep, or suspended, in recent weeks.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 7--The Congo's central Government moved on several fronts today to place an economic squeeze on secessionist Katanga province and to isolate the province from the rest of the world.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 7 --Mrs. E.C. Kip Finch of the Country Club of New Canaan, the medalist in the 39th annual Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association championship, won the last four holes to defeat Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of Westchester C.C., 1-up, in a first-round match at the Round Hill Club today. Mrs. Nesbitt won the title from 1956 through 1960.
The bitter complaints and the generalized recriminations by many metropolitan-area Army reservists now returning to civilian life after active duty during the Berlin crisis are deeply disquieting.
YONKERS, Aug. 7--Dr. Werner Leszynski, a physicist and author, died today in St. Joseph's Hospital at the age of 64. He lived at 595 McLean Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) --The Kansas City Athletics used a pair of big innings tonight to rout Washington, 10--3, for their fifth victory in a row and tenth straight over the Senators.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7-- Justice William J. Brennan Jr. of the Supreme Court proposed today the creation of a new world court to protect individuals against oppression by their governments.
The Federal Maritime Commission will reconsider its approval of the sale of two C-4 vessels by the Bull Lines to the Waterman Steamship Company of Puerto Rico.

The household handyman would have had a tremendous day at the Coliseum yesterday. Devices by the thousand were displayed by some 200 exhibitors at the Eastern Housewares Show for the benefit of the retailers, the distributors and the dealers who before long will be putting on their own displays.

MOSCOW, Aug. 7 (UPI)-- The leader of a group of young Americans who were informally "tried" in the Soviet Union recently for allegedly having distributed anti-Soviet literature termed the incident a shocking experience today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7--The mood in Communist China is one of "apathy, dejection and demoralization" in the midst of economic disaster, United States Government experts on Chinese affairs reported today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7-- Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon left the impression at a House committee hearing today that he was opposed to income tax reductions at this time.
Subscribers to the Southampton (L.I.) Horse-Show Ball to be held on Aug. 18 in the Parrish Art Museum have been announced by Mrs. Wilfred J. Funk, chairman of the patrons and patronesses committee.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7-- Norman K. Winston, a nationally known developer of housing projects, was sworn in today as United States Commissioner to the 1964-65 New York World's Fair.

OTTAWA, Aug. 7 (AP)-- Justice T.G. Norris indicated today that he would take the Industrial Inquiry Commission to key St. Lawrence River and Great Lakes ports for on-thespot investigations of labor strife and the disruption of shipping.
ONCE again, it is Gilbert and Sullivan time off Broadway. With sparkle and freshness, Dorothy Raedler's American Savoyards are back for another season.

CALGARY, Alta., Aug. 7 (AP)--Independent companies, prominent in the rags-to-riches development of western Canada's oil industry, face a harsh set of alternatives: Either to go up in a hurry or down just as quickly.

All of yesterday's thunder did not come from the sky. Some emanated from the Stadium, where the Yankees severed a three-game losing string with an eighteen-hit assault that crushed the Minnesota Twins, 14--1.

A two-day meeting of Federal Aviation Agency officials and those of the six-nation Eurocontrol Association was held in Washington last week. They exchanged views on air traffic control, research and development, and liaison.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7--The White House attempted to lay to rest today persistent rumors that President Kennedy would make no great effort this year to defeat the Senate Republican leader, Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois.
PARIS, Aug. 7--Le Monde, a leading afternoon newspaper, took pity today on "Augustians" and published a directory of special addresses.

LONDON, Aug. 7--Britain rejected, today the claim of the Philippines to North Borneo, the British colony that will be merged in the Federation of Malaysia. The federation is scheduled to be formed by next August.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7-- Legislation proposed by President Kennedy would provide the "death warrant" for inland waterway common carriers, the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee was told today.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Aug. 7 --Malcolm X, leader of the Black Muslim movement, announced tonight that he would not speak here at a rally on Aug. 18.
RAVELLO, Italy, Aug. 7--A renovated Ravello has prepared an elaborate reception for Mrs. John F. Kennedy, its most distinguished visitor in many years.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7 (AP)--Harvey Kuenn hit his fifth home run of the season here today in leading the San Francisco Giants to a 4-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies. The triumph was the Giants' fourth in a row.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 7 (Reuters)--The two major Angolan nationalist insurgent movements in exile here have begun talks aimed at finding a basis of collaboration in the struggle for the independence of the neighboring Portuguese territory.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7--The United States is urging Britain and Israel to permit the transfer of Dr. Robert A. Soblen's passage from El Al Airlines to Pan American World Airways.
MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 7-- Designating petitions filed at the Nassau County Board of Elections today indicated that there would be eight primary contests to be decided Sept. 6.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 8-- Mrs. Stanley Welch Royse has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Nancy Anne Royse, to John Gibson Crossman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Gibson Crossman of New York and Litchfield, Conn.

The nation's railroads, whose financial health has continued to deteriorate, are now faced with a strike threat from five major rail unions. CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP)-- Nearly all grain futures sold at the lows of the season today on the Board of Trade. But the market had advanced by the close.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 8-- Israel balked today at being a go-between for the removal of Dr. Robert A. Soblen from Britain to the United States aboard a United States carrier.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 8-- Roscoe Pound, dean emeritus of the Harvard Law School, was honored today for his contributions to legal philosophy and judicial reform.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 8 (AP) --A young Roman Catholic priest from Troy, N.Y., who protested against the conduct at a saloon was shot dead last night by a barman in Montera, in central Bolivia. A mob then lynched his killer over the protests of other priests.
LONDON, Aug, 8--Archie Compston, outstanding British golfer, died here today at the age of 69.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8-- The Eastern team from the New York area reached the semifinal round of the United States girls' grass court tennis team championship by defeating, New England, 5--2, today at the Germantown Cricket Club.

COHASSET, Mass., Aug. 8-- Dr. Frederick L. Good, the Boston gynecologist and obstetrician who delivered all nine chilician who assisted at the births of all nine children of former Ambassador and Mrs. Joseph P. Kennedy, died at his summer home her a last night at the age of 80.
LONDON, Aug. 8--Buyers, made cautious by the Wall Street trend, kept out of the stock market here today. Small selling lowered prices of the leading industrials.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 8-- Edwin G. Michaelian, County Executive of Westchester and Republican county leader, made counter-charges today against Representative Edwin B. Dooley in their battle over food concessions.

WASHINGTON Aug. 8-- Five railroad unions disclosed today that they had ordered 200,000 train-operating workers to be prepared for a nationwide walkout if the railroads went ahead with announced job curtailments on Aug. 16.
Cotton futures were 10 cents a bale up to 30 cents down yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 8 --A brief, simple funeral service was held today for Marilyn Monroe at the small Westwood Village Funeral Chapel here.

RAVELLO, Italy, Aug. 8-- Almost all of Ravello's 2,500 residents, plus many tourists and visitors, turned out today to greet Mrs. John F. Kennedy and her daughter, Caroline, on their arrival for a vacation.
MIAMI, Aug. 7 (UPI)--Eastern Air Lines' flight engineers rejected today the company's latest offer to settle the fortyseven-day strike, and no further talks were scheduled.

HOUSTON, Aug. 8 (AP)-- Billy Cannon signed a new contract for more than $100,000 with the Houston Oilers today and officials of the American Football League champions hinted the action was prompted by overtures from the rival National Football League.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8-- Peru's military junta was reported today to be urging Latin-American Governments to oppose President Kennedy's stand against the junta.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 8 (AP)--Colombia's top military men asked tonight to be relieved of duty, confronting President Guillermo Le n Valencia with a crisis a day after his inauguration.
Gower Champion will direct and choreograph the new, untitled musical by Richard Rodgers and Alan Jay Lerner.
CERNE ABBAS, England, Aug. 8--This lovely unspoiled bit of English countryside has taken on an appearance of boisterous manner and violence such as it has not known for centuries.
The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday the following changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 8-- Miss Sally Ann Weld and Ensign Jerome Pierce Webster Jr., U.S.N.R., were married here this afternoon in St. Francis Protestant Episcopal Church by the Rev. Edward W. Mills. The Rev. Edric Weld, assisted.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 8 (AP)--Ambassador John Kenneth Galbraith today depicted the Negro vote as a major factor in the 1960 election of President Kennedy.

The Central Presbyterian Church way the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Mrs. Aurora Troconis Moore, daughter of Mrs. Mercedes del Ciervo Troconis of Caracas, Venezuela, and New York, to William Mellon Hitchcock. The bridegroom is a son of Mrs. Thomas Hitchcock of 10 Gracie Square and Westbury, L.I., and the late Mr. Hitchock.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8--Secretairy of State Dean Rusk met today with Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin of the Soviet Union in an effort to persuade Moscow to accept the new United States proposals for a nuclear test ban and disarmament.
The Preload Corporation denied yesterday that its method of strengthening concrete had been responsible for the collapse of a sewage tank at the city's Owls Head sewage-treatment plant in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP ) --Representatives of metals, luggage, textile and organic chemical groups continued the barrage of testimony against President Kennedy's trade expansion bill before the Senate Finance Committee today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8--A visitor from a rational land interviews an authoritative Administration spokesman
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UPI)--Eleven large American concerns have been engaged for several months in a unique business-to-business technicalaid venture in the Dominican Republic, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) --A Senate Judiciary subcommittee will try to complete hearings next week on Thurgood Marshall's nomination to be a Federal judge, Chairman Olin D. Johnston, Democrat of South Carolina, said today.

The president of New York Blue Shield clarified yesterday its intention to discontinue its so-called $2,500-$4,000 contract. A hearing on the matter will be held today by the Joint Legislative Committee on Health Insurance Plans.

NORWICH, N.Y., Aug. 8-- Governor Rockefeller, mending political fences in strong upstate Republican territory today, petted a newborn calf, posed for a picture holding a monkey, and again ran into the issue of free tuition for City University students.

HAVANA, Aug. 8 (UPI)-- Cuban athletes who will leave tomorrow to compete in the Caribbean Games in Kingston, Jamaica, have been warned that counter-revolutionary groups may try to bribe them to defect from Cuba or try to provoke them in order to create a scandal.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Aug. 8--The Rev. Dr. Hugh Dwight Darsie, pastor of the Flatbush Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) at Dorchester and Marlborough Roads in Brooklyn from 1930 to 1957, died of a heart attack at his home yesterday. He was 69 years old and lived at 35 Ferris Hill Road.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 8-- Gen. Juan Bautista Loza resigned as Argentina's Secretary of War and Commander in Chief of the Army tonight to resolve a dispute among army leaders and a mutiny.
MILFORD, Conn., Aug. 8 (AP)--The Board of Education has decided that the Lord's Prayer will continue to be heard daily in the classrooms of public schools here.
An independent slate running for offices on the American Stock Exchange has staged a mild upset by electing two of its candidates.

THE United States Government, which was created to facilitate the pursuit of happiness, remains on the side of the poets. Those who regard romance as the exclusive province of the young may be heartened by a recent Government finding that love is ageless.

With just a month to go before school starts, the Board of Education has not yet found a successor for Superintendent John J. Theobald, nor has it decided on a plan for the operation of the school system after he leaves the post on Sept. 1.
BERLIN, Aug. 8--A year after the East German Communists closed off passage between East and West Berlin, the Western sectors of the city give a thriving appearance.
ALBANY, Ga., Aug. 8--The Justice Department intervened today in the civil rights struggle in Albany.
The stock market advanced to a small gain yesterday after two days of declines. A late rally erased earlier losses and put many issues on the plus side at the close.

BEATNIK 'BOHEME' OPENS AT JAN HUS New York has had an interesting year for operatic transmigration. Last winter we had a Yiddish "Carmen" set in Israel, and last night Puccini's "La Boh me" turned up in an English version and a Greenwich Village setting. It was given at the Jan Hus Playhouse, where it will be repeated tonight and tomorrow night, with an admission charge.

The fairy tale didn't quite materialize for Cinerama, Inc., yesterday. Mediocre reviews greeted the opening of the "Wonderful World of the Brothers Grimm" and the Cinerama stock, which had risen sharply in anticipation of the commercial potential of this film, dropped. The shares are traded on the American Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8-- President Kennedy's Council of Economic Advisers told a committee of Congress today that present income taxes were a drag on the economy. The three council members left the impression that they favored a cut now.

As the Soviets continue their nuclear test explosions the United States launches a new effort for agreement on a treaty to ban such tests forever. Secretary Rusk has called in Soviet Ambassador Dobrynin to urge more serious consideration of the new American inspection proposals containing important concessions to the Soviet.
A Citizens Commission adopted a report yesterday favoring a local law to establish immediately a minimum wage of $1.25 an hour for all workers in the city.
The Port of New York Authority will pay up to $3,000 to each commercial tenant displaced by the World Trade Center.

KATMANDU, Nepal, Aug. 8-- Sizable numbers of Nepalese rebels, entrenched on a hillside near the Indian-Nepalese border, have been fighting Royal Nepal Army and Home Guard forces since Sunday afternoon, authoritative sources said here today.
Cheery confusion filled the Board of Elections offices yesterday as politicians pored over the nominating petitions for what may be a record number of primary contests here.

The work of the Manhattan Society for Mental Health will be furthered by the proceeds of a theatre party at the Oct. 24 performance of "Beyond the Fringe" at the Golden Theatre.
A severe storm that raked Oradell and Emerson in Bergen County, N.J., Tuesday afternoon was classified by the Weather Bureau here yesterday as a "confirmed tornado."
Soviet trade with other Communist-ruled countries dropped last year to the lowest level since 1958.
The Chemway Corporation, whose advertising had been spread among five different agencies, plans to consolidate its consumer accounts at North Advertising, Inc.

STOWE, Vt., Aug. 8--All sixty-two starter's in the MG Car Club's tenth annual 1,000-mile rally completed the first stage without mishap today. The first car rolled into this Vermont town noted as a ski resort shortly after 5 o'clock this afternoon.
PARIS, Aug. 8--The French Government offered substantial financial inducements tonight to civil servants and technicians to work in Algeria.
The Planned Parenthood Federation of America reported yesterday that no cases of blood clots had appeared in any of its nearly 11,000 women patients who were using an oral contraceptive pill.
PARIS, Aug. 8--Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower reaffirmed today his belief in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and its "sacred task" of safeguarding the values of Western civilization.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Aug. 8--John J. Oppasser of 53 Highland Avenue, vice president, general manager and a director of VariTyper Corporation of Newark, manufacturer of type composition machines, died yesterday at his home after a brief illness. His age was 56.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8-- Uncontrolled railroad rate cutting that would become legal under Administration-sponsored legislation "would finish off the remaining coastwise and intercoastal operators," a Congressional committee was told today.
The Dowager Princess Brinda, Maharani of Kapurthala, died on July 25 of coronary thrombosis at Woodville, her villa in Simla, India.
Dominic John Mercorella is beginning a double life.

The United Aircraft Corporation showed a sharp improvement in sales and earnings for the quarter and six-month periods ended with June, over those of the periods last year, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday. Half--year earnings nearly equaled the profits shown for all of 1961.

A $15,000,000 issue of the Ekco Products Company's 4.6 per cent sinking-fund debentures was quickly oversubscribed yesterday, after it was marketed at par by an underwriting group headed by Lehman Brothers.
SALVADOR, Brazil, Aug, 8-- A critical reappraisal of the Alliance for Progress program is the major theme that has developed in the conference here on Western Hemisphere tensions.
PARIS, Aug. 8--The steady rise in oil purchases from the Soviet bloc by members of the European Economic Community in recent years is expected to give way to a small decline this year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) --A chief auditor of the Agriculture Department's southwestern division testified today he had heard of suspicious deals in cotton planting allotments involving Billie Sol Estes and others, but had waited many months to check them out.
The United States Steel Corporation announced plans yesterday to build a giant new five-stand tandem cold rolled sheet mill and companion facilities at its Gary, Ind., works.

THE cry "Take the dog out for a walk" is as familiar in Leningrad as it is in any city in the United States, according to Mr. and Mrs. Elbert Budin of New York. The Budins returned recently from a visit to the Soviet Union.

TEANECK, N.J., Aug. 8-- Acting on the order of Township Manager Werner Schmid, a township demolition crew today knocked down the house on stilts the boys from New Milford built and took it to the town dump.

FLORENCE, S.C., Aug. 8 (AP)--Aggressor battle groups of the Eighty-second Airborne Division attacked from the air and by ground today to seize control of a thirty-mile strip in the heart of friendly territory during Operation Swift Strike II.
CHICAGO, Aug. 8--America of Rio de Janeiro rallied brilliantly tonight for a 1-1 tie with Dukla of Czechoslovakia at Soldier Field before 15,282 fans.
LONDON, Aug. 8--George Lincoln Rockwell, the American Nazi party leader, was apprehended in central London tonight. A deportation order against him had been issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) --The Kennedy Administration's feed grains program was attacked today by Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, as a "boondoggle" designed to let a lot of big companies and landowners qualify as family farmers.

Jan Murray, television performer, has bought the one-andone-half-story bank building at 1850 New York Avenue, Huntington, L.I., for investment. Loomis J. Grossman, New York realty investor and builder, was the seller in a deal negotiated by Arthur Forman of Leonard, Levits, Schiller, brokers.
GENEVA, Aug. 8--The United States disclosed today that it was proposing a reduction of more than half in the number of control posts originally planned for monitoring a ban on nuclear testing.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 8-- If Roger Craig doesn't watch himself, he'll never lose twentyfive games this year.
San Antonio, Tex., borrowed $20,000,000 yesterday through the sale of electric and gas revenue bonds at an interest cost of 3.2186 per cent.

Lancer Industries, Inc., the former fall-out shelter maker, has purchased eleven furniture and discount retail stores from Mount Clemens Industries of Philadelphia, for stock valued at about $2,000,000.
MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 8 (AP) --A Federal judge convicted William Worthy Jr. today of having entered the country illegally from Cuba.
PARIS, Aug. 8--The French Government countered tonight the official British version of why the negotiations in Brussels on British entry into the European Common Market failed to produce agreement.

ELMONT, L.I., Aug. 8-- State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz was asked today for court action to force the Port of New York Authority to reduce the noise from jets at New York International Airport.
World sugar rose and cocoa declined in moderately heavy trading on the local commodity exchanges yesterday. Other items were generally firm and quiet.
It was indicated at City Hall yesterday that the use of paper ballots in the Sept. 6 primary would be avoided by using borrowed voting machines.

Operations of the B.V.D. Company, Inc., in the quarter ended with June resulted in a 128 her cent increase in earnings from the 1961 level, Sol Kittay, chairman and president, told the annual meeting here yesterday.

A temporary but concentrated spell of Yankee incompetence afield helped the fourthplace Baltimore Orioles break even in a double-header yesterday before 29,137 spectators at the Stadium.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 8-- Twenty-one buses of the Yonkers Transit Corporation were destroyed early this morning in a fire that badly damaged the company's garage at the foot of Downing Street here.

Sidney Kingsley said yesterday that the Columbia Broadcasting System would provide the entire backing--$165,000-- for his new play "Night Life."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) --The House passed today a bill aimed at streamlining the operations of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Dr. Harold Kushel, a surgeon, died yesterday in Fordham Hospital, the Bronx. He was 60 years old and lived at 600 East 178th Street, where he had his offices.

WHO IS responsible for starting a fashion trend? Not the designer, according to Halston Frowick, whose millinery designs have made him a fashion force to be reckoned with in the short space of the last three years. Halston, as he is known to almost everyone but the United States Passport Agency, is Bergdorf Goodman's custom hat designer and buyer of imported hats as well.

The National Labor Relations Board has set a hearing for next Tuesday on an application by a local of the International Longshoremen's Association for permission to conduct its contract bargaining separately.

KEENE, N.H., Aug. 9-- The woodchuck is a hard pressed citizen who asks nothing more than to be allowed to eat his way through a farmer's garden or crops. He digs his holes wherever he feels like, so cattle hoofs and tractor wheels can get stuck in them. He digs multiple entrances and exits so he can come and go as he pleases.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9--The Government took the first step today to tighten its control over testing of new drugs on human beings.
The price of silver added new luster yesterday as the market continued to reflect scarce supplies of the precious metal.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 9--Negotiations for an international long-term agreement on coffee, which have been proceeding here behind closed doors for a month, have reached the critical stage. Adjournment of the conference has been set for Aug. 17--the first anniversary of the Alliance for Progress.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 9 (AP) --The Minnesota Twins, with Lennie Green leading their attack with four straight hits, defeated the Kansas City Athletics, 12--10, today.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., Aug. 9 --Bob Gardner, the defender, won two matches as the metroPolitan amateur golf championship began today at the Sunningdale Country Club.
