PARIS, Aug. 9--The major unanswered question in Algeria, as seen from Paris, is the same one that plagued France for so long: Can the civil power impose its control on the military?
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug 9. (AP)--The associate membership of Greece in the European Common Market will come into force on Nov. 1, it was announced today.

The derailment of two freight cars yesterday morning caused delays of up to two hours and eleven minutes for several thousand commuters on the Hudson Division of the New York Central Railroad and some longdistance passengers.
OTTAWA, Aug. 9--In a drastic reorganization of his Government, Prime Minister John Diefenbaker, dropped Donald M. Fleming of Toronto as his Minister of Finance today.
Miss Beatrice Warren Sprower and Lawrence St. Clair Sheets plan to be married Oct. 13 in Forest Hills, Queens.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 9-- White citizens of Albany have spoken out bluntly against a suggestion that they urge their City Commission to negotiate with Negro leaders to end the racial stalemate in Albany.

A word of caution on interest rates has been voiced by Dr. Walter W. Heller, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. Testifying before Congress' Joint Economic Committee, Dr. Heller observed that the pressures on the dollar in foreign markets should not be permitted to encourage "premature or excessive tightening" of credit, which would produce higher interest rates.
LONDON, Aug. 9--The stock market threw off today the bullness of the last two days, and most industrial sections rose.
LONDON, Aug. 9--A group of leading ornithologists has stunned British bird watchers by charging that more than 500 reported discoveries of rare species were "completely fraudulent."

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 9-- With the entry today of Thomas Atkyns, an Argentine horse, a field of eight was assured for the fourth $50,000 International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway on Aug. 18. The 12-year-old Thomas Atkyns, whose home course is at Cordoba, will be the oldest trotter in the mile-and-a-quarter race.

WHEN Louis Broido was sworn in as Commissioner of a non-existent city department last January, at a salary of $1 a year, he was charged the usual 6-cent swearing-in fee. As Mr. Broido paid the 6 cents, thus making his salary 94 cents for the year, he quipped: "After twenty-six

PARENTS and officials charged with the well-being of chil dren are growing increasingly concerned about the molesting of youngsters. In 1961 in New York City, four children--all under 12--lost their lives because of molesters.

An eight-man group of United States shipping experts will leave tomorrow for the Soviet Union to study that country's maritime transport under the terms of the U.S.-U.S.S.R. exchange agreement program:
Thousands of American Legionnaires marched along Fifth Avenue through a driving rain yesterday between 7:30 P.M. and 8:30.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 9 (AP)-- The International Typographical Union convention voted today to raise the strike and lockout fund from $500,000 to $5,000,000.

A youth who had been waiting in jail four months for the city to try him on a misdemeanor charge was released yesterday after his mother had complained to a lawyer about the long wait. Apparently the court papers in his case had been mislaid.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz was asked last night to investigate alleged favoritism by the Board of Elections toward Representative Charles A. Buckley's regular Democratic organization in the Bronx.

William F. Hyland, a retired New York newspaper man, died yesterday in St. Anthony's Hospital in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 75 years old and lived at 45 Lincoln Court, Keansburg, N.J., and in St. Petersburg.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) --Najeeb E. Halaby has told a Senate subcommittee that the Federal Aviation Administration would not allocate more money to Love Field in Dallas because there already was a "darn good jet airport halfway between Dallas and Fort Worth.
The pharmaceutical industry generally took a wary attitude yesterday toward the Federal Government's proposed new regulations on the clinical testing of drugs.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9-- Budget Director David E. Bell said today that tax cuts and budget deficits did not necessarily go together.

PARIS, Aug. 9--A continuing favorable trade balance and rising industrial production in France were reported here to day by Valery Giscard d'Estaing, Minister of Finance M. Giscard d'Estaing told a press conference that in July, France exported 6 per cent more goods than the imported. As a whole, France took in $154,000,000 in foreign currencies in July plus $50,000,000 from a British purchase of French francs.

EGGS are up: eggplant is down. The former is now going into a production decline that will continue into the fall. The latter, on the other hand, reaches its peak in this area during August. This wealth of supply has brought about a drop in eggplants, which now sell generally for 15 cents a pound.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9--The Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on inter-American affairs is pressing the Administration for an accounting on military aid to Latin-American countries.

Richard J. Bambery and Alfred A. Medica have been named vice presidents of the Admiral Sales Corporation, the marketing subsidiary of the Admiral Corporation of Chicago. Mr. Bambery will be in charge of distributing branches, and Mr. Medica will head the electronics division.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP)--Gen. Bernard A. Schriever said today that the Defense Department had ordered a downward revision of a program to develop very large solid fuel space boosters. He said the new plan would be on his desk next week.

"Did journey last night to the Village of Greenwich, there to attend a consort of musicke done prettily at a coffee house. A brave kind of sound cometh forth, methinks, at these houses, for the which am much stirred."
DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 9 (AP)--President Nazem elKodsi told a cheering Crowd today, "No tyrant can ever usurp Syria's adherence to freedom, equality and justice."
The stock market gave the appearance of coming to a standstill yesterday. After minor fluctuations, prices ended a bit higher in the slowest trading in more than two weeks.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 9 --President Guillermo Le n Valencia has won a victory and has been rebuffed since he took office Tuesday.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 9 (AP)--Archie Moore and undefeated Cassius Clay signed today to meet here in a twelve-round heavyweight fight on Oct. 23.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9--The State Department emphatically denied today Republican charges that new United States proposals for a nuclear test ban represented concessions to the Soviet Union and endangered this country's security.

The L. G. Construction Company has assembled a plot with a frontage of 400 feet on the east side of Palisade Avenue, between Palisade Terrace and the Children's Christian Home, in Fort Lee, N.J. The company plans to improve the site with a luxury apartment house for 150 families.
Television and other news media will probably use Telstar, the communications satellite, for regularly scheduled transmissions from Europe beginning next week.

WHY is it considered almost compulsory that novels about murder trials should be told from the point of view of the defense lawyer struggling manfully to save the life of an innocent man nearly damned by the weight of circumstantial evidence? Some day, perhaps, a, bold and original novelist will dare to write about a prosecuting attorney
Directors of the Xerox Corporation increased the quarterly dividend on the Common stock yesterday with the declaration of 25 cents a share.

The Aetna Finance Company has declared the regular quarterly cash dividend of 10 cents a share, payable on Sept. 14 to holders of record of Aug. 31. The company also voted a 2 per cent stock dividend payable on Oct. 1 to holders of record of Sept. 14.
Eleven men were arraigned yesterday as members of an international narcotics ring that assertedly brought $10,000,000 in pure heroin into the country in the last nine years.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug.9--A spokesman for Representative Edwin B. Dooley today ridiculed an accusation that Mr. Dooley had violated his franking privilege and used official Congressional stationery to seek a food concession for a constituent at the Westchester Community College.
AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 9 (AP) --Arnold Palmer took a twostroke lead in the first round of the $50,000 American Golf Classic today with a threeunder-par 67.

GENEVA, Aug. 9--Hermann Hesse, German-born Swiss who won the 1946 Nobel Prize for Literature, died today of a heart attack at his home in Montagnola, near Lugano in southeastern Switzerland. He was 85 years old.
MOSCOW, Aug. 9 (UPI)-- The military newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda has put the spotlight on Soviet atomic battlereadiness during the last week in an apparent tie-in with nuclear maneuvers in the Arctic.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Aug. 9 (UPI)--A deadlock over reapportionment of the Vermont Senate ended today in a victory for Gov. F. Ray Keyser Jr., bringing a quick adjournment of the special legislative session.

Two Bronx landlords, a man and his wife, were arrested last night on charges of conspiracy to defraud tenants during the time the Temporary State Housing Rent Com mission controlled rents in the city.

A cancer-causing virus has, for the first time, produced cancer-like changes in human cells. This finding lends new support to the widely spreading view that viruses can cause cancer in humans as they do in plants and other animals.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9-- Railroad carloadings last week were slightly above the preceding week but down from the corresponding level of 1961.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UPI)--A Senate subcommittee was told today that Representatives J.T. Rutherford had arranged for a meeting to reconsider cancellation of Billie Sol Estes' cotton allotments after accusing the Agriculture Department of "crucifying" the Texan and his attorney, John P. Dennison.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9--It is now just two months since President Kennedy went to Yale University and called on the nation to abandon the myths of the past in order to deal more effectively with the urgent realities of the present.
The Port of New York Authority borrowed $5,475,000 on state-guaranteed commuter car bonds yesterday due 1962 to 1966 at an interest cost of 1.942 per cent. Gloro, Forgan Co.,

Juan Serrano, an uncommonly talented guitarist from Spain, which exports many, opened a month's engagement Wednesday evening at the Bitter End. Andalusia, where flamenco music and Se or Serrano were born, has lost a native son but Greenwich Village has gained a promising instrumentalist.
TEANECK, N.J., Aug. 9-- The Teaneck Fair Housing Committee said today that it had filed thirty-three complaints against nine Bergen County real estate brokers.
TWENTY cruisers have been entered in the ninth annual Captain Billopp Trophy 44.5mile predicted-log contest to be held tomorrow by the Richmond County Yacht Club.

Two tall and muscular youths were captured early yesterday after they assertedly had beat and robbed a man of $4 in Greenwich Village. The victim was 130-pound Horge Miller, who is 38 years old and lives at the Albert Hotel, 23 East Tenth Street, near University Place.

The public career of the late Samuel T. Rayburn, who served as Speaker of the House for nine full terms, is the subject of a 583-page book by a fellow Texan and friend, C. Dwight borough. Called "Mr. Sam," the ...
BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS Utah, Aug. 9 (UPI)--Dr. Nathan Ostich walked away unhurt today after his jet racing car had broken an axle, spun out of control at 331 miles an hour and lost a wheel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9--A revived filibuster against the Administration's satellite communications bill was in prospect tonight after the Senate Foreign Relations Committee sent the measure back to the floor without amendments.
PARIS, Aug. 9--New light was shed today on the intricate operations among the leading central banks of Europe, whose purpose is to calm nervousness about the dollar and other currencies.

MONT TREMBLANT, Que., Aug. 9--Seven and a half hours driving time from Stowe, Vt., today brought the MG Car Club's international rally field of sixty-two cars to this Canadian resort in the Laurentian Mountains.
Mayor Wagner signed a local law yesterday to set up a Department of Commerce and Industrial Development to encourage existing businesses and attract new ones to the city.
A retrospective survey of dance films made by Gene Kelly has been scheduled to follow the well-received Howard Hawks series at the Museum of Modern Art.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP)--Edward J. McCormack Jr., who is doing his best to keep one brother of President Kennedy from winning a Senate seat, opposed today a bid for new wiretap authority by another, Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy.

The group that stormed out of a board meeting of the B.S. F. Company on July 24 and said it would take "appropriate steps" to protect its 3 per cent investment has quietly been buying additional stock in the company. It now Owns "nearly 50 per cent" of the 800,000 outstanding shares.

The Realty Equities Corporation, a realty investment and building company, has brought the fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 1215 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of 102d Street. The building, which is 100 by 100 feet, was sold by the Abmorr Real Estate Corporation for cash over mortgages amounting to $900,000.
GENEVA, Aug. 9--The Soviet Union categorically rejected today new United States compromise proposals for a treaty to end nuclear testing.
Cotton futures were unchanged to 50 cents a bale up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 9--The engagement of Miss Judith Hill Allgood to the Rev. Theron Stanford Nease, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melville Nathaniel Nease of Savannah, Ga., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Dwight Maurice Allgood of Cleveland.

Leaders of the state American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations have voted to oppose any law extending collective bargaining rights to hospital workers that contains a compulsory-arbitration clause.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 9 (AP) --The Milwaukee Braves blanked the Chicago Cubs, 1-0, today on Joe Adcock's twentythird home run of the season.
CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP)-- Heavy selling smothered rallies in some grain futures today. The market was weak on the Board of Trade.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 9--Haiti's armed forces chief has fled into asylum in the Venezuelan Embassy.

President Kennedy in his press conference last week urged the City Council of Albany, Ga., to "sit down with the citizens of Albany who may be Negroes, and attempt to secure them in a peaceful way their rights." The Department of

AT meetings held coincidental with the national tournament just completed at Minneapolis the American Contract Bridge League established a precedent by reelecting the captain of the North American, team that played for the world championship earlier this year.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Aug. 9-- Governor Rockefeller cautioned today that the country would be in economic difficulty if the rate of wage increases and the reduction in hours outpaced an increase in productivity.

SHORT HILLS N.J., Aug. 9--Miss Lee Heather Cairns daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Alexander Cairns, was married this afternoon to Philip Valentine Havens, son of Mrs. Donald Havens of Little Compton, R.I. and West Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Havens.
CAREFUL planning and the use of a reliable book or pamphlet can often eliminate the pitfalls in the canning of food.

The Bronx Zoo exhibited some "new recruits" yesterday. The arrivals include a honey badger, which is reportedly led to bee trees in the African jungle by a little honey bird; two of the world's largest frogs; a rare spectacled owl named Professor; a rare baby Thomson gazelle, and two newborn llamas.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UPI)--Members of a House committee accused a World War I veterans group today of pressing a "vicious and abusive" letter campaign against representatives who have refused to support the organization's multi-billion-dollar pension bill.

"Take home a machine-made painting--while U Wait" reads the aggressive sign over the door of the "Automatic Art Show" in a little shop at 110 Macdougal Street. The plea, not to be resisted, has been drawing amused and interested crowds these summer evenings.
Eastern Air Lines successfully put its Air-Shuttle service back in operation yesterday despite a continuing strike of flight engineers, now in its forty-ninth day.
National Airlines will build a multimillion-dollar terminal at New York International Airport under a contract announced yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 9--A supplementary nomination fee of $500 to the Saratoga National Hurdle Stakes turned out to be a sound investment for the Windward Farm.
SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Aug. 9--Mrs. J.B. Balding of The Creek took a two-stroke lead today in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's twelfth annual 36-hole senior championship.
MILAN, Italy, Aug. 9--Five horses destined for Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L.I., left were by air tonight.
Nearly 100 persons staged a protest last night to the proposed $100,000,000 Lower Manhattan Expressway.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Aug. 9 --Paul B. Zuber, a New York lawyer and integration leader, announced today that he would not run against Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. to represent Harlem in Congress.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 9-- Military commanders from all over Argentina were headed for Buenos Aires today for a highlevel meeting to deal with the crisis that led to the resignation yesterday of Argentina's War Secretary and Commander in Chief, Gen. Juan Bautista Loza.
A Liberal party spokesman charged yesterday that the House of Representatives subcommittee inquiry into the garment industry here was "political blackmail" intended to take vengeance upon the party.
A 20-year-old youth who was held in jail for more than four months did not even have a charge against him, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP)--Excellent growing weather in the Midwest is helping to raise this year's indicated crop production to within less than 3 per cent of the record harvest of 1960, despite new cutbacks in the acreage planted.

UNITED NATIONS. N.Y., Aug. 10--The Netherlands lodged a strong protest tonight with U Thant, Acting Secretary General, over two new Indonesian landings this week in Netherlands New Guinea while negotiations over the disputed territory were being carried on under United Nations auspices.

ROME, Aug. 10--The impasse in Common Market negotiations is a blow to Rome's diplomacy, which has been trying to avoid crisis between the Continental powers and Britain. All the slick Italian efforts to dodge pitfalls and obstacles seem for the nonce to have failed.
MADRID, Saturday, Aug. 11 --The Government announced early today it planned to organize worker-management meetings for collective bargaining.
CANTON, Ohio, Aug. 10-- The New York Giants will open their exhibition schedule here tomorrow night against the St. Louis Cardinals.
LONDON, Aug. 10--The stock market continued its advance today in most sections.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 10 (AP)--The San Francisco Giants belted Johnny Podres and Ed Roebuck for six runs in the sixth inning tonight and scored an 11--2 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

A LIST that would defeat even the most avid shopper-- 700 watches, 65,000 Christmas cards, 100 silver-framed desk calendars, 300 gold pencils-- does not faze Tiffany's Corporate Gift Department, which is composed of specialists in company buying.
DUBLIN, Aug. 10--The Italian riders today won the premier award of the Royal Dublin Society's Horse Show-- the Aga Khan Trophy--by beating the American team by a point.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., Aug. 10 --Bob Gardner, the defender, moved with ease into the semifinal round of the metropolitan amateur golf championship today at the Sunningdale Country Club.

The first writing by Pierre Salinger to appear in book form since he joined the White House staff will not be a political tract or a report on the joys and sorrows of being a Presidential press secretary. It will be an essay on music.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10--A Federal employe whose arms and legs are almost totally paralyzed was granted a patent this week for an automatic desk. He has used the desk himself for four years and hopes it will help other handicapped office workers.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug 10 (UPI)--Arnold Palmer increased his lead in the $50,000 American Golf classic to five strokes at the half-way mark today when he shot a 69 for 136 on the 7,165-yard, par-70 Firestone Country Club course.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP)--Pete Ramos pitched a six-hit shutout tonight as the Cleveland Indians broke a string of twenty-five scoreless innings and whipped the Washington Senators, 3--0.
CHICAGO, Aug 10 (AP)-- The most general recovery of the week sent many grain futures up major fractions to more than a cent a bushel today on the Board of Trade.

One of the city's strangest and most heartening picket lines appeared in New York recently. It wound its way around Pennsylvania Station led by upper-echelon architectural professionals carrying signs of protest against the impending destruction of McKim, Mead White's classic monument to make way for a $90-million-dollar redevelopment scheme of dubious-grandeur.
ALBANY, Ga., Aug. 10--The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was freed from jail today after having served two weeks, and Negro leaders promptly called off two scheduled mass demonstrations.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 10 (AP)--Belgium told the United Nations today that she was willing to apply economic pressure to end Katanga Province's secession from the Congo if negotiation failed.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10-- The Senate filibuster against the satellite communications bill, halted a week ago Wednesday under a unanimous consent agreement, was resumed today.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10-- Ted Husing, whose dramatic, resonant voice made him one of radio's top sports announcers for thirty years, died today. He was 60 years old.

BOSTON, Aug. 10 (AP)--The Gillette Company announced today that it has reached an agreement with the Sterilon Corporation of Buffalo, N.Y., under which Gillette will acquire all the assets of Sterilon in exchange for 200,000 common shares of Gillette. Inasmuch as there are 300,000 Sterilon shares outstanding, this would represent two shares of Gillette for three shares of Sterilon.

RAVELLO, Italy, Aug. 10--Italian policemen and United States security agents blocked the entrance to the small fishing village of Conca dei Marini today and the public beach was placed off limits to protesting inhabitants and tourists.
G.M. Minard has been elected president of Kimberly-Clark Canada, Ltd., and of the Spruce Falls Power and Paper Company, Ltd. He succeeds Frederick S. Seaborne, who has retired.

Autumn breezes paid a premature call on Yankee Stadium last night, accompanied by a bone-chilling drizzle. The Yankees overcame those unwelcome guests, as well as the Detroit Tigers, by the simple stratagem of stationing Whitey Ford on the mound.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI)--President Kennedy signed a bill today appropriating $48,136,000,000 for the armed forces. It was the largest single amount ever given the military in peacetime.

DON'T ever say that musiclovers are soft. About 3,500 of them turned up at Lewisohn Stadium last night and sat in a steady drizzle at chilly temperatures to hear a performance of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony under the direction of Josef Krips. The size and endurance of the audience were quite a tribute to both the work and the conductor.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10-- The factory work week, a key economic indicator that usually starts dropping before total economic activity does, declined in July for the third month in a row.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 10 (AP)--Early Wynn of the Chicago White Sox, who pitched his first major league baseball game twenty-one years ago, gained his 298th victory tonight by beating the Kansas City Athletics, 3--1.
A campaign to force the owners of about 100 buildings to install sprinklers and other fire protection devices was announced yesterday by Fire Commissioner Edward Thompson.

LONDON, Aug. 10--The Duke of Edinburgh was thrown into the sea today when his sailboat capsized off the Isle of Wight and half an hour later he escaped serious injury when the boom of a crane crashed near him.
ALGIERS, Aug. 10--Algerian civilian leaders moved today to restrict the power of the Algerian Army.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 10 --Every morning the In dians filter into this city from the usually overcast mountians that stand above it.
LONDON, Aug. 10--Britain has canceled her effort to produce a tactical nuclear weapon for close army support, it was officially announced today.
Cost cutting has hit the newly expanded research departments of Wall Street brokerage houses. Scores of analysts are pounding the pavements looking for work.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 10--On turf soaked by two days of rain, William Bond of La Jolla, Calif., the winner of the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship, was beaten today by Charles Pasarell of Puerto Rico in the Southampton invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club.

PORT ANGELES, Wash., Aug. 10 (AP)--Mrs. Robert F. Kennedy fell in a creek and the park superintendent was thrown from a horse but otherwise everyone was having a fine time today at the Kennedy-Douglas camp in Olympic National Park.

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 10-- Helen and Larry Hough of Westport, Conn., the 1961 national rally champions, were the leaders today as the MG Car Club's 1,000-mile rally teams began the third of its four stages.
PARIS, Aug. 10--A warrant has been issued here for the arrest of former Premier Georges Bidault, who is accused of plotting against the authority of the French state.
One of the three maritime unions striking the nuclear ship Savannah was ordered by an arbitrator last night to send its men back to their jobs.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10(AP) --The United States enlisted the aid of the world's scientists today in a special study of how when and where radioactive debris falls to earth from high altitudes.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 10-- Counsel for Representative Edwin B. Dooley announced today that the Post Office Department had ruled that the Congressman had not abused his privilege on July 31 when he franked a letter seeking help for a constituent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10--The National Labor Relations Board barred today the use of inflammatory racial propaganda by employers to defeat organizing campaigns of unions. But it said truthful and temperate descriptions by one side of the other's position on racial matters were all right.

REPRODUCTIONS of the Culbertson trophy, em blematic of the world pair championship were shipped yesterday to Dr. Pierre Jais and Roger Trezel of Paris, who won the title for France in the World Bridge Federation's Olympiad pair tournament at Cannes last spring.
A telephone call from the White House has caused Nassau County Democrats to accept Liberal party support for three Democratic candidates for the House of Representatives.
MOSCOW, Aug. 10--A significant increase has been noted in the amount of news and information circulating among the Soviet people from Western sources.

A joint state legislative committee said yesterday that United Medical Service, Inc., which administers the Blue Shield plan in the metropolitan area, should keep better records and do a better job of policing member physicians.
LONDON, Aug. 10--Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower visited Sir Winston Churchill in Middlesex Hospital today and reported that "he looks the same old Winston to me."

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 10 --Delegates to the American Bar Association gave their support today to a proposal designed to let persons who move shortly before Presidential elections vote in their new states.
Young Africans attending colleges and universities in the United States are also getting an education in American life through a wide variety of summer jobs.

Polyclinic Hospital and its 340 nonprofessional workers agreed yesterday on a new three-year contract that will raise minimum salaries from $1.15 to $1.71 an hour by late 1964. It also bans strikes and lock-outs.

NEWARK, Aug. 10--John J. Magovern Jr. today was elected president of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company of Newark. The 56-year-old executive succeeds H. Bruce Palmer, who resigned after holding the post since 1953.
NICHOLAS SAMSTAG'S "The Uses of Ineptitude" is a merrily solemn lampoon. It charts oblique ways for hotly competitive half-tycoons to succeed in pleasure by only half trying.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10-- President Kennedy will disclose his decision on an immediate tax reduction in a special television and radio address from the White House Monday evening.
CUTCHOGUE, L.I., Aug. 10--The oldest English house in New York State, appropriately named the Old House, will be dedicated here tomorrow as a national shrine.
A Port of New York Authority program for relocating commercial tenants from the site of the projected World Trade Center was called a "good sign" yesterday by a merchants' group.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 10 (AP)--Three tennis stars of the Nineteen Thirties, Ellsworth Vines Jr., John H. Doeg and Helen Hull Jacobs--were named today to the National Tennis Hall of Fame.

The Independent Telephone Corporation announced yesterday that through its subsidiary, the Independent Telephone Corporation of Michigan, it had acquired the Levering Telephone Company and the Elmira Telephone Company, both serving northern Michigan.
Art News, the oldest and most widely read magazine in its field, was sold yesterday to The Washington Post Company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP)--Business organizations urged the Senate Finance Committee today to strike from the Trade Expansion Bill a provision to compensate workers left idle by an increase in imports.
Pope John XXIII has honored twenty priests of the Archdiocese of New York by elevating them to Monsignor, Cardinal Spellman announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) --The United States balance of payments deficit dropped sharply to a rate of about $1,000,000,000 a year in the AprilJune quarter, the Department of Commerce reported today.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., AUG. 10--Cicada will race against fillies tomorrow when she competes in the eighty-second running of the Alabama Stakes.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 10 (AP)--Fourteen 3-year-olds were entered today for the mileand-a-sixteenth Ventnor Handicap on Atlantic City's grass course tomorrow.
Show magazine has acquired USA 1, a monthly news magazine that began publication last April. USA 1 will not be published anymore.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10-- The Federal Maritime Commission still "faces the challenge of full understanding and compliance" of United States shipping laws, Thomas E. Stakem, chairman of the regulatory agency, declared today.

From Havana and Peiping to Moscow, Sofia, Prague and East Berlin most of the Communist world today is beset by politically troublesome food shortages. Castro has sought to meet his problem by rationing, while Mao Tse-tung is shipping millions of city dwellers to the countryside to raise food. East Germany has now decided to introduce meat rationing.

The International Rescue Committee will benefit by a dinner dance on the evening of Sept. 26 at the preview opening of the St. Regis' redecorated Maisonette. Mrs. Averell Harriman is chairman of the event.

MORE than 100 children's and teen-agers' librarians of the New York Public Library system are helping to form the reading tastes of the city's young. Keeping pace with the thousands of children who are library members and keeping 1,113,500 children's books circulating among them is only part of their work.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 10-- Su Mac Lad has won many important races, including the Roosevelt International, but the American Trotting Championship has eluded the 8-year-old gelding. Nevertheless, he will go to the post as the 8-5 favorite in that event tomorrow night at Roosevelt Raceway.

Adult coloring books, a vogue for nearly ten months, are engaged in political warfare. The issue has been drawn with the publication this week of "The John Birch Coloring Book," which lives up vigorously to the gold legend on its blue cover:

GENEVA, Aug. 10--The Soviet Union termed "unacceptable" today the United States plan for progressive inspection by zones to verify compliance with disarmament... pledges. Arthur H. Dean of the United States had just outlined the plan in detail for the first time at the seventeen-nation disarmament conference here.
Mrs. Hortense Gabel, City Rent and Rehabilitation Administrator, announced last night a complete shake-up of the agency's Brooklyn and Bronx offices.

WHETHER it is called pate en croute, veal and ham pie, raised pie, Warwickshire pie or Melton Mowbray pie, a lightly seasoned mixture of pork or veal encased in a tender crust makes delectable eating for summer dining.
The city signed a contract yesterday for the purchase of 2,750 voting machines from the Shoup Voting Machine Company of Canton, Ohio.
Britain will become a member of the European Common Market by next Jan. 1, according to a prediction advanced yesterday.

CUYAHOGA FALLS, Ohio, Aug. 10 (AP)--Tom Stock broke all records and Ted Stickles shattered his listed world record today in pacing the Indianapolis Athletic Club to a huge lead in the Amateur Athletic Union's men's national outdoor swimming championships.

VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Aug. 10 (UPI)-- An Atlas F missile blasted aloft today, but was deliberately destroyed less than a minute after launching. It rained debris on a small near-by community.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 10-- Willy H. Schlieker, long considered one of the "wonder boys" of West Germany's postwar "economic miracle" lost his fight today to avert bankruptcy.
Striking flight engineers ignored yesterday Eastern Air Lines' deadline for union acceptance of its "final" offer of settlement in the seven-week-old walkout.
Long-term United States Government bonds continued to be in good demand yesterday, with the new issues brought out in the Treasury's $8,800,000,000 financing again furnishing the leadership.
The Continental Can Company has announced increases in the prices of kraft grocery bags and sacks and kraft wrapping paper, effective with orders accepted for shipment Sept. 10.

President Kennedy's news conferences will be a primetime Wednesday-night feature on Channel 13.
Houston, Tex., borrowed $16,000,000 on the bond market yesterday at an interest cost of 3.0506 per cent. Various-purpose bonds were sold to the First National City Bank and associates.

The International Telephone Telegraph Corporation disclosed an inter-office communications system yesterday which it termed "the first commercially feasible electronic private automatic telephone exchange."
Confirmation of plans for the consolidation of the Pittsburgh Metallurgical Company into the Air Reduction Company, Inc., was made yesterday by the two concerns.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 15 (AP) "Modernist" churchmen were accused today before the International Council of Christian Churches of walking hand in hand with communism.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 The strategy for a quick election of U Thant to a full term as United Nations Secretary General and the urgency of settling the Katanga problem are expected to be the main problems occupying Secretary of State Dean Rusk in New York tomorrow.
BRIDGETON, N.J., Aug. 15 (AP)--Parents of twenty-nine Negro children have asked the State Commissioner of Education to block the city's $1,125,000 school construction program.
Stocks continued their rally yesterday and made another sizable gain in the heaviest trading in more than a month. It was the sixth consecutive advance.

MOSCOW, Aug. 13 Soviet scientists, exultant over the prolonged orbital flights and the safe return to earth of Vostaks III and IV, looked ahead today with confidence to early manned trips to the moon, Venus and Mars.
A new type of prefabricated one-ply, built-up roofing material has been developed and is said to weatherproof roofs of any contour or design effectively.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI) Representative Carl Vinson, Democrat of Georgia, who is chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, accused Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara today of overcentralizing Pentagon authority in his effort to eliminate waste.
This is a profile of a president of one of the nation's 500 largest industrial companies:...
ALBANY, Aug. 15 Officials of Vermont and New Jersey declared today that New York's 18-year-old drinking age protected commercial interests at the expense of lives.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 15 (AP) Albert Warnoff, Santa Claus' chief carpenter here, died of lung cancer today after making more than 42,000 Christmas toys in sixty years. He was 72 years old.
There seems to be a bubbling, stirring and inter est in recreational shooting that may well forexell an expansion of this traditional American sport.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 15 (AP) Space officials here applauded today the return to earth of the two Soviet astronauts.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 15 Dr. Arthur Frucht of 600 Front Street, a radiologist, died, today at South Nassau Communities Hospital in Oceanside. He was 64 years old.

CLEVELAND, Aug, 15 (AP) and spoiled Early Wynn's bid for the 299th pitching triumph of his career tonight after the White Sox had scored ten runs in the ninth inning to win the opener of a doubleheader, 10-2.
LEESBURG, Ga., Aug. 15 A Negro church that served as the center for a voter regisstration campaign was destroyed by fire before dawn today.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Aug. 15 The organization of a City Police Youth Bureau to combat juvenile delinquency has been recommended to city officials by a committee studying youth problems. The annual cost of the proposed bureau is estimated at $30,000.
WESTFIELD, N.J., Aug. 15 C. Alan Phillips of 862 Rahway Avenue, a lawyer, was found dead, apparently of a heart attack, yesterday in a hotel room in Honolulu. His age was 53.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 15 Representative Edwin B. Dooley began a $250,000 defamation-of-character suit in State Supreme Court here today against County Executive Edwin G. Michailian, who also is chairman of the Westchester Republican Committee.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 15 The Turkish Defense Ministry reported tonight that Iraqi war planes attacked border areas today, killing two Turkish soldiers and wounding another in a morning raid and causing heavy damage in an afternoon attack.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 Sixteen years ago at a castle in the Hoge Veluwe game preserve in the central part of the Netherlands, Dutch and Indonesian diplomats sat down for the first formal discussions of Indonesian independence.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Aug. 15 The proposal of New York State to build the controversial Interstate Route 87 on what has been called the westerly route through the Town of Bedford was rejected today by the Federal Bureau of Public Roads.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Aug. 15 (UPI) It appeared certain tonight that Alaska's incumbent Democratic Governor, William A. Egan, would vie with a Republican, Mike Stepovich, in the November election.
I WANT a happy dog and that's what I seek when I breed them," said Mrs. Willard K. Denton of Mount Kisco, N.Y. "If you have a moody, vicious animal, he isn't good either as a show dog or pet."
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 15 Minnesota fans, game to the last, set a Metropolitan Stadium attendance record tonight for the second time this week with a turnout of 41,536.
The Yorkville Youth Council and the Parents League of New York will benefit from theatre parties to "The Dragon" at the Phoenix Theatre on Nov. 29 and 30.

CZESTOCHOWA, Poland, Aug. 15 (AP) Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski sadly told thousands of pilgrims tonight that he had tried in vain to persuade Poland's Communist regime to admit Franz Cardinal Koenig of Vienna into the country for the annual church celebrations at the shirne here.
PARIS. THE hordes of triumphant tourists who conquer the top of the Eiffel Tower every August look down on an empty city. The Parisians have closed up shop and gone on vacation.

GENEVA, Aug. 15 Italy joined the neutralist countries today in urging an immediate ban on nuclear testing in the atmosphere and under water as a first step toward the outlawing of all atomic explosions.

GARDEN CITY, L.I, Aug. 15 A strong civil rights plank for the state Republican platform was recommended here today at the third of six hearings being conducted by the State Republican Platform Advisory Committee.
HAVANA, Aug. 15 (Reuters) A critical shortage of animal fodder has led to a national campaign throughout Cuba to collect every bit of hay.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 15--Prince Talal, a younger son of the late King Ibn Saud of Saudi Arabia, challenged his half brother, King Saud, today on the issue of political reform.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 What an unrewarding old-age it is being a retired Premier of the Soviet Union. The thought must have occurred with unusual poignancy to Georgi Malenkov and Nikolai Bulganin this week as their country celebrated its latest triumph in space technology.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 After a brief truce, George Meany and Walter P. Reuther, the top leaders of the American labor movement, are again seriously at odds. Their new differences reached the crisis point at a private meeting here last night.
ALBANY, Aug. 15 The Court on the Judiciary voted today to prefer charges against Supreme Court Justice Louis L. Friedman of Brooklyn.
Reaction was mixed on seventh Avenue yesterday to the petition for an arrangement with creditors under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act that Grayson-Robinson Stores, Inc., filed on Tuesday.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 15 (AP) A neutralist Cabinet minister charged today that American planes were violating Laotian air space and said a jet fighter with United States Air Force markings had been shot down.
ROME, Aug. 15 Pope John XXIII asked Roman Catholics today to pray for a "true peace" in Algeria.
The Rent and Rehabilitation Administration announced yesterday a new regulation aimed at increasing the supply of apartments for larger families.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 9 About forty miles out on the highway north from Belgrade to Novi Sad and the Hungarian border, an unobtrusive sign used to direct travelers to turn right down a narrow, unpaved side road.

MOSCOW Aug. 15 (UPI) Frank Froehing and Don Dell won their matches in the Russian national tennis championships today, but Billi Jean Moffitt suffered America's first loss when she was beaten by Roby Ebbern of Australia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 The head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration predicted today in the face of the latest Soviet space accomplishment that the United States would be first to land men on the moon and bring them back safely.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 15 The Port of New York Authority dedicated the first section of its $150,000,000 Port Elizabeth pier complex here today.

SYLVESTER GINTELL, who died of a heart at tack on Aug. 2, had long been one of the most respected members of New York's bridge-playing community. He was a member of several of the famous teams of the New York Bridge Whist Club, which in its fifty-five-year history, had some of the greatest players and most successful bridge teams.
MONTREAL, Aug. 15 (Canadian Press) Executives, secretaries and clerks are having a hard time adjusting to working in the new skyscrapers that line Dorchester Boulevard here.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 15 Bandits bombed and machinegunned a bus in the Department of Boyaca, about 100 miles northeast of here, today, killing the driver and twenty-three passengers and injuring twelve passengers.
LONDON, Aug. 15--A leading British scientist declared today that the Soviet Union had demonstrated a clear military superiority over the United States in space.
"Accent," a cultural and informational program covering art, music, drama, literature and other fields, will be discontinued by the Columbia Broadcasting System television network on Sept. 6.

The flagging of accident report files at the Department of Traffic to permit quick identification of chronic trouble spots and to speed corrective action has been started by Deputy Commissioner William D. Flye.
Some tour guides still make disparaging remarks about the city, hint that tips would be welcome and promote certain hotels and restaurants, the Department of Licenses reported yesterday.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 15 Austin Young Hoy, retired machinery manufacturer, died yesterday in Bridgeport Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Westport at 30 Hyde Lane.

Reports from Washington indicate that we are on the verge of recognizing the Peruvian military junta. The necessity to do so before long is obvious, but to pick a moment when the Argentine generals are fighting over the prostrate body of their nation and moving toward a military dictatorship is clearly unwise.
GAINESVILLE, Fla., Aug. 15 (AP) Cowles Magazines and Broadcasting, Inc., has purchased all of the stock of the Gainesville Daily Sun.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 15 U Thant was preparing today to ask Premier Cyrille Adoula of the Congo to support coercive measures against Katanga Province.
National Airlines has reported that air cargo in the first six months of this year rose 81 per cent compared with the like 1961 period.
Odds on Dry Labor Day: 3 to 1, 2 to 1 Bet 'Em

ROME, Aug. 15 Most Italians were only moderately impressed when Russians put Vostok III into orbit. Major Nikolayev's feat followed that of two other Russians and two Americans and there was at first no indication that his achievement differed in kind or in degree from those of his predecessors.

Directors of the Worthington Corporation reduced yesterday the quarterly dividend on the common stock with the declaration of 37 cents a share, payable on Sept. 20 to holders of record of Aug. 31. Shareholders had received 62 cents quarterly for several years.
DEL MAR, Calif., Aug. 15 (UPI) Fun House, a 4-yearold filly owned by Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, scored a four-length victory today in the $27,900 Ramona Handicap at Del Mar race track.
The Argentine crisis has developed in an alarming manner. This is not just a quarrel of military personalities; it is a crisis of the nation, with profound social, economic and political features.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 15 Argentina's new Secretary of War attributed the country's periodic crises today to the troubled state of the nation and contended that it was a "grave error" to blame the military.
Ford Bond, former radio announcer and radio and television producer, died yesterday in St. Croix, Virgin Islands. He was 57 years old.
A new salary schedule announced yesterday by the Board of Higher Education puts the City University of New York among the highest-paying institutions in the nation.

The Indonesians have triumphed at last after a decade and a half of struggle, and gained control of all of what was once the Dutch East Indies. The Dutch formally agreed yesterday to yield possession of West New Guinea.

IN all of Europe there are few foods more celebrated than the woodland strawberries of France. In their own way, they rank with caviar, foie gras and truffles as one of the ultimate pleasures of the table. Freshly picked fraises des bois, as the wild strawberries are called, have a perfume to rival the attar of roses.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 15 The establishment of a special teachers college here for the training of prospective Jewish educators from other nations was proposed today to alleviate a critical shortage of such teachers outside Israel.

Two men Suspected of fifteen to twenty burglaries in midtown Manhattan, in which approximately $25,000 worth of belongings were stolen, were arrested yesterday in front of an apartment house at 112 East Thirty-sixth Street.
CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP) Longshoremen refused today to load a Canadian grain ship docked at Chicago's St. Lawrence Seaway port.
Total attendance at the Stadium Concerts, which concluded their forty-fifth year on Saturday increased by 20,700 over last season's figure despite the fact that fewer concerts were given.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 An air of acrimony pervaded the usually placid Senate today as Senators chafed under an unusual limitation of debate.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 15 An agreement to transfer to Indonesia the administration of Netherlands New Guinea was signed here tonight.

More than 800 persons, including several judges of the Federal, state and city courts, lawyers and political leaders, attended a funeral service yesterday for Carson DeWitt Baker, lawyer and former Municipal Court Justice, in St. Martin's Protestant Episcopal Church in Lenox Avenue and 122d Street.
ALBANY, Ga., Aug. 15 The Negro porter locked the barbershop door and pulled the shade for the evening. A fly buzzed lazily toward the television set.
PLYMOUTH, Mass., Aug. 15 A spreading search was pressed today for hijackers who robbed a mail truck of $1,500,000 last night. The robbery was the largest on record in the United States.

Roscoe Brabazon Ellard, a well-known educator and editor and professor emeritus of journalism at Columbia University, died on Tuesday of a heart ailment in Alamogordo, N.M., his colleagues at Columbia were notified yesterday. Professor Ellard, who had lived in Alamogordo for the last year, was 68 years old.

West African women may soon be wearing cosmetics made in the United States. Sadico, a company situated in the Ivory Coast, has recently signed a contract with Cameo Cosmetics, Inc., of New York, for the distribution of the Cameo line to nineteen countries in West Africa, according to Franklin H. Cooper, president of Cameo. The arrangement was made through the Ivory Coast Ambassador to the United States, M. Koman Bedie.
OTTAWA, Aug. 15 (Canadian Press) Justice Minister Donald Fleming regained today a seat on the Treasury Board, the financial watchdog committee of the Cabinet.
WHEN people asked Ernest Hemingway's mother it she wasn't awfully proud of her son, she was known to reply rather briskly:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI)--Foy D. Kohler, who has been named Ambassador to Moscow, assured Senators today he would never again risk carrying classified documents home for study.

A spokesman for the nation's dwindling tramp ship fleet charged the Maritime Administration yesterday with haphazard, and inadequate administration of the Cargo Preference Act. The measure provides that at least 50 per cent of all foreign-aid goods be moved in United States flag ships.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 15 (AP) Clutch hitting by Bob Clemente and Bill Mazeroski backed Bob Friend's pitching tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates handed the Los Angeles Dodgers their fifth straight defeat, 6-3.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 8:

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 15 Rafael Osuna, and Antonio Palafox, the Mexican team that beat the United States in the semi-finals earlier this month, will contest the singles when the American Zone Davis Cup finals begin here Friday with Yugoslavia.

Following are the texts of statements issued yesterday by Dr. Subandrio, Indonesian Foreign Minister; Dr. J.H. van Roijen, Netherlands Ambassador to the United States, and U Thant, Acting Secretary General of the United Nations, on the signing of an agreement on Netherlands New Guinea:
The last remnant of Dutch sovereignty in Southeast Asia will be ended under the agreement announced yesterday for the transfer of Netherlands New Guinea to United Nations and Indonesian control.

AN unusual and colorful international collection of fashions, combining the talents of a fabric manufacturer, artists and couturiers, was previewed Tuesday at Le Club, a private club here, before going on a nation-wide goodwill tour.
LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 15 (AP) Former Gov. Victor E. Anderson, a Lincoln business man, died, apparently of a heart attack, today at his home. He was 60 years old.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Aug. 15 A Sept. 16 wedding in Great Neck is planned by Miss Edith Frances Herman and Herbert Clarke Brauner. Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Herman have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ira Brauner of Brooklyn, N.Y.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 15 (UPI) Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru asked Indians today on the fifteenth anniversary of their independence to pledge themselves to the defense of India in view of border disputes with Communist China.
LONDON, Aug. 15 Prices moved ahead in almost every section of the stock market today. Only gold mining issues fell.
TAMIMENT, Pa., Aug. 15 The Chrysler Corporation has abandoned extremism in styling and has decided to "follow the leaders."
Exchange teachers from Britain and the United States straightened each other out yesterday on such things as the value of half a crown, coffee breaks vs. tea and how cold it gets in Denver.

RAVELLO, Italy, Aug. 15 Opening the second week of her vacation in Southern Italy, Mrs. John F. Kennedy attended mass today in the twelfth century Cathedral of San Pantaleone, the patron saint of Ravello. After the mass, which was celebrated to mark the Feast of the Assumption, Mrs. Kennedy set off for the nearby beach at Conca de Marini.

News of a wildcat strike by some workers at Kennecott Copper Corporation's Braden producing facility in Chile, plus a rising stock market, resulted in increased activity in copper futures yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange. Prices closed unchanged to up 20 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on the sale of 264 lots.

Revision of the state's controversial Condon-Wadlin Law, which bans strikes by public employes, was urged yesterday in a staff report to the Joint Legislative Committee on Industrial and Labor Conditions.

HILLSIDE, N.J., Aug. 15 John N. Richards of 19 Bailey Avenue, a former supervisor of physical education in the Newark public school system, died yesterday at St. Barnabas Hospital, Newark, after a short illness. His age was 72.

The city will have about $617,600,000 in borrowing power within its debt limit to help finance the next capital budget, Controller Abraham D. Beame predicted yesterday. The eighteen-month period for the next budget starts Jan. 1, 1963.
GREENWOOD, Miss., Aug. 15 A Negro desegregation leader said today he had complained to the Federal Bureau of Investigation about a beating he said he received Monday at the hands of three white men.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) Blinking in the sunlight and looking a bit pale, ninetynine Navy men marched out of an underground fall-out shelter today after spending two weeks inside.

Eastern Air Lines, Inc., which has been struck for fifty-four days, reported yesterday that it reduced its net loss to $3,806,000 for the first six months of this year from $6,388,000 for the 1961 period. Operating revenues rose about 20 per cent to $178,908,739 from $149,284,000.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 Senate investigators sought to show today that high Agriculture Department officials had wavered in their determination to penalize Billie Sol Estes for his disputed cotton deals.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP)--The Federal Power Commission granted temporary authority today to three Columbia Gas System subsidiaries to build pipeline facilities estimated to cost nearly $23,000,000 to provide additional gas for the coming winter heating season.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit denied a plea today by the nation's railroads to set aside a temporary injunction against putting new work rules into effect.
Plans are under way to televise six forthcoming Broadway shows free of charge in five cities across the country.

VENICE, Aug. 15 In the courtyard of the Palace of the Doges, whom he served as a fighting leader, Othello is living out his tragic destiny these warm evenings for the Venetians and tourists. One should call him Othello, for it is the magnificent adaptation of Shakespeare by Verdi and Boito, his librettist, that holds the alfresco stage.

James J.P. McShane, chief United States Marshal, who accompanied Dr. Robert A. Soblen when the convicted spy was deported from Israel on July 1, arrived from London yesterday at New York International Airport. He refused comment on the case.
The second annual Toy Ball has been arranged for Nov. 30 in the Terrace Room of the Plaza.
OTTAWA, Aug. 15 (AP) The lower exchange rate on the Canadian dollar helped lift exports in May to the highest monthly value on record, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 A major decision on airline fares is expected to be handed down by the Civil Aeronautics Board this week.

No baseball club habitually goes so far to accomplish so little as the New York Mets are want to do. They went thirteen innings last night at the Polo Grounds and wound up with their seventh straight defeat.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 15 United Artists hand Cinerama, have made a deal whereby two major United Artists movies will be filmed in Cinerama.
LONDON, Aug. 15 Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower said today he did not believe the Soviet Union was leading the United States in the exploration of space.
AVRANCHES, France, Aug. 15 (UPI) Jim Beatty of the Los Angeles Athletic Club set an American citizens' record of 7:54.2 for the 3,000-meter run at an international track meet today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP) A group of former University of Chicago football players held a special birthday party today for their old coach, Amos Alonzo Stagg, on the eve of his 100th birthday.
BERLIN, Aug. 15 Machinegun fire in East Berlin today resulted in the death of one person and the wounding or death of a second, an East German border guard.
A riot with racial overtones flared at the Fort Greene Housing Project in Brooklyn last evening. Eight persons, including two women and three patrolmen, were injured; five persons were arrested.
Mayor Wagner said in a television broadcast last night that he would say "no" oftener than "yes" to the "hundreds of pressures" constantly exerted on him.
The Tidewater Oil Company, which has been industriously interviewing a dozen advertising agencies for five months, has finally decided to assign its $3,000,000 account to Grey Advertising, Inc.

"THE thing to remember about resort hotels," a male newcomer was told, "is that no matter how pretty and poised a girl appears, she's here to meet men. And no matter how handsome and self-satisfied a man appears, he's here to meet women. So when a likely prospect appears, just make believe you're running for public office and walk over and introduce yourself."

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15 Dennis Ralston and William Bond were beaten in the Newport invitation tennis tournament at the Casino today and Michael Sangater of Great Britain narrowly escaped defeat against Crawford Henry of Atlanta.

The Pepperell Manufacturing Company achieved the highest sales in its 111-year history in the fiscal year ended on June 30. Earnings were lower, however, reflecting increased costs of raw materials and wages as well as the revised higher depreciation charges, the report added.
PLAINVIEW, L.I., Aug. 15--The Long Island Expressway went across the line into Suffolk County this morning when a ribbon barrier was cut for a new five-mile section of the six-lane expressway.

After a twenty-one-year absence, First National City Bank will be in busines again in Belgium. The bank is opening a branch this morning in a new twenty-three-story skyscraper, the tallest building in Brussels, at 8, rue Cardinal Mercier.

CLARK, N.J., Aug. 15 A voice amplifying device known as a "rigid submarine repeater," that permits up to 128 two-way conversations to be transmitted simultaneously over a single underwater cable, was introduced here today by the Western Electric Company.
The man who sublets an eleven-room apartment to U Thant, Acting Secretary General of the United Nations, said yesterday that parties in the apartment had caused $6,447 in damage to furniture.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 An article in The New York Times yesterday regarding the communications satellite bill now under debate in the Senate incorrectly described the role of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in the corporation that the bill proposes to establish.
Controlling interest in the Locke Steel Chain Company has changed hands again for the second time in less than a year.
SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 15 Gen. Chung Hee Park, leader of South Korea's military junta, urged North Koreans today to rise up against their Communist regime to re-unite the country.

A block of 260,346 common shares of the New England Electric System will be marketed today at $23.50 each. They represent the unsubscribed part of the 872,786 shares that were offered in May to the company's shareholders and employes.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 New York Democratic leaders are mentioning Robert M. Morgenthau as a possible opponent of Governor Rockefeller.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, Aug. 15 (UPI) Violence broke out again tonight at the Caribbean Games as a Cuban athlete and an anti-Castro exile fought before the start of a basketball game.

The Automatic Canteen Company of America announced yesterday that directors omitted dividend action on the common stock. The company had been paying 15 cents quarterly, the last of which was distributed in July.

WANTAGH, L.I., Aug. 15 When Stanley Mann walks into the kitchen of his split-level home here, sees his wife standing over a hot stove, and then sniffs and smells nothing, he knows what she's doing. She's frying marbles.

A three-judge Federal Court heard evidence yesterday intended to prove that the Republican-controlled state government had discriminated against Negroes and Puerto Ricans in drawing new Congressional dis trict lines for Manhattan.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Aug. 15 Mitchell Sharp of Canada, chairman of the international conference on coffee, requested today that all delegates hold themselves available in order to complete negotiations on substantive matters by Friday. Adjournment has been set for then.

WASHINGTON, Aug.15 The outlawing of strikes and lockouts was recommended today by Marriner S. Eccles, former Federal Reserve Board chairman. He called also for an immediate reduction of 5 per cent in personal income taxes.

HAVANA, Aug. 15 (AP) The Armed Forces Ministry said today the United States submarine Seahorse invaded Cuban territorial waters Monday and a United States plane twice violated Cuban air space the same day.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 15 Greeting cards designed by twelve artists for the United Nations Children's Fund went on sale today at United Nations Headquarters.
The market for corporate and municipal bonds continued strong and active yesterday. Governments, which began the day on a strong note, eased to close mixed.

GOOD chess play, like good music, is never dated. A sparkling game of 1893 in which a queen sacrifice is the jewel in the setting, may, when seen for the first time, provoke as much keen interest as the latest victory achieved by an underpromotion of a pawn.
Support of Governor Rockefeller's hospital peace plan was reaffirmed yesterday by A. Philip Randolph and Joseph Monserrat, co-chairmen of the Committee for Justice to Hospital Workers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 A sailor President went down to the Navy Yard Annex on the Anacostia River this morning to review a noble sailing ship the Coast Guard's training bark Eagle.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Aug. 15 Inquiries at City Hall today were said to indicate considerable interest in the city's questionnaire seeking information of use in ending racial imbalance in the elementary schools.

BLACKSBURG, Va., Aug. 15 (AP) Dr. Wernher von Braun, rocket expert, said tonight the orbits of the United States astronauts Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. and Lieut Comdr. M. Scott Carpenter were comparable to those of the newest Soviet cosmonauts in terms of close alignment.

James Farmer, national director of the Congress of Racial Equality, said yesterday that more than eighty restaurants along major highways in Florida, Virginia and North Carolina had been desegregated in the current "Freedom Highways" campaign.

A, "reform caucus" is being organized among prospective delegates to this year's Democratic State Convention. Its purpose is to insure a voice to the party's reform faction in the choice of candidates and the writing of the party platform.
ALBANY, Ga., Aug. 15 A Negro delegation presented de mands for desegregation of Albany's public facilities to the City Commission tonight but was rebuffed.
MADRID, Aug. 15 Some Spaniards will have to eat less fresh fish so that others "can start eating refrigerated codfish which they have never tasted in all their lives."
CINCINNATI, Aug. 15 (UPI) Frank Robinson hit two home runs and Bob Purkey reached a season high of eighteen victories as the Cincinnati Reds scored a 4-3 victory over the Milwaukee Braves.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 15 After she had succeeded in getting out of a jam near the head of the stretch today, Ogden Phipps' Fashion Verdict sped on to win the $24,550 Adirondack Stakes by three-quarters of a length from William Markery's Fast Luck.

SAN ANTONIO, Aug. 15--The second round of the anual United States Open Chess Championship Tournament, was completed here last night at the Gunther Hotel. It is a twelve-round Swiss-system event with 144 participants.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 George M. Humphrey's holdings in a chain of M.A. Hanna companies raised his personal fortune by $8,000,000 in eight and a quarter years, a Government auditor testified in a Senate hearing today.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 15 If Thomas Atkyns, the Argentina trotter who left Buenos Aires today for Saturday night's $50,000 International at Roosevelt Raceway, is not on the grounds by 10 o'clock Friday night he will not be permitted to race.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 15 Government forces were unofficially reported today to have begun a major operation against Communist guerrillas.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) The Government released $1,900,000,000 in frozen highway funds today to speed Federal-state road building programs across the country.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug 15--One of the most spectacular accidents in recent years marred the first race at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. A four horse pile-up sent three drivers catepulting through the air and another was dragged for nearly a sixteenth of a mile.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15 The trial racing that eventually will lead a 12-Meter yacht into the role of defender of the America's Cup began today with solid victories for Columbia and Weatherly.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 14 A Leftist labor group called on its member unions today to prepare for a general strike in support of Premier Francisco Brochado da Rocha's request that Congress grant him emergency powers.
MOSCOW, Aug. 15--A proud and relieved nation rejoiced today after the safe return of its two astronauts.

The Jules Verne journey of the two Soviet cosmonauts now safely back from their rendezvous in space after traveling ten times the distance to the moon is a spectacular accomplishment, an amazing feat.
The Institute of Certified Public Accountants has subleased a floor in the Tishman Building, 666 Fifth Avenue at Fifty-second Street, from the Foster Wheeler Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) A renewed demand that President Kennedy cut Federal spending and say now specifically what his tax cut plans are for next year came today from Republican Congressional leaders.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 The expulsion of the Netherlands as administrator of West New Guinea, and its replacement by the Government of Indonesia, is the latest of the triumphs of the threat of armed force as a means of territorial aggression. And in this particular instance it was the United States which supplied the pressures by which this triumph was attained.

Unishops, Inc., a large operator of men's and boys' wear leased departments in department stores, joined forces yesterday with three other large retail companies to open two discount stores in Atlanta on a joint ownership basis.
Like most other motion picture publicity men, Charles Einfeld of Twentieth Century-Fox is not given to understatement.
The solidarity of the Western powers at the seventeen-nation disarmament conference at Geneva, already impaired by France's boycott, has been further weakened.
GLENDALE, Calif., Aug. 16 Dewitt Mackenzie, one of the few battlefield correspondents of World War I and for many years an Associated Press foreign news analyst, died here today. He was 78 years old.
Louis I. Bloom of 64-74 Saunders Street, Rego Park, Queens, a retired manufacturer of stuffed toys, died Tuesday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 79 years old.
Although he performs his prodigious feats exclusively for the St. Louis Cardinals, Stan Musial is a baseball institution who belongs in the public domain.
The New York Titans have traded Al Dorow, their No. 1 quarterback, to the Buffalo Bills for Billy Atkins and Johntry Green.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 16 Premier Francisco Brochado da Rocha was reported today to be ready to stake his Government on the approval by Congress of a plebiscite to judge Brazil's parliamentary system.

A quiet, retiring New York woman described as a "lady of mystery" has left more than $4,000,000 in bequests to two universities, three medical institutions and the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.
A TREASURY of American verse enriched the tele vision screen for one hour last night, unmarred by station breaks or commercials.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 16 Head-on collisions on the Tappan Zee Bridge have become so numerous that the New York State Thruway Authority has ordered a prevention program.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Aug. 16 (AP) Dr. Lloyd H. Gaston, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, drowned today off Treasure Island Beach. He would have been 52 years old tomorrow.

The Moody Foundation of Galveston, Tex., one of the nation's largest philanthropic organizations, is apparently liquidating much of its vast business interests, including newspaper and hotel properties.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 Department store sales in the week ended Saturday, Aug. 11, were 6 per cent above sales for the similar 1961 period. All the twelve Federal Districts showed gains.

SCUDERIA SECOND IN $13,925 RACE SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 16 Although not pressed in the running of the feature, the $13,925 Promise Stakes Exhibit A. of the Overbridge Stable broke the track record in winning the mile-and-five-eighths hurdles event today.

Sound basic principles to make workable the prohibition of strikes by governmental employes are put forward in the staff recommendations for revising New York State's Condon-Wadlin Act just issued by the Joint Legislative Committee on Industrial and Labor Conditions.
After six successive, advances, the stock market eased yesterday and took a small loss on average.
Volume of Only One Sale Sets Low for a Day Cotton futures were 30 cents down to 5 cents a bale up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 16 Urged on by the cheers of a Ladies Day gathering of 41,588 the fourth straight capacity crowd of the series the Minnesota Twins, with an effort born of despair, brought down the New York Yankees 9 to 8, today in ten innings.
Harry Horwitz, realty investor, has sold the four-story business building at 40, 42 and 44 West Thirty-sixth Street in the wholesale millinery district to Mikelieb-Ross, Inc., and Jack Landsman.
Two men were arrested yesterday for allegedly filing inflated bills upon which rent increases estimated at $250,000 were granted in New York City.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 George M. Humphrey stoutly defended today his behavior as Secretary of the Treasury for more than four years and the profits made by one of his companies on Government nickel contracts.
DETROIT, Aug. 16 Retail sales of new cars in the first ten days of August reflected an expected seasonal decline but were substantially better than in the same period a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) A powerful new weapon aimed at stock-selling "boiler rooms" was proposed today by the Government part of a vigorous effort to develop more effective policing of the securities industry.

A demonstration of test scenes showing recent developments in the Cinerama process was held at Loew's Cinerama Theatre yesterday morning before an invited audience of newspaper men and film executives.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 16 Gen. Lauris Norstad assured Chancellor Adenauer today that the United States would continue "without reservations" to make "the decisive contribution" toward the defense of Europe.
Sales of the nation's leading retail store chains registered a healthy 4.9 per cent increase last month from the level of July, 1961, according to a survey completed yesterday by The New York Times.
Commissioner of Markets Albert S. Pacetta yesterday ordered the banishment of what he called "voodoo objects" from retail markets owned by the city.
RYE, N.Y., Aug. 17 Winged Foot Golf Club's team captured the Hoffhine Memorial tourney today for the fourth year in a row.
WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 16 Instead of picking horses they were picking cars at Roosevelt Raceway today.

A proposal to televise free six Broadway plays in five cities drew mixed comment yesterday. Two objections came from Broadway producers, Leland Hayward and Arthur Cantor. For different reasons, each thought that the project would not be a good idea.

Activity in both world and domestic sugar was heavy yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Other areas will make up the shortages.

Picketing against Eastern Air Lines and Pan American World Airways was carried on yesterday at New York International Airport. But in neither case did the demonstration affect the airline's operation.
The board of the Eastman Kodak Company raised the quarterly dividend yesterday with a declaration of 55 cents a share on the common stock. It will be paid on Oct. 1 to holders of record Aug. 31.
