RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 18 --Teodoro Moscoso, United States coordinator of the Alliance for Progress, visited a slum and a housing project yesterday on the first anniversary of the signing of the alliance Charter.

WHEN the paperback book was successfully revived in this country, the air was filled with doleful prophecies. The usually lurid covers were a portent. Only the cheapest and most sensational writing, we were told, would be encouraged; the level of appeal must inevitably be lowered.
Somewhere in the world in every month of the year, wheat is being harvested and planted.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18-- "I don't belong to any organized political party," goes the old saying. "I'm a Democrat." That gentle jab at the interior warfare customary to the party of James O. Eastland, John F. Kennedy and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. began to take on this week an ominous ring for certain of its battered elements.

Although some activities pursued by college students outside class would seem to be as much "anti" as "extra" curricular, others, such as the international relations clubs, continue to perform an important educational function despite the growth of courses on international affairs.
More than 1,700 persons made their way through wind and rain Friday night to Pier 81, where they boarded a fourdeck excursion boat for a "Hootenanny on the Hudson."

WHENEVER a writer strikes a false note, you see the print; in this truly original novel by the young Swedish writer, Sara Lidman, you never once see it. By precision use of the simplest language with the densest penumbra she articulates the texture of village life in the northern Sweden of fifty years ago to the very letter. Her book is also a stark line-engraving of the human heart.
PARIS, Aug. 18--France has embarked on a tremendous program of relief and rehabilitation for more than 800,000 of her citizens. However, they are not feeling too grateful about it.
WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. --Miss Nancy Lee Keith and Edmund Arthur LeFevre, teachers at the Tatnall School here, were married this morning in Grace Methodist Church.

REGARDLESS of how much room the home owner now has in his garage or basement, chances are that he will find plenty of use for a back yard storage house like the one shown here. Roomy enough to hold a power mower garden tools, bicycles and outdoor furniture, this attractivelooking shed can be put up in just a few week-ends.
WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 18--Bernard M. Baruch, who will be 92 years old tomorrow, says he's "just a young fellow doing the best I can."

AMONG the achievements that Igor Stravinsky can add to his already long list is the establishment of an attendance record at the Ravinia Festival outside of Chicago this summer. His appearance, as co-conductor with Robert Craft in a program devoted to his works, drew 10,251 people, the largest number to...
BALTIMORE, Aug. 18 (AP) --The Cleveland Indians scored the winning run without a hit today and defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 4--3, in ten innings.

By HELENE CANTARELLA OVER the centuries the word "matriarchy" has taken on derogatory connotations which seem never to have affected the meaning of its masculine counterpart. If the word "patriarchy" evokes an essentially noble image, the term matriarchy, alas, conjures up a far less inspiring picture, too often majesty gives way to power complex, Jovian serenity to embattled ruthlessness.

The Soviet people are now acclaiming with justified pride their latest heroes--the twin cosmonauts who staged a history-making rendezvous in space and circled the earth for up to four days to set a new mark in man's reach for the stars. The world joins in paying tribute to the courage and endurance of the new spacemen and to a magnificent scientific achievement.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 15-- A national parents' association with headquarters here is preparing a last-ditch stand against the state of Nuevo Leon over the right for a voice in choosing the textbooks used in private schools.
TACOMA, Wash., Aug. 18 (UPI)--The welterweight champion, Emile Griffith, gained a split decision over Denny Moyer, a middleweight, in a ten-round, nontitle bout at the Tacoma Sports Arena tonight.
CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP)-- Rex C. Ellsworth's Prove It, Carrying 130 pounds smashed Arlington Park's mile-and-a quarter track record today even though he was eased near the finish by Henry Moreno.

Among the bigger mysteries on the modern business scene are the reasons behind the financing of more than $20,000,000 of equipment that never existed by some of the nation's leading finance companies.
ROME, Aug. 18--The inside of St. Peter's Basilica looks and sounds like a shipyard these days.
The Soviet Union's feat of orbiting two men last week added a new sense of urgency to the race into space.
LEON Lewis, the Negro director of news and special events at radio station WWRL, leaned back in a studio chair the other day and began reminiscing about his fourteen years in radio broadcasting.

THE one television chore guaranteed to knit eye brows (backstage; hopefully, not the viewers') or to cudgel minds is the task of explaining an unphotogenic concept in visual terms that won't lead to angry mutterings of "Why couldn't this be done on radio instead?"

SALLY DANIELS' novel, "The Inconstant Season" is a good deal like a photograph album, with its owner stirred into reflection by the familiar faces as she slowly turns the pages. Most of the "photographs" the narrator Peggy Dillon sees are family faces.

THERE have been a number of excellent books on various segments of World War I --notably Barbara Tuchman's evocation of its first days, "The Guns of August," and Alan Moorehead's "Gallipoli"-- and at least one satisfactory history of the entire cataclysm, "The Great War" by Cyril Falls. But no book ever told the comprehensive military story concisely and undertandably with reference to politics, economy and the sweep of history.

Pratt Institute has received a $237,600 grant from the Federal Housing and Home Finance Agency to conduct a three-year demonstration project in costsaving construction methods for multi-level housing.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 16-- Trade unions are being assigned a key role in the development of Africa.

The building industry's heavyhanded plastic surgeons, armed with pile drivers, iron wrecking balls, steam shovels and cranes, have almost completely changed the face of many of New York's main thoroughfares. But for many reasons they have left the midtown garment district almost untouched.

Electronic control is being applied in land surveys on Staten Island with an instrument that can measure distances of up to fifteen miles by transmitting polarized light. The device, known as a Geodimeter, might be called a sort of super-stopwatch.

At a news conference last week, a State Department spokesman was asked what the U.S. would do if there were a military coup in Argentina. He replied carefully: "We do not look with favor upon military coups against constitutional democratic regimes." The exchange reflected a delicate problem for the U.S.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 18-- The Yankees hit six home runs tonight, but all it got them was an even break in their double-header with the Athletics before a crowd of 35,147, a record baseball gathering for Municipal Stadium.
Two models have been completed at Tuxedo Park Estates, a colony of thirty-eight ranch and Colonial houses at Melby Lane and Flamingo Road in the East Hills section of Roslyn, L.I.

Under Title VIII the National Defense Education Act the Government is underwriting vocational education at state and local levels in the hope of attracting more youngsters into technical fields. The program has been eminently successful since 1959, when Congress introduced it in the conviction that the nation must take cognizance of the momentous technological changes then developing.
CHICAGO, Aug. 18--Corn is still king in the Midwest but soybeans have become the Cinderella crop.
LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, Aug. 18--The possibility of a third round of fighting between United Nations and Katangese forces appeared to have lessened today.
Small auction galleries in the Greenwich Village area, unusually active this summer, have from time to time offered unusual inducements to matinee audiences.

Almost three months have elapsed since the stock market break in late May. When it took place, the drastic decline in securities values brought some drastic predictions about a forthcoming decline in the economy. Apparently it has not taken place and, with the passing of every day, prospects appear to be brighter rather than dimmer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18-- The recent elevation of Senator Jacob K. Javits to the Senate Appropriations committee is regarded here as evidence that the venerable institution of the Senate and the New York Republican are finally beginning to come to terms.
One or more unknown ingredients in some vegetable oils has been found to retard hardening of the arteries in chickens, which develop atherosclerosis faster than humans.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 18 (AP)--This was a day for the younger generation at the At lantic City race course. After the nation's leading apprentice jockey, Ronnie Ferraro, rode four straight winners, the Jaclyn Stable's Noble Jay, took the $27,750 Atlantic City Handicap. Noble Jay was the only 3-year-old in the race.

An unusual colony of beachfront homes is being created at a leisurely pace on Long Island's North Shore. Although the beach itself has been fully installed with the requisite improvements in a year's time, nearly a decade will pass before the 527-acre wooded tract that adjoins it has a full complement of 1,200 houses.

MONTREAL. THE Montreal Festivals opened its twenty-seventh season on Aug. 2 with Monteverdi's "Vespers in Honor of the Blessed Virgin," accompanied by the usual debate and dialectics on the respective contributions by the English and French cultural communities in this bilingual city.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 18--To win the ninetythird running of the Travers Stakes today, George D. Widener's Jaipur had to break the record of the legendary Man o' War.

HONG KONG, Aug. 18-- United States forces will retain permanent headquarters in Thailand even if the units now there or their replacements eventually are withdrawn, according to informed circles in Bangkok.

LAKE FOREST, Ill., Aug. 18 --The Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Louise de Marigny Smith to John Adams Bross Jr. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Eastwood Atwater. A reception was held at the Onwentsia Club.
Ordinarily a rise in sales is a good omen for the future. This has not been the case, however, in the recent sharp rise of United States grain exports to Western Europe.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 18-- In a program aimed at reducing possible danger of iodine 131 concentration in milk, Minnesota's milk producers will be paid a premium for milk from herds fed on aged feed.
MODENA, Italy, Aug. 10-- The world's foremost producer of race cars is having a badseason; yet, characteristically, he is happy.

Last Tuesday vocational rehabilitation of the handicapped in the United States passed a historic milestone.
CINCINNATI, Aug, 18 (AP) --Joe Nuxhall's four-hit pitching helped the Cincinnati Reds score a 12-1 victory tonight over the league-leading Los Angeles Dodgers.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 19--Israel, already well in the vanguard of nations concentrating on scientific research on water supply and conservation has begun a three-year investigation of the chemical changes involved in large-scale underground storage of such reserves.
Fire of suspicious origin broke out early today in the Circle in the Square, a leading off-Broadway playhouse at 159 Bleecker Street in Greenwich Village.

The revival of interest in Robert M. Morgenthau as a possible Democratic candidate for Governor, which followed Mayor Wagner's "social" visit to Washington last week, is attributable to several significant factors. One is the chaos and confusion in the Democratic state leadership.

The Dutch-Indonesian agreement on West New Guinea has left in the disputed territory and Indonesia problems almost as critical as the threat of war the settlement averted. Indonesia has now taken on the burdens of a primitive area that the Dutch have been subsidizing at the rate of $30,000,000 a year.

Harry S. Bandler, for sixtysix years a member of the New York bar, died yesterday after a heart attack at the Fairview Country Club, Elmsford. He was a past president and golf champion of the club. He was 89 years old.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19 (AP)--The Los Angeles Angels broke a sixth-inning tie on a two-run double by Felix Torres and, defeated the Washington Senators, 5--2, today behind the five-hit pitching of Dean Chance.

Dr. James A. Van Allen said yesterday that a new radiation belt, created by the high-altitude nuclear test staged by the United States in the central Pacific on July 9, had "increased the potential danger for manned space flights."
The McDonnell Aircraft Corporation has begun a $21,000,000 program to build new facilities near its St. Louis plant, J.S. McDonnell, chairman, announced over the week-end.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 19 (UPI)--Hank Aaron hammered his thirty-second and thirtythird home runs of the year and Del Crandall and Lee Maye hit one each today to lead the Milwaukee Braves to a 13-8 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

City, State, Federal and World Health Organization officials joined here yesterday to track down anyone who might have had contact with a youthful traveler ill with what has been diagnosed as smallpox.

THE first group of Britishtravelers who came here re cently aboard the liner Canberra for a brief look at the United States complained about only one thing. In Washington, they were subjected to six solid hours of sight-seeing without a single break for a cup of tea.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (AP)-- Speculation dominated the grain futures market last week and it pushed most commodities substantially higher.
ST. PAUL, Aug. 19 (UPI)-- Doug Sanders won the $30,000 St. Paul open tournament today with a final 65 and a 72-hole total of 269, nineteen strokes under par.

A car westbound on Fortyseventh Street collided with a taxicab southbound on Broadway yesterday morning, smashed the window of a store and ran out of control into a Sanitation Department water truck. Ten persons were injured.
City departments and agencies have asked the City Planning Commission for $1,127,792,172 in additional funds for permanent public improvements in the eighteen months beginning Jan. 1.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI)--If the United States wants a top public school system, it will have to spend about $33,000,000,000 a year by 1970, the National Education Association said today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19-- The injury-riddled New York Giants were racked up, 42--10, today by the aggressive San Francisco Forty-Niners in an exhibition between National Football League teams.

BRINDISI, Italy, Aug. 19--Italy is a land rich in paradox. Its vast bureaucracy still numbers on its payroll officials for colonies long since yielded. Its nobility includes Communist militants and two claimants to Byzantium's ancient throne, one of whom works as a clown.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 19-- A new political movement was formed here today at a meeting of 4,000 Luo tribesmen as a warning to Kenya's majority Kikuyu tribesmen to "abandon their dreams of domination."

BALTIMORE, Aug. 19 (AP) --Two-run homers by Jim Gentile and Whitey Herzog and a bases-filled error by the Cleveland shortstop, Woodie Held, gave the Baltimore Orioles a 6-5 victory of the Indians today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (UPI)-- Grand-slam home runs by Charlie Maxwell in the opener and Billy Bruton in the finale marked the Chicago White SoxDetroit Tiger double-header split today.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 19-- Kirkham Wright Torney, a television production company executive and former chain store operator, died of a heart attack yesterday while being taken to Norwalk Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived on Cardinal Hill Road in Southport.
MONTREAL, Aug. 19--Financing of the Wabush Iron Ore Company's $230,000,000 iron-ore project in Quebec-Labrador is expected to be completed by Tuesday.
Cotton prices in the domestic futures market last week followed initial firmness with an easier turn, closing with small net losses.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19--The United States, keenly concerned over North African political stability, is studying ways to provide urgently needed aid to troubled Algeria.

A concept in public housing not used for nearly a quarter of a century--combining a number of individual projects into one complex and thus creating a village--is being put in reality by the New York City Housing Authority.
BOSTON, Aug. 19--Sometime in the next few days surgeons at the Massachusetts General Hospital plan to undertake the solicing of severed nerves in the arm of a 12-year-old boy.
"I WANT to get involved in the passions and actions of our times," a housewife and mother of several children told an employment specialist recently.

One of New York's hardy summer perennials, the Municipal Concerts Orchestra, wound up a busy week of concerts in various local parks with a concert at Central Park Mall on Saturday night. Julius Grossman conducted, and the soloists were Charles Libove, violinist, and Gerald Warburg, 'cellist.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19-- Vice President Johnson leaves on a mission to the Middle East this week, with instructions to say to Greece and Iran: "We love you still but not quite so many bushels and a peck as before."
The Mets lost to the Cardinals, 10--5, at the Polo Grounds yesterday but ended one of the nastiest baseball rumors since Babe Ruth was accused of eating wheat germ.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19-- Every third or fourth week in the year some forty officers and staff of the Federal Reserve System gather here to analyze the economy and credit conditions and to plot credit policy for the three or four weeks ahead.

Jerry Bock, composer, and Sheldon Harnick, lyricist, who collaborated on "Fiorello!," have written the songs for a new musical, tentatively named "Tevye." The plot, which stems from the character Tevye, created by Sholom Aleichem, the Yiddish humorist, was adapted by Joseph Stein.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 19-- South Vietnam is ready to embark on a large-scale program of deficit financing to help pay for the increasingly costly struggle against Communist insurgency.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 19 (UPI) --The Los Angeles Dodgers scored five runs in the ninth inning today on homers by Frank Howard and Willie Davis and three bunts. That gave the Dodgers a 5-1 victory over the Cincinnati Reds and Don Drysdale his twenty-second triumph of the season against six defeats.

A growing number of companies these days are stepping up efforts to improve the efficiency of their advertising. "The trend is not hard to explain," notes Richard C. Christian, president of Marsteller, Inc. "The squeeze on corporate profits has induced many advertisers to scrutinize their budgets more closely and try to determine exactly what each dollar is accomplishing."

Less than a hundred feet from a large and modern machine for producing scientific glassware, three glassblowers worked feverishly in Vineland, N.J., to produce pieces of glass similar to those made more than 350 years ago.
The New York Shipping Association has been asked to negotiate a contract expiration date with longshoremen that would put the dock workers in step with the nation's other maritime unions.

Reflecting higher sales, net income of Deere Co. for the nine months ended on July 31 increased to $25,515,839 from $23,884,729 in the like period of the preceding fiscal year, the farm and industrial machinery producer reported over the week-end. The earnings were equal to $3.70 a share, compared with $3.46 a year earlier.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 19--Ralph Petersen's bay gelding Gangster, from Glen Head, L.I., dominated the working hunter classes and won the championship with 23 points as the Southampton horse show ended today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19-- Senator Howard W. Cannon charged today that civilian officials in the Defense Department had delayed programs to exploit space for military purposes, handing the Soviet Union a commanding position by default.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19--If the Republicans were better politicians they would start doing something about the high price of medical care for the car in this country before the Democrats beat them to it.

TIMBALES--savory, unmolded custard mixtures con taining meat, fish, poultry or vegetables--are attractive, convenient and economical light entrees suitable for serving at summer luncheons and suppers.

JAMES FELT'S earliest ambition was to be a rabbi, and one of his favorite lessons from the Talmud is: "He is a strong man who can control his passions, and who is able to convert an enemy into a friend."

The Sea Fare, a well-known restaurant, has leased the firstfloor store area, the mezzanine and the basement of the former Jay Thorpe Building at 24 West Fifty-seventh Street. The lease is for thirty years with a renewal option and involves about $1,000,000 in rentals.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 19 (AP)--Harmon Killebrew and Jim Kaat sparked the Minnesota Twins to a sweep over the Boston Red Sox today, 4--2 and 7--4.
MADRID, Aug. 19--A bomb exploded outside the summer residence of Generalissimo Francisco Franco near San Sebastian early this morning. No one was hurt and the damage was said to be small.

Enkells-Rakoff Co., realty investors, have bought the leasehold on the thirteen-story office and store building at 350 Lexington Avenue, southwest corner of Fortieth Street, for cash. President Kennedy and his economic advisers, who have been remarkably loquacious on almost every aspect of the economy, seem to have sealed their lips when it comes to discussing the impending budget deficit.

Roman Catholic schools must meet the challenges of "aggressive secularism" by offering quality education and devout religious instruction, Cardinal Spellman said in a pastoral letter read yesterday.

MOSCOW, Aug. 19--Janos Kadar, the Communist chief of Hungary, has carried out a drastic purge of former Stalinist leaders within his party.

HORNELL, N.Y., Aug. 19-- A cream-colored French bulldog, Ch. Ratanda Ami Francine, was chosen best in the Southern Tier Kennel Club show today. The victor, owned and bred by Mr. and Mrs. Ralph N. West of Livonia, Mich., was handled by Jerry Rigden. It was the dog's twenty-first best-inshow and sixty-third non-sporting triumph.
MADRID, Aug. 19--Spaniards discussed today a published letter to the editor of a Madrid newspaper denouncing wages that left a worker's family of three the equivalent of only 76 cents a day for food.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19-- Premier Fidel Castro told Cubans last night that agriculture would henceforth be based completely on collectives and that the cooperatives owned by the peasants would be turned into "state farms."

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 19-- This may be the week that will bring an end to the America's Cup defense aspirations of one or two of the four 12-Meter yachts that began the final selection trials last Wednesday. The New York Yacht Club committee charged with making the choice is an amiable group, but close-lipped, so its daily deliberations are a mystery.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 19--United Nations air reconnaisance reports made public here today indicate that gendarmes of secessionist Katanga dispersed a number of Congolese Army units in two weeks of widespread skirmishes in north Katanga.

BERLIN, Aug. 19--A Soviet troop bus was stoned by a screaming crowd of West Berliners today. The incident was a new manifestation of anger in West Berlin over the shooting on Friday of a young refugee who was allowed to lie dying for more than an hour by the Communist wall.

WHEN Don Drysdale, the Big D of the Dodgers, won his twentieth game on Aug. 3, he drew even with the time schedule posted by Dizzy Dean in 1934, the year the self-styled Great Man became the last thirty-game winner baseball has produced. Ol' Diz virtually called the turn on his thirty. Just before the start of the season he offered a consoling thought to his manager, the usually apoplectic Frank Frisch.

NICCOLO TUCCI's "Before My Time," a massive and intricate novel of labyrinthine psychological subtlety, is basically a comedy of egoism. It is other things, too, but more than anything else it is an exploration and a detailed demonstration of the misery, unhappiness, folly and self-destruction that are the fruits of inordinate self-love.

Fur-trimmed coats maintained last week the popularity they have held for several months, resident buying offices here reported, although sales of untrimmed coats continued to grow. Two and three-piece wool knit suits also sold well.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) --The Federal Aviation Agency disclosed today a broad technical plan for the modernization of the nation's air traffic control system.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19-- The President's Cup rowing regatta on the Potomac River this afternoon wound up in a protest over points.
Customs collections in the Port of New York last month totaled $58,225,650, a rise of $8,242,981 over receipts for June and $9,560,284 over those for July, 1961.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 19-- Hopes for a September improvement in steel shipments faded last week. Orders of the biggest mills indicated no gain or only a minor improvement next month.
DIEPPE, France, Aug. 19-- The Canadians came back to Dieppe today--twenty years after one of their finest divisions shattered itself against the German-held cliffs and beaches here.

DES MOINES, Aug. 18--A 125-acre forest inhabited only by birds and squirrels earlier this week has suddenly become a bustling city. Tents have sprouted throughout the woods. The aroma of bacon, beans and freshly brewed coffee fills the air.
MOSCOW, Aug. 19 (AP)-- Frank Froehling of Coral Gables, Fla., won the singles final in the Soviet tennis championships today by beating John Newcombe of Australia, 3-6, 6-2, 6-2, 4-6, 7-5.
NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 19--The second new work of this final weekend of the American Dance Festival at Connecticut College was given its premiere Saturday night by Josh Limon and his company.

NEW book called "Mathematics for Pleasure," published on Aug. 1 by the McGraw-Hill Book Company in New York and written by Onward Jacoby, in collaboration with Prof. William H. Benson of Dickinson College, has very little about bridge in it.

Pete McArdle, a 32-year-old New York bus mechanic, established a course record yesterday while winning his third straight Amateur Athletic Union national 25-kilometer (15.52mile) running championship. His time was 1 hour 21 minutes 58.6 seconds. McArdle also paced the New York Athletic Club to the team title.
POMONA, N.Y., Aug. 19-- Members of the First Unitarian Society of Rockland County spent an extra hour after this morning's service working on the construction of their church here.

The Federal Maritime Commission has been asked to find as "harsh and inequitable" a $143,370 reparation award against a shipping company becaause it refused to transport a banana dealer's fruit during a two-year period.

LONDON, Aug. 19 (AP)--A translation of the Old Testament being made by a ten-man panel of British and Irish scholars will contain fundamental changes in wording that will give it a new idiom and rhythm, the panel director said today.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19-- A new campaign theme, reminiscent of "Let's get this country moving again," may have emerged from President Kennedy's "nonpolitical" tour of the West.

Mayor Wagner and the Board of Estimate have apparently decided to postpone final action on the controversial Lower Manhattan Expressway project until after the general election on Nov. 6.
Finch College gave a bon voyage party yesterday for nine of its students who are leaving for Europe tomorrow to spend their junior year examining the art treasures and politics of four countries.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (AP)-- Sharon Finneran of Los Angeles smashed the women's world record for the 200-meter butterfly today as the Amateur Athletic Union women's national outdoor swimming championships ended.

A beaming, perspiring Governor Rockefeller squeezed hands, slapped backs, kissed babies and was kissed by women, ate frankfurters and autographed paper plates yesterday as he toured the city's beaches to "see and talk to the people."

Representative William E. Miller, chairman of the Republican National Committee, said last night that if the Republican party failed to elect major candidates in November "I think we will have to look under a rock to get someone to take our nomination in 1964."

A bill setting up a new oceanographic post in the Office of Science and Technology has been approved by the Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries of the House. It may be acted upon by the full chamber this week.
LONDON, Aug. 19--The London stock market moved ahead with such vigor last week that the experts were pronouncing it as recovered from the break of late May and June.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- After weeks of space-age debate, the Senate is ready to renew the fight over farm legislation.

ALGIERS, Aug. 19--The Al-, gerian Communist party has requested that its candidates for election be included on a joint list headed by members of the National Liberation Front, the party of nationalists that won independence from France.
LONDON, Aug. 19--Two stately homes that encourage visitors are competing for popularity among the British public.
"Arthur Godfrey in Hollywood," the first of three hourlong specials starring the entertainer, will be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System on Saturday, Nov. 10, from 8:30 to 9:30 P.M.

Dr. Gonzalo E. Arostegui, a former surgeon in Cuba, who was director of the Municipal and Emergency Hospital and the Clinical Institute in Havana, died yesterday of cancer in Doctors Hospital. His age was 70.

KANSAS CITY, Aug.19--The New York Yankees, paced by Elston Howard and Mickey Mantle, went on their biggest scoring spree of the year today as they battered the Kansas City Athletics, 21 to 7, in the fourth encounter of a five-game series.

THE flutter of an eyelash has won many a woman a favor in the past. Today, if nature has not given her a dazzling abundance of real ones, a woman may choose from the false variety, made of real mink, seal, hair or plastic.
Negro folk music, which has been singing of a promised land since the days of slavery, has become a vital force in the attempt to fulfill that promise in the South today.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 19 --Reports from the Turkish frontier said Iraqi planes bombed six smaller Turkish border villages today. Confirmation could not be immediately obtained in Ankara. In telephone calls to Istanbul,...
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 20 President Kennedy is considering taking another non-political" tour. This one would cover several large cities. Its theme would be the need for urban renewal.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 20The Argentine Government began a national loan drive today, hoping to obtain the equivalent of $40,000,000 in public subscriptions over the next two months.
The police warned yesterday that New York City was being invaded by a small army of Latin American pickpockets who can do what was thought impossible pick the hip pocket of a seated victim.
More and fancier fancy foods will be placed on American tables, buffets and television trays this fall and winter.

The refusal of construction workers at the Marshall Space Flight Center in Alabama to return to work is an unconscionable impediment to United States efforts to beat the Soviet Union to the moon. The walkout began last week while the two Russian astronauts were demonstrating how far ahead their country already is in that contest.
WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 20 The sixteenth annual Little League world series will start here tomorrow with eight teams aiming for the championship to be decided on Saturday.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 20 The Laotian coalition Government failed again today to break a deadlock on the question of withdrawal points for foreign forces.
A group of residents on the North Shore of Long Island will open their homes on the afternoons of Sept. 25 and Oct. 2 to help raise funds for the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange at the close of business on Aug. 15 amounted to 5,389,604 shares, the Exchange reported yesterday. This was the highest since Sept. 15, 1958, when the short interest was 5,646,414 shares.
GENEVA, Aug. 20 (AP) The Soviet Union threw cold water today on a proposal for a ban on nuclear tests in the atmosphere to end radioactive fall-out and lessen international tension.
The first of three new cargopassenger liners of the American Mail Line fleet has set successive records on her first three voyages.

LONDON, Aug. 20 Colin Jordan, 39-year-old leader of the National Socialist Movement in Britain, was sentenced to two months in prison today for addressing a public rally last month with insulting words that were likely to cause disorder.
JERSEY CITY, Aug. 20 Superior Court Judge Morris Pashman today prohibited the construction of a motel and tenstory tower on the Palisades just south of the George Washington Bridge, pending a trial.
THE deal shown today, gave a striking illustration to about sixty bridge players and onlookers that one should not double an opposing slam, bid voluntarily, when he knows he can beat it.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 20 Now comes the denouement in the crumbs-to-caviar saga of the Los Angeles Angels. This could be midnight for the Cinderella club and its preposterous pretentions to the 1962 American League pennant.

EUGENE, Ore., Aug. 20 Seven hundred community and educational theatre workers from around the nation are meeting on the University of Oregon campus to learn new ways of making the theatre something distinctive.

HONG KONG, Aug. 20--Jenmin Jih Pao, the offiicial organ of the Chinese Communist party, published an editorial today denouncing the United States and the Chinese Nationalist Chinese regime on Taiwan for collaborating to "create two Chinas."
Herbert Zelenko angrily walked out of a scheduled debate with William Fitts Ryan last night after waiting forty minutes for his opponent to appear. Mr. Ryan arrived five minutes later.
Harry Randolph Guggenheimer, who retired in 1960 after many years as a lawyer in Wall Street, died yesterday at the Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital. His age was 83 and he lived at the Biltmore Hotel.
Traffic violators unable to pay their fines will be paroled for forty-eight hours so that they can raise the money.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the Air Force disputed today a report in the magazine Aviation Week that Vostok III and Vostok IV had rendezvoused and docked in space.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 20 The contruction of a $150,000 library will be undertaken soon by the B'nai B'rith near, the Negev settlement of Sede Boqur.
MOSCOW, Aug. 20 It was a rainy Monday morning. Workmen took down the banners of celebration for the triumph in space. The Soviet people went back to work and the realities of daily life.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 20 Michael Sweeney, representing Cedar Point Yacht Club of Westport, led the qualifiers for the thirty-seventh midget sailing championship of Long Island Sound as the three-race elimination series was completed today off Black Rock Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 Compromises and new demands appeared today as the Senate began consideration of its new farm bill, which contains only a fraction of the strict production controls sought by the Administration.
LONDON, Aug. 20 Demand was modest and selective in the stock market today. Small gain dominated most of the important industrial sections.

Less than a month has passed since President Kennedy signed a law to shift the emphasis in public welfare from handing out doles to restoring the needy to self-respect and self-support. But already the bill's purposes are being undercut by the launching of a new national drive to ferret out relief "chiselers."
As the Temperature-Humidity Index climbed to the range of distinct discomfort, the Department of Sanitation made preparations yesterday for severe snowstorms of the future.

RUMSON, N.J., Aug. 20 Myron B. Diggin, vice president, technical director and a board member of the Hanson-Van Winkle-Munning Company of Matawan, manufacturer's of electroplating equipment, died yesterday at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank.
DALLAS, Aug. 20 (AP) A committee of Billie Sol Estes' creditors considered today selling his assets to Morris D. Jaffe of San Antonio, who was reported offering $6,500,000.

Robert Moses announced yesterday that he had asked for "drastic action" by the State Superintendent of Public Works to get contractors to speed "lagging" work on a main highway leading to the World's Fair.

The Sabre Line, which has become the world's largest independent liner service since it was organized a year and a half ago, yesterday challenged the domain of about twenty longestablished steamship lines engaged in United States trade with Japan.

MILFORD, Conn., Aug. 20 Alexander's opened its sixth store the first outside the metropolitan New York area in ceremonies today in the Connecticut Post Center, at the intersection of the Boston Post Road and the Connecticut Turnpike.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy said yesterday that the city police force was making headway against crimes and violence.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 20 The massive influx of Chinese Communist refugees into Hong-Kong since 1949 has not caused a major unemployment problem in the British crown colony, according to a report issued here today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 20 Veterans of the Twentieth Century-Fox campaigns of Italy and Egypt are returning here in waves and, like most warriors, bringing with them wondrous tales of the most expensive movie ever made.

BELLPORT, L.I., Aug. 20 A series of mishaps in the third race of the elimination series marred today's opening of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's competition for the Picken Trophy. At stake is the area's midget sailing championship.

HOUSTON, Aug. 20 Mrs. Mary Gibbs Jones, widow of Jesse H. Jones, a former Secretary of Commerce and publisher of The Houston Chronicle, died today at her apartment in the Lamar Hotel. She was 90 years old.
DETROIT, Aug. 20 (AP) The nation's passenger-car manufacturers are expected to start volume production of 1963 model cars this week.
Cotton futures were 60 cents a bale down to 5 cents up on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 The Senate Judiciary Committee cleared the way today for floor action later this week on legislation to safeguard the public against harmful and ineffective drugs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 Matters of grave national consequence depend on the ability of Eastern Air Lines to effect its announcement today of resumption by Sept. 13 of all but its "non-profitable" flights.
The State of Washington raised $37,000,000 in the bond market yesterday on $20,000,000 of school bonds due 1963 to 1981, and $17,000,000 of revenue bonds due 1966 to 1973.

Although a thorough reform of the Federal tax structure has been pledged for next year, Secretary of the Treasury Dillon is reluctant to disclose the proposals to be presented to Congress. He says the Treasury has not yet completed work on the bill, but it is also apparent that he does not want to give opponents of reform an opportunity to muster their guns against change.
Bonds moved up again yesterday. Governments were strong, and corporates attracted sporadic attention. Recent state and municipal offerings continued to be whittled down.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 20 A deep split in organized labor reflecting Brazil's political crisis was demonstrated at the national conventions of two major labor groups that closed last night.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 A Senate decision on Thurgood Marshall's future as a Federal judge was postponed indefinitely again today amid growing protests and threats
ALGIERS, Aug. 20 More than a third of the members of independent Algeria's first Constituent Assembly will be military officers.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 20--Announcement has been made by the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Ralph D. Read of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lucy Anne Read, to Francisco de Asis Pastor de Masferrer, son of the late Senor and ...

PARIS, Aug. 20 Summer is the season for skling the money end of it. All over the Alps new lifts are being built and slopes cleared. Ski instructors are studying English intensively. In the courts, people are collecting for real or imagined injuries suffered last season. Five Paris banks
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20--President Kennedy's Advisory Committee on Labor Management Policy has shelved its potentially explosive examination of labor and business monopoly power.
Buses are now providing the missing crosstown link for air travelers going between Manhattan's East Side and West Side Airlines Terminals.
A proposal to construct cottages on a ten-acre site to house dependent, neglected children was put forward yesterday by the Welfare Department.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 20 Urged into the lead in the stretch by Sheridan Mellon, Waltz Song won the $27,350 Diana Handicap today by a length. Second in the mile-andan eighth fixture for older fillies and mares was Seven Thirty, sent off as a favorite by the 13,502 customers.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 20 The National Front for the Liberation of Angola announced today that it had established a military training camp for Angolan rebels on Congolese territory.

BOSTON, Aug. 29 (AP) Fingerprints found in two places are the best clues to date in the investigation of the nation's biggest cash robbery the $1,551,277 haul from a United States mail truck last Tuesday.

TOKYO, Aug. 20 (AP) An American released by the pro-Communist Pathel Lao in Laos after fifteen months as a prisoner said during a stopover in Tokyo today, "You wouldn't think anyone would treat a human being like that."

SPRINGFIELD, III., Aug. 20 (UPI) Anti-segregation domonstrators, some with bandaged heads, milled about the foot of Abraham Lincoln's statu today and won from the Governor of Illinois a promise to investigate conditions in the river town of Cairo.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 Legislation to preserve Fire Island by setting it aside as a national seashore was introduced today by Representative John V. Lindsay, Republican of Manhattan.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug.20 (AP) Hard-core Vietcong guerrillas have survived a massive Government offensive in the southern swamplands.
ALBANY, Aug. 20 Governor Rockefeller today appointed Justice William T. Cowin, now a member of the City Court bench in New York, as justice of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial District.

The United States is getting ready to send more help to Algeria. We have been helping the Algerian people for at least six years, with almost $22 million worth of foodstuffs during the worst of the fighting. The proposals now being considered include sending more food to help support workers on public projects.
Though the television networks customarily preview their programing plans for the forthcoming television season, they do not advise viewers what they might expect in the way of commercials.
Steel production renewed its upward movement last week after holding steady the preceding week.

Creditors of Grayson-Robinson Stores, Inc., crowded the Trianon ballroom of the Astor Hotel yesterday to learn firsthand how the big apparel chain plans to pay the $10,500,000 it owes and how it expects to keep operating.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 20 The Foreign Ministry announced today that Turkey would withdraw jet fighter patrols from the Iraqi frontier region "in the interest of good neighborly relations."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 Treasury bill rates were off slightly on today's sales of the regular weekly issues.
A power failure plunged at least six square miles of Brooklyn into darkness at 9:05 last night. Power was not fully restored until 12:23 A. M.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 20 (AP) Mrs. Frances King, an Atlanta grandmother, won the Champion of Champions competition for women state titleholders today as the sixty-third Grand. American Trapshoot opened.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 20 (AP) Flames destroyed the old unoccupied Carson-Union MayStern building today and spread a series of fires over downtown St. Louis.

The Shell Oil Company said yesterday it planned to distribute to stockholders a 50 per cent interest in the Shell Oil Company of Canada. The company said it had received a ruling from the United States Internal Revenue Service concerning the proposed distribution and that the ruling now was being reviewed by counsel.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug, 20-Steps to end the secession of Katanga Province from the Congo were urged on the Security Council's members today by U Thant, Acting Secretary General of the United Nations.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 20 Chuck McKinley and Dennis Ralston began their defense of the national lawn tennis doubles championship today in the same decisive manner in which they won the Newport final yesterday.

The Frankel family, one of whose members was involved in the 1955 proxy fight for control of Libby, McNeill Libby, yesterday was revealed as heading the group buy ing the stock in the Kirby Petroleum Company.

IT took two rather bizarre and unusual incidents to give Burton (Barney) Shotton his two terms as manager of the Brooklyn Dodgers. Each made such impact on baseball history that they should not be ignored even though several weeks have elapsed since Old Barney's death at the age of 77.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, which televised a program of poetry without identifying either the poems or their authors, said yesterday it had received an estimated total of 40,000 letters asking for a list of the poets and their works.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 20 Ralph Houk is a solidly built citizen, but along about 4:10 P.M. today you could have knocked him over with a feather.
The Board of Education announced yesterday the names of 216 men and women who had agreed to serve as members of the city's reorganized local school boards.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Tuesday, Aug. 21--A Brazilian jet airliner crashed while taking off last night at Galeao International Airport for Europe with 102 persons aboard.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug. 20 Antonio Medina of Venezuela has taken the lead in the annual United States Open Chess Championship tournament at the Gunther Hotel here.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 20 (AP) Frank Robinson hit a grandslam home run with one out in the tenth inning tonight and gave the Cincinnati Reds a 7 3 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
The New York City Ballet Company, led by George Balanchine, will tour the Soviet Union for eight weeks this fall under the International Cultural Exchange Program.

Just how the Securities and Exchange Commission can absorb all the information obtained from the innumerable questionnaires sent out recently, no one knows. However, yesterday it announced still another. This time it goes to forty-five over-the counter broker-dealers who are not members of the New York Stock Exchange.
Entertainment will abdicate to education tomorrow in the Brooklyn Paramount Theatre. Long Island University will take over the premises, at Flatbush Avenue Extension and De Kalb Avenue.
MOSCOW, Aug. 20 A Russian astronomer said today that radiation had proved to be no hazard to Soviet astronauts in their orbital flights of the earth.

As the mercury rose into the nineties yesterday and New Yorkers loosened their ties and shed their jackets, several thousand visitors to the city were busy with cool thoughts of the coming Christmas season.

BERLIN, Aug. 20 Angry mobs of West Berliners stoned and pursued Soviet Army ve- hicles tonight and clashed with the West Berlin police in bloody street fights near the wall that runs along the East-West border.

Brazilians have agreed to disagree until midSeptember, when Congress, Premier Brochado da Rocha and President Goulart will resume their struggle. The Government wants Congress to agree to a plebiscite on a return to the old system of Presidential powers.

One hundred years ago next Friday, the Confederate war vessel Alabama slipped out of a Port of the Azores on a voyage that made history. The Alabama destroyed much Union shipping and kept many merchant vessels huddled in harbors for safety.
CHICAGO, Aug. 20 (UPI) Wheat futures gained and other grain contracts were mined today on the Board of Trade. Profit taking erased an early general advance.

A Federal study of quarantine safeguards was ordered yesterday as officials sought to determine why the improper vaccination papers of a youth with smallpot were not detected at New York International Airport.

Eastern Air Lines, crippled by a strike of flight engineers that lasted nearly two months, announced yesterday the reopening of more ticket offices in preparation for a further resumption of service Thursday.
Governor Rockefeller, Secretray of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg and Mayor Wagner named three officials yesterday to assist in resolving a dispute over the manning of railroad tugboats in New York Harbor.

WHO buys satire? An acceptable answer is: all who heartily hate fraud. but I think satire is also amazingly popular with the people being satirized. And perhaps a deeper investigation might show that it is pretty attractive to thousands who would rather enjoy being right up there with the satirist's big targets.

A decision will be made at the end of the week regarding the future of "La Belle," the musical starring Menasha Skulnik, Joan Diener and Howard Da Silva. As scheduled, the offering may open on Sept. 18 at the Plymouth.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 20--The Government warned today that it was listing as criminals any East Germans who participated in the shootings of fellow Germans.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 20 Pakistan has been asked by the United Nations to provide a military force to keep order in Netherlands New Guinea.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20 The first heavy-weather tests of the America's Cup defense trials developed with a vengeance today.
HAMBURGERS, steaks, chop and occasionally chicken that is about the extent of the fare placed over glowing coals by the average back-yard barbecue buff.
Edward M. Gilbert, the speculator who fled to Brazil last June 12, has expressed the hope that he can "repay everybody that lost money as a consequence of my mistakes."
Maine potato futures advanced and world sugar declined in moderately active trading yesterday. Other commodities traded in New York were mixed and slow.

The barn of Normandy Farms, the Litchfield, Conn., estate of Mrs. Stanley Mortimer of New York, includes a dance floornot for cows but for the people who will attend the annual ball she gives there in behalf of the Connecticut Association for Mental Health.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 20 After eleventh months in "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying," Rudy Vallee is finally taking a week's vacation. He returned yesterday to the scene of his early success: the Music Hall stage on the Steel Pier.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 18 A lively Roman Catholic priest answers charges that he backs anti-Semitism here by contending that it is Jews who are starting trouble.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 20 Jean-Rene Gougeon, who drove the French trotter Nicias Grandchamp in Saturday night's $50,000 International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway, was found guiltless tonight of wrongdoing during that mileand-a-quarter race.

The fashionable Union Club was sued for $1,000,000 yesterday by three neighboring residents who charged that noise from the club's new air-conditioning system was causing them "discomfort, ill health and lack of sleep."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 The arrival in Cuba in the last week of July of fifteen Soviet ships, including five passenger vessels, was reported today by United States officials.
Beau Ideal, Inc., manufacturer of bedspreads and draperies, has leased a floor at 352 Park Avenue South near Twenty-fifth Street, in a move that will expand its production about 50 per cent.

Yonkers Raceway is making a determined effort to bring the Hambletonian back to New York State. It would like to hold harness racing's most celebrated race at Goshen's Good Time Park, which it also operates, starting in 1964.

Directors of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., at a meeting yesterday in Wilmington, Del., elected Lammot du Pont Copeland as the big chemical concern's eleventh president. He succeeds Crawford H. Greenewalt, who had held the post for nearly fifteen years.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP)--The White House has ordered the National Science Foundation to set up general public information urocedures on contracts and research grants.
DEARBORN, Mich., Aug. 20 Everything came up Thunderbird today as the Ford Motor Company staged a preview of its varied Ford division lines.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 20 (UPI) Tommy Aaron's two-run home run touched off a five-run seventh inning tonight that gave the Milwaukee Braves a 9 4 decision over the San Francisco Giants. Warren Spahn pitched all the way for the Braves and gained the 322d victory of his career.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 20--Gimbels' third store on Long Island was opened at the Roosevelt Field shopping center here today.

The United Nations Headquarters in this city needs more room. It has a reasonable amount of space for the work of the Secretariat, but not enough for a membership that has grown from the fifty-one nations that attended the first Assembly in January, 1946, to a present total of 104, which is soon likely to increase to 112 and eventually to at least 120.
The Mets, Manhattan's biggest losers since the Indians, dropped a double-header to the Pirates before 8,214 staunch fans at the Polo Grounds last night.
PHNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 20 (AP) Prince Norodom Sihanouk made a bid today for United States support of his call for a fourteen-nation conference to guard Cambodia's neutrality.
Charles S. McVeigh of 950 Fifth Avenue, a lawyer and former banker, died yesterday at his home after a long illness. He was 79 years old.
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Aug. 20 (AP)--An X-15 had a failure in its electronic brain today while the rocket plane was streaking through the sky.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 James M. Symes, chairman of the Pennsylvania Railroad, sought today to refute charges of "bigness" that had been hurled by opponents of the proposed merger of the Pennsy and the New York Central Railroad.

ALMOST two years ago, when John F. Kennedy and Richard M. Nixon were debating on television during their contest for the Presidency of the United States, the term "gross national product" was an important part of their discussions.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP)--The total national debt has reached $300,000,000,000 for the first time in history, the Treasury said today.

The American Hospital Supply Corporation has purchased for an undisclosed amount of cash the plant, equipment, and inventory of Amsco Laboratories, Inc., a subsidiary of the American Sterilizer Company, Erie, Pa., it was announced yesterday.
Stocks advanced again yesterday in a continuation of last week's rally. Trading expanded as the market posted its eighth gain in the last nine sessions.
CHICAGO, Aug. 20 City, county and state authorities pressed studies and investigations today of charges that a seventeen-unit nursing home chain for elderly people violated health regulations.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 20 An informal organization of educators known as the Boston Area Faculty Group on Public Issues appealed today in an open letter to President Kennedy to adopt a three-point program of defense strategy.
The Democrats are being forced to shorten this year's state convention from three days to two.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20--The State Department consulted United States authorities in Berlin today on ways to diminish tension along the Communist wall that divides the city Officials here were considering moves to assure West Berliners, particularly the younger people, that this country is not indifferent to trouble along the wall.

THE waterfowl situation remains as gloomy and confused as ever. This condition was not alleviated by the announcement of the Federal seasons and limits on ducks and geese. They were, generally, the most restrictive in many decades.

Samuel Knepper, New York realty investor, has purchased the one and two-story taxpayer at Rockaway Beach Boulevard and 116th Street in Rockaway Beach, Queens. The property, which fronts 140 feet on the Boulevard and 159 feet on the street, has eight stores and offices.
ANTHONY (TOUGH TONY) ANASTASIA would probably be turned down if he auditioned to play the part of a dock boss in a Hollywood or television waterfront drama.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) The Defense Department selected the Martin-Marietta Corporation today as the prime contractor for the Titan III booster rocket designed for launching space vehicles.
IN THE old-fashioned country store, foods were sold in bulk and packaged after purchase. They were displayed in barrels, baskets, jars and bins and along wooden counters for all to see and sample.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Aug. 20 (AP)--Bennett Kilpack, a radio actor who for many years played the National Broadcasting Company's "Mr. Keen, Tracer of Lost Persons," died of cancer Friday at the Berkshire Sanitarium here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 James Vincent Piersol, an authority on aviation and assistant public information officer with the Civil Aeronautics Board's Bureau of Safety, died Saturday at Walter Reed Hospital. He was 61 years old.

MUTTONTOWN, L.I., Aug. 20 Ray Hayden, Irish-born assistant at the Glen Oaks Club, led the Long Island Professional Golfers Association championship today. His opening-round 66, five under par, at the new Muttontown Golf and Country Club course, gave him a fivestroke edge.
Anthony (Tough Tony) Anastasia, the Brooklyn waterfront boss, was ousted yesterday from the wage scale committee of the International Longshoremen's Association.

The League of New York Theatres has postponed the formation of a nonprofit central ticket agency. The move, designed to increase attendance in Broadway theatres and to curtail scalping, is now proposed for early next year.
DETROIT, Aug. 20 Dr. Herold C. Hunt, a nationally known educator, suggested today that President Kennedy appoint a task force to establish a national education policy.

The Household Finance Corporation announced yesterday that its net income in the first six months of this year rose slightly to $14,251,337 from $13,463,338 in the same period last year. Share earnings, however, held steady at $1.48.

MANHASSET, L.I., Aug. 20--Abraham Levitt, founder of the building concern of Levitt and Sons, which has constructed more than 60,000 homes on the East Coast, died here today at North Shore Hospital at the age of 82.

"There's a fellow sitting near me who is heavily short of the market, especially Xerox. He's sitting tight hoping for a reaction," said a brokerage firm partner yesterday. That apparently was what many shorts were doing.

Directors of the Republic Steel Corporation reduced yesterday the quarterly dividend to 50 cents a common share from the 75 cents the nation's third largest steel producer had paid since November, 1956.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 The Cuban Government has suspended for fifteen days without pay the head of the nationalized sugar industry and four other high-ranking industrial chiefs for illegally "altering" the supply data for their operations.
LONDON, Aug 21--Sir Winston Churchill returned to his London home today after fifty-four days in Middlesex Hospital convalescing from a fractured thigh. Smoking his ever-present cigar, he smiled,
CHARLES FRIEDMAN, writer and director for Broad way, Hollywood and television, recently described one of the triumphs of his latest avocation, cooking.
Representative Charles A. Buckley scored a major legal victory yesterday in his fight to retain the Democratic leadership of Bronx County despite Mayor Wagner's opposition.
BERLIN, Aug. 21 The Western Allies announced today that they would attempt to go into East Berlin to give medical aid to any refugee wounded by East German guards.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 21 (AP) Racial integration was ordered today for the public schools of Duval, Volusia and Hillsborough counties.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) The Senate Antitrust Subcommittee voted 5 to 3 on party lines today to issue "second chance" subpoenas to four steel companies that had balked at submitting production cost data.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 George P. Shultz, an industrial relations and labor expert, was appointed dean today of the Graduate School of Business at the University of Chicago.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 21 John T. Carpenter Jr., a livestock photographer for magazines, catalogues and exhibitors, died of a heart attack here yesterday in St. Agnes Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 8 Highclere Lane, Valhalla.
The city is investigating the possibility that some property owners have been "kiting" the sales of apartment houses to drive up the rents.

The five-story elevator apartment building containing twenty apartments at 14 and 16 Fifth Avenue, midway in the block between Eighth and Ninth Streets, has been sold by the estate of Eva B. Gebhard Gourgaud.

ONE of the nation's two top ranking tournament bridge players yesterday challenged the other to a full-scale match, along the lines of the highly publicized ones played in the early days of contract bridge thirty-odd years ago, but the challenge seems to have been declined.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., Aug. 21 A collection of aerial photographs that resemble finger paintings, cubist designs, X-ray studies of bone structure and examples of impressionist and surrealist art has been put on display here.

HOLLANDIA, Netherlands New Guinea, Aug. 21 (AP)--Brig. Indar Jit Rikhye of India led a United Nations military team here today and ran into a demonstration by Papuans protesting, "U. N. Don't sell us like animals."
Six new leases in the Empire State Building have been announced by Helmsley-Spear, Inc., the managing agents. Four of the tenants are companies opening offices in New York for the first time.
OFF TO a fresh start for a new season, Bonwit Tel ler has redecorated, revamped and overhauled two floors. In the process, two new departments have been established and two others have been enlarged.
ROANOKE, Va., Aug. 21 (AP) An Oklahoma Congressman warned here today that major oil companies cannot long avoid Congressional investigation of practices he called monopolistic.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 Secretary of State Dean Rusk urgently requested the Soviet Union today to enter four-power discussions in Berlin for the purpose of averting further dangerous incidents along the wall dividing the East and West sectors.
Declines in prices of world sugar and copper futures were the main trading features in a dull day on the New York commodity exchanges.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 21 Urged on by the roars of a crowd of 50,830, Bill Rigney's astounding Angels made an heroic effort tonight to keep aloft in the American League pennant race. They even carried the mighty Yankees into overtime, but there they ran out of heroics.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (UPI) Maremont Corporation announced today the acquisition of two companies engaged in rebuilding automotive parts.

A GAZETTEER describes New Hope, Pa., settled in 1712, as a Bucks County village with a population of just over 1,000, noted as an artists' colony, a paper bag manufacturing and agricultural center on the banks of the Delaware River opposite Lambertville, N.J. It also is

There have been some ugly rumors that New York bus drivers and their passengers do not always exchange pleasantries or exude charm when they meet. So yesterday the Transit Authority signed up Amy Vanderbilt to act as its Impartial Chairman of Etiquette.

- WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UPI)--A panel of economists took the Kennedy Administration to task today for what they called its failure to press antitrust actions against business monopoly with either "vigor or imagination."

Mayor Wagner's bill to establish a minimum wage of $1.25 an hour for employes of private industry and business here was received by the City Council yesterday. It was immediately placed on a legislative schedule calculated to bring about its passage by the Council at a meeting Aug. 30.

Stocks eased yesterday in quieter trading. The action came as neither a surprise nor a particular disappointment; it marked only the second setback in the last ten trading sessions. Since the market began its latest rally nearly...

LISBON, Portugal, Aug. 21 Foreign Minister Alberto Franco Nogueira repeated Portugal's warning today that she may not be the first country to abandon the United Nations but may become "one of the first" to do so.
DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 21 William Atkin, a designer of small sailing and power yachts died yesterday in Stamford. He was 79 years old and lived on Outlook Drive in Noroton.
Twelve comely, athletic young women employes of the Takashimaya department store in Osaka, Japan, arrived here yesterday en route to the world softball championship tournament at Stratford, Conn.

ABOARD NUCLEAR SHIP SAVANNAH at Sea, Aug. 21 (AP)--The atomic reactor that powers this vessel automatically shut down yesterday during a test of a newly modified mechanism for controlling the ship's speed.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 21 The story of Dr. Knox, the nineteenth-century Edinburgh anatomist, has often been told.

MOSCOW, Aug. 21 Maj. Andrian G. Nikolayev and Lieut. Col. Pavel R. Popovich disclosed today that their spaceships had been about five kilometers (a little more than three miles) apart at one point in their flights around the earth.

Two leaders of the reform Democrats charged yesterday that attempts were being made to mislead voters by presenting Representative Leonard Farbstein, Democrat of the Nineteenth Congressional District in Manhattan, as a reform candidate.
DUBLIN, Aug. 21--Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower held up Dublin's rush-hour traffic today when he arrived for a three-day visit.
HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 21 (AP) Jim Beatty reeled off the mile in 3 minutes 56.3 seconds today the fastest ever by an American citizen and missed by less than two seconds his bid for a world record.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Aug. 21--Parliament gave initial approval today to broad new legislation that could outlaw further African nationalist campaigns in Southern Rhodesia.
The favored tryout stations near Broadway are receiving competition as producers continue exploring new frontiers from Canada to the West Coast.
The three Allied commandants and the Governing Mayor met today to discuss the consequences of the most recent murder of an East German refugee by East German border guards.

The Anaconda Company cleared an indicated $15,170,000, equal to $1.41 a share, in second quarter of this year. These results topped both the $13,900,000 and $1.30 reported for the first quarter this year and the indicated $14,830,000, or $1.39 a share, for the second quarter of 1961.

MUTTONTOWN, L.I., Aug. 31 Tom Nieporte added the Long Island Professional Golfers Association championship to his Long Island open title today. Nieporte had a 54-hole total of 215 after a morning round of 68 and an afternoon 74 at the Muttontown Golf and Country Club. This gave him a two-stroke victory on his first crack at the tournament.

Alexander Taylor Mason Van Rensselaer, author of several books and advertising manager for a number of publishing houses, died Monday night in Roosevelt Hospital after a short illness. He was 70 years old.
The Federal Aviation Agency has apparently alleviated airplane noise in one area of the city only to find that it has created a new noise problem in another.
Theodore R. Kupferman, former legislative assistant to the late Stanley M. Isaacs, was unanimously elected by the City Council yesterday to Mr. Isaacs' seat.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP)--Makers of trade-marked prepparations for sale over the counter joined prescription medicine producers today in opposing some features of the Administration's drug-control bill.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 The giant Pennsylvania Railroad clashed head on today with the much smaller New Haven Railroad over the best approach to solving what is euphemistically called the New England railroad problem.
DEARBORN, Mich., Aug. 21 The Ford Motor Company has moved its Lincoln-Mercury division up a notch in the automotive ranking.
LONDON, Aug. 21 Buyers were hesitant and selective on the stock market today. Small declines outnumbered gains.
The Police Department promised yesterday not to punish the cab driver who has been sought since he drove a smallpox victim from New York International Airport to Grand Central Terminal on Aug. 11.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 Adlai E. Stevenson told 7,923 temporary Federal employes working here today that he wished they could all join his staff in New York.
TRENTON, Aug, 21 Gov. Richard J. Hughes blocked the extradition of two escaped prisoners today. He placed the men one from South Carolina and the other from Florida on indefinite parole.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) is well prepared to maintain its position in the domestic and international oil industry, David A. Shepard, an executive vice president of the company, said yesterday.
The New York Shipping Association and the International Longshoremen's Association exchanged sharp words yesterday at their sixth bargaining session on a new three-year contract.
MONTREAL, Aug. 21 Financing of the Wabush Mines $235,000,000 iron-ore project in the Newfoundland-Labrador region was announced here today.

The National Steel Corporation announced yesterday that volume production had been started on a new process employing a pure acrylic adhesive to bond a rugged layer of colorable polyvinyl fluoride film to galvanized steel.
Cotton futures were unchanged to 20 cents a bale up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

ATHENS, Aug, 21 The principal weapon of the cold war is propaganda, which is now deliberately employed by both power blocs and the neutrals in between to encourage, discourage, incite or invite friends or opponents, as the case may be.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) The Agriculture De partment announced today that it would restrict mainland production of sugar cane, but not of sugar beets, next year.
The Wellington Fund sold 340,000 shares of Martin-Marietta Corporation stock Aug. 6, 7 and 8, Wall Street sources said yesterday.

The nation's highest voltage experimental electric power line will be installed in a section of the Bonneville Power Administration's system in Oregon. This was announced yesterday by Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company, which will supply the equipment.

ONE way of introducing Brian Glanville to American readers would be to say that he is the English Philip Roth Both are young men under 30. Both are immensely talented and capable of better work than they have yet produced.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug 21 The Democratic State Platform Advisory Committee heard recommendations today for the revision of the state formula for distributing seats in the Legislature, increased state aid for education and the establishment of a uniform procedure for voter registration.
A debonair Australian livetock dealer with $18,000 in bogus $20 bills in his possession was seized here yesterday aboard a plane about to take off for London.
RIO DE JANIERO, Aug. 21 The casualty toll aboard the DC-8 jet that plunged into Guanabara Bay last night with 104 persons was reported today to have been fifteen persons killed and one missing.
"Catch-22," Joseph Heller's novel of the Army Air Forces in World War II, will be turned into a play and a film by Columbia Pictures.
HONG KONG, Aug. 21--Informed sources here believe that Communist China will maintain the present concentration of military forces along the Fukien coast opposite Taiwan within the immediate future.
TRENTON, Aug. 21 New Jersey telephone users will save $5,600,000 annually as a result of a voluntary agreement between the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company and the State Board of Public Utilities.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 The top command of the major international financial organizations is being changed.
LONDON, Aug. 21--The British Government refused today to permit an anti-Fascist rally to be held in London's Trafalgar Square because it might cause "grave inconvenience" to the public.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UPI) Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara said today the United States planned to spend more money on huge booster rockets in an attempt to overcome the Soviet Union "substantial" lead in some space developments.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Aug. 21 (AP) Former Gov. Milward L. Simpson had a slight lead tonight over Kenny Sailors, 41year-old former basketball star, for the Republican nomination for Senate in Wyoming's primary election.

HOUSTON. Tex., Aug. 21 (AP) Lieut. Comdr. M. Scott Carpenter reviewed today the final harried moments of his May 24 space trip and said time had just slipped away and he had had to rush his return to earth.

Borough President Abe Stark of Brooklyn expressed doubts yesterday about the Mobilization for Youth program, under which $13,000,000 will be spent on Manhattan's Lower East Side to combat juvenile delinquency.
Dissenting views by eleven of the seventeen Senators on the Senate Finance Committee regarding the Revenue Act of 1962, which the committee nevertheless approved last
Dr. Albert R. Hibbs, scientist and educator, has been named host for "Exploring," a children's show than will start Oct. 13 on National, Broadcasting Company television.
TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 13 For the first time in their history, five major Iranian towns in the Persian Gulf area are going to have a modern power supply soon.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21--The America's Cup defense aspirations of Columbia and Easterner ended today. Both yachts were ruled out of further contention after they had absorbed bad beatings at the hands of their adversaries in high winds and forbidding seas.

THE lowly paper shopping bag, the ubiquitous carry all of the overburdened American, is no longer simply a means of carrying a lot of packages. It has become a status symbol for both the concern that gives it away or sells it and the customer who carries it.
The chairman, president and two directors of the Bon Ami Company were accused in State Supreme Court yesterday of embezzling at least $500,000 of the company's funds.

Moise Tshombe, who is tactfully referred to by U.N. Acting Secretary General Thant as the "provincial President" of Katanga, has reached a point at which he must definitely decide whether or not he intends to cooperate with the United Nations and with the central Government of Premier Adoula at Leopoldville.
The ornamental bronze traffic lights that for thirty-two years have graced Fifth Avenue as part of that thoroughfare's noted decor are about to disappear.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 15--In the midst of its third straight unsatisfactory harvest, the Tito regime has decided to take direct action to enlarge the "Socialist sector" of Yugoslav agriculture.
The Federal Aviation Agency has again cleared the Boeing Vertol 107 helicopters of New York Airways as safe for operation in this area, an agency official said yesterday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (UPI) Grain futures were uneven today on the Board of Trade as dealers watched farm legislation developments in Congress.
The Museum of Modern Art has barred its circulating exhibitions of paintings, sculpture and photographs from display before segregated groups.

Albuquerque, N.M., borrowed $7,759,000 on five bond issues yesterday. Halsey, Stuart Co. and First Boston Corporation submitted the best bid for $3,800,000 of storm sewer bonds and $886,000 of sanitary sewer bonds.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 President Kennedy pressed Senate leaders today for passage of the foreign trade expansion bill, already voted by the House.
NEWPORT, R.I., . Aug. 21--The news that Columbia had been eliminated as a contender for the America's Cup she had defended so valiantly four years ago hit her crew hard.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 The bipartisan coalition supporting Thurgood Marshall's confirmation as a Federal judge drafted plans today to force a floor vote on his nomination within a week, perhaps sooner.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug, 21--Little Leaguers who speak only Japanese, Little Leaguers who speak only Spanish and Little Leaguers who speak only English but ordinarily watch only French television helped make the opening of today's miniature world series a blend of boys, baseball and bedlam.
Three successive cable failures were blamed by the Consolidated Edison Company yesterday for a major power blackout in Brooklyn Monday night.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 The Administration's latest estimate of the war in South Vietnam is that the United Statesbacked Vietnamese forces and Communist guerrillas have fought to a temporary draw.
Kerstin Hesselgren, the first woman to sit in the Swedish Parliament and a leader in social reform, died Sunday at her home in Stockholm. She was 90 years old.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 21--Chancellor Adenauer announced today that he would send separate letters to the heads of government of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union expressing the West German Government's "grave concern" over the Berlin situation.
The market for debt securities quieted yesterday. Corporates and municipals continued upward in price. Governments were mixed.
The following listing includes events that have been selected by New York Times critics. For children of all ages unless otherwise noted.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 21 Argentina's Economics Minister, Alvaro C. Alsogoray, has delivered the most searing public attack yet by a Government official against wrangling military leaders here.

Joseph Falcone, sought for four years for questioning about the meeting in 1957 of underworld leaders in Apalachin, N.Y., told the State Investigation Commission yesterday that he had been in Florida taking the sun for his health during most of that time.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 21 The City Council took the first step today toward a community renewal plan that would redevelop sixteen blocks paralleling the beach. Most of this resort's hotels, motels and guest houses are in the sector.
DETROIT, Aug. 21 The president of the American Federation of Teachers called today for an expanded program of organizing the unorganized teachers of the nation.
The directors of Globe-Union, Inc., Milwaukee, proposed yesterday a three-for-two stock split, and announced their intention to increase the quarterly cash dividend by 10 per cent on the new shares.

BEING men of infinite wisdom, the schedule-makers deftly arranged that the Giants and the Dodgers would have a day of rest yesterday. This will enable the two teams to recoup their strength, deploy their forces and stock up their ammunition before launching successive assaults on the virtually impregnable fortress of the New York Mets, a ball club that terrifies the entire league, especially its manager, Casey Stengel.
The president of Universal American Corporation has agreed to sell back to the company certain assets to satisfy a stockholder's suit.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 21 Boro Jovanovic and Nikola Pilic of Yugoslavia were on the court for nearly two and a half hours today in winning their first tennis match on American turf.
