KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 21 The "largest scheduled power exchanges ever to take place between electric systems in this country" were announced today by the Tennessee Valley Authority and the Mississippi Power and Light Company.

A committee has been announced for the sixth annual event for the benefit of the International Cultural Center for Youth in Jerusalem. This year's event has been named the Star-Spangled Ball and will be a salute to the culture of the United States. It will take place at the Waldorf-Astoria on Nov. 7.

LUCIAN CARY, an authoritative writer on fire arms and shooting, points out in an article in the September issue of True Magazine what is generally unrecognized among the shooting fraternity. This is that while Americans are great trap shots on their home grounds, they are outclassed by the rest of the world.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 21 Chicha, of the El Peco Ranch, won the Saratoga Springs Handicap, a $10,000 purse for fillies and mares that served as the feature attraction on today's program.
WINCHESTER, England, Aug. 21 Detective work by a British archaeologist has disclosed the buried foundations of one, and possibly two, large Saxon minsters, or churches.

NAPLES, Italy, Aug. 21 Two rolling earth tremors ten minutes apart spread panic in Naples and killed six persons in southern Italy tonight. Three died of heart attacks. A 15-yearold girl was killed when a cornice of a building fell on her.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 21 President Moise Tshombe of Katanga Province said today that his secessionist regime would consider reintegration with the Congo as "an autonomous region" under a new federal constitution.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 21 Richard M. Nixon and Gov. Edmund G. Brown have reached an impasse in their negotiations for television debates in their contest for the governorship.

In theory, nothing could be simpler than advertising through the mails. A letter is dispatched to the potential customer. He opens it, reads it and hopefully fills out the order form and encloses his check.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 The statistics that tend to indicate general economic trends in advance were pointing up more than down in July, according to the incomplete information now available.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn. Aug. 21 (UPI) Management of General Mills, Inc., told stockholders today that despite the company's lower earnings in the fiscal year ended May 31, the outlook was brighter than in the past several years and indicated that the present dividend payment was secure.
EAST ISLIP, L.I., Aug. 21 Entire families joined the search today for 3-year-old Stephen Papol, who was lost Sunday at a Cub Scout outing in Heckscher State Park.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 21 President Tshombe's statement in Elisabethville to day that he was ready to discuss Katanga's federation with the rest of the Congo aroused no immediate enthusiasm in the United Nations Secretariat.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 The Senate wrote into its new farm bill today provisions designed to whittle down the vast surpluses of livestock feed grains held by the Government.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) John C. Bagwell, the Agriculture Department's general counsel denied today that a memorandum he had prepared on cotton land transactions was intended to "bail out" Billie Sol Estes when his transactions were questioned.

If there are any such things as baseball laws of improbability, the Mets defied at least a half-dozen of them while splitting a double-header with the Pittsburgh Pirates at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 21 A day that held little promise for good sailing in the morning turned into a beautiful yachting afternoon today as Manhasset Bay Yacht Club opened its thirtieth annual race week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UPI ) The United States will be ready to consider seriously a ban on nuclear tests in the at mosphere, space and underwater without demanding inspections against cheating unless a complete ban is agreed on within a few weeks, informed sources said tonight.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 The railroads asked a Federal Court today to speed action on proposed work-rule changes aimed at eliminating "featherbedding."
AT a very early age Theodore Roosevelt Kupferman started taking part in political campaigns.

If there are any such things as baseball laws of improbability, the Mets defied at least a half-dozen of them while splitting a double-header with the Pittsburgh Pirates at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 21 A day that held little promise for good sailing in the morning turned into a beautiful yachting afternoon today as Manhasset Bay Yacht Club opened its thirtieth annual race week.

Following are the texts of Mayor Wagner's message to Eric J. Treulich, City Council majority leader, on local wage legislation and of the summary of provisions of the proposed local law setting minimum scales:
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Aug. 22 The split among the leaders in the Negro community here over last Saturday's integration rally was partly healed last night.
LONDON, Aug. 22 Dr. Robert A. Soblen today resumed his challenge to the deportation order under wrhich Britain hopes to return him to the United States.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22 (AP) A series of earthjarring explosions killed four workmen in a sewer tunnel forty feet under the Philadelphia street today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 15:
ELIZABETH HARDWICK can draw a Steinberg caricature with words. Look: "Harvard and Boston," she says, "are two ends of one mustache."
LONDON, Aug. 22 Most industrial shares advanced on the stock market today.

Met spines stiffened at the sight of Jack Sanford and the rest of the San Francisco Giants at the Polo Grounds last night. Before a roaring throng of 33,569, Manager Casey Stengel's National League tail-enders downed the second-place Giants, 5-4.
Production of electric power in the country totaled 16,838,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended Aug. 18, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 President Kennedy urged the Eighty-seventh Congress today to act favorably on the "many bills of great importance" that will come before it in the next few days and so leave behind "a very impressive record." [Opening statement, Page 14.]

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 22 U Thant, the Acting Secretary General, presented today a 1963 budget calling for $86,649,500, an increase of $4,500,000 over the 1962 budget for the United Nations. Mr. Thant warned that the financial condition of the organization was "a matter of grave concern."

A great deal of news is being published in the American press these days about Cuba, and it is entirely bad of food shortages, industrial breakdowns, short agricultural crops, a switch from cooperatives to collective farms, executions, sabotage.

OF the scores of international dishes that have enriched and added interest to the American table within the last few decades, there may be none with a wider appeal than curries. An enthusiasm for curried dishes seems to be national and curries are as welcome in Wichita as in Westchester.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 22 The Board of Education of Lockland announced today that the Lord's Prayer would be led by teachers in public schools, beginning with the opening day of school on Sept. 5.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 22 The new Hollywood elite is the "pre-sold" writer. The cachets and privileges of this group were discussed today by one of its prominent members, Leonard Spigelgass, author of the hit play, "Majority of One."

FORGET Rossellini's "Open City" and any other films you may have seen about the hardships and tensions among the people in occupied Rome during World War II. Conditions were tough, but everybody had a jolly, jouncy, topsy-turvy time while the Nazis were in control of the Eternal City even the Nazis.

Stocks rose sharply yesterday in more active trading. It was a decided resumption of the summer rally that had been curtailed briefly on Tuesday. In fact, it was the biggest gain on average in a week.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 22 The Grand American trapshooting tournament is something of a corn-fed state fair punctuated by unceasing gunfire from eight o'clock in the morning until light begins to fail.
AVELLINO, Italy, Aug. 22 A severe rainstorm added today to the misery of several thousand people left homeless by yesterday's earthquakes. The quakes shook all of southern Italy.
Two candidates for the Democratic nomination for Governor gave suggestions yesterday about the platform on which they would like to run.
An upstate handyman was indicted yesterday on a charge of possessing counterfeit $20 bills described as "atrociously amateur samples."

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22 (UPI) District Court Judge C. William Kraft Jr. ruled today that the Federal Government could have access to grand jury records in preparation of its damage suits against the General Electric Company and other electrical concerns convicted of price fixing.
Consulting engineers yesterday advised the city to go ahead with plans for industrial parks in Queens and on Staten Island.
The Administrative Board of the Judicial Conference of the State of New York does hereby prescribe the following rules, effective September 1, 1962:

Jofa, Inc., one of the country's oldest and largest wholesalers of drapery and upholstery fabrics, has leased a floor at 250 Park Avenue South, corner of Twentieth Street. The floor contains 9,500 square feet of space and will be used for additional warehousing.

The simmering Berlin crisis appears to be rushing toward a new climax. For Soviet Russia has now taken further unilateral action that bears ominous resemblance to its maneuver in 1948 that culminated in the Berlin blockade.
The Soviet Union's announcement yesterday that it had "abolished" the post of Soviet military commandant in Berlin marked the end of a fruitless seventeen-year effort.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 22 An accidental switch in the mailing of diplomatic correspondence has made public a private anti-Western account of the last General Assembly by the permanent representative of Ceylon.

Ray Cannavaro, an engineer with a flair for the dramatic, scrambled up a ladder to the marquee of the Brooklyn Paramount Theatre yesterday and slid six letters into place. To passers-by, they announced: "THE END."

IN the Soviet Union there are at least a score of players some recognized as grand masters, others little known in this country whose playing strength is no whit behind that of the five Soviet stars who played in the Challengers' Tournament in Curacao.
STORRS, Conn., Aug. 22 The "frustration tolerance" of 400 family life specialists and their children was tested here at the opening of the annual meeting of The National Council on Family Relations.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 Senator Clair Engle, Democrat of California, accused George M. Humphrey's Hanna companies today of deliberately misrepresenting costs to the Government at least twice.
Middle South Utilities, Inc., has named Gerald L. Andrus to become its second president. He succeeds Edgar M. Dixon, who died on Aug. 2. Middle South has no chairman.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 22 Governor Rockefeller suggested today that neighboring states could discourage their teen-age drivers from visiting New York State taverns by enacting more stringent traffic laws.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 The definite and detailed offer of negotiation of the Congo impasse by Moise Tshombe of Katanga offers the U.N. and the principal backer of its Congo policy, the Kennedy Administration, an opportunity to substitute equitable statesmanship for incessant threats of, and resorts to, armed compulsion.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 Two United States nuclear-powered submarines have made a "historic rendezvous" at the North Pole, President Kennedy announced today.
TRENTON, Aug. 22 The New Jersey Turnpike Authority is considering adding four new lanes for buses and trucks and two new bridges to its toll road.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22--The Senate passed a new farm bill today that falls short of the production controls sought by President Kennedy.

LaVerne Madigan, executive director of the Association on American Indian Affairs, was killed Tuesday in a fall from a horse while vacationing with her family in Orleans, Vt. She was in her early forties.
Philharmonic Hall, scheduled to be the scene of the most dazzling opening night in New York's cultural history one month from today, is at the moment an architect's and contractor's nightmare.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 22--Giora Josephthal, Israeli Minister of Development and Housing, died this morning of a heart attack in Lucerne, Switzerland, the Israeli Government announced today. He was 50 years old.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug. 22 Grand Master Arthur Bisguier of New York, Grand Master Robert Byrne of Indianapolis and Stephen Jones of Austin, Tex., are tied for the lead in the annual United States Open Chess Championship Tournament here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 The United States is "well behind" the Soviet Union in the space race, President Kennedy acknowledged today. But he repeated his belief that the nation would forge ahead of the Russians before the end of this decade.

WILTON, Conn., Aug. 22 This town's annual Yankee Fair on Saturday, its nineteenth, will undoubtedly be like the town well organized, determinedly Early American and, if other years are any gauge, quite prosperous.
Today's International Edition of The New York Times carries several articles transmitted from this city to Paris by way of Telstar.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 Allan Lawrence Pope, United States flier serving a life sentence in an Indonesian prison, was released July 2 and has been back in the United States for several weeks.
The Continental Can Company yesterday rescinded increases in the prices of kraft grocery bags and wrapping paper that had been scheduled to take effect Sept. 10.
The full development of the City University will cost $400,000,000 and tape thirteen years, the City Planning Commission was told yesterday.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 22--Argentina had a new army Chief of Staff today to replace a recently appointed staff chief who resigned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 Arthur Brewster Emmons 3d, Deputy Director of the State Department's Office of Southwest Pacific Affairs, died today in George Washington Hospital. He would have been 52 years old on Aug. 30.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 22 Exactly thirty days after the signing of the Geneva accords on Laos, Gen. Phoumi Nosavan, Right-Wing leader, released six North Vietnamese Communists held by the royal army for as much as two years.
MOSCOW, Aug. 22 The Soviet Government abolished today the office of the Soviet commandant of troops in East Berlin.

LOWELL, Mass., Aug. 22 (UPI) Vito (Babe) Parilli threw one touchdown pass and ran for another tonight to lead the Boston Patriots to a 17-10 victory over the New York Titans in an exhibition game between the two American Football League teams.
VIENNA, Aug. 22 The Hungarian regime of Premier Janos Kadar has smashed a revolt against it by high Government officials and some generals, reliable sources reported here today.
BONN, Aug. 22--Rudolf Alexander Schroeder, a poet, died today at a hospital in Bad Wiessee, Bavaria, after a brief illness. He was 84 years old.
The Defense Ministry of the U.S.S.R., in conformity with a decision of the Soviet Government, has ordered the abolishing of the commandant's office of the garrison of Soviet troops in Berlin.
Luther H. Hodges, the Secretary of Commerce, has written an account of his years as Governor of North Carolina called "Businessman in the State House."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 President Kennedy said today he had received assurances from the Senate leadership that Thurgood Marshall's nomination to the United States Circuit Court of Appeals would be taken up on the floor before Congress adjourned.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 Senator John L. McClellan said today that apparently either the Secretary or the Under Secretary of Agriculture had tried to help Billie Sol Estes.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 22 The Tennessee Democratic Executive Committee declined today to certify a nominee for Congress for the Fifth District (Nashville), leaving this place open on the party's ticket for the November general election.
Mrs. Ely Jacques Kahn, wife of the architect, died yesterday afternoon of a heart attack in her home at 1185 Park Avenue. She was 72 years old.

A sudden change has affected the direction and sponsorship of "God Bless Our Bank," in which Ann Sothern will return to Broadway. The staging will be handled by Daniel Mann rather than Burgess Meredith.
LISBON, Portugal, Aug. 22 A pamphlet advocating a liberal, pro-Western policy for Portugal and enlightened emancipation of her African territories is stirring public opinion here.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 22 Former President Juscelino Kubitschek has urged President Kennedy to call a meeting of Latin-American leaders to draw up a political doctrine for the Alliance for Progress.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 22 The Government condemned tonight the abolition of the Soviet commandant's office in Berlin as "illegal and arbitrary."
MOSCOW, Aug. 22--Premier Khrushchev asserted today that the United States was "in a state of lethargic sleep."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 President Kennedy said today he "would hope" to talk with Premier Khrushchev should the Soviet leader attend the autumn meeting of the United Nations General Assembly in New York.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy reported today that identical bidding on government contracts "appears to be less frequent than had been thought."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 Railway labor undertook today to discount any benefits from a union of the Pennsylvania and New York Central railroads.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP)--The Senate took up a drug control bill today and entered into a debate-limitation agreement that should bring a final vote tomorrow.
ALGIERS, Aug. 22--The rivalry between military commanders and the Political Bureau, headed by Vice Premier Ahmed Ben Bella, appeared today to have reached a showdown stage.

The Board of Education has wisely named a full-time director of staff relations to develop sound policies, conduct union negotiations and carry on the day-to-day task of administering contracts and processing grievances.
The bond market held firm yesterday in the face of two large new offerings.
An alleged attacker in Central Park and an alleged moneysnatcher in Washington Square met unpleasant surprises last night. Their victims turned out to be young patrolmen disguised as women.
Two teacher's who were suspended in 1955 for falsely swearing that they were not members of the Communist party were dismissed by the Board of Education last night.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 22 The Angels lost their second straight game to the front-running Yankees tonight and this time Bill Rigney's cast had the good sense not to get killed in the operation.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22 (UPI) The Philadelphia, Phillies defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 5 1, tonight on Chris Short's three-hitter. It was the Dodgers' eighth loss in their last eleven games.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 22 Porterhouse, entered in the race only two hours before, drew the pole today for the $25,000 Gold Division of the Challenge Cup Saturday night at Roosevelt Raceway. This is the sequel to the $50,000 International held here last Saturday.
PARIS, Aug. 22--President de Gaulle emerged unscathed tonight from a hail of submachine-gun bullets fired at his car in a Paris suburb.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 22 The final trials to choose a 12Meter yacht to defend the America's Cup, started eight days ago, resume tomorrow with two of the four boats still in contention.

SEVERAL recently published books are attracting attention among dog owners. They cover a variety of subjects behavior, care, training, field work and dealing with the problem dog. With the field trial season rapidly approaching, ...

The results of a four-month study of the nation's commercial banks will be published next month, James J. Saxon, Controller of the Currency, said yesterday. Mr. Saxon ap pointed twenty-four bankers in April to determine why commercial banking has grown more slowly than the economy generally.

The name of Abilities, Inc., the Long Island manufacturing concern that is a pioneer in the field of giving disabled persons an opportunity for gainful employment, is to appear on a product for the first time.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 22 Twenty-one years after she won the first of her thirteen national doubles championships, Mrs. Margaret du Pont is still a formidable foe on the tennis court.
MILFORD, Mich., Aug. 22 Chevrolet expects to retain its automotive leadership in 1963 by adopting its competitors' best weapons.

A Democratic state ticket headed by United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau for Governor and District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor for Senator was proposed yesterday by William F. Luddy, Westchester County Democratic chairman.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 Vice President Johnson left today for a nineteen-day fencemending tour of the Middle East and southern Europe.
Twenty-three years after Generalissimo Francisco Franco's civil war victory, Spain is under going a profound social, political and economic transformation.
Federal agents are making gains in the East in their campaign against the moonshine business but are encountering difficulties in the South.
Cotton futures were 20 cents a bale down to 25 cents up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
FAKENHAM, England, Aug. 21--Four months ago the people of Fakenham predicted sadly that cattle soon would be grazing on what was left of the United States air base at Sculthorpe, seven miles away.

H. Bruce Palmer, former president of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company, said yesterday that an irreconcilable difference in management philosophy led to his unexpected resignation from the Newark concern on Aug. 10.
BERLIN, Thursday, Aug. 23--Two United States Army cars entered East Berlin early today after the Soviet Union's abolition of its commandant there took effect at midnight.

CONSIDERING the slightly bedraggled state of American tennis in recent years, it is almost consoling to be forced to take a glimpse into the past. The backward look was inspired last week by the enshrinement in the tennis Hall of Fame at Newport of three great players of yesteryear. They are Ellsworth Vines, Johnny Doeg and Helen Jacobs.

Anthony Anastasia, leader of the Brooklyn waterfront, will be tried early next month by his fellow unionists on charges of "sabotaging" the wage-scale committee of the International Longshoremen's Association.
A top steel executive said yesterday that Republic Steel Corporation's recent dividend cut had disproved President Kennedy's 1961 prediction that "good profits" in steel lay ahead.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22 Senator Barry Goldwater, in a new role as a theatre and television critic, said tonight that the Greeks would have had a hard word for American television: barbaric.

H. F. Construction, Inc., a company headed by Sidney Fetner and Herman Hinderstein, has bought land at the northwest corner of Tratman Avenue and Rolland Street, the Bronx, for improvement with a seven-story apartment building. The fifty-five apartments will contain two and a half to five rooms.
Two appointments were made yesterday at Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation.
Bronx Democrats opposed to Representative Charles A. Buckley moved quickly yesterday to upset a Board of Elections ruling disqualifying nearly 500 of their candidates for county committee.
THE PRESIDENT I have several announcements to make.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Aug. 22 (UPI) Former Gov. Milward Simpson of Wyoming, who earned the right yesterday to challenge for the Senate the man who ousted him from the statehouse four years ago, called today for an end to "immature leadership and the left-leaning goal of the Kennedy Administration."

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 22 The Gateway is Edin burgh's own repertory company and its inclusion in the official festival programs of the past seemed more a tribute to native patriotism than to the depth of its performances.
Judges have been told to keep their courtrooms open at least six hours a day under the reorganization of New York courts beginning Sept. 1.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP) A broad general advance in wheat futures competed with close-out dealings in August soybeans for speculative interest today on the Board of Trade.
Three Brooklyn youths were arrested on homicide charges yesterday after a 16-year-old boy had been shot to death Tuesday night in a juvenile gang battle.
AN active bridge league in this region is composed of six golf clubs in Nassau County: Engineer's, Glen Oaks, Woodmere, Glen Head, Pine Hollow and Middle Bay.
Eastern Air Lines is scheduled to resume full jet service today despite a continuing strike of flight engineers that began two months ago.
The suburban community of Short Hills, N.J., about five miles west of Newark, will have a new commercial bank on Nov. 1.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 22 The calm, good humored detachment of Gunapala Piyasena Malalasekera, the head of the Ceylonese delegation, was put to a severe test by one of the most embarrassing misadventures that can befall a professional diplomat.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 22 The Little League world series put on an Oriental ceremony today before a nip-andtuck ball game in which tiny Japanese players from Tokyo were edged by Monterrey, Mexico. The score was 3 2.
A public offering of $106,210,000 of new Public Housing Authority bonds, representing thirty-four local housing agencies, was offered on the bond market at competitive bidding yesterday.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 22 Thoroughbred horse racing presented in the traditional and championship atmosphere of Saratoga Springs, delighted a crowd of 14,804 today.

GENEVA, Aug. 22 Delegates at the seventeen-nation disarmament conference, with only an East-West deadlock to show for five months of work, voted today to recess from Sept. 8 to Nov. 12 and let the United Nations try to find a way to break the deadlock.
The stock of the International Business Machines Corporation made news yesterday when it crossed 400. It closed at 409, up 16 points, its highest point since May 24.

MONTREAL, Aug. 22 (UPI) Doug Harvey, the New York Rangers' playing coach last season, disclosed today he would accept a $30,000 offer to end his short-lived retirement and return to the Rangers as a player.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP) International Harvester Company reported today a sales gain of 12.6 per cent for the first nine months of its fiscal year and a net income of $44,240,000 compared with $39,046,000 in 1961. The earnirgs were equal to $2.83 a common share, against $2.46 in the 1961 period.
WESTON, Conn., Aug. 22 Dr. Elbert K. Fretwell, educator and former head of the Boy Scouts of America, died here today in his home on Cedar Lane. He was 83 years old.
Cocoa, copper and world sugar futures led a general retreat on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22--Following is the summer edition of The Dispensable News, a service for returning vacationists who have lost touch with the world situation.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 22 Eight of twenty starts showed repeat winners this afternoon as 176 yachts sailed in the second round of Manhasset Bay's thirtieth annual Race Week.
ALTHOUGH wash-and-wear cotton garments offer the advantage of little ironing, they do require a certain amount of special treatment.

Defiance Industries, Inc., a, diversified manufacturing company based in Defiance, Ohio, has won control of the B.S.F. Company, a holding company based in New York and Wilmington, Del. B.S.F. controls nearly 35 per cent of the stock of the American...
The Racine, Sturtevant, Wis., Unified School District 1 said it would sell $10,025,000 of bonds, due from 1963 to 1982, on Sept. 6.
Atlas General Industries, Inc., has signed a financing agreement and an option to purchase a substantial interest in International Fabric Molders, Inc.
A decline of 707,000 barrels in the country's gasoline stocks in the week ended Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.
E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., announced yesterday that it had been awarded a basic patent covering the production of polypropylene resin.
The 132-year-old Navy Hydrographic Office was quietly transformed last month to a new agency one with a name that meets the nation's burgeoning interest in "the seas around us."
The merged labor movement's only Negro vice president defended the International Ladies Garments Workers Union yesterday against charges of discriminating against Negroes.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., Aug. 22--Three-year-old Stephen Papol was found alive this morning in the storm-soaked underbrush of Heckscher State Park after a three-day search. His clothes were in tatters and his body was a mass of scratches and insect bites.

The American and National Broadcasting Companies withdrew yesterday from a plan to make network television time available to state and local candidates in the coming election campaign. The Columbia Broadcasting System had rejected the proposal earlier.

The fifth annual Spoleto Festival of Two Worlds Ball will be held in the ballroom of the Plaza on Nov. 15. Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Heinz 2d are again sponsoring the event for the benefit of the Festival Foundation, Inc., the organization that supports Gian Carlo Menotti's Festival of Two Worlds, held every summer in Spoleto, Italy.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (UPI) Eddie Kasko powered the Cincinnati Reds to a 9-5 victory over the Chicago Cubs today with a grand-slam home run in the tenth inning that ended a game in which forty-two players were used.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 22 (UPI) Mike Hershberger's homer off Hoyt Wilhelm with two out in the ninth inning gave the Chicago White Sox a 7-6 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.
When David Cattanach was hit on the head in Central Park on Monday night, it was generally assumed that he had been mugged even though he saw no one and was not robbed.

Political magazines have never received much aid or solace from Madison Avenue. To most advertising agency then, politics means controversy and controversy means possible troubles with clients or pressure groups.

The Harvey Phillips Corporation, a company engaged in trading and processing seaweed for use in food and other products, has leased space for an executive office in 375 Park Avenue at Fifty-second Street. The concern is the representa
Brokerage firms are long on opinions and usually short on surveys. In fact, survey-taking is quite rare among Wall Streeters.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., Aug. 23--Wearing a pair of borrowed golf shoes proved no deterrent to Bill Mangin today as he won the William Beers Memorial tournament.

IN September of 1957 the Giants bade farewell to the Polo Grounds. It was an occasion that dripped with nostalgia and gushed with sentiment. But the Giants bade farewell to the Polo Grounds all over again yesterday and not a tear was shed. In fact, the great event virtually escaped unnoticed.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23-- Rail-freight movements last week moved ahead of the preceding week's volumes but were down from the similar week last year. Truck tonnage rose on the two levels.

The Lionel Corporation announced yesterday it had contracted to sell the physical assets and inventory of its subsidiary, Hathaway Instruments, Inc., Denver, Colo., to a group of investors headed by the GulfSouthwest Capital Corporation of Houston, Tex.

There was a terse news bulletin out of Boston yesterday announcing that Paul Pender, the middleweight champion of Massachusetts, New York and Europe, would defend his title in Boston Garden on Nov. 2 against a Puerto Rican named Jos Torres. This news did not jolt the Dow-Jones stock averages. But it was important to Torres.
A Federal judge yesterday frustrated a maritime union's attempt to erect legal safeguards around the jobs of 250 seamen employed on Government missile-tracking ships.
A series of highly inflammatory anti-religious essays written by Mark Twain in his later years will be made public for the first time on Sept. 21.

President de Gaulle lives dangerously. He escaped a hail of machine-gun bullets on Wednesday, presumably fired by terrorists of the Secret Army Organization (O.A.S.). This was not the first attempt and, unhappily, it is not likely to be the last.
A major Hungarian Communist policy statement offers reconciliation to past enemies of socialism in Hungary, greater literary and artistic freedom and an end of discrimination against nonproletarians.
Dr. Frank Weitenkampf, former curator of prints for the New York Public Library, died yesterday in his home at 45 Fifth Avenue. He was 96 years old on Aug. 13.

A TOUCH of color in the kitchen, a bit of fantasy in the study or an interesting object in the living room can be a refreshing addition to the home. With this in mind, Ohrbach's has assembled a new group of imported accessories designed to give the d cor a lift.
LONDON, Aug. 23--Demand increased on the stock market today. Almost every important section advanced.
After a month-long stock battle and a $4,000,000 investment, Defiance Industries, Inc., yesterday was installed at the helm of the B.S.F. Company.

BOSTON, Aug. 23--Irving Fine, the composer, died today of a heart attack at Beth Israel Hospital at the age of 47. He was Walter W. Naumburg Professor of Music at Brandeis University and chairman of its School of Creative Arts.
Only 3,000 taxable cigars were imported by this country from Cuba in the first half of 1962 compared with 4,200,000 in the initial half of 1961 and with 9,200,000 two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP)--More than three times the 309 channels now allocated to educational television will be needed in the next decade, according to a report issued today by Anthony J. Celebrezze, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

The Federal Insurance Company and its subsidiaries, Vigilant Insurance Company and Great Northern Insurance Company, reported yesterday net income of $4,262,000, or $1.22 a share, for the first six months of 1962. This compared with $3,091,000, or 88 cents a share, in the corresponding period of 1961.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 23 --Premier Souvanna Phouma's coalition Cabinet agreed today on three exit points for the evacuation of foreign troops from Laos.

BERLIN, Aug. 23--Tension heightened in Berlin today as the Russians threatened new harassment, East Germany named its own East Berlin commandant and border guards fatally wounded a youth trying to flee to West Berlin.

CONSCIENTIOUS students of the indigenous American art form known as the Western, in both its motion-picture and television subdivisions, have long known that the West was finally won when John Wayne and other similarly stalwart actors defeated the Apache Indians.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. confirmed yesterday that he would campaign in the Bronx next week for James H. Scheuer, a reform Democrat seeking the party's nomination for Congress in the Twenty-first District.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 24-- Bus Mosbacher and Weatherly made a short stride toward the America's Cup defense berth at the beginning of the decisive stage of the final trials today by beating Nefertiti.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23-- House Appropriations Committee leaders have quietly set the stage for cutting the Administration's foreign aid program by at least $1,500,000,000. A sum of $4,672,000,000 was authorized earlier in the session.
"IT'S easy to be a housewife in America," a Finnish woman observed recently after a three-month visit to the United States.
A bandwagon drive to clinch the Democratic nomination for Governor for United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau collided head on yesterday with a burgeoning "Stop Morgenthau" campaign.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 23--Allison Stern's Naval Treaty contributed a recordbreaking performance today in winning the fifty-fifth running of the $19,425 Saratoga Steeplechase Handicap.
The Internal Revenue Service has stepped up its efforts to bring tax evaders to justice and reports that the enforcement drive has been successful.
Eastern Air Lines, which is expanding its service despite a flight engineers' strike, reported yesterday that its passenger planes were now operating at more than half of their capacity.

Defeat failed to diminish the fervor or frequency of huzzahs for the Mets at the end of a ten-inning duel with the San Francisco Giants at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Most of the 18,815 witnesses probably felt the Giants were lucky to win by 2--1 behind Juan Marichal's five-hitter.
A $3,460,000 public housing project in Queens won unanimous Board of Estimate approval last night after a bitter and emotional four-hour public hearing.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 23 (AP)--The World Coffee Conference was deadlocked again today by a dispute among Latin American delegates over what export quotas their nations should get.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23-- If the Democrats gain Congressional seats in the fall election, or even keep their losses to a minimum, the chances are they will have California to thank.
John Benson, former president of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, died yesterday in his home at 35 Hampton Road, Scarsdale. His age was 89.

A new first mortgage loan of $3,000,000 for fifteen years at 5 per cent has been placed on the Maritime Exchange Building at 80 Broad Street. It was made by the Aetna Life Insurance Company through the Charles F. Noyes Company,
A House inquiry into New York's garment industry turned up evidence yesterday of a sweetheart deal between an employer and Local 102 of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23-- A former official of the Agriculture Department said today that department aides had agreed last January not "to fine Billie Sol Estes for selling cotton without valid allotments."
The bond market held firm again yesterday. Governments were active and up small fractions. Corporates and tax-exempts quieted as recent offerings continued to be absorbed.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23--Several funny things happened on the way through the verbiage at the forum where President Kennedy and the reporters met yesterday.
Mrs. Gladys Hannaford is a frail, gray-haired grandmother from Boston who, at hundreds of schools across the country, is known simply as "the diamond lady."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23-- Railroad rate-making practices came under attack today at an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing. They were blamed for the financial problems of Eastern railroads.

Net new orders for machine tools dropped in July, continuing the decline that began in June. However, a revision in June figures indicated that the total for that month was higher than the preliminary figures had indicated.
WARWICK, N.Y., Aug. 23-- Here in the foothills of the Ramapos, Utopia is nearing the end of its first season.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23-- Bill Rigney's Angels, treading fearlessly on ground others would have neither the courage nor hardihood to invade, once again battled the Yankees into extra innings today.
LAKEVILLE, Conn., Aug. 23 --Percival R. Moses, a retired New York electrical and consulting engineer, died today in his home here. He was 87 years old and formerly lived in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.
American space scientists have calculated that the "group flight" of two manned Soviet spaceships that ended Aug. 15 was probably an even more spectacular feat than had been suspected initially.

TWICE monthly, Jewish families torn by internal strife take their problems to a nonjudicial body whose decisions are binding upon the disputants. Made up mostly of rabbis, judges, business men and lawyers, the Jewish Conciliation
MARQUETTE, Mich., Aug. 23 (AP)--United States District Judge W. Wallace Kent yesterday ordered that an in junction against the Seafarers International Union be dissolved effective Oct. 1.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 23 --Vice President Johnson engaged here today in diplomatic courtesies and Texas-style handshaking. His efforts were well received by those... Lebanese who saw him, especially since he is the highest ...
ALGIERS, Aug. 23--Vice Premier Ahmed Ben Bella and other members of Algeria's ruling Political Bureau won thunderous cheers today from an unruly crowd of 15,000.

The Mississippi River Fuel Corporation announced yesterday that it would seek tenders of Missouri Pacific Railroad Company stock, seeking to increase the fuel concern's holdings to more than 80 per cent of the voting shares.
PORT WASHTNGTON, L.I., Aug. 23--Six triple winners and one double winner emerged from today's third round of Manhasset Bay's thirtieth annual Race Week, in which 169 boats started.
BAKERSFIELD, CALIF. It was time for another spraying of pesticide on a field of longstaple cotton outside Bakersfield.
Stocks backed and filled yesterday in active trading and wound up with a small gain on average.

MONROVIA, Liberia, Aug. 23 (Reuters)--The economy of Liberia has taken on a healthier appearance following a decade of Government efforts to exploit the country's rich natural resources as well as the traditional rubber supply.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23-- Senate hearings on the Government's stockpiling of critical and strategic materials will probably not be resumed until after the elections in November.
The Police Department announced yesterday that its Operation Decoy plan for trapping muggers and rapists would be extended to all units wherever feasible.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) --Robert Troutman Jr., resigned today from the President's Committee on Equal Employment Opportunity. He was praised by Mr. Kennedy for work that "has apparently borne immediate and dramatic results."
A Brazilian Governor who was interviewed by a class at Pace College by long-distance telephone last spring will play host to five Pace students and a professor this week.

An investment banking group headed by Ira Haupt Co. has purchased $2,955,000 of Juneau, Alaska, various-purpose bonds, maturing from 1963 to 1992. The group bid 100.00864 for the bonds with a variety of coupons, setting a net interest cost to the city of 4.0998 per cent.

The United Nations has discovered that 104 or more members cannot live as cheaply as the original fifty-odd members. It has also learned that new responsibilities, such as the use of U.N. police in the Middle East and the Congo, cost more than the do-nothing policy that killed the old League of Nations.

PARAMUS, N.J., Aug. 23-- A new drilling technique developed in Sweden to permit the blasting of bedrock without first stripping off overlying dirt and sand was demonstrated for the first time in the United States here today.
HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Aug. 23 (AP)--The business agent of a local electricians union told about 125 members tonight to go back to work tomorrow.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 23--Hoot Gibson, one of Hollywood's most famous cowboy stars, died early this morning of cancer at the Motion Picture Country House and Hospital, in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 70 years old.
THE American Contract Bridge League has an- nounced the winners in the nation-wide charity tournament played on July 28.
MOSCOW, Aug. 23--Western officials said today that President Kennedy might have encouraged Premier Khrushchev to attend the opening session of the United Nations General Assembly Sept. 18.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 23-- Myer Feldman, President Kennedy's deputy special counsel, ended today a five-day visit that has intensified the nervous discussion in Israel about United States policy in the Middle East.
The president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association warned the city yesterday that unless the P.B.A. was recognized as a collective bargaining agent, its members might join unions.
Broadway theatre owners expressed opposition yesterday to a plan to televise six forthcoming Broadway shows free of charge in five cities.
A sonic tag for tracing the movements of large fish in the ocean has been successfully tested for the first time by the Department of Ichthyology of the American Museum of Natural History.
ALGIERS, Aug. 23--Mohammed Khider, the chief aide of Vice Premier Ahmed Ben Bella in Algeria's political strife, is one of the oldest and toughest fighters of the Algerian nationalist movement.

PARIS, Aug. 23--President de Gaulle's narrow escape last night from death by assassins' bullets unleashed nation-wide police action and new political debate today on how to protect the President and assure his succession.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 23 (AP)--The nuclear merchant ship Savannah has opened the way to development of improved yet cheaper atomic--powered vessels for world commerce, according to Robert E. Wilson, a member of the Atomic Energy Commission.
HONG KONG, Aug. 23--A cholera case was confirmed in Hong Kong today providing a new headache for a government that already is troubled by a water shortage and a steady influx of refugees by sea.
The Kings County rackets grand jury will begin an investigation Monday of reports by City Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan of widespread rent swindles in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23-- Following is the text of a joint communiqu on Berlin issued today by the United States, Britain and France:

CLEVELAND, Aug. 23 (AP) --Stockholders of Bobbie Brooks, Inc., approved today a 2-for-1 stock split that increases the number of authorized shares to 4,000,000. The company manufactures wearing apparel for girls and women.

Darryl F. Zanuck, the new president of Twentieth CenturyFox, said yesterday that the company would increase its television activity as part of a "firm policy" to secure a significant place in a "rich and growing field."
North American production of newsprint in July declined from the year-ago level, although consumption in this country rose to a record high.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 23--The United Nations announced today that it had released Hubert Fauntleroy Julian, an American Negro known popularly as the Black Eagle. He was arrested in Katanga as a mercenary last April.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23-- House leaders today scheduled the communications satellite bill for final Congressional action next Monday.

The low estate of American tennis was reflected yesterday in the draw for the eightysecond national championships. Only four United States players--two men and two women --were in the seeded list of sixteen. The tournament starts Aug. 29.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that the Housing Authority police force would be increased by 100 men.

HERSHEY, Pa., Aug. 23 (AP)--Pete Retzlaff, star end of the Philadelphia Eagles and president of the National Football League Players Association, said today that his group would seek tax relief from the Government at the next session of Congress.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23-- Senator Jacob K. Javits took President Kennedy to task today for not recommending more civil rights legislation to the Congress.

The head of the Veterans Administration paid tribute yesterday to the contributions made by World War II veterans toward making the United States stronger, more confident, richer and more powerful since their return to civilian life.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 23 --Dr. John Hodgdon Bradley, geologist and geographer, died Saturday at his home in Escondido, Calif. He was 63 years old.

STORRS, Conn., Aug. 23--Permissive parents who spare the rod to strengthen their children's mental health may have been misled by pseudo-scientific tracts on the subject, a family life specialist suggested here today.
The recovery of world sugar futures from recent declines was the feature of quiet and mixed day on the New York commodity exchanges.
LONDON, Aug. 23--The lymphatic leukemia afflicting Dr. Robert A. Soblen is in "remission" and could remain that way for several years, a British High Court justice was told today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23--The United States Court of Appeals, reversing its own ruling made in June, upheld today dismissal of a suit asking $150,000 from each of two magazines for alleged invasion of privacy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23--The Government warned today that an unknown quantity of unlabeled thalidomide pills of various shapes and colors was still available in family medicine cabinets across the country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23--The Senate Finance Committee voted for the first time on the trade bill today and gave the Administration a victory. It knocked out, by voice ... vote, a House provision to deny most-favored-nation treatment to two Communist countries--Poland and Yugoslavia.
CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP)-- Broad advances were general in all grain futures except wheat today in active dealings on the Board of Trade.

THIS week-end is a good time for chicken, whether it be cooped outdoors or in. Smallsize chickens, selling generally for 39 cents a pound, continue to represent one of the best meat buys. To make things even better, a number of stores offer them at reduced prices.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 23 --The discovery of a mysterious new source of X-rays was reported here today.

The International Longshoremen's Association and the New York Shipping Association met for an hour yesterday in their seventh attempt to agree on a rough draft of a new contract. The present three-year agreement expires on Sept. 30.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 23 --Chuck McKinley and Dennis Ralston were played off their feet in the first set by Michael Sangster and Billy Knight of Britain today before going on to victory in the national doubles tennis championships at the Longwood Cricket Club.
AFTER a few lean years, the hydro-racing circuit continues to show surprising vitality this season as the unlimited hydroplanes move into the Midwest.

The land and hunting rights of Alaskan Indians and Eskimos are in danger of dissolution because of the Federal Government's failure to define them, the Association on American Indian Affairs warned here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23-- The Western Allies declared today that they would take any steps necessary to preserve their position in Berlin against Communist encroachment.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 23--Using a gun to get ahead politically is not usually considered good form. But yesterday a shotgun used by Bernard B. Kalapach in quite good form won him the North American clay target championship here at the Grand American trapshooting tournament and incidentally got him some helpful political publicity back home.

BEAUMONT, Tex., Aug. 23 --District Judge Harold R. Clayton today granted a temporary injunction restraining Dr. Harold Lindley of Pecos, Tex., from selling 11.7 acres of land in Port Neches, Tex. Dr. Lindley seeks to sell the land to satisfy a $153,497,40 note that Dr. Lindley says is owed to him by Billy Sol Estes and his wife Patsy.
The Beneficial Finance Company, Wilmington, Del., reportved yesterday increases in net and operating income for the six months ended June 30.
Spain under Generalissimo Francisco Franco is striving for close economic and political association with nations of Western Europe that had shunned her in the post-war years.

BEFORE "The Stone Tower," a children's play, be gan yesterday morning at the Delacorte Theatre in Central Park, a little boy turned to his mother and said, "Wow, it's getting hot." She told him to forget the sun and watch the play.

J. Dudley Devine lost a legal round yesterday in his battle to force the Board of Elections to reinstate him as a candidate for the Republican nomination for City Council in Manhattan's Twentieth District.
SYRACUSE, N.Y. Aug. 23 (AP)--New York State Republicans were asked today to support legislation that would lighten employers' taxes and repeal the full-crew railroad laws.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI)--The Public Health Service said today that it was convinced the Sabin oral poliomyelitis vaccine was safe and effective despite a dozen recent polio cases among persons who took the vaccine.
LONDON, Aug. 23--The National Farmers Union, acting as spokesman for most of the farmers in the British Isles, came out strongly today against Britain's membership in the European Economic Community.
Action on the $100,000,000 Lower Manhattan Expressway was postponed by the Board of Estimate yesterday at the request of Mayor Wagner as residents of the area picketed City Hall.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 23 --Warner Brothers and the American Broadcasting Company network see a bright future for war as a subject for television series.

A minority of the Citizens Commission on the City Economy has urged "extreme caution" in adopting a city minimum-wage law, lest it spur industries and businesses to leave town and eradicate many jobs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23-- Two Democratic Senators, Paul H. Douglas of Illinois and Albert Gore of Tennessee, announced today that thet would not vote for the "wreck" that Congress had made of President Kennedy's tax revision bill.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23-- The Senate unanimously approved tonight a bill to tighten the Federal drug laws.
Nancy Kelly is set for the part that Rita Hayworth reliquished in "Step On a Crack" because of illness. The announcement was made yesterday by the sponsors, Roger L. Stevens and Herbert Swope Jr.
Business loans at major New York commercial banks fell $5,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 23--Pitman, N.J., sent its chiropodist, its court clerk, its Mayor, its barber, a former Mayor, a butcher, a plumber and a roofer here today to root for its team in the semi-finals of the Little League world series.

WELL-ORGANIZED people who are already in the midst of their Christmas shop ping might also be tempted to do a little buying for themselves when they see Bendel's new collection of what might be called "luxury gifts," most of which are imported. For the men on the list there is a butane lighter...

GENEVA, Aug. 24--The United States and the Soviet Union told the seventeen-nation disarmament conference today that their special talks on a possible nuclear test ban had failed to produce any agreement.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 24 (AP)--A dairy organization called today for immediate release of surplus Government grain to offset a feed shortage caused by drought.
TRENTON, Aug. 24--Local boards of education throughout New Jersey were advised today that they may legally contribute funds for participation in the forthcoming programs of Channel 13 (WNDT).

THE versatility and inviting ruby-red color of beets are two of the strongest lures of that staple root vegetable. Beets, now much in evidence as the new-season crop reaches its height, can be served as pickles, as a bright addition to salads or as a vegetable plain or variously embellished.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 24 (AP)--Milton Youngs, a 51year-old Chicago detective, won the sixty-third Grand American handicap trapshoot today. He defeated K.F. Kiplinger of Lewisville, Ind., 23 to 22, in a shoot off after they had tied at 99.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 24--Coffee producers and importers were reported in agreement today on trade quotas to give fair conditions to all concerned.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 (AP)--Billy O'Dell of the San Francisco Giants shut out the Philadelphia Phillies, 6--0, tonight. Orlando Cepeda had a perfect night at the plate with two bases-empty homers and three singles, driving in four runs.

BERLIN, Aug. 24 (UPI)-- A white and gold carriage drawn by two white horses and taking a West Berlin police officer and his bride to their wedding ceremony, almost stole the show today at the wall at Checkpoint Charlie.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 24 --Avtar Singh, chairman of the International Control Commission supervising the Laotian truce agreement, received formal notification today of the exit points chosen by the coalition Government for the withdrawal of foreign forces.

Reports circulated yesterday that agreement had been reached for the proposed merger of Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines. Spokesmen, however, for both said an agreement was not imminent.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24--The Western Allies and the Soviet Union exchanged diplomatic thrusts today in continued tense maneuvering on the Berlin problem.
Mayor Wagner signified yesterday that he was neutral on the Democratic nomination for Governor--and then implied that his neutrality might not last long.

The customer's right to a single scoop of ice cream--if he doesn't want two scoops--at a city soda fountain or restaurant was upheld yesterday by Mayor Wagner and Markets Commissioner Albert S. Pacetta.
Dr. Fred Schwarz, director of the Christian Anti-Communism Crusade, will conduct his antiCommunist school here for five days, beginning Monday.
World sugar and cocoa continued to rise yesterday in otherwise listless trading on the New York commodity exchanges. Other prices generally were lower.

Hubert Fauntleroy Julian, an American Negro and self-appointed colonel who is known popularly as the Black Eagle, returned to New York yesterday from the Congo after his release by the United Nations.
So many of the city's summer high school students failed the Regents examinations in four subjects that the director of the program has appealed to Albany to lower the passing mark of 65.
David Dubinsky defended his union for three and a half hours yesterday against charges of racial discrimination, sweetheart deals, low wages and racketeering.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 24--The Hopeful, perhaps the most appropriately named horse race on the thoroughbred calendar, will have its fiftyeighth running tomorrow at the main attraction on the final program of the season at this racing center.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24 (AP)--A crowd of 40,000 is expected at Memorial Coliseum tomorrow night when the Los Angeles Rams meet the New York Giants.

ROME, Aug. 24--George B. Wally, Brooklyn-born artist who teaches the blind to draw in perspective and paint in color, told today of his recent special audience with Pope John XXIII at the pontifical summer palace in Castel Gandolfo.
OTTAWA, Aug. 24 (AP)-- One of Canada's toughest union leaders will go before a stern judge next week to testify about shipping disruptions on the Great Lakes.

MADRID, Aug. 24--A week long strike of coal miners in the north was reported today to be spreading. About 13,000 work ers, more than a fourth of all miners in the Asturias region, were said to be idle.

The City Planning Commission heard Manhattan's Supreme Court building characterized yesterday as a "dirty and insanitary old barn" with dingy hallways "that remind one of Alfred Hitchcock's alleyway to the corpus delicti."
BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 24 --Rodney Laver of Australia, the world's top amateur tennis player, went down to defeat today in the national doubles championship at the Longwood Cricket Club.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Aug. 24 (AP)-- Carbon Petroleum Dubbs, an inventor of petroleum processes, died Tuesday night at Santa Barbara Hospital. He was 81 years old.
THERE are games when a pause of ten seconds be- tween bids or plays can seem interminable and other games when two minutes' thought does not seem excessive.
CHICAGO, Aug. 24--Filtertip cigarettes contain enough tar to cause skin cancer in mice, four New York State Department of Health researchers reported today.

ROME, Aug. 24--Pope John XXIII reaffirmed today the Roman Catholic tenet that education of the young is the responsibility of the church and the family even more than of the state. The church and the family are the "main architects of education," he said, and the state should not attempt to replace them. It should limit itself to coordinating their efforts when these efforts appear insufficient, he declared.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24--A chemical engineer and inventor has patented new catalysts that, he believes, will create great economies in the oil industry. He estimates that they will last from two-to-five times longer than present catalysts.
TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 24 (AP)--Vice President Johnson hailed the Shah of Iran tonight for his "invaluable strong stand for freedom" and told him the United States regarded him as a special friend.
ALGIERS, Aug. 24--Local military commanders served notice today that they would oppose a dissolution of the army's regional organizations for the time being.
LONDON, Aug. 24--Most sections of the stock market were mixed today, with only small price movements.
The quarterly excise tax figures that offer interesting insights into the habits of United States consumers have just been published for the three months ended on June 30.
OTTAWA, Aug. 24--Secretary of State Dean Rusk explained the Western Big Three's position on the Berlin crisis today to Prime Minister John Diefenbaker.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 24-- Chancellor Adenauer will make a personal appeal to Premier Khrushchev to order an end of the shootings along the Berlin wall, sources said here today.
The New York City Central Labor Council ruled out yesterday a "boycott or barricade" in support of the strike of flight engineers against Eastern Air Lines, now in its third month.
KATMANDU, Nepal, Aug. 24 --Six rebel Nepali Congress leaders in India were sentenced to life imprisonment in absentia by a special tribunal yesterday.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 24-- Duke Rodney, who has won more races and more money this season than any other freefor-all trotter, is the 5-2 favorite in the Gold ($25,000) Division of tomorrow night's Challenge Cup at Roosevelt Raceway.

ALTHOUGH Macy's opened its remodeled wing for modern furniture last January, it is still making refinements on the project. The latest addition is a gallery of fine fabrics created by the style-setting designer Jack Lenor Larsen. Heretofore, these fabrics, which range from $9.50 to $50 a yard, were available through decorators only at the Larsen showroom.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 24-- Weatherly scored her second straight victory over Nefertiti today in their duel for the assignment of defending the America's Cup against the Australian challenger Gretel three weeks hence.
LONDON, Aug. 24--Dr. Robert A. Soblen lost another round today in his struggle to avoid being deported to the United States.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI)--The Labor Department is going to start using a robo press agent to help speed information to newsmen.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24-- The Senate approved and sent to the White House today the bill authorizing $73,000,000 to complete payments in the Philippines for damage that occurred there during World War II.

Unanimous Senate approval of the bill to tighten the Federal drug laws will be welcomed by the American people as an important step toward preventing such tragedies as followedtne use of thalidomide, the sedative blamed for thousands of deformities in babies born abroad. Tests on animals had found thalidomide to be safe when given to normal adults.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 24 (AP)--The newly appointed United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union said today that "diplomacy is no longer a matter of dealing with a handful of leaders, of influencing a sovereign."

P. Joseph Connolly, a retired Deputy Chief of the New York Fire Department, died Wednesday in Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica, Queens. He was 70 years old and lived at 73-51 194th Street, Flushing, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP)--Dr. Kenneth M. Endicott, director of the National Cancer Institute, said today the sponsors of krebiozen had not supplied information that he regarded as necessary to determine whether the drug was a cancer cure.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 24--The Rev. Dr. J. Allison MacRury, who retired in 1947 after thirty-three years as pastor of the First Presbyterian Church in Woodhaven, Queens, died yesterday in Huntington Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived here at 38 Bunker Hill Drive.
A 67-year-old business man was killed early yesterday in a plunge from the fourteenth floor of the Summit Hotel, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-first Street.
MOSCOW, Aug. 24--Bobby Fischer, the former United States chess champion, was accused here today of "slander' in charging that Russians used collusive tactics in chess tournaments.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP)--The Senate staged an unscheduled five-hour debate today on a bill to give educational and other benefits to "cold war" veterans. It then put the legislation back on the shelf--where it had been for more than a year.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 24--The United Nations chief in the Congo, Robert K.A. Gardiner, gave Katanga today the proposals drafted by U Thant, Acting Secretary General, for ending Katanga's secession from the Congo.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 24--Governor Rockefeller set as his re-election objective today the "greatest plurality" the Republican party has ever rolled up in the state.

COLON, Mich., Aug. 24--A motley group of chuckling men and awe-struck boys surrounded "Milky the Clown" (Clare Cummings) today as he raised the blade of a guillotine above the neck of Mrs. Marion Pilipick. For her part, she smiled with a confidence that could stem only from long-time residence in Colon.

Edward George Wilmer of 50 Popham Road, Scarsdale, N.Y., former president of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and the Dodge Brothers Motor Car Company, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital, after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

Stated with more bluntness than tact, the object of U Thant's current Soviet trip is probably to find out Moscow's asking price for supporting his election as a formal U.N. Secretary General. The Burmese statesman is still only "acting" in that role. His temporary term expires next April.
Federal aeronautic investigators are sifting the bottom of Jamaica Bay for additional parts of the American Airlines jet that crashed there March 1 with a toll of ninety-five lives.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 24 (AP) --A four-run third inning enabled the Cincinnati Reds to score a 4-2 victory tonight over the Houston Colts.

SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 24 --The chief United Nations representative in Netherlands New Guinea, Brig. Indar Jit Rikhye, said today that 400 Indonesian troops who had landed in the territory were prisoners of the Dutch.
MOSCOW, Aug. 24--The Soviet note to the United States today on the Berlin problem did not specify what measures Moscow would take if new attacks were made on Soviet personnel.
TURKU, Finland, Aug. 24 (AP)--Jim Beatty ran the fastest 5,000 meters ever by an American today. He clipped 6.8 seconds from his listed United States record with a clocking of 13 minutes 45 seconds.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 24 (AP)--Scientists and technicians combined a Mariner II spacecraft with an AtlasAgena B rocket today and pronounced everything ready for an attempt Sunday to send the craft near the planet Venus.

FASHION and diplomacy are first cousins, according to Senora Clara Nieto de Ponce de Leon first secretary of the Colombian Mission to the United Nations. In both fields, she believes, one should accept people as they are.
FRENCH LICK, Ind., Aug. 24 --President Kennedy called tonight for a Democratic victory in the Congressional elections to strengthen his hand in seeking world peace and a better life for Americans.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 24--The proud and high-flying Yankees, zooming in orbit these many weeks, crashed head on into something tonight--and it definitely wasn't the moon.
MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 24--Bob James' Skiddoo III took the honors in the 210-Class national championship races at the Eastern Yacht Club by taking a first and a second today.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Aug. 24--Sir Roy Welensky dismissed today as "pious poppycock" warnings that Southern Rhodesia was being turned into a police state.
Although five months have elapsed since the city took over the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, riders of the buses seem hardly to have noticed the change.

It was a typical pre-week-end trading session on the stock market yesterday. Prices moved back and forth in slow and quiet trading and at the close showed a small loss on average. No great buying or selling interest was evident.

TENAFLY, N.J., Aug. 24-- Miss Jeralea Fooshee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irb Haskell Fooshee, was married here tonight to Stephen Bradley Hesse. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold George Hesse Jr. of Englewood. The Rev. Henry Powers performed the ceremony in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Atonement.
WASHINGTON, Aug, 24--Approval of the proposed merger of the Seaboard Air Line Railroad and the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad was recommended today by an examiner

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 24--They have an exciting new idea in highway engineering out here. It is called the low-speed, two-lane, unlimited access road, and to anyone who dreads the drudgery of expressway driving it looks like the wave of the future.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 22--Large patches of bright green rice plants, surrounded by ditches filled with water, stretch along the road in a valley fifty miles north of Santo Domingo.

The board of directors of Russ Togs, Inc., apparel and sportswear manufacturer, declared yesterday a 50 per cent stock cent dividend on its outstanding Class A and B common shares. It will be payable on Sept. 20 to holders of record on Sept 5.

ALBANY, Aug. 24--The State Board of Regents approved today the establishment of an Office of Planning in Higher Education, which will prepare a long-range master plan for college and university education.
MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 24--The Department of Justice moved today against the House of Seagram, Inc., and several liquor distributors and retailers in three actions charging price fixing.
HARTFORD, Aug. 24--Democratic leaders were obviously relieved today when word came that Representative Frank Kowalski would not run as an independent candidate for the Senate.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 24-- As the Berkshire Music Festival entered its final week-end of concerts today, two events took place on the grounds of Tanglewood that illustrated the range and emphasis of musical activity here.
TRENTON, Aug. 24--The United States Civil Rights Commission and its New Jersey Advisory Committee are planning a series of public hearings to study racial problems in this state.
MONTREAL, Aug. 24 (Canadian Press)--Doug Harvey who makes his living playing professional hockey, took a whirl at teaching last night and ended up with a broken knuckle in his left hand.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24-- Japan has agreed to reduce or halt temporarily her exports of more than a half-dozen types of cotton goods to this country, the State Department announced today.
The Cinerama Corporation plans to open two additional theatres in New York next year.
WELLESLEY, Mass., Aug. 24--Mary Evans Chase, vice president and director of admissions at Wellesley College, died of cancer today at the Newton-Wellesley Hospital. She was 53 years old.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 24--Miss Jane Hilleary Burgess and James Langhorne Wiley Jr. were married here this afternoon in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church. The Rev. Lawrence B. Larsen performed the ceremony and there was a reception at Bartow Pell Mansion in Pelham Bay Park, the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) --A Justice Department official said today that no Communists had registered under the Internal Security Act of 1950.

WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 24 --Anson T. Leary, founder and president of Leary, Nylen Damann, Inc., an insurance agency, died Thursday in Queen's Hospital in Honolulu. He was 72 years old at lived at Brooklawn Drive.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 24 --Mrs. Edith Judson Kidde, civic and educational leader here, died today after a stroke in Mountainside Hospital. She was 89 years old and lived at 80 Elm Street.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 24--James P.C. Southall of 24 Alden Place, Professor Emeritus of Physics at Columbia University, died last night. He was 91 years old and had lived here since 1957.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP)--A labor federation official urged today that Congress extend temporary unemployment compensation benefits for another year. Leaders of business groups argued that the plan should be rejected.
E.W. Bliss Company is attempting to recover a loss it incurred in an acquisition made last year, Carl E. Anderson, president, told the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A, Barnes said yesterday that the city intends to install seat safety belts in all its automobiles.
Donald A. Sehrader has joined the MacFadden-Bartell Corporation as production manager for MacFadden books. For the last twelve years Mr. Schrader has served as production manager for Avon Books.

A New York physician read another of the many articles last week about the possible dangers of the drug thalidomide, and quickly called his insurance broker to reappraise his professional-liability policy. The doctor had given the sedative to several of his patients.

The Department of Justice has advised the Federal Maritime Commission that it must "enforce antitrust principles and preserve appropriate independent competition" in its regulation of dual rate contracts of steamship conferences.

MARACAIBO, Venezuela, Aug. 24--A five-and-a-halfmile pre-stressed concrete bridge spanning Lake Maracaibo was inaugurated here today by President Romulo Betancourt. He called it a work of "transcendental economic importance" for the country.

ATHENS, Aug. 23--Although enough of the ruins at Delphi remain to give an imaginative visitor a notion of what Apollo's shrine looked like thousands of years ago, the modern Greek does not think of invoking an oracle there-- not even in fantasy.
MOSCOW, Aug. 24 (AP)-- Following, as made public in English by the United States Embassy here, is the text of a Soviet note to the United States on the Berlin issue:

President Kennedy's foreign aid program seemed to be doing well this year when in the authorization stage. The President had asked for close to $5,000,000,000 and he got an authorization for $4,672,000,000, which the Senate passed 61 to 23 and the House 221 to 162. Unfortunately an authorization puts a ceiling over a money bill but does not put a floor under it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24-- Senate investigators heard testimony today indicating that Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman might have known about the Billie Sol Estes case earlier than had previously been believed.

HONOLULU, Aug. 24 (AP) --The Rev. Dr. Shelton Hale Bishop, retired rector of St. Philip's Protestant Episcopal Church in New York died today in the Maui Island church he had been serving as vicar since 1957. He was 73 years old.
The prevention of juvenile delinquency will be discussed at a conference of 1,500 Mormons in the New York area here today and tomorrow.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Saturday, Aug. 25--Felix Dias Bandaranaike, Ceylon's Finance Minister, announced his resignation in the House of Representatives at 3 o'clock this morning.

WILLIAMSPORT, PA., Aug. 25--The dedication tomorrow of the Little League Museum and Hall of Fame seems likely to touch off renewed controversy about the "overemphasis" of the organizational phase of baseball for boys up to 12 years old.

Pete Bordes, a radio station owner from Milford, Conn., won the Thistle Class national sailing championship yesterday off Staten Island after Doug MacGregor of Winthrop, Mass., had been disqualified for fouling at the start of the fifth and final race.
A new theatre project, headed by Paul Shyre, will be started in Milwaukee in the fall.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24-- Richard M. Nixon and Gov. Edmund G. Brown announced today rival series of television appearances in their gubernatorial contest.
BARI, Italy, Aug. 24 (AP) --The police used tear gas today in a street clash with 400 striking building workers that left fifty injured.
Bond prices were mixed yesterday, in exceptionally quiet trading.

WILLIAM THAW, of Pittsburgh, learned to fly before the airplane was a dozen years old. On a holiday trip with a friend he suddenly saw a bridge dead ahead of him. Instead of going up he went down and somehow cleared it.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug. 24--Antonio Medina of Venezuela moved into a tie with two other players, for the lead in other players for the lead in Championship Tournament today.
STORRS, Conn., Aug. 24--Is it more important for a mother to iron the family's sheets or to give comradeship to her husband and children?
THYSVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 22--A few miles outside this sleepy provincial capital, a track of hub-deep ruts twists off to the north.

After losing his way in the park twice, a surgeon from Malone, N.Y., arrived in time to save Leo Durocher's life last night at the Polo Grounds. The Los Angeles coach had suffered a severe reaction to a penicillin shot prior to the Dodgers' game with the Mets.

Paperback bookshops, which have increased here from a half-dozen three years ago to forty today, have created new retail markets for wholesalers, new jobs for salesmen opposed to wearing neckties, and a kind of browsingon-the-Seine atmosphere for New Yorkers.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., Aug. 23 (AP)--A brake lining on President Kennedy's plane overheated and poured out a cloud of smoke today as he landed at near-by Otis Air Force Base.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Saturday, Aug. 25 (AP)--A bicycle race this morning opened competition in the fourth Asian games. They began on schedule despite a political argument over the exclusion of Taiwan and Israel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24--The balance-of-payments problem has prevented the Federal Reserve System from pursuing an easier money policy that might have helped the nation's economy grow faster this year, according to George W. Mitchell of the Federal Reserve Board.
Tennessee Gas Transmission Company has placed in registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission 225,000 cumulative convertible preferred shares with $1OO par value.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24-- Hearings on the judicial qualifications of Thurgood Marshall came to a close today, eleven months after President Kennedy first nominated him to fill a vacancy on the United States Court of Appeals.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 24--Three years ago, while head of Ghana's civil service, Robert Kweku Atta Gardiner dismissed a senior nurse for having overstayed a leave of absence. The fact that she was his sister did not deter him, although it caused a certain amount of...

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 24--Professor Gunapala P. Malalasekera, head of Ceylon's delegation, charged today that the circulation of a private report that was meant for his Government was an "unethical maneuver." He said it was designed to "undermine" his candidacy as President of the General Assembly.

MARION, Ohio, Aug. 24 (UPI)--Clark (Shorty) Templeman, who once quipped that he was too tough to die in a race car, and Jim Hemmings were killed last night in an eleven-car pile-up at a county fair midget-auto race.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP)--Norbert A. Schlei of North Hollywood, Calif., became an Assistant Attorney General today in a ceremony marked by the official presence of a Supreme Court Justice and the frolicking of Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy's dog.
Eight of New York's finest became eight of, well, New York's fairest yesterday as the Police Department's Operation Decoy moved from the underworld up to the glamorous world of high fashion.

Miss Nancy Mary Peay was married here yesterday afternoon to Boynton Mott Rawlings in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (Little Chureh Around the Corner). The Rev. Dean Calcote performed the ceremony.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI)--Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, urged today that the military be given its own space vehicle launching program as part of an effort to catch up with the Soviet Union.
GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 24--Albert A. Frost Jr. of San Diego, sailing Lani, won the international championship of the 110 Class today for the fourth consecutive year.
