LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24 (AP)--Ray Herbert had his string of scoreless innings broken at thirty-one tonight, but scored his fourteenth victory as the Chicago White Sox defeated the Los Angeles Angels, 7--1.

PARIS, Aug. 24--Investigators of the assassination attempt Wednesday against President de Gaulle had one solid lead today--a detailed description of the man who rented the light panel truck used by the gunmen.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) --The General Services Administration announced today that it was investigating fully the expense reimbursement claims of the Hanna Smelting Company under the company's contract to produce nickel at Riddle, Ore.

The Meredith Publishing Company, Des Moines, Iowa, reported yesterday a decline in net income on increased revenues for the year ended June 30. Earnings totaled $2,097,847, equal to $1.58 a share, compared with $2,514,277, or $l.90 a share, in the preceding year. The company, a publishing concern, disclosed revenues of $69,300,000, against $60,200,000 a year earlier.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 24--U Thant, Acting Secretary General, departed tonight for a four-day visit to Moscow. He then will fly to Warsaw, Prague and Vienna, before returning here Sept. 4.

HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Aug. 24 (AP)--More electricians returned to their jobs at the Marshall Space Flight Center today. A spokesman for the center said, "We certainly are heading back toward a normal situation."
The Securities and Exchange Commission's long-awaited study of mutual funds concludes that size alone has no direct relationship to any ills plaguing the industry.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 24--Five skippers remained undefeated and two suffered their first losses today in the fourth program of Manhasset Bay's thirtieth annual Race Week off this North Shore village.

DETROIT, Aug. 24 (AP)-- New car sales in mid-August declined slightly from those of the early part of the month but were still the best for this time of year since 1955, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24-- United States officials said today that Soviet equipment and technical personnel, military and civilian, were pouring into Cuba.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 24--A California dairy farmer varied the feed of his milch cows by including a diet of tomato pomace--the skins and seeds of tomatoes after the juice has been squeezed out.
DETROIT, Aug. 24 (AP)-- Steve Boros, Rocky Colavito and Billy Bruton hit home runs tonight in accounting for ten runs as the Detroit Tigers routed the Washington Senators, 11--1.
CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP)-- The umpires working the Milwaukee Braves-Chicago Cubs game today didn't look their customary dignified blue-dressed selves.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Aug. 24 --A Negro integration-movement meeting here ended in dissension and a call for the police tonight.
If you were a major league pitcher badly in need of your twenty-third victory of the season, chances are you'd welcome a crack at the New York Mets some balmy summer eve.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 24--A Hungarian Foreign Ministry spokesman denied today Vienna reports that several high-ranking Hungarian officials had been ousted from their jobs and some arrested on charges of having planned a "revolt" against the regime of Premier Janos Kadar, Hungary's Communist chief.
The professional wrestling program at Madison Square Garden last night drew 17,022 fans. The gate of $52,982.53 pushed the receipts for two shows in August over the $100,000 mark.

VENICE, Italy, Aug. 24-- The last-minute withdrawal of "Eva," a competing feature at the twenty-third Venice Film Festival, has ruffled the quiet prefestival atmosphere and upset local hopes for a troublefree event. The defection brings the competing entries at the competition, which gets under way tomorrow night, down to thirteen.
For the second time in his long and brilliant baseball career, Gil Hodges was hailed as a conquering hero at the Polo Grounds last night before the game between the Mets and the Dodgers.
QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 24-- The Cabinet of President Carlos Julio Arosemena Monroy resigned today.
The professional wrestling program at Madison Square Garden last night drew 17,022 fans. The gate of $52,982.53 pushed the receipts for two shows in August over the $100,000 mark.

VENICE, Italy, Aug. 24-- The last-minute withdrawal of "Eva," a competing feature at the twenty-third Venice Film Festival, has ruffled the quiet prefestival atmosphere and upset local hopes for a troublefree event. The defection brings the competing entries at the competition, which gets under way tomorrow night, down to thirteen.
For the second time in his long and brilliant baseball career, Gil Hodges was hailed as a conquering hero at the Polo Grounds last night before the game between the Mets and the Dodgers.
DETROIT, Aug. 24--Delegates to the forty-sixth annual convention of the American Federation of Teachers went home today, leaving their executive committee with a problem.

LITTLE SILVER, N.J., Aug. 24--Mrs. Jeannette Ballantine Barrows was married in her home this afternoon to Felix Ferdinand Molzer of Red Bank and Vienna. The Rev. James Rupert, pastor of the RumsonFair Haven Methodist Church, where the bridegroom is organist and choirmaster, performed the ceremony.
QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 24-- The Cabinet of President Carlos Julio Arosemena Monroy resigned today.
The marriage of Miss Deborah Ann Kretschmann, daugter of Professor and Mrs. Philip Miller Kretschmann of Lynbrook, L.I., to John Robert Taylor took place here yesterday afternoon. The bridegroom...

BROAD BROOK, Corn., Aug. 25--The marriage of Miss Dorothy Elizabeth Hearn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Edward Hearn, to Anthony Pratt, son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Nickerson Pratt of New York and South Kent, took place here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents.
LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 25--A rural-urban dispute over reapportionment of seats in the State Legislature has become a major political issue here.

WATERBURY, Conn., Aug. 25--This industrial city of 115,000, about twenty miles north of New Haven will hold its second annual arts festival Monday to Thursday for less than $10,000. The major performances will take place on the 2.2. acres of the Green in the Center and the exhibitions will be in the churches, banks, buildings and stores surrounding the Green.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Katherine N. Reed, daughter of Mrs. Morris Osborne Reed of Holland, Mich., and the late Mr. Reed, to Second Lieut. Joseph J.H. Humphrey, U.S.A. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Humphrey of Flushing, Queens.

THE recent "group flight" by Russia's Vostok III and Vostok IV represents a major step to ward man's conquest of the moon. By this feat, the Soviets demonstrated the ability and technical competence to time a multiple launching so precisely as to bring vehicles to a rendezvous in

CAPE CANAVERAL, Aug. 25 (AP)--Technical problems tonight forced a twenty-fourhour postponement of an attempt to launch a Mariner II spacecraft to the vicinity of Venus. The launching had been scheduled for early tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI)--The Agency for International Development recounted a story today of a Nigerian visitor and New England generosity.
WHY is it that Britain seems as the moment to be producing so may new, young and vigorous playwrights?

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Aug. 25 --The home of Mr. and Mrs. John Mumma Young was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Virginia Calhoun Young, to Edward Alun Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. Tudor Alun Jones, of Port Dinorwic, Wales.

Last year, if a manufacturing company had needed capital to finance plant expansion there would have been no problem. With the public buying every new issue of stock as fast as it came along, equity financing was a convenient fund-raising device for businesses large and small.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 25--An impressive breakaway by Weatherly on the first windward leg today settled the final race of her trial series against Nefertiti for the Ameri- ca's Cup defense assignment. Every leg of a twice-around windward-leeward course totaling twenty-four miles was a winning one for Henry D. The American Federation of Teachers, at its annual convention in Detroit, last week hit back at the National Education Association. The declaration was viewed as an effort to turn Saturday's "semiresignation" of the Political Bureau into a full-scale abdication of power. [Page 1, Column 8.]

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 26-- Weatherly's people never had a sunnier Sunday than the one they had today. LENOX, Mass., Aug. 26-- The 1962 Berkshire Music Festival came to an end this afternoon, and with it ended an era for the Boston Symphony Orchestra. The occasion was the final appearance of Charles Munch as its conductor, a post he has held for thirteen years.

At the Polo Grounds yesterday, the Mets enacted what appeared to be a taped re-run of their all-summer series, "This Is Our Life." In losing to the Dodgers, 16--5, New York made five errors that led to twelve unearned runs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) --The United States took new steps today to revise an extradition treaty with Brazil so that several American financiers residing there could be brought home for prosecution in swindle cases.
NICE, France, Aug. 27-- The week-long European outdoor swimming and waterpolo championships ended Saturday at Leipzig in East Germany. They were a huge success.

LONDON, Aug. 27--Peter Thorneycroft, Britain's Minister of Defense, will visit the United States early next month for talks that are expected to have a far-reaching effect on Britain's defense policies.
WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 27-- Glenn D. Loucks of 8 Colonial Road, a leading advocate of physical fitness for youths, died of cancer yesterday in White Plains Hospital. His age was 55.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 27--Foreign consulates and United Nations delegations will get automobile parking spaces in designated areas in Manhattan.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 27-- Following is the text of a joint statement by President Kennedy and Prime Miniter Mucmillan, as made public by the White House staff here:

The Flight Engineers International Association, on strike against Eastern Air Lines since June 23, set up a waterborne picket line off New York International Airport yesterday in a move to halt fuel deliveries to the carrier.
ALGIERS, Aug. 27--There were growing indications here today that the postponement of Algeria's election of a constituent assembly, announced Saturday, might be continued for a long time.

Complications have been resolved between Alan Schneider and Caroline Swann concerning Mr. Schneider's direction of Mrs. Swann's double bill of the Harold Pinter plays, "The Dumbwaiter" and "The Collection."
HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 27 --A Finnish-Soviet committee reached agreement today on the leasing to Finland of part of a waterway lost to the Russians in 1940.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27--Since the Supreme Court, March 26 last, in effect reversed the doctrine in Colegrave v. Green (1946) that controversies among the citizens of a state over the apportionments made of voting districts by the Legislature are "political," and not "jus- ...

SEATTLE, Aug. 27 (AP)-- Five insulation material producers were fined $5,000 each in Federal District Court today on charges of fixing prices and rigging bids. Officers of three of the companies were fined $3,000 each.

TORONTO, Aug. 27 (Canadian Press)--A union leader told a Federal shipping inquiry today that he had never taken any steps to stop harassment and picketing in United States ports of vessel owned by a Canadian shipping concern.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UPI)--The Washington Senators tonight did what the New York Yankees couldn't do in five week-end games. The last-place Senators beat the Baltimore Orioles, 7--0, behind Tom Cheney's four-hit pitching.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27-- Liberals and conservatives maneuvered today to delay, alter or eventually kill the tax revision bill as the Senate began its formal debate on the measure.
The price of silver advanced one half cent an ounce to $1.09 here yesterday, touching the highest level since 1920 and ending two weeks of stability at $1.09 .
GENEVA, Aug. 27--The United States and Britain formally offered the Soviet Union today the choice of an internationally inspected total ban on nuclear weapons tests or an uninspected limited ban.

The Martin-Marietta Corporation announced yesterday that it was selling for more than $7,000,000 its adhesives and resins division whose headquarters and research laboratories are on Harbor Island, Seattle. Two buyers are involved in the transaction to be closed about Oct. 1.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 27 --A fully loaded Civil War cannon that stood in the State House as a memorial to Rhode Islanders who died at Gettysburg was disarmed today, ninety-nine years after it was loaded.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 27--Samuel Goldwyn said today that the movie industry must work out an ethical economic code or perish.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 27 --Vice President Johnson told Turkey's leaders today that the United States would help support their long-range economic plans and efforts to modernize defenses against the neighboring Soviet Union.

Sir Tyrone Guthrie, the distinguished stage director, is associated with a production coming out in the fall. The production has been successfully tested for a number of years in the small village where Sir Tyrone makes his Irish home.

MONTREAL, Aug. 27--Canada's Social Credit party was the center of a heated controversy today despite an explanation by Real Caouette, its deputy leader, of some words of praise he had recently for Hitler and Mussolini.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27--The House headed off an expected new Senate filibuster against the communications satellite bill by sending the measure directly to the White House today.

LONDON, Aug. 27--Edward Turnour, the sixth Earl Winterton and former senior member of the House of Commons, died yesterday in a sanatorium in Midhurst, Sussex, after an illness of several months. He was 79 years old.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27-- The Post Office Department put up its biggest reward today in an effort to recover the money taken in the largest theft of cash in United States history.
The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it would try locking vestibule doors at night in its lowrent projects in an effort to reduce crime and violence.
The outer-space eating habits of the nation's astronauts may lead to some earthly success for manufacturers of collapsible metal tubes.
An infectious virus has been made in the test tube for the first time from inert chemicals, a University of Utah researcher reported yesterday.

Is the end of the numerous gasoline price wars at hand? Yesterday the Gulf Oil Corporation, one of the nation's leading marketers, announced that it was "withdrawing its temporary competitive allowances to all dealers" throughout the forty states in which it operates.

Directors of the New Process Company, a Warren, Pa., mail-order house whose thinly held shares rocketed 52 points last Thursday and Friday on the American Stock Exchange, proposed yesterday a five-for-one stock split.
The Robert Shaw Chorale, which begins a Soviet tour in September under the United States-Soviet cultural exchange agreement, will perform the Bach B minor Mass as its main offering there.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 27-- Chancellor Adenauer has told Prime Minister Macmillan that West Germany favors Britain's membership in the European Common Market provided its principles are not altered by the expansion.
A far-reaching plan to save animals threatened with extinction by the spread of civilization was outlined before the City Planning Commission yesterday.
Former President Herbert Hoover, who is 88 years old, will be operated on today for the removal of a growth on the interior of his large intestine, his physicians announced yesterday.
In Western Europe, where the European Economic Community is fast dissolving traditional barriers, one great obstacle remains almost intact--the problem of communication among nations.
PARIS, Aug. 27--President de Gaulle, heavily guarded, returned to Paris today along the same route that brought him under assassins' fire last Wednesday.
An affiliate of the National Maritime Union suffered a setback yesterday in a dispute involving representation rights of ship engineers aboard fourteen American Export Lines freighters.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 27 --The killing of twenty-eight persons in an attack by a group of uniformed bandits was reported today in the Department of Valle.

MADRID, Aug. 27--At least ten persons have been arrested on charges of political agitation during the present coal miners' strike in the Asturias region of northern Spain, it was reliably reported today.
Robert E. Herman, State Rent Administrator, spent more than two hours yesterday before a Kings County grand jury investigating rent gouging in Brooklyn.

A new program designed to train teachers and administrators for work in underprivileged communities in this country will get under way this fall at Yeshiva University's Graduate School of Education here.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 27. --South Vietnam's massive campaign against Communist guerrilla strongholds at the southern tip of the country appears to have achieved some significant military successes during its first twelve days.

John Henry Faulk, the radio and television entertainer who was recently awarded $3,500,000 in a libel suit against Aware, Inc., will return to television next week as a guest panelist on "To Tell the Truth."
LONDON, Aug. 27--British Government bonds continued to gain on the stock market today. Industrial stocks were hesitant.
The bond market was quiet again yesterday. Governments were narrowly mixed Corporates were off a bit at the close. Municipals were unchanged.
Federal mediators stepped in yesterday to try to close the gap in contract negotiations between longshoremen and steamship operators.

ROSCOE, N.Y., Aug. 27-- As if Harry Darbee, one of America's premier flytiers, didn't have enough worries. For the past ten years he has been on the warpath because he's convinced that New York State is turn- ...

Some paper ballots will be used in the Sept. 6 primary elections, but only for contests involving delegates to party state conventions and judicial conventions, James M. Power, president of the Board of Elections, said yesterday.
MEYERSVILLE, N.J., Aug. 27--A scant thirty miles from Times Square in New York City is some of the roughest, toughest country this side of the Rockies.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 27 (AP)--Gretel headed to sea today and tested a new mainsail.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27--The House gave final Congressional approval today to a constitutional amendment outlawing the poll tax as a requirement for voting in Fed eral elections. The proposal now goes to the states for ratification.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 27-- Argentina's military leaders were seeking today an "important civilian" to take over the post of Defense Minister and give more authority to the Government of President Jose Maria Guido.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27-- The New York Central and the Pennsylvania Railroads were accused today of having projected an independent New England railroad system as a maneuver to shut out the New Haven Railroad from the proposed Pennsy-Central merger.
LONDON, Aug. 27--Four British leaders of a neo-Nazi movement were accused in court today of building an organization that would use force to achieve its political ends.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP)--Following is the rollcall vote by which the House passed a resolution today submitting to the states a proposed constitutional amendment to abolish the poll tax in Federal elections:
With much backing and filling, stocks moved slightly higher yesterday in dull trading. There was no clear-cut market trend.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP)--Enrollment in the nation's colleges and schools will increase during 1962-63 for the eighteenth consecutive year to reach a record of 51,300,000, the Office of Education estimated today.
Elsie Ferguson, the former stage and silent screen star who died last year at the age of 76, left $500,000 to the Animal Medical Center, at Sixty-second Street and the East River Drive.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Aug. 27--Rufus W. Scott of 960 Fifth Avenue, New York, one of the early manufacturers of rayon in this country, died yesterday at his summer home here. He was 88 years old.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP)--Scientists around the world are trying to change the weather, President Kennedy was told today in a report from the National Science Foundation.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 27 --Communist influence in Brazil is developing into one of the major issues in the campaign for the Oct. 7 Congressional and state elections.

Back to accessible Aqueduct came the thoroughbred horses yesterday after the annual summer campaign at Saratoga Springs, On hand for their first bit of local action in almost a month were 31,612 customers, who bet $2,771,113 on the ninerace program.
The Democratic-Liberal candidate for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District, Dr. Martin B. Dworkis, defied the law yesterday for more than an hour by campaigning in Central Park.

With the inexorable clock of history ticking away toward the moment when the atomic arms race may get wholly beyond control, the United States and Britain are making another serious attempt to persuade Soviet Russia to join them in a nuclear test ban. To this end, they have submitted to the Geneva disarmament conference two alternative draft treaties.

Once when Thomas Wolfe was in the full flower of his best-selling fame, a gentle and ambitious ... reader wanted a list of "six or a dozen books" which the author of "Look Homeward, Angel," had enjoyed reading recently. Wolfs replied that in those hard-writing years he had been drawn back to the comfort of a few books which he had read many times.

Interest rates, which bobbed up and down during most of the post-World War II era like the bouncing ball in a singalong movie, recently have been rolling along almost as evenly as a cue-ball on a pool table.

ETHEL KENNEDY said to her husband: "For a Seaman Second Class, you've come a long way." It was a whispered remark made as the Attorney General of the United States reviewed a splendid honor guard on the free side of the Berlin Wall early this year.

BERLIN, Aug. 27--More than 300 East Berliners attended today the funeral of Peter Fechter, the 18-year-old youth whose killing by East German guards at the Berlin border wall ten days ago set off a series of violent demonstrations in West Berlin.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 --Following is the text of a United States note on the Berlin situation delivered to the Soviet Foreign Ministry in Moscow today:
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 27-- For want of a callus, a pennant may be lost.

Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the Cambodian Chief of State, has handed countries concerned with Southeast Asia a prickly issue in his proposal that members of the recent fourteen-nation conference on Laos meet and agree to a formal guarantee of his country's borders and neutrality. He requests commitments similar to those just made by the same powers for Laos.
The Chrysler Corporation has switched its $10,000,000 corporate advertising account from the Leo Burnett Company to Young Rubicam, Inc.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Aug. 27-- Charles Percival de Silva, Minister of Agriculture and leader of the House of Representatives, was appointed tonight as Minister of Finance. He succeeds Felix Dias Bandaranaike, who resigned Saturday.

LONDON, Aug. 27--Britain is following, with a lag of fifteen years, the United States' inclination to skyscrapers, internal migration, private cars and a decline in public transport, according to a study by a professor of civic design at the University of Liverpool.

Second thoughts on the hit-and-run raid by Cuban exile youths on Havana reinforce the original impressions. The intention was to strike a blow against tyranny and for freedom. The effect was to help Fidel Castro and his Government greatly at a moment when he most needed such help. It also embarrassed the United States and has weakened our case against Havana.
Venus is the earth's closeest planetary neighbor but has remained a tantalizing riddle, hiding its secrets behind a thick veil of clouds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UPI)--The Internal Revenue Service issued a ruling today that will cost movie and TV producers higher taxes, Profits on the sale for reshowing of television films and tapes and some motion pictures are taxable at ordinary income rates, not the lower capital gains rates, it was ruled.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27-- Treasury bill rates dropped sharply on today's sale of the regular weekly issues.
Two Federal aeronautical agencies began a joint inquiry yesterday into the emergency landing of a New York Airways helicopter in the East River Sunday with twenty-eight persons aboard.

PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 27--One of the wrier wits at the California Institute of Technology's Jet Propulsion Laboratory remarked that "Bob Parks' job is simple--all he has to do is carry out the ideas that Jules Verne had seventy-five years ago."
The astronautics division of the General Dynamics Corporation of San Diego has been granted a $23,700,000 Air Force contract for installation and checkout of Atlas missiles.

Brooklyn's up and the Bronx is down; a Hawaiian setting becomes a beer garden peopled by gypsies; "Yes, Sir, That's My Baby" becomes an old lied called "Ausgerechnet Bananen," better known here as "Yes, We Have No Bananas."
The Massachusetts Electric Company raised $67,500,000 in the market for new capital yesterday through first mortgage bonds and preferred stock.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27--The swivel chair belonging to the general manager of the White Sox seems to have magic powers. Ideas spring from it--or from its occupants. They came popping out of the cranium of Frank Lane when he sat there and in even more profusion from the noggin of Bill Veeck when he was running the show. The latest eruption has come from the current resident genius, Ed Short.
DETROIT, Aug. 27 (AP)-- The United States auto industry may build fewer passenger cars this month than in any month since September, 1958.

The Addressograph-Multigraph Corporation declared a dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock at a meeting of the directors in Cleveland yesterday. The company paid 22 cents in previous quarters.
EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 27 (UPI)--American Photocopy Equipment Company announced today it had acquired all outstanding stock of an Italian manufacturing company.
Record first-half earnings were reported yesterday by the American Investment Company of Illinois.

THE last of the four weekly programs of Chamber Mu sic in Washington Square Park this season turned out to be significant. Last night two first performances were heard, and the 51-year-old Brazilian conductor Leo Peracchi made his United States debut.
PENSACOLA, Fla., Aug. 27 (AP)--Nine Escambia County schools opened their doors to Negro pupils today for the first time. Twenty-one Negroes were enrolled.
The New York football Giants, happy for a stand-off in a two-game visit to the Pacific Coast, returned to their Connecticut camp counting these blessings:

ALBANY, Aug. 27--Dr. Thomas H. Hamilton, president of the State University of New York for the last three years, announced today that he was resigning to become president of the University of Hawaii next Jan. 1.
The New York Times will begin printing and distributing its new Western Edition on Oct. 1, Orvil E. Dryfoos, publisher of The Times, announced yesterday.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 27--A pair of firsts in the opening races gave the Newport Harbor (Calif.) Yacht Club crew a clear lead today as the North American junior sailing championship for the Sears Cup opened.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP)--Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, urged the Interstate Commerce Commission today to order an immediate stay of all railroad merger proposals until it decides the Pennsylvania-New York Central case.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 27--The second conference of the Latin American Free Commerce Association was inaugurated formally here this morning with words of encouragement but with a growing fear that the meeting could be blown apart over the question of Cuba's demand for admission.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 27 (UPI) --Forgive Robin Roberts a show of emotion. In his fifteen years in the major leagues he hasn't displayed much, but after the final out of his 2-1 victory over the New York Yankees and Whitey Ford yesterday, the Oriole pitcher let himself go.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 27 (AP)--Gen. Dusan Simovic, who headed the Yugoslav Royal Government when the country was invaded by Germany in 1941, died here today. He was 80 years old.

Long Island's increase in manufacturing employment is less than the increase in the United States in the last sixteen months, the Franklin National Bank of Long Island reported in the current issue of its JulyAugust business review.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27--The United States again urged the Soviet Union today to cooperate in ending "wanton provocations" by East German guards at the Berlin wall.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27-- At least twenty-five states will have reapportioned the membership of their Legislatures by the end of next year and thus will have effected a major change in government, Charles S. Rhyne, a Washington lawyer, said today.

BOSTON, Aug. 27--Edward M. Kennedy waded into his first political brawl tonight and emerged still standing on his feet. But he and his foe, Edward J. McCormack Jr., inflicted wounds that may be long in healing.
PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 27 --Early fears that Mariner II might be woefully off course were dispelled today as the 447pound spacecraft hurtled at 8,000 miles an hour toward the planet Venus.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 27 --James C. Fox a real estate man in New York for more than fifty years, died yesterday at Stamford Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 19 Hobson Street in Shippan Point.
CHICAGO, Aug. 27--A strike against the Chicago and North Western Railway by its 1,000 telegraphers is scheduled for 7 A.M. Thursday.
MOSCOW, Aug. 27--U Thant, Acting Secretary General of the United Nations, said today that he was not soliciting Soviet support for his re-election when his interim term of office expires next April.
United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau was accused yesterday of being coy by two rivals for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 27 --There were some unexpected reversals as the women's United States amateur golf championship got under way today. Between morning and evening rainstorms, three members of the United States Curtis Cup team bowed out at the Country Club of Rochester.

Dr. Fred C. Schwartz' Greater New York School of Anti-Communism drew a disappointing crowd of 400 "students" to morning and afternoon sessions at Carnegie Hall yesterday, the first day of a five-day course.
Blue Shield postponed yesterday a plan that would have increased medical costs for about 3,000,000 of its 5,000,000 subscribers in the metropolitan area.

THE deal shown today was played in a highly expert game at the Cavendish Club in New York Every bid and pass on the first round of the auction might seem strange in a casual bridge game but it was only the play and not the bidding that was discussed.
The New York Yankees, who have been teasing the American League lately with false hope, ended a six-game losing streak last night by drubbing the Cleveland Indians, 5--0.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 27-- St. Margaret's Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting this morning for the marriage of Miss Carlys Bowden, daughter of Mrs. Logan Morrill of Annapolis, formerly of Bermuda and Laurens R. Bowden of New York, to John S. Belmont.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 27--Aeronautical exports from twenty-six countries heard an appeal here today for postponement of the development of supersonic airliners "on ethical grounds."
Steel production declined slightly last week for its first drop in seven weeks.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 27-- A new pay scale for Westchester's forty-five county supervisors was proposed today by Barrington Co. of New York, salary consultants. The scale would add $55,500 to present costs.
Contracts awarded for new construction throughout the country last month amounted to $3,746,628,000, a gain of 6 per cent over the volume of $3,528,553,000 in July, 1961.
A Staten Island bank manager was charged yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court with missapropriation of his employer's funds in granting loans.
AT about the halfway point of last night's "Riddle of the Lusitania" on Channel 4, the program got around to its Subject.
In a generally quiet and mixed day on the New York Commodity exchanges, world sugar continued strong and cocoa dipped in moderate trading.

DALLAS, Aug. 27 (UPI)-- Attorney General Will Wilson charged today that Texas state employes took pay-offs to cover up a multi-million-dollar "slanthole" oil-stealing operation in the giant east Texas oil field.

WALKER VALLEY, N.Y., Aug. 26--The Good Life--football-training-camp style--is being gently supervised here by two policemen who make certain the athletes never drink soda pop, secretly munch on chocolate bars or stay out later than 9:30 P.M.

A VISITOR to the Charles Etzel summer home at Montauk, L.I., is likely to be greeted by the entire family-- including uncles, aunts, nephews and nieces--and probably an uncle bearing the morning's catch. Recently a fish received more attention than any visitors, however, because it was a nine-pound bluefish-- the largest caught so far that season at that particular spot.
FREEHOLD, N.J., Aug. 27 (AP)--The New Jersey Racing Commission was awaiting a request today for the approval of the sale of Freehold Raceway to Yonkers Raceway.
DETROIT, Aug. 27--Wage increases ranging from 6 to 9 cents an hour will go into effect for 500,000 automobile workers next week.
Miehle-Goss-Dexter, Inc. reported yesterday higher earnings for the quarter and nine months ended July 31 than for the periods a year earlier.
The new State Commissioner of Social Welfare, George K. Wyman, pledged yesterday that he would give a full accounting of the tax dollars paid to welfare programs.
PEIPING, Aug. 22 (Reuters) --Chinese industry is hard at work on a campaign to "keep the peasants happy."
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28-- Alvin Jackson, who never drinks, smokes or says naughty things to umpires, proved tonight that any clean-living Met pitcher can beat the Phillies with a threehitter.

ROCKVILLE, Ind., Aug. 28 (UPI)--Sen. Homer E. Capehart, Republican of Indiana, said last night that most of the Soviet personnel sent to Cuba were combat troops--not technicians as President Kennedy reported last week.

HONG KONG, Aug, 28--Some observers here predict that Chinese Communist nuclear scientists will attempt to explode an atomic device on Oct. 1, when the Peiping regime celebrates its thirteenth anniversary in power.
Carry Back won a relatively insignificant race at Aqueduct yesterday with most significant impact.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- The Kennedy Administration won the first Senate test on its tax revision bill today with the approval of a $1,000,000,000 tax credit for business. The vote was 52 to 30.

OTTAWA, Aug. 28--Dr. Edgar William Richard Steacie, physical chemist, educator and president of the Canadian National Research Council, died of cancer in his sleep early today at his home here. He was 61 years old.
Three more counties, all upstate, endorsed United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau yesterday for the Democratic nomination for Governor.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- Two Americans perished in the crash of a Thai Air Force helicopter Saturday night, United States agencies reported today.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 28-- Attempts to arrive at a formula for dealing with Cuba's demand for admission to the Latin American Free Trade Association failed today.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 28--At 9 o'clock this morning, the 1962 New York State Fair opened here with magic (the traditional ribbon was cut by a woman untraditionally suspended in air), a bevy of thirtyone beauty queens and Don J. Wickham, Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets. The exposition will run through Monday and is open from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M.
The bond market was mixed yesterday in continued quiet trading.

Operations of the McCrory Corporation resulted in net income of $2,008,000 for the second quarter, ended June 30, but a net loss of $2,566,000 for the first six months, the company reported yesterday.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 28 (AP)--Five records fell today while officials continued to haggle over whether the Asian Games were officially that or just another athletic carnival.
Studies of TV and Films Studies of the motion picture and television industries are planned for publication this season.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP)--President Kennedy interceded tonight in a threatened strike by Railroad Telegraphers against the Chicago and North Western Railway with an appeal for resumption of "intensive collective bargaining" in Chicago tomorrow morning.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 28-- Chancellor Adenauer sent letters today to the heads of government of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union appealing for a restoration of human rights in Berlin.
A new freighter whose speed makes her capable of holding her own on the North Atlantic with most passenger liners made her debut here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- The United States was reported today to be preparing a message to Cambodia intended to dissuade her from pressing her proposal for an international conference on means to insure her neutrality.

TWO HUNDRED of the nation's leading drivers will compete in the Sports Car Club of America national championship point races at the Thompson, Conn., course on Sunday and Monday. Seven sprint events, scheduled to start at 2 P.M. are to be run on Sunday.
NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 28--With a white-whiskered red-suited Santa Claus aboard, the nuclear-powered submarine Skate returned triumphantly today from her voyage to the North Pole.
Cotton futures were unchanged to $1.20 a bale down yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 28 (AP)--Urged into the lead by Steve Brooks just past the half-mile pole, Colonial Farm's Decade easily won the Frankford Purse by five lengths today at the Atlantic City track.
PARIS, Aug. 28--Balenciaga and Givenchy held showings this week one month after revealing their collections to buyers from stores and their customers.
Seymour Poe has been appointed vice president in charge of world distibution at Twentieth Century-Fox, it was announced yesterday by Darryl F. Zanuck.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- The House Ways and Means Committee dealt President Kennedy's legislative program another sharp blow today.

MONTGOMERY, Ala. Aug., 28 (AP)--Democratic voters chose new nominees for the Legislature in twenty-one of Alabama's sixty-seven counties today. The elections were held to comply with a Federal court reapportionment order.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- The Soviet Union has hinted that it is interested in fourpower discussions on Berlin, informed sources said today.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug, 28-- Miss Evelyn Tome Cavin, a social worker here for more than forty years, died today at her home in West Chester. She was 77 years old.

TOKYO, Aug. 28--Japan's sports world is split these days and Japan's diplomats, politicians, business men and newspapers are unhappy about the whole thing. Embarrassment, confusion and anger have marked the projection of the Japanese into an unpleasant political squabble being con-...

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 28--Samuel Margules, president of Huntington Auto Parts, Inc. and formerly a professional comedy magician known as Rami-Sami, died Friday in Huntington Hospital. He was 66 years old.
ALBANY, Aug. 28--Arthur S. Hirsch, Deputy State Tax Commissioner in charge of the Brooklyn office, was appointed by Governor Rockefeller today to the City Court bench in Brooklyn.

SANTA ROSA, Calif., Aug. 28 (AP)--Frank L. Taylor, former publisher of The Milwaukee Sentinel and former executive vice president of The New York Herald Tribune, died in his sleep early today, apparently of a heart ailment. He was 61 years old.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug, 28 (AP)--Three youths from wellto-do Argentine families, accused of having fixed shots at a theatre here showing a Jewish, play, were turned over today to a Federal court.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- The Consumer Price Index rose two-tenths of 1 per cent in July to a record of 105.5.
A Surrogate's Court was asked to decide yesterday whether the United States Government is a charitable institution.
GENEVA, Aug. 28--The United States and Britain refused to accept a negative answer today to their latest proposals for a total or a limited ban on nuclear weapons tests.
Benjamin Franklin is still making his influence felt on the French, even after 200 years, but in his role of musical inventor rather than that of statesman.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) --The Department of Commerce said today that imports into this country during July were valued at $1,353,400,000 on a seasonally-adjusted basis.

David H. Holbrook, former assistant director of the National Social Welfare Assembly, Inc., 345 East Forty-sixth Street, central national coordinating body for social welfare work, died Monday in San Diego, Calif., where he had lived recently in retirement. His age was 83.
Carol Burnett has signed a long-term, exclusive TV contract with the Columbia Broadcasting System

ROCHESTER, N.Y. Aug. 28 (AP)--Howard S. Samuels, a Democratic candidate for the governorship nomination, said today Governor Rockefeller's administration was one of "unrelieved failures" in the field of higher education.

A representative of the city's busineas and industry charged yesterday that some members of the Mayor's special commission on the minimum wage bill had been committed in advance to an hourly minimum of $1.25 at once and one of $1.50 within one year.
The first total synthesis of an antibiotic of the tetracycline group has been achieved, it was reported yesterday at a scientific meeting in Prague, Czechoslovakia.
Tennis had its own United Nations assembly yesterday at the Hotel Manger Vanderbilt.
ROME, Aug. 28--The Vatican newspaper Osservatore Romano rebuked today the Soviet astronauts Maj, Andrian G. Nikolayev and Lieut. Col. Pavel R. Popovich.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) --Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman declared today that a controversial farm program suggested by a business-supported research group "would in fact be a disaster."
The House of Seagram, Inc., denied yesterday all of the charges in proceedings filed against the company by the Department of Justice in Federal Court in Miami last week.
ALBANY, Ga., Aug. 28--The police arrested and jailed seventy religious leaders from the North and Midwest today during an anti-segregation protest at the City Hall.

BOSTON, Aug. 28 (AP)-- Irving Berlin's new musical "Mr. President" opened here last night but failed to win all the critics' votes.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 28--Prokofieff's opera. "The Gambler," which the Belgrade Opera performed tonight at the Edinburgh Festival, is one of the composer's least known works.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Aug. 28--Parliament ignored growing criticism today and passed the first of two measures giving Southern Rhodesia its strongest police powers in history.
Obstacles which had prevented the merger of the Metal and Thermit Corporation into the American Can Company were a removed and the two companies now appear to be headed for a possible union.

ALGIERS, Aug. 28--For the first time since Algeria gained independence July 3, Col. Houari Boumedienne and the two other members of the Army General Staff entered openly into the power struggle today.

Baseball rules prohibit the use of galoshes, slickers or bumbershoots, so last night's Stadium exercise between the Yankees and the Cleveland Indians ended in the fifth inning of the opener of a scheduled double-header.
PARIS, Aug. 28--Agreements defining the terms of French aid to Algeria, including joint exploitation of the mineral wealth of the Sahara, were signed in Paris today.
Stocks took a sharp loss yesterday in slow trading.
Less than one-sixth of the candidates and campaign committees involved in next week's primary in New York City have made public preliminary financial statements as required by law.
Yuri Faier, the Bolshoi Ballet conductor who is nearly blind, showed yesterday that a cool head for music and a warm heart for friends could go together.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 28 --Finding a gaping hole in the final sixteenth Dick Byrd moved from sixth at the top of the stretch and won the United Epilepsy feature by a nose tonight before 16,805 at Roosevelt Raceway.
Everyone would give a little in a proposed settlement of a stockholders derivative suit against officers and directors of Foremost Dairies, Inc., a leading dairy products company.
The Board of Elections warned yesterday that a strike on Saturday by the Teamsters Union would prevent the delivery of voting machines in Brooklyn in time for the primary Sept. 6.
Governor Rockefeller promised last night to investigate a complaint that Negroes were having difficulty getting jobs at the 1964-65 New York World's Fair.

Sales and earnings of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation in the three months ended July 31, first fiscal quarter of its operations, increased over those of the 1961 period. John R. Kimberly, chairman, told shareholders yesterday at the annual meeting in Neenah, Wis.
After three weeks without change, the United States' supply of monetary gold sustained a $34,000,000 loss on Aug. 23, a Treasury report disclosed yesterday. The Treasury

DALLAS, Aug. 28 (UPI)-- Texas oil pirates paid a former state oil official a $58,000 bribe to let them steal from wells adjoining their own in a multi-million-dollar "hot oil" scandal, officials charged today

NOROTON, Conn., Aug. 28-- Myers Noell of the Miami Yacht Club, sailing Corvus, won the opening race of the thirteenth Raven Class national championship on Long Island Sound in a heavy blow off Noroton Y.C. today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- The House opened its floor fight today over a proposed $900,000,000 authorization to accelerate public works to relieve unemployment.
A rusty, modern Noah's Ark wallowed into port here yesterday. It was the S.S. Lombok, out of South Africa, and she docked at Pier 1, Bush Terminal, Brooklyn.

There is an odd contradiction between our craving to entice foreign tourists to this country and the way we greet them when they come. The first view of the United States --as displayed by our largest port of entry, New York City--is enough to scare most visitors right back where they came from.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- Despite the Soviet Union's apparent decision to engage in a crash program of economic, technical and military aid to Cuba, numerous problems of their cooperation have not yet been worked out, diplomats here said tonight.

Department store branch outlets continued last year to lead their downtown parent stores in registering sales gains, according to a study to be released today by the National Retail Merchants Association.

Capital gains from the sale of property enabled the Hilton Hotels Corporation to lift its net income for the second quarter well above that for the 1961 period despite lower profits from operations, Conrad N. Hilton, president, reported yesterday.

BERLIN, Aug. 28--Mayor Willy Brandt told Berliners tonight that they must acecpt the "reality" that Berlin's fourpower status was destroyed when East Germany built the wall dividing the city last year.

MIAMI, Aug. 28 (AP)--The Monmouth Boat Club of Red Bank, N.J., held a narrow lead today after five races of the competition for the Adams Cup, which is emblematic of the women's sailing championship of the United States and Canada.
Television is normally thought of as the most "massive" of the mass media. But one advertiser is using TV to reach an extremely small, selective audience--namely, millionaires.

The quarrel between the United Arab Republic (Egypt) and Syria, which exploded again yesterday, is another sign of the failure to achieve Arab unity. Whether the quarrel is patched up or not, the fact will remain that the Arab League is a hope, not a reality.

During the month of June, the nation's principal stock exchanges handled $6,984,735,000 of securities sales. The New York Stock Exchange accounted for the lion's share--$6,272,888,765, or almost 90 per cent of the total.
ROCHESTER, N.Y. Aug. 28 --Players with international experience as well as newcomers to the event were among thirtytwo remaining in the United States women's amateur golf championship tonight.

Continuing their automatic rejection of all Western disarmament proposals, the Soviet Union has served notice that it will not even consider an agreement for a nuclear test ban based on the draft treaties submitted to the Geneva disarmament conference by President Kennedy and Prime Minister Macmillan.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 28 --Vice President Johnson arrived here tonight after a full day of ceremonies, military talks and cheering crowds.

EASTVIEW, N.Y., Aug. 28-- Dr. Webster Stover, a retired college president, chose jail rather than pay a fine and was imprisoned in Westchester County Penitentiary here today for maintaining lines of tattered clothes and dirty rags in the front yard of his home at Rye Beach and Forest Avenues, Rye.
MOSCOW, Aug. 28--The Government disclosed today that the volume of maritime shipments from the Soviet Union to Cuba in 1962 would be twice that of last year.

PARIS, "the city of light" and the mother of all the arts including the art of living, is also a city of blood. An extrava gant overstatement? No. At least it won't seem so to readers of "The Turbulent City: Paris 1783-1871" by Andre Castelot.

THE deal shown today, played in a home game in New York last week, may be added to large numbers of similar cases in which a declarer has dropped a singleton king for reasons that may seem obscure at first glance, but are good and sufficient upon further examination.
Houston, Tex., announced yesterday a tentative offering date for $14,000,000 of water-works revenue bonds.

The corporations that form the capitalist opposition to the company of Gagarin, Titov, Nikolayev, Popovich and Associates are not only trying to win the competition in space, but do it at reduced prices.

Judy Holliday has been signed to return to Broadway on Feb. 28 as the star of "Hot Spot," a musical satire dealing with Federal aid overseas. She will portray a member of the Peace Corps who has a penchant for complicating problems.

The mutual funds' leading spokesman said yesterday that the so-called Wharton School study of his industry's size was full of "misleading, incorrect and highly speculative comments." He charged that such statements "serve to impair investor confidence in mutual funds."
A 75-year-old woman was fatally hurt last night when a car hurtled out of a midtown parking lot, mounted the opposite sidewalk and drove her through a brick wall.
Former President Herbert Hoover was reported doing "fine" last night after a tumor had been removed from his large intestine in a three-hour operation.

The Winslow Hotel at 551-53 Madison Avenue, northeast corner of Fifty-fifth Street, has been purchased by the LeaderDurst Corporation, a real estate company. The seventeen-story building with penthouses was sold by the H.R. Weissberg Company for more than $2,400,000, of which $1,000,000 was in cash and the balance on a first mortage.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- Senator Kenneth B. Keating came out today in favor of Senate confirmation of Irving Ben Cooper as a Federal district judge.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 28--Mike Turnesa Jr. of Knollwood survived a shaky start this morning and then settled down to win two rounds of match play in the Westchester County Golf Association's junior championship at Pelham Country Club.

LONDON, Aug. 28--Four British neo-Nazi leaders were committed today to trial in criminal court on a charge that they had oorganized and trained a group that would employ force to achieve its political objectives.
A masterpiece of traffic engineering, four years in the making, will be unveiled today with the opening of the second deck of the George Washington Bridge.

AT this time of year, when stores are introducing mer chandise that is the fruit o' their buyers' trips abroad, customers may become confused by some of the terms applied to these fashions. Following is a glossary of some of the most frequently used terms.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (AP)-- Scattered late buying lifted grain futures to a mixed range on the Board of Trade today. But soybeans came under increasing pressure and scored broad setbacks for the third successive day.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 28 (AP)--Johnny Podres, backed by an eleven-hit attack that included two home runs, pitched the Los Angeles Dodgers to an 8-1 victory over the Cincinnati Reds tonight before 46,536 at Dodger Stadium. Podres scattered eight hits in scoring his eleventh victory and he knocked in a run with a single in the second.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28-- Senator Walter J. Mahoney, majority leader of the New York State Senate, severely criticized here today the manner in which American cities are being governed.
"No Strings," the Richard Rodgers musical now in its sixth month on Broadway, has been acquired for filming by Seven Arts Productions for more than $2,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- The Justice Department started a broad legal effort today to open the voting rolls in Mississippi to Negroes.
SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 28-- The ruling military junta imprisoned former Premier John M. Chang today after the army prosecutor at his court-martial had demanded a life sentence.
The Daitch-Shopwell, Kings, Packers and Waldbaum supermarket chains have joined the Bohack and Mayfair organizations in issuing King Korn stamps, effective as of yesterday.
The New York Conservative party has issued a preliminary campaign platform calling for "victory over communism" and strengthening of "free enterprise" elements in the nation's economy.

DES MOINES, Aug. 28--The militant young National Farmers Organization called a strike today for higher grain and livestock prices. Hogs, cattle, sheep, corn and soybeans will be held off the market, beginning at midnight Friday. Dairymen in the organization will decide soon whether to add milk to the list.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 28 (UPI)--Willie Mays hit his thirty-ninth home run tonight and then turned in one of his extraordinary catches that preserved the San Francisco Giants their fifth straight triumph, a 4-3 victory over the Milwaukee Braves.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. Aug. 28--Chattanooga will become the last of the four largest cities in Tennessee to desegregate its public schools tomorrow when 26,000 pupils report for registration.
The International Brotherhood of Teamsters has lent the Flight Engineers International Association $100,000 in support of its strike against Eastern Air Lines, reliable informants reported yesterday.
ALBANY, Aug. 28--The development of an improved waterway between the St. Lawrence and the Port of New York was urged today as a vital factor in the industrial expansion of the northeast.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 28 (AP)--A holocaust swept out of the mountains around the San Fernando Valley today.
First notice of intention to deliver on the September contract produced heavy trading in cocoa futures yesterday. Other commodities traded on New York exchanges were quiet and mixed.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 28 (AP)-- Don McMahon and Bob Bruce combined to pitch the Houston Colts to their third straight victory tonight, a 4-2 decision over the St. Louis Cardinals.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- The director of a study of mutual funds for the Securities and Exchange Commission defended today the study's findings that, on the average, an individual investor could do as well as the funds have done.

ELGIN, Ill., Aug. 28--With hands' clasped contentedly behind his head, Floyd Patterson was relaxing at his hilltop training quarters in the bucolic setting of Marycrest Farm. He was wearing a T-shirt, rumpled brown slacks, heavy walking boots and his ever-present sly little grin. Suddenly his right hand flashed out and captured a buzzing fly.
LONDON, Aug. 28--British Government bonds, which have been advancing slowly but steadily for weeks, rose sharply on the stock market today.

DU QUOIN, Ill., Aug. 28-- Fifteen 3-year-olds will be off and trotting in the $116,612.78 Hambletonian tomorrow. A record crowd of 40,000 is expected to turn out in 90-degree weather for the thirty-seventh edition of harness racing's counterpart of the Kentucky Derby.

The Appellate Division last night unanimously upheld the right of J. Dudley Devine to be listed on the ballot as a candidate for the Republican nomination for City Council in Manhattan's Twentieth District.
The fiftieth anniversary fundraising campaign of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York will open with a tea and reception in the main ballroom of the Americana on Oct. 16.
Percy C. Magnus failed to file Federal income tax returns from 1948 through 1957 and failed to report income totaling $1,200,000 for that period, the Government said yesterday in Federal Court.
An attempt may have been made this week to corner the floating supply in the weekly Treasury bill auction.

SHTURA, Lebanon, Aug. 28 --The United Arab Republic, angered by Syria's charges of Egyptian interference in Syrian affairs, walked out of an Arab League council meeting today and threatened to quit the league.

ROME, Aug. 28--The British delegate to the general assembly of the International Civil Aviation Organization urged today a general hands-off policy to permit national development of supersonic jet aircraft.

George Shaw, Tom Tracy, Jess Richardson and Don Gillis, all first-string National Football League players a year ago, were among a host of players cut yesterday as the clubs got down to the forty-three-man limit.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- Alfred E. Perlman, president of the New York Central Railroad, said today that the inclusion of the New Haven Railroad in the system that would result from the proposed merger of the Central and the Pennsylvania Railroad would not be in the public interest.
The Federal Aviation Agency said yesterday that it would begin air traffic studies on Nov., 26 on three possible sites for a new metropolitan area jetport.
MOSCOW, Aug. 28--A form of industrial organization known as "the firm" is being increasingly promoted in the Soviet Union as a remedy for some of the country's economic ills.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 28--The Belgian Government expressed the belief today that there was a basis for "an acceptable settlement for all parties" in the Congo in Premier Cyrille Adoula's plan for a federal constitution and the proposals advanced by U Thant, Acting Secretary General of the United Nations.
About twenty real estate agents and speculators have been subpoenaed to appear before the city Commission on Human Rights to face charges of block-busting in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 28 (AP) --Bill Mazeroski's home run off the left-field scoreboard clock in the eighth inning tonight broke a 6-6 tie and carried the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 7-6 victory over the Chicago Cubs.
Notices of rent reductions will go within ten days to 925 tenants in the Bronx and Brooklyn whose rents have been increased illegally, the city announced yesterday.

The study of mutual funds prepared for the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Wharton School is a comprehensive and largely factual report that provides the first real profile in depth of a dynamic, expanding industry. It should be useful to the public and Congress and, above all, to the industry itself, for it presents a wealth of information on the scope of mutual funds and the problems that they face.
MOSCOW, Aug. 28--Premier Khrushchev conferred on international problems today with U Thant, Acting Secretary General of the United Nations, and Walter Ulbricht, Communist leader of East Germany.
Plans for extensive highway building, much of it needed for the World's Fair in 1964 and 1965, were outlined yesterday before the City Planning Commission.

The Transit Authority disclosed yesterday that it had asked the city for money for 300 new buses. They would be used on the seventy-five routes in Manhattan and the Bronx that were taken over by the city from the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines last March.

ATHENS, Aug. 28 (AP)-- A severe earthquake jolted Greece today and sent tremors through Mediterranean bedrock to southern Italy, Sicily, Grete and Malta. Homes were toppled in some areas of Greece. Elsewhere the damage was apparently slight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- The Port of New York Authority was authorized today to operate the railroad facilities of the bankrupt Hudson and Manhattan Railroad.

LONDON, Wednesday, Aug. 29--Prime Minister Macmillan has declared that Britain will join "wholeheartedly" in the move toward greater political union in Europe once negotiations are completed on her bid to join the Common Market.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- Democrats in the Senate put on an unusual demonstration of support today for Charles S. Murphy, Under Secretary of Agriculture, who has come under fire for his handling of the Billie Sol Estes case.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- President Kennedy told 5,000 college students today that the burden of preserving world freedom in the next ten or twenty years "will be
A growing sense of urgency prevailed at talks yesterday between Federal mediators and the longshoremen's union. The contract covering 90,000 New York dockworkers expires Sept. 30.

CHICAGO, Thursday, Aug. 30 --Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg presided all day yesterday and early today at negotiations seeking to avert a strike against the nation's third largest railroad, the Chicago and North Western, set for 7 o'clock this morning.

"It would be impossible," said the great Learned Hand a few years ago, "for me to think of any other judge whose continuance in his duties I welcome more unreservedly." He was speaking of Felix Frankfurter, whose retirement as Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States was regretfully announced yesterday by President Kennedy.
Alma, the tropical storm that became a hurricane Monday, dwindled to a mediumsized gale last night as it moved northeast about 100 miles from the coast of Massachusetts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP)--A Senate Judiciary subcommittee was reported tonight to have voted 2 to 1 to recommend Senate rejection of Thurgood Marshall's nomination to be a Federal Circuit Court judge.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29-- President Kennedy announced today that the foreign ministers of the four Western powers would meet in September. The primary topic of discussion will be Berlin.

DALLAS, Aug. 29 (UPI)-- Five men, one a former state oil inspector accused of taking a $47,000 bribe, invoked the Fifth Amendment a total of 101 times today and refused to testify before a legislative committee investigating Texas multi--million--dollar slant well scandal.
HONG KONG, Aug. 29-- Premier Chou En-lai has pledged Communist China's support for a conference to recognize and guarantee the neutrality and territorial integrity of Cambodia.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 29 (AP)--Orlando Pena handcuffed Los Angeles with a three-hit shutout tonight as the Kansas City Athletics beat the Angels, 6--0.
Most commodity futures traded on New York exchanges advanced yesterday in moderate to light trading.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 29-- Sophocles returned today to the ghost city of Caesaria, the onetime pagan metropolis on Israel's Mediterranean coast.

MANCHESTER, England, Aug. 29--Sir John Cockcroft, one of Britain's leading scientists, said tonight that the British had "a good deal to learn from some American organizations who have a consistent record of success in developing new products by objective basic research and applied research."

CAIRO, Thursday, Aug. 30 (Reuters)--The United Arab Republic's delegation returned here early today after having walked out of a meeting of the Arab League Council at Shtura, Lebanon, because of remarks by Syrians.
The Alpha Portland Cement Company, Philadelphia, announced completion of arrangements yesterday for $40,000,000 in loans from the Prudential Life Insurance Company and the Chase Manhattan Bank.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 29 --Rock 'n' roll music is being recorded here by concert violinists, violists and 'cellists on instruments of great value. At a few recent recording sessions of rock 'n' roll, the string instruments were worth more than $250,000.
Five more landlords were arrested yesterday in the city's investigation of the state's administration of rent control here.
Stocks rallied yesterday afternoon after sizable morning losses, but the rebound was not quite large enough to avert a small decline on average at the close.
SINGAPORE, Aug. 29--Efforts of pro-Communists to win control of the strategic port of Singapore are expected to broaden significantly after a referendum Saturday.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 29-- Adolfo Lanus, a journalist who has held high political posts in the past, became Argentina's Defense Minister today.

HAVANA, Aug. 29--The regime of Premier Fidel Castro put tight controls today on the wages of Cuban workers, invoked stiff penalties for absenteeism and authorized... the sharp curtailment of vacation time in an effort to increase production.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29-- Under Secretary of Agriculture Charles S. Murphy spoke up in his own defense today in the Billie Sol Estes case.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29-- Plans to bypass a reluctant Senate committee and force a floor vote authorizing Government sale of the General Aniline and Film Corporation were announced today.

Kidder, Peabody Co., Dean, Witter Co., and associates, offered yesterday $45,000,000 of Air Reduction Company convertible subordinated debentures due Aug. 15, 1987, priced at 100 with a 3 7/8 per cent interest coupon.

The United States Steel Corporation announced plans yesterday to install a pair of 150ton-capacity oxygen steel-making furnaces at its Duquesne, Pa., works, which is part of the facilities the company has along the Monongahela River near Pittsburgh.

HONG KONG, Aug, 29 (AP) --Religious groups in this parched British colony prayed for rain today as the Government reduced the time allotted for obtaining water from five to three hours each day because of a record dry spell.
Three major railroad operating unions sued the Association of American Railroads for $1,500,000 yesterday, charging that management had falsely accused them of featherbedding.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 29--The Congolese Government announced today that it was giving aid to Angolan rebels against the Portuguese in the same way that Morocco and Tunisia had supported "their Algerian brothers" in the fight against the French.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP)--The House, in a surprising reversal, left the door open today for possible use of waste steam from a Hanford, Wash., nuclear reactor to produce electricity.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 29--Premier Viggo Kampmann has decided to resign the Premiership and his seat in Parliament, according to a source close to him. The Premier had his second heart attack in less than four months yesterday.

An "immense majority" of the French favor the new friendship and understanding with Germany fostered by President de Gaulle and Chancellor Adenauer, according to Admiral Antoine Sala, president of the French Association of the Atlantic Community.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 29 (AP)--The wind shifted today and dramatically turned a raging brush fire back into the mountains. The multi-million-dollar blaze had threatened to sweep into the populous north rim of the San Fernando Valley, but foothill communities are no longer endangered, firemen said.

Prices of Treasury and corporate bonds slid off in professional trading yesterday morning, but retail buying in the afternoon helped erase the losses. Municipal issues continued to show a good tone in fairly active trading.
Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman, long identified with the reform movement in the Democratic party, endorsed a regular Democrat for re-election yesterday.

HONG KONG, Aug. 29-- Three Chinese Communist guards were injured, one seriously, when a bomb exploded at the Lowu frontier post this morning. The Communists im mediately closed the border with Hong Kong.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29-- Speculation about a successor to Arthur J. Goldberg as Secretary of Labor centered today on Under Secretary W. Willard Wirtz.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 29--The traditional end-of-season "The Village Vanities," which each year is staged here as a benefit for Guild Hall, will have a changed format this year. In place of the customary musical revue, this year's event will be the musical comedy ...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI)--The arrest of seventyfive ministers in Albany, Ga., was denounced and defended in the Senate today. There were charges of Southern "rebellion" and counter-charges of subversion by racial groups.

The Brooklyn Hospital is offering a refresher course designed to meet the needs of the inactive professional nurse who wants to return to nursing. The course is to be given twice a year at the hospital, 121 De Kalb Avenue, Brooklyn.
PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 29 --Scientists activated by radio four observation devices on the Venus-bound spacecraft Mariner II today at a distance of 447,897 miles and instantly began receiving data.
The Curtis Publishing Company has subleased most of the third floor in the Tishman Building, 666 Fifth Avenue at Fifty-second Street.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI)--Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy said today that President Kennedy might issue an order by Jan. 1 banning racial discrimination in housing built iwth Federal aid.
The International Silver Company plans to diversify its activities further through the proposed acquisition of a crown bottle-cap maker.

SAN ANTONIO was recently the scene of the an nual United States Open Chess Championship Tournament. The event drew 144 players from nearly every state. The two games discussed today are from the first round.

The Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Barbara Gayle Pollock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max Edwin Pollock of 1125 Park Avenue, to Robert Perkins

George Abbott, 75-year-old director of two currently popular Broadway shows, "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum" and "Take Her, She's Mine," has undertaken the staging of "Cradle and All." It will mark the eighty-second local directorial effort for the producer, director and author.

Los Angeles borrowed $33,300,000 yesterday on revenue bonds of the Department of Water and Power, consisting of $21,000,000 of electric plant bonds due 1963 to 1992 and $12,300,000 of electric plant refunding bonds due 1963 to 1986.

HOUSTON, Aug. 29 (UPI)-- --A Federal grand jury indicted two former Agriculture Department officials and another man today on thirty-five charges of bribery and conspiracy in the fraudulent transfer of Texas rice acreage allotments.

The Board of Elections intends to list the names of candidates and campaign treasurers who violate the state law requiring them to file accurate accountings of campaign contributions and expenditures.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29-- The saddest episode of that gripping baseball serial, "Casey Faces Life," was enacted at Connie Mack Stadium tonight as the Phillies beat the Mets, 3--2, in ten innings.
The United States Weather Bureau has become a training ground for tomorrow's weathermen.
Increased sales were shown by Federated Department Stores, Inc., for the twelve, twenty-six and fifty-two weeks ended Aug. 4 over the corresponding periods a year earlier.

August 28, 1942. My Dear Mr. President: Pursuant to the provisions of 28 U.S.C. (Sec.) 371 (B), 68 Stat. 12, I hereby retire at the close of this day from regular active service as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States.
The first player from the Soviet Union to compete in an American tennis tournament left the Forest Hills Stadium of the West Side Tennis Club in triumph yesterday.

With a Morgenthau-for-Governor headquarters already set up, and endorsements from Democratic county chairmen rolling in around the clock, the question begins to arise whether the party's trip to Syracuse Sept. 17 is really necessary. Only a few days ago the troubled Democrats were wondering whether they ought not to have two conventions. Now it looks as though one may be more than they need.
LONDON, Aug. 29--British Government bonds were irregular on the stock market today. After yesterday's big rises and the accumulated gains of recent weeks, there was considerable profit taking.

A giant stripping shovel, said to be the largest mobile land machine ever built, has gone to work at the Sinclair mine of the Peabody Coal Company at Paradise, Ky. Designed and built by Bucyrus-Erie Company of South Milwaukee, Wis., the new machine stands 220 feet tall-- ninety feet higher than the top of the Statue of Liberty.

The Spring Valley Water Works and Supply Company which provides water service for a large part of Rockland County, pledged yesterday a $1,000,000 contribution toward the cost of financing a proposed Rockland County sewer system.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) --Four companies and two unions involved in the aerospace industry will meet in Washington Sept. 4 to try to settle their labor dispute.
Stockholders of the Premier Industrial Corporation at their annual meeting yesterday in Cleveland approved an increase in the number of common shares authorized from 1,500,000 to 2,500,000.
The slate of administrative officers of the recently formed New York 65 Health Insurance Association was announced yesterday by Morton D. Miller, president of the new group.

Consolidated Sun Ray, Inc., big drug chain, said yesterday in Philadelphia that it had completed transactions to raise $4,000,000 over the next six months. The money is wanted chiefly for working capital.
ROCHESTER N.Y., Aug. 29 --Marcia McLachlan of St. Petersburg, scored the principal upset today in the women's United States amateur golf championship.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29-- Arthur Joseph Goldberg was working on a labor-management dispute in Chicago, a few miles from his West Side birthplace, when President Kennedy called today to tell him his next assignment was the Supreme Court.

PORT ABINO, N.Y., Aug. 29 (AP)--Carl Eichenlaub Jr., sailing a boat he built in his San Diego workshop a month ago, scored a victory and a second-place finish today in the North American Lightning championships.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29-- President Kennedy rejected today the Soviet Union's proposal for an unpoliced moratorium on all nuclear weapons tests.
LONDON, Aug. 29--Britain emphasized today that there had been no change in her plan to participate in a European political union if she became a member of the Common Market.
About 100,000 students will enroll this fall in the seven colleges of the City University of New York, the Board of Higher Education announced yesterday.
Negotiators for 57,000 truck drivers in the New York-New Jersey area agreed yesterday to extend their contract, which expires at 12:01 A.M. Saturday, to Sept. 9.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29-- The Senate rejected tonight President Kennedy's proposal for withholding personal income taxes on dividends and interest at the source. The vote was 66 to 20.
The Securities and Exchange Commission and the American Stock Exchange are looking into trading in the stock of the Kirby Petroleum Company.
Cotton futures fell 10 cents to $1.15 a bale yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

Maradel Products, Inc., cosmetics and toiletries manufacturer, has appointed Dr. J.B. Nagler as director of research and development. He was director of research for the Northam Warren Corporation and the Lehn Fink Products Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29--A White House spokesman said today that President Kennedy "is working at high speed" to find a replacement for Sterling M. McMurrin as Commissioner of Education.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y. Aug. 29. (AP)--A Democratic committee gathering recommendations for the party's convention platform heard vigorous union opposition today to a railroad management plea for repeal of full crew laws.

In a move to offset the impact of the new Anglo-American test-ban proposals, Soviet Russia has now resorted to a strategy throwing the negotiations back to where they began. The U.S.S.R. proposes at the Geneva disarmament conference that all nations simply stop all nuclear weapons tests beginning Jan. 1--without any international inspection or control.
Railroad men have not had much cause for optimism in recent years. Earnings have been low, merger plans have been sidetracked and work-rule changes have been slow to come.
Darryl F. Zanuck yesterday closed the Twentieth CenturyFox studio in Hollywood for an indefinite period.

Charles Hamiel, arraigned yesterday in Felony Court on a burglary charge, doesn't like to make mistakes. And so, according to the arresting detective in the case, John Sheehan, he made a list for himself on how to be a good burglar.
BURAS, La., Aug. 29 (UPI) --Five Negro children entered a Roman Catholic school today to end parochial school segregation in Louisiana. Most of the white pupils stayed away.

An engine of a New York Airways helicopter that landed in the East River Sunday was clogged by material from a weather protection "boot" on its forward rotor head, Federal investigators said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug.29 (UPI) --A Harvard University doctor questioned today the often-heard statement that the United States is the healthiest nation in the world.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 29 --Chauncey D. Steele Jr. of Cambridge, Mass., won two matches in the Eastern senior grass court tennis championships today at the Huntington Crescent Club.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29-- Felix Frankfurter has retired from active service on the Supreme Court after twenty-three years as an associate justice.
