ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 29--Three bids were received by the City Council last night for luxury housing to be constructed on a municipal beachfront site at the north end of the boardwalk between the ocean and Deal Lake. The plot is now occupied by a restaurant building.
The sweetest detective in town this week also was one of the shrewdest.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 29--The foreign ministers of the six Common Market countries are planning to meet here in late September or early October to discuss the proposed European political union.

ALBANY, Aug. 29--Dr. James E. Allen, Commissioner of Education, ruled today that Hicksville, L.I, could not designate a portion of the National Anthem as an official school prayer. But he added that there was nothing to prevent reading, reciting or singing it in the schools.
The Citizens Union made public yesterday its preferences in eight Democratic legislative primary races in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx.

BONN, Aug. 29--The Federal Health Ministry announced today that the sleep-inducing drug thalidomide had caused about 10,000 birth deformities in West Germany. The pill was put on the market in 1957, and was sold without prescription.

HANKINS, N.Y., Aug. 29 --Assemblyman R. Wat son Pomeroy, the chairman of New York State's Joint Legislative Committee on Natural Resources, was the commander of a three-boat flotilla that made a thirteen-mile "float-down" on the Delaware River yesterday.
SYRACUSE, Aug. 29--This is Women's Day at the New York State Exposition, which opened yesterday. And the general consensus seems to be that all the exhibits look good enough to eat.
August is customarily a tranquil month on Madison Avenue. The advent of the vacation season seems to inhibit the usual ebb and flow of accounts and personnel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29-- President Kennedy announced today that the Schola Cantorum, a forty-voice mixed choir from the University of Arkansas in Little Rock, won first prize in the International Polyphonic Contest at Arezzo, Italy.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29--If present mergers do not solve the railroads' problems, the next step would be nationalization of the industry rather than new consolidations of merged systems.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 (AP)-- Smart Deb, an undefeated filly owned and bred by Mrs. Russell L. Reineman of Chicago, scored her sixth victory by winning the $67,400 Arlington Lassie by three and a quarter lengths today at Arlington Park.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug 29-- A proposal that consumer education be made a part of school curriculums was made here today. Miss Mary E. Cunningham, speaking to a conference on consumer protection, urged:
THE PRESIDENT--I have several announcements to make. I regret to announce Associate Justice (Felix) Frankfurter has retired from regular active service on the Supreme Court.

Herbert Hoover was progressing to his physicians' satisfaction yesterday twenty-four hours after an intestinal operation, and the former President was thinking again about canasta games with his family.

The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, the nation's largest tobacco concern, is negotiating to acquire the Pacific Hawaiian Products Company, manufacturer of fruit-juice beverages under the Hawaiian Punch brand name.
Gene Shue came back to the New York Knicks yesterday. The star guard of the Detroit Pistons was acquired for a reported $25,000 and Darrall Imhoff, a 23-year-old, 6-foot-10inch center.
DUQUOIN, Ill., Aug. 29-- Sanders Russell, a harness racing driver for forty-seven of his sixty-two years, rarely has gone to the whip because he disapproves of it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29--Following are the main points of President Kennedy's forty-second news conference today: Supreme Court--He announced the retirement of Associate Justice Felix Frankfurter and the nomination of Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg to succeed him. [Opening statement]
A new "Carmen" will be given at the New York City Opera this season. After more than 200 performances there, the Bizet opera is having its face lifted.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29-- President Kennedy took issue sharply today with Congressional advocates of heavy cuts in his $4,672,000,000 foreign aid program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29-- Charles Springs Murphy said recently, "I'm a realist, but I think I'll survive." As an old Washington hand, Charlie Murphy knows the pitfalls of politics as well as any man. He has been around ...

The refusal of the House Ways and Means Committee to recommend extended unemployment insurance for workers who have exhausted their state benefit rights disregards the needs of 850,000 victims of long-term joblessness. It transfers to idle workers and their families the burden of paying unassisted the price for the nation's failure to solve its most pressing domestic problem--the fuller use of its manpower and industrial capacity.
Joseph Santly, a song plugger who also was a song writer and vaudeville performer, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 807 Riverside Drive.

Yankee pitching resources seemed temporarily depleted yesterday as the American League leaders fell before the Cleveland Indians in both ends of a Stadium double-header. The scores were 3--2 and 9--5.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 29 --Two Birmingham policemen have been indicted by a Federal grand jury on a civil rights charge involving the shooting of a Negro father and an assault on his son.

A new era in the life of the George Washington Bridge started at 3:17 P.M. yesterday when the six-lane lower deck went into service. The opening of the second deck makes the bridge across the Hudson the only fourteen-lane vehicular crossing in the world.

AURORA, Ill., Aug. 29--In the forlorn setting of an abandoned race track, Aurora Downs, Sonny Liston is viotently and viciously at work in a heavyhanded bid for Floyd Patterson's world heavyweight championship. Neglect and disuse have left their marks at the track. So have the auto racers who last used it. Rails have been smashed and some of the outer fences toppled. It's a ghost track.
George C. Lessner has resigned as a director of the Pratt Whitney Company, Inc., the second largest division of the Fairbanks Whitney Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29--The House passed today a $900,000,000 public works bill designed to relieve unemployment in economically depressed areas. It gave its approval by voice vote after rejecting, 221 to 192, a Republican attempt to kill the measure by sending it back to the Public Works Committee.

LONDON, Aug, 29--Dr. Robert A. Soblen began his appeal today against deportation by Britain to the United States. His argument was presented before three justices in the Court of Appeal. The hearing will continue tomorrow.

A 43-year-old butcher was accused yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, of possessing $18,000 in counterfeit $20 bills. Arrested by Secret Service agents, Anthony Ruggiero of 784 East Eighth Street, Brooklyn ...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI)--A special emergency board in a report to President Kennedy rejected today a proposal of the Brotherhood of Railroad Telegraphers that the New York Central Railroad be prohibited from abolishing any job that existed March 4, 1958.

Rachel Carson, who has warned that the use of pesticides threatens to poison man's environment, is expected to appear on an hour-long "C.B.S. Reports" program that will examine her book, "Silent Spring," and the reaction to it. The program will be televised next fall by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

The Consolidated Foods Corporation, food processor and distributor, had record sales and earnings for the seventh consecutive year in the twelve months ended June 30, Nathan Cummings, chairman, and S.M. Kennedy, president, reported yesterday
GENEVA, Aug. 29.--The Soviet Union submitted to the disarmament conference today a formula for halting nuclear weapons tests that the United States and Britain have repeatedly termed unacceptable.

SEATTLE, Wash., Aug. 29-- Mrs. Theiline McGee Pigott and John A. McCone, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, were married here this morning. The Rev. William Gallagher performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in St. Anne's Chapel of the Sacred Heart Villa.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 29--Governor Rockefeller used the occasion of his annual visit to the State Fair to reassure the Onondaga Republican organization today that the higher taxes his administration had imposed were essential to the maintenance of a healthy economy.

Sugar Ray Robinson, the former world middleweight boxing champion, sailed on the Queen Elizabeth yesterday to keep a Sept. 25 date in London for a ten-around bout against Terry Downes, also an ex-champion.

The Commonweal, a leading Roman Catholic journal edited by laymen, assailed the Jesuit weekly America yesterday for warning Jews that continued pressure by them to keep religion out of the public schools might lead to an outbreak of anti-Semitism.
A drop of 1,640,000 barrels in the country's gasoline stocks in the week ended Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.
A newspaper editor from Albany, Ga., said last night that seventy-five religious leaders who had held an anti-segregation rally there Tuesday had been "practicing blasphemy."
Henry Goelet, president of the Transnation Realty Corporation, 285 Madison Avenue, died yesterday of cancer in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 65 years old.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (UPI)-- Sparked by Bob Allison's threerun homer in the first inning, the Minnesota Twins defeated the Chicago White Sox, 5--3, tonight and moved within two games of the league-leading New York Yankees. With Los Angeles losing to the Kansas City Athletics, the Twins went into second place, a game ahead of the Angels.

AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 29-- The Kings of Saudi Arabia and Jordan, friends amid the hostilities of the Arab world, said tonight that they would merge their military forces and coordinate economic policies.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 (AP)--The Reading Company has acquired the Lehigh and Susquehanna Railroad, a 105mile line between Phillipsburg, N.J., and Wilkes-Barre, Pa., it was announced here today.

WOMEN may be playing an increasingly more important role in the dog show picture in the United States but it still is largely a man's sport in the Caribbean. Harley A. Miller, the president of the Puerto Rico Kennel Club ...

New York State toughened its urban-renewal regulations yesterday to advance racial integration in housing. Chiefly affected will be small upstate communities and suburban areas, where charges have often been made that urban renewal means "Negro removal."
MOSCOW, Aug. 29--Robert Frost, the poet, and Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall arrived here today for ten-day visits under the United StatesSoviet exchange program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29-- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 22:

Saw Robinson McIlvaine, Ambassador to Republic of Dahomey; met with representatives of Junior Red Cross from forty-one countries; saw the Very Rev. Paul Boutros Meouchi, Patriarch of Maronite Church of Lebanon; held news conference.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29--A dollar earned by the average American consumer a year ago will buy a shade less than 99 cents worth of goods and services today.

SANDS POINT, L.I., Aug. 29 --Dick DeMane of Engineers and Tom Strafaci of Dyker Beach gained the semi-finals of the Bob Stuhler Memorial propro championship of the Long Island Professional Golfers Association today at the Sands Point Golf Club.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Aug. 29 (AP)--A 14-year-old football player for St. Cecilia High School of Englewood died of a heart attack Monday after a practice session at the Carmelite Seminary in Hamilton, Mass., it was disclosed today. The school is operated by the Carmelite order.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 29 --Mr. and Mrs. John K. Colgate have made known the engagement of their daughter. Miss Mary Katherine Colgate, to Rufus Bullock, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. George Bullock of North Grafton, Mass.
ICE CAPADES came to town last night for the premiere of its twenty-third edition at Madison Square Garden with something old, something new, something borrowed and something blue.

Four foreign and six American musicians will make their first appearances with the New York Philharmonic this season and Pierre Boulez, the French composer, will conduct the first United States performance of his orchestral work "Doubles."
ITHACA, N.Y., Aug, 29-- Harold D. and Percy Uris of New York, investment builders, have granted Cornell University securities valued at $1,000,000 in support of the Undergraduate Library,
The Board of Education was told yesterday that it must "drastically" reduce its proposed capital, budget of $242,109,204.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 29--A British aviation expert said today that the development of commercial airliners that fly faster than sound was not only inevitable but also socially acceptable and economically sound.
TROYES, France, Aug. 29-- The trial of five men accused of having tried to kill President de Gaulle last year began today in a heavily-guarded provincial courtroom here.
ALGIERS, Aug. 29--Fighting between rival Algerian military factions broke out today in the Casbah, the city's historic Moslem section.

ACCRA, Ghana, Aug. 29-- President Kwame Nkrumah jailed today two of his senior Cabinet ministers and the executive secretary of his ruling Convention People's party. The party's chief newspaper immediately linked the three with the recent bomb attack on the President.

NOROTON, Conn., Aug. 29-- Carter Saies of Grosse Point, Mich., won the second race of the thirteenth annual Raven Class national championship with Sea Sails IV off Noroton Y.C. today. The victory put him 1 point ahead in the regatta, which ends on Long Island Sound tomorrow, Sales has 43 points.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 29-- Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas Derrico's Volo Mon, a full brother to today's Hambletonian winner, A. C.'s Viking, tried to duplicate the feat of his younger brother in the first race at Roosevelt Raceway tonight but failed.
Four thousand employes of nine hotels, in uniforms of many colors, staged a thirty-minute work stoppage yesterday.

Morgan Guaranty Trust Company admitted yesterday it was the big bidder in Monday's Treasury bill auction but denied it was attempting to corner the short-term securities market. The bank had submitted a bid for $650,000,000 of the $1,300,000,000 in ninetyone-day bills that the Treasury auctioned last Monday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29--President Kennedy told the reporters today that he is totally opposed to a military "invasion" of Cuba; and that the Government as yet has no information concerning the "technical" personnel and cargoes Soviet Russia is landing, or will land, on the island that justifies any reconsideration of his position. He will ...

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 29--Long ago, when St. Louis was a big town in the shoe trade, the local wits used to describe it as "first in booze, first in shoes and last in the American League." Times have changed. St. Louis today is so average in everything that it's downright eerie.
The Transit Authority plans new subways on the basis of city needs generally and not to conform to the demands of localities for more service, its chairman, Charles L. Patterson, declared yesterday.
Directors of the Wheeling Steel Corporation cut the dividend on the common stock yesterday to 25 cents a share, from 50 cents paid in each of the last three quarters.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29-- Anyone who has fallen under the spell of Felix Frankfurter --and that includes nearly everyone who has met him briefly --knows how difficult it is to capture in words the spirit of his effervescent personality.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP)-- The Seventh Circuit United States Court of Appeals granted a motion by the railroads today for an expedited ruling in a dispute on work rules they contend are costing them $1,600,000 a day for unnecessary jobs.
Burnett Olcott McAnney, vice president of The New York World-Telegram and Sun, died Tuesday night in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 70 years old and had suffered a heart attack Saturday night.
Mohawk Airlines canceled yesterday almost half its flights for today because its pilots were nearing the maximum amount of flying time allowed for the month.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29 (UPI)--The Milwaukee Braves, routing Billy O'Dell for the second consecutive time, ended the San Francisco Giants' winning streak at five today by scoring a 10-3 triumph.
Igor Stravinsky and his associate, Robert Craft left yesterday for Israel, where they will tour for a week.
Mayor Wagner's bill to establish a two-step minimum wage for employes in industry is scheduled for passage by the City Council today.

James B. Donovan, former counsel to the Central Intelligence Agency, left for Havana yesterday to negotiate with the Catro regime for the release of 1,113 Cubans imprisoned after last year's ill-fated invasion.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 29 (AP)--The Eighth United States Circuit Court of Appeals, in an unusual action, has reduced by more than half a $1,056,250 damage award obtained by the now-bankrupt Automatic Washer Company, of Newton, Iowa, against the Bankers Life and Casualty Company of Chicago.
CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP)-- All grain and soybean futures gained today.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 29 --India disclosed today a clash with Chinese Communist troops Aug. 14 near Pangong Lake in the disputed border region of Ladakh in eastern Kashmir.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 29 (Reuters)--The labor shortage inside the European Common Market remains acute and is slowing down expansion in certain economic sectors, the market's Executive Commission said today.
PARIS, Aug. 29--President de Gaulle authorized today increased measures to protect his life. He also promised action to insure his succession.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29-- President Kennedy firmly rejected today Congressional suggestions that the United States invade Cuba because of the alleged presence there of Soviet combat troops.

EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Aug. 29 (UPI) --Maj. Bob Rushworth of the Air Force resorted to an emergency control system in one of the X-15's hottest heat flights today when the ship's troublehaunted electronic brain suffered a mysterious failure.

VENICE, Italy, Aug. 29--The film "Lolita," listed as a United States-British entry at the Venice Film Festival, was almost withdrawn tonight when the producers learned that the film would lose a reported $400,000 in British subsidy unless its part-American status was dropped.

Nine lectures delivered last year by Arnold J. Toynbee have been brought together in "America and the World Revolution," which Oxford University Press will issue here Oct. 4. In three lectures at the University of Pennsylvania, he ...
EXPERT bridge tends to be tricky and a good player probably views his opponents with a suspicious eye, but in the long run it pays to trust one's opponents.

Play Time, the Pin Oak Stable's 4-year-old filly, likes mud. She won a handicap at Saratoga on Aug. 14 when the going was gooey. She won again yesterday at Aqueduct, kicking big gobs of mud back at the D.C. Stable's Linita and the odds-on favorite, Darby Dan Farm's Primonetta.
In thirty-one states more than two-thirds of the populations are protected by some form of voluntary health insurance, the Health Insurance Institute reported yesterday.
United States Attorney Robert N. Morgenthau continued to make progress yesterday toward nailing down the Democratic nomination for Governor.

Six persons were injured yesterday in accidents that blocked traffic twice on the West Side Highway. Three others were hurt critically when their car crashed into the center mall of Park Avenue South at Seventeenth Street.

One of the main reasons why Iran's former Premier, Dr. Ali Amini, had to resign in June was his inability to cut expenditures for Iran's 200,000-man military forces. He faced a $70,000,000 budget deficit, and the United States declined to add to grants that were already higher than those given to previous regimes.
Harry M. Olsen of Haverstraw road, Suffern, N.Y., national treasurer of United Cerebral Palsy , Associations, died Tuesday of a heart ailment in New York Hospital. His age was 58.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 30-- A new crisis arose today in the Argentine Army and there were fears of an attempted coup d'etat against the Government of Jose Maria Guido. Such a coup could set off fighting between groups in the army.
Two of the nation's oldest cultural magazines are undertaking an interesting new experiment aimed at solving their persisting financial problems.

ACF Industries, Inc., showed a sharp increase in sales and earnings in the three months ended July 31 over those of the similar first fiscal quarter last year, William T. Taylor, chairman, told stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting in Flemington, N.J.

The nation's chronic farm problem has been accentuated by the strike-call made by the small but vociferous National Farmers Organization. It wants farmers to keep their products off the market so that they can obtain higher prices. And it insists that the farm problem can be solved if farmers are allowed to "run their own affairs."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30--When the governors of the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) assemble here on Sept. 17 for their annual meeting, they are going to hear from President Kennedy much more than the customary greeting from the head of the host country.

Mr. and Mrs. Lester Brion will give a cocktail reception at their home, 9 East Seventyninth Street, on Sept. 11 for committee members for the Blue Grass Ball. The ball will be held at the Plaza Sept. 27 for the benefit of the New York Travelers Aid Society.
The progress of Mayor Wagner's minimum wage bill for private industry was slowed yesterday after the City Council had received a report that favored the measure but suggested a number of amendments.
LONDON, Aug. 30--David Leslie Murray, a British novelist, died last night in New End Hospital, Hampstead, London. He was 74 years old.
A 17-year-old Brooklyn boy asked the State Supreme Court yesterday to certify him for admission to Brooklyn College, even though he fell short of requirements by seven-tenths of a point.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 30 --The biggest surprise of the women's United States amateur golf championship occurred today in the quarter-final round. Patricia Hahn of Wilmington, Del., the 22-year-old champion of her state, routed the defender, Mrs. Anne Quast Decker, with par golf and won, 5 and 4.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30-- Canada lost $190,000,000 of gold to the United States during her financial crisis last spring. It was the biggest inflow of gold to this country since Britain's crisis a year earlier.
The bond market was mixed yesterday in quiet trading.
The Russians want it known that any top United States coach who would like to help show them the tricks of international tennis will get a redcarpet welcome in Moscow.
Some of the largest aluminum die castings ever produced are being shipped today from the Aluminum Company of America's Chicago foundry to Cummins Engine Company, Inc., at Columbus, Ind.

Mayor Wagner rushed yesterday to name three new justices to the city's Domestic Relation's Court before his appointive powers become limited by the state's court reorganization plan. The new plan takes effect at midnight tonight.

Although the Senate has not yet completed its consideration of the tax revision bill, there is no doubt about the shape in which it will emerge. It is accepting the Finance Committee's handiwork, which produced a mutilated and distorted version of the Administration's original bill.
A New Yorker's arrest in a peaceful Southern civil rights protest would not bar his getting a city job under a bill unanimously passed yesterday by the City Council.

LONDON, Aug. 30--Sir Eric Vansittart Bowater, chairman of the vast international pulp and paper corporation, died early today at Dene Place, his home in West Horsley, Surrey. Sir Eric, who had been ill for several weeks, was 67 years old.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 30--Sources said today that an application by Jamaica and Trinidad for United Nations membership is expected in due course.
LONDON, Aug. 30--The decline in industrials gathered momentum on the stock market today.

LISBON, Portugal, Aug. 30 (AP)--Richard Stearns and Lynn Williams Jr. of Wilmette, Ill., finished third and fourth in Harbor Glider in two races of the Star Class world sailing championship today and advanced to second place in the over-all standing.
Samuel Bronston, one of the most tenacious disciples of the late Cecil B. DeMille, plans his own version of the circus theme that earned Mr. DeMille his only Oscar.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30-- William Willard Wirtz, who is to be the new Secretary of Labor, has been in and out of the Government for twenty years. He has been more out than in because he never cared for a career in Government. Nevertheless, he has always been ...
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 30 --Governor Rockefeller indicated today he had reservations about Mayor Wagner's proposal to establish a minimum wage in New York City.
The passengers and crew of a Pan American jetliner from Brazil were quarantined at New York International Airport early today by the United States Public Health Service.
Air Cargo, Inc., the ground service organization owned by United States airlines, announced yesterday it had contracted for improved freight pick-up and delivery service in this area.

HONG KONG, Aug. 30-- Chinese Communist newspapers reported today that two persons died from injuries received in yesterday's bomb explosion at the Hong Kong border. One was a Chinese customs official.

A SECOND book of bridge problems, of English ori gin and written by Capt. Ewart Kempson of England and Paul Lukacs of Hungary, is being published this week by Barclay Bridge Supplies Company in New York. The title is "Single Dummy Plays."

AN aroma reminiscent of Thanksgiving probably will pervade many homes this weekend. Turkeys, which once made their annual appearance only on that November holiday, now are so abundant that they are served for virtually every festive occasion the year around.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI)--E. William Henry, a lawyer of Memphis, Tenn., was selected today by President Kennedy to be a member of the Federal Communications Commission.
MOSCOW, Aug. 30--U Thant, Acting Secretary General of the United Nations, said today he had found Premier Khrushchev favorably disposed to a meeting with President Kennedy if the need should arise.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 30--Acting Secretary General U Thant said in Moscow today that the Soviet people had not been given all the facts on the Congo issue. If they were givers all the facts, Mr. Thant declared, he was sure they ...
SELDOVIA, Alaska, Aug. 30 (UPI)--A Gruman Goose aircraft crashed on a heavily timbered hillside near here today, killing five of the nine persons aboard. Four others were seriously injured.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30-- President Kennedy designated W. Willard, Wirtz as Secretary of Labor today.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Aug. 30 (UPI)--The trade of Charlie Flowers, who figured in a court battle between the National and American Football League teams, was completed today after a brief dispute over his status by the San Diego Chargers and the New York Titans of the American League.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30-- Under Secretary of Agriculture Charles S. Murphy and Senator Karl E. Mundt sparred angrily today over the Agriculture Department's handling of the Billie Sol Estes case.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30-- The effectiveness of Government programs dealing with the use and control of pesticides is under review by a special Federal committee.

The Labor Day holiday seemed to have arrived a little ahead of schedule on Wall Street yesterday as the stock market almost stood still. Stocks drifted slightly lower on average in the dullest and smallest trading in more than three months.

PELHAM, N.Y., Aug. 30-- The engagement of Miss Christine Harrison Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Smith, to Gregory Michael Rossie, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. Rossie ...
Kennecott Copper Corporation yesterday announced it would cut its copper production schedules from seven operating days a week to six days, effective in mid-September.
A Reform Jewish leader yesterday congratulated the editors of Commonweal, a journal edited by Roman Catholic laymen, for criticizing an editorial a Catholic journal edited by Jesuits.

DARWIN, Australia, Aug. 30 (AP)--Portugal appeared today to be bolstering her garrison on Timor Island in the heart of the Indonesian archipelago to offset a reported troop build-up on the Indonesian half of the island.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30-- Jeannette E. Muther, a member of the research staff of the Brookings Institution, died Monday at her home here. Her age was 51.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30-- The American Bar Association's Committee on the Federal Judiciary today termed Arthur J. Goldberg "highly acceptable" as a nominee to the Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 --A dozen members of the Peace Corps, ranging in age from 60 to 76, were praised today by President Kennedy. "Your presence inspires us all," the President told the volunteers, who will serve as teachers and technical experts in foreign lands, Mr. Kennedy ...
TRENTON, Aug. 30--The Port of New York Authority will take control of the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad at 12:01 A.M. Saturday and immediately begin a $150,000,000 rehabilitation of the tube system.
MALMOE, Sweden, Aug. 30 (UPI)--Bob Hayes of Florida A. and M. ran the 100-meter dash in 10.2 seconds tonight in an international meet despite a soggy track and threatening weather.
TOKYO, Aug. 30--Economic flirtation between the Soviet Union and Japanese business is getting a little warmer and the public attitude of Japanese Government officials is getting a little cooler.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30-- The United States announced food grants totaling $25,200,000 for Algeria today as the current installment of a growing assistance program.

The city lost a case yesterday against a service-station operator who has been advertising trading stamps. The city's Administrative Code prohibits a service-station operator from displaying any sign that directly or indirectly refers to the price of gasoline.
LONDON, Aug. 30--The flower of English chivalry is blossoming on the sides of wastepaper baskets.
RYE, N.Y., Aug. 30--Kiyose Nakae, a leading authority on jujitsu in this country, died early yesterday at United Hospital in Port Chester. He was 79 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) --Weather satellites are beginning to pay their way with such chores as predicting ice pack break-ups and the run-off expected from snow as well as helping forecast weather--a House space subcommittee was told today.
LONDON, Aug. 30--In the seventeen years since World War II the British Empire has shrunk from one of the largest territorial groupings in history to a scattering of comparatively small territories.
Paul E. Fitzpatrick, a former state Democratic chairman, took command yesterday of the campaign to win the Democratic Governorship nomination for United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau.

Bidu, Inc., commercial printing and wholesale office supplies, has leased a floor in the Beekman Paper Building at 137 Varick Street. The lease involves 11,500 square feet of space and was made with Harry G. Silverstein Sons, owners and managers of the building.

The chairman of the City Commission on Human Rights said yesterday that he had evidence suggesting that the lending practices of banks made possible the widespread real estate practice of block-busting.

O. Roy Chalk's ofer to acquire the 48 per cent common stock interest in International Railways of Central America owned by the B.S.F. Company was approved yesterday by the B.S.F. board. Victor Muscat, B.S.F. chairman, said the purchase price for 241,900 shares was "in excess of $2,000,000."
MADRID, Aug. 30--A Roman Catholic workers movement accused organs of the Spanish regime today of having "robbed the working class" of progressive social teachings by the Pope.

More than 1,200 parishioners filled the sanctuary and overflowed into a basement auditorium of St. Philip's Protestant Episcopal Church yesterday at a requiem mass for its former rector, the Rev. Dr. Shelton Hale Bishop.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 30 (AP) --The Washington Senators scored twice in the first inning tonight and went on to defeat the Baltimore Orioles, 3--2, behind the nine-hit pitching of Dave Stenhouse.
Yankee derelictions in recent weeks have inspired feelings of insecurity among baseball fans dedicated to the proposition that the perennial champions are going to win the pennant again.

A new nation, a new member of the Commonwealth, a new addition to the United Nations comes onto the world stage today with the independence of Trinidad-Tobago. It is only three weeks since Jamaica, 1,000 miles away, also became independent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30-- The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to reinstate the conviction of Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, for contempt of Congress.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI)--Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower appealed today to House members to give bipartisan support to President Kennedy's U.N. bond purchase plan.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Friday, Aug. 31--Ceremonies here are marking the transition today of the islands of Trinidad and Tobago from colonial status to independence within the British Commonwealth as the new nation of Trinidad-Tobago.

The Kayser-Roth Corporation, diversified apparel manufacturer, had the best year in its history in the fiscal year ended June 30. Chester H. Roth, president, reported yesterday that sales and earnings set new records for the fourth successive year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP)--President Kennedy will spend the Labor Day week-end in Newport, R.I., where he will hold a reunion with Mrs. Kennedy and their daughter, Caroline, who have been in Italy since Aug. 7.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 30 (UPI)--Gretel, the Australian challenger for the America's Cup, weathered twenty-fiveknot winds today during a brief outing on Rhode Island Sound to test two new genoa jibs.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 30--Mrs. James R. Hand of Sleepy Hollow and Kathryn L. Ekirch of Bonnie Briar won low gross honors today in the annual two-ball foursomes tournament of the Women's Westchester Fairfield Golf Association.
Angelo J. Arculeo, a 38-yearold Brooklyn Republican who considers himself "a liberal with conservative tendencies," yesterday became minority leader of the City Council.

The four-story building on a lot 20 by 103 feet at 104 West Thirteenth Street has been purchased for investment by the Harris Block Company. The buyer plans to renovate the building for occupancy by a new restaurant.
A motorcycle plunged into a group of pedestrians in Times Square yesterday morning, fatally injuring two brothers here on a business trip from Minneapolis.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30-- The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today a joint resolution calling for a constitutional amendment guaranteeing equal rights for women.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30-- President Kennedy's selection of Irving Ben Cooper as a Federal district judge was approved today by the Senate Judiciary subcommittee that has been investigating the controversial judge for the last five months.
A 17-year-old Queens boy was accused yesterday of slaying a 14-year-old girl because he allegedly "wanted to see what it felt like to kill somebody."

Paul Hall, president of the Seafarers International Union, yesterday called upon both Houses of Congress and the Administration to investigate the transfer of a contract for missile-tracking vessels from one ship operator to another.
Sears, Roebuck Co. attained the highest sales and earnings in its seventy-six-year-history during the six months ended on July 31, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.
The scramble among savings institutions to obtain mortgages was reflected yesterday in the Federal National Mortgage Association's report on secondary market operations from April to June.

An analysis released here yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers said that facts did not support union contentions that unions were responsible for improvement in the living standards of working people.

FORT LEE, N.J., Aug. 30-- The Mayor and City Council last night adopted an amendment to the zoning ordinance to permit the construction of thirty-story apartment houses atop the Palisades. The former limit was fourteen stories.

BERLIN, Aug. 30--Maj. Gen. Helmut Poppe, military commander of East Berlin, announced plans today to strengthen the "military dedefense" of the border wall built by the Communists between the Eastern and Western sectors of the city.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Friday, Aug. 31 (AP)--Four United States military advisers were wounded by Communist groundfire in South Vietnam's central highlands yesterday when their two United States Army helicopters were shot down.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30-- Rail-freight loadings last week were 1.6 per cent below 1961 levels and only one-tenth of 1 per cent higher than the preceding week's volumes. Truck tonnage was also behind compared to last year and fractionally up from the prior week.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 30 (UPI)--The Alabama State Supreme Court upheld today a $500,000 libel judgment against The New York Times.

The following is a listing of restaurants that are recommended on the basis of varying merits. Such a listing is published every Friday in The New York Times. Unless otherwise indicated, the restaurants are open seven days a week.
BONNIE CASHIN, who is known for her imaginative country and travel clothes, has turned her talents to the design of handbags and what goes into them.
Broadway became a classroom yesterday for 100 Indiana students.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30-- Andres Vargas Gomez, once a ranking diplomat in Premier Fidel Castro's regime in Cuba, was sentenced to thirty years in prison in Havana last night after his death sentence had been commuted.
The New York Symphonic Band, conducted by Frank Cola Santo, will give a concert at Steeplechase Pier, Coney Island, tonight at 8:30.
SOAP opera, long a favorite target of satirists, was the subject of an operatic spoof shown last night over Channel 2.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30--One definite thread throughout the warp and woof of Supreme Court decisions demonstrates the fallacy of assuming that new justices invariably will interpret the law as they did in their pleadings at the bar for a special--interest group of clients.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30-- Two big brush fires on the outskirts of Los Angeles were rapidly burning out today after more than two days of picturesque and costly damage.
DU QUOIN, Ill., Aug. 30-- The Hambletonian Society, the group that controls the Hambletonian, delayed today the awarding of the 1964 race until the directors met again in New York on Oct. 21.

Thousands of New York home owners will pay less for fire, windstorm, personal liability, burglary and other casualty insurance under new rates that go into effect on Sept. 21. Some home owners, however, will pay more.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30-- Top executives of four steel companies notified a Senate subcommittee today that they would neither submit subpoenaed company documents nor appear themselves at a hearing tomorrow morning.

Community leaders, most of them critics of noise from aircraft flying near New York International Airport, were taken yesterday for a ninety-minute ride to observe methods used to reduce noise. But many seemed unimpressed.
TRENTON, Aug. 30--The New Jersey Department of Health today barred further distribution of certain drugs found to be contaminated with two insecticides.
MOSCOW, Aug. 30 (AP)-- A priest of the Russian Orthodox Church has been sentenced to three years in prison for having broken up a volley ball game.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30-- With the first 100 defeats out of their systems, the Mets were relaxed tonight and ready to realize their natural potential. But not even the Phillies expected them to realize it so soon.

Eastern Air Lines, which has been struck for sixty-nine days, has received $1,580,675 so far from some of its competitors under the airlines' mutual assistance agreement, records of the Civil Aeronautics Board have disclosed.

Harry Flood Byrd of Berryville, Va., is said to own the largest apple orchard in the world; he does not like to be called a political boss, but anybody who wants to get anywhere in politics in Virginia had better consult him; and he is the Chairman of the Senate Finance Committee.
The Garrett Corporation more than tripled its earnings in its fiscal year ended June 30, according to preliminary results announced yesterday by the West Coast manufacturer.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30 (AP) --The Cincinnati Reds, bailed out of a bases-filled ninthinning jam by Jim Brosnan, defeated the league-leading Los Angeles Dodgers, 5--4, tonight before 42,588 fans.

QUONSET, R.I., Aug. 30-- Navy's 1961 football team was a pleasant surprise to Coach Wayne Hardin. With pea-green personnel, the midshipmen defeated seven of their ten opponents, capping the campaign with a third straight victory over Army.
The United States Treasury gold stock declined by $50,000,000 during the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) --Exchanging charges of unfairness and incredibility, a railroad president and a union lawyer debated today the reasons for the money troubles of eastern railroads.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Aug. 30--Harry Darbee and his Beaverkill-Willowemoc Rod and Gun Club compatriots, perturbed over New York's plan to tamper with the two famous Catskill streams in the Roscoe area for highway purposes, certainly have strong sympathizers here.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30-- Alexander R. Boyd, early motion picture exhibitor who built and at one time operated several large theatres here, died yesterday in Jefferson Hospital. He was 85 years old.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) --The House Interior Committee approved today a bill that would set up and preserve a huge wilderness area in this country.
JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 30 (UPI)--United States District Judge Harold Cox rejected today a Justice Department suit to restore a Negro school teacher's job.
LOGAN, Utah, Aug. 30 (AP)--An earthquake jolted five Western states today, centering its force on the narrow Cache valley of northern Utah.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30--French objections have raised doubt that Western foreign ministers will hold a projected conference on Berlin. President Kennedy announced yester day that the ministers of the United States, Britain, France and West Germany had agreed "in principle" on such a meeting before the General Assembly of the United Nations convenes Sept. 18.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30-- Mrs. Harald PaumgartenHohenschwangau-Erbach of Chestnut Hill and Northeast Harbor, Me., has made known the engagement of her daughter, Miss Gerda Crozer Paumgarten, to Arthur Emlen Newbold 4th. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Newbold 3d, also of Chestnut Hill.

IT was "Kookey Toccata" time at the McMillin The atre of Columbia University last night. The stage was crowded with odd-looking contraptions that glittered in the spotlights, and from them were coming strange sounds like muted flutes and bells.

With the completion of the qualifying preliminaries yesterday, the combined men's and women's United States lawn tennis championships will present today some of the great array of talent that has been waiting in the wings at Forest Hills.
Play-Pix Productions Inc. has been formed to operate in the stage and film departments.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 30-- Chancellor Adenauer came under some of the harshest press criticism of his post-war political career today. It came in the wake of his latest row with London over Britain's place in Europe.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 30-- Vice President Johnson arrived in this strategic island republic late today to stress United States friendship and to urge Cypriote leaders to take seriously the threat of Communism here.

The pending television series featuring former President Harry S. Truman may wind up on educational stations. The series, on which Mr. Truman deals with major historic events and his years in the White House, already has been turned down by the major commercial networks.
Declines in world sugar and cottonseed oil and an advance in copper were the highlights of an otherwise quiet day on the New York commodity exchanges.

BURAS, La., Aug. 30 (AP) --The five Negro children who integrated a Roman Catholic school in this little town near the mouth of the Mississippi River failed to attend classes today. There was no explanation for their absence.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 30 --Miss Cornelia Dale Sharp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dale Sharp of Oyster Bay Cove, was married this afternoon to Archibald Cox Jr. in St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor.

NOROTON, Conn., Aug. 30-- Carter Sales of Grosse Point, Mich., sailing Sea Sails IV, won the thirteenth annual Raven Class national championship today as the three-day series on Long Island Sound ended with two races.
Travelers over the Labor Day week-end will find driving a bit easier in and around New York as a result of the elimination of one major bottleneck and two lesser ones.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30-- The Administration's plan for withholding personal income taxes on dividends and interest at the source has been killed without any apparent prospect for revival.

PROBABLY few literary classics as famous as "Boswell's Journal of a Tour to the Hebrides With Samuel Johnson, LL. D., 1773" are as little read today. This statement, of course, does not apply to members in good standing of either the Johnson or Boswell cults. But it does apply to most cultivated readers, who usually claim to have read at least part ...

Business men, troubled by the legislation that is designed to prevent undue accumulation of profits abroad, are watching the progress in the Senate of the Revenue Act of 1962 with apprehension. The Senate hopes to complete work on the tax bill before Labor Day week-end.

The city's $200,000,000 program of waterfront rehabilitation moved closer to completion yesterday with the start of construction on a new Hudson River freight terminal and the signing of contracts for the building of a newsprint pier on the East River.
Negotiations continued last night between three locals of the teamsters' union and intracity cartage employers.
Mayor Wagner turned his back on Greenwich Village reform forces yesterday and publicly endorsed an opponent of the reformers.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30--A comparison of mental patients who committed suicide with a group of mental patients who did not has indicated some basic personality differences between the two groups, the American Psychological Association was told here today.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 30--Mrs. Webster Stover said today she would string another line of tattered clothes and dirty rags in the front yard of her home here for every day her husband remained a prisoner in the Westchester County Penitentiary at Eastview "for protesting against Rye taxes."
Allison Stern's 5-year-old gelding Kampina set a course record in winning the fortyfourth running of the $11,175 added Harbor Hill Steeplechase Handicap at Aqueduct by a length yesterday.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan has subpoenaed the records of the Bon Ami Company, whose "reform" management was accused in Supreme Court last week of having embezzled and misused at least $500,000 of company funds.
PARIS, Aug. 30--Government sources indicated today that President de Gaulle would seek a popular referendum in October on constitutional changes.

WEST MILFORD, N.J., Aug. 30--Three residents of Awosting, a summer community on the southeast shore of Greenwood Lake, were wondering today what to do with a piece of land they acquired at the height of a wind storm.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 30 (AP) --Donn Clendenon, a rookie, hit two doubles and a homer tonight as he paced the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 5-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30--A strike by 1,000 telegraphers today shut down the nation's third largest railroad, the Chicago and North Western. More than 15,000 other em- ployes, members of other unions, refused to cross picket lines set up by the Order of Railroad Telegraphers at major points on the carrier's 10,000-mile network in nine Midwestern states.
LONDON, Aug. 30--Legal arguments continued today on Dr. Robert A. Soblen's appeal against orders to deport him to the United States.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 30--The United Nations warned Katanga today that any attempt to interfere with the world organization's chartered flights to Elisabethville on Air Congo "will be resisted by force if necessary."

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 30 (AP)--The Government will try to get the United States to open its gates to about 10,000 Dutch immigrants from Netherland New Guinea, a spokesman of the Dutch Emigration Council said today.
Mayor Wagner gave his blessing last night to the complete insurgent ticket for the Democratic primary election in the Bronx next Thursday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) Farmers voted by a narrow margin in an Agriculture Department referendum today to continue controls on wheat next year.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, ruddy-cheeked and cheerful, docked here yesterday after a thirty-six day trip to seven European nations.

James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said here yesterday that his union's executive board would decide next week whether to accept the flight engineers' union as an affiliate.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes rejected yesterday a plea by the Fifth Avenue Association to retain the ornamental bronze traffic lights on the avenue.

MANCHESTER, England, Aug. 30--The gap in wealth between the "have" and the "have not" countries is not only big, but is getting progressively bigger, in the opinion of a speaker at the 124th meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 30-- The fifteenth annual congress of the United States National Student Association ended in harmony here tonight. Its political position, as usual, was fixed somewhere left of center.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30--The Food and Drug Administration said today that a number of pharmacies in this country had stocks of thalidomide.
A former law professor who had pleaded guilty to incometax evasion escaped a prison sentence yesterday in Federal Court despite a Government recommendation for severe punishment.

Now that so many people have become interested in watching--and trying to analyze--economic statistics, the First National City Bank has become a little worried. It favors "a well-informed and economically sophisticated public" as a stabilizing influence on the economy.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Aug. 31--Miss Nancy Elizabeth Dennis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Dennis, was married here tonight to V. Lee Barnes, son of Lieut. Gen. Verdi B. Barnes, U.S.A., and Mrs. Barnes of Honolulu. The ceremony was performed in the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. James Seth Stewart. There was a reception at the Scarsdale Golf Club.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The Soviet Union made an unsuccessful attempt at a Venus space probe last Saturday, Government sources said tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31--A United States Navy plane, flying a training mission yesterday near Cuba, was fired on by two naval vessels believed to be Cuban, the White House announced tonight.

LISBON, Portugal, Aug. 31 (AP) A Soviet sloop won the fourth race today, but an Illinois craft took over first place in the over-all point score with one race to go in the Star Class world sailing championships. Seventy-nine yachts are taking part in the series.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI)--Members of Congress from textile-producing states had a "heart-to-heart" talk with President Kennedy today about the plight of the industry and came away "comforted."

Msgr. John E. Kelly, director of the bureau of information of the National Catholic Welfare Conference for the last seven years, relinquished his post yesterday to return to parish work in Trenton, N.J.
A 100 per cent increase in the number of security fraud indictments filed in the Southern District of New York during the last year was reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The Senate made little progress on the Administration's tax-revision bill today, and leaders abandoned hope for passage before late next week.
Summary of the Day
Armed with a book of regulations and wearing a look of determination, Park Commissioner Newbold Morris repulsed a political invasion of his domain yesterday.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 31 Sydnor V. Reiss, manager of the commercial research department of the Greybar Electric Company in New York, died this morning in Stamford Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived at 21 Oak Shade Avenue in Noroton Heights.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 31 Ann Baker, a 17-year-old high school senior from Maryville, Tenn., and JoAnne Gunderson of Kirkland, Wash., who has held the title twice, gained the final of the women's United States amateur golf championship today.

Television's first visit to Philharmonic Hall, on opening night, Sept. 23, will have to encompass 407 musicmakers onstage all at once, will cost the sponsor $600,000 and will have to go on the air without even a dress rehearsal.
LONDON, Aug. 31 Frank O. Salisbury, noted British painter of kings and statesmen, died at his home here today. He was 87 years old.

HICKSVILLE, L.I., Aug. 31 The school board of this Nassau County community, rebuffed in its efforts to use a section of the National Anthem as an official prayer, unanimously voted tonight to require a reading of a verse of the song at the beginning of each school day.

STONE RIDGE, N.Y., Aug. 31 Charles C. Walden Jr., board chairman of Walden Sons Mott, Inc., of Oradell, N.J., publishers of newspapers and magazines for the printing and paper industries, died here today in his home. His age was 76.
Four young Englishman a physician, a composer, a writer and a historian have arrived in New York with plans for their Broadway debuts and the continuation of their nonacting careers.

The Paramount Pictures Corporation showed a sharp drop in earnings in the quarter and six months ended June 30 from those of the periods a year ago, the report of the motion picture producer disclosed yesterday.
THERE is more to farina than a bowl of hot breakfast ce real. Farina is one of the most popular dishes in many European and Mediterranean countries and often takes the place of potatoes on the menu.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Aug. 31 Eric Eustace Williams, Prime Minister of Trinidad-Tobago, appears headed into a sea of difficulties much larger than the Caribbean, which surrounds the newly independent country.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Plans for a conference of Western foreign ministers on Berlin next month appeared today to have collapsed from French resistance.
ATHENS, Aug. 31 Vice President Johnson arrived tonight from Cyprus to discuss what Greek leaders have publicly termed an unfair cutback in United States defense aid.
There will be no more scrambling after tonight to board or leave the middle cars of northbound IRT Lexington Avenue local trains as they roll into the Brooklyn Bridge subway station.
The appointment of Miss Anne M. Kelly as Deputy Commissioner of the Department of Commerce and Industrial Development was announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner.
The happy alternative of shooting for a big part of $59,400 today or for a sizable part of $100,000-plus on Monday is what the cabinet of Ridan will resolve today.
The islands of Trinidad and Tobago, now united as an independent nation in the British Commonwealth, have much in common geographically and historically, but many significant differences too.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 31 The Stamford Yacht Club's twenty-eighth Vineyard race, the last of the Long Island Sound blue-water distance events this season, began in haze at sunset tonight off The Cows bell buoy outside Stamford Harbor.

BERLIN, Aug. 31 The Russians brought in their own escort for the first time today to accompany the armor they have been using for ten days to transport guards to the Soviet war memorial in West Berlin.
Bonds redeemed before maturity in August dropped to their lowest level since March but rose above the total for August, 1961.

DALLAS, Aug. 31 (AP) Big Paul Bondeson and Juan (Chi Chi) Rodriguez, a 116pound Puerto Rican, fired threeunder-par 67's today and shared the first-round lead in the $35,000 Dallas open golf tournament.
LEESBURG, Ga., Aug. 31 Night riders poured volleys of rifle fire early today into four rural homes of Negroes involved in a voter-registration campaign.
A new film version of "Hamlet," directed by a leader of the French "new wave," is due for release here this fall.
GENEVA, Aug. 31 (AP)--The United States proposed today that the three nuclear powers hold special direct negotiations here aimed at producing agreement by Nov. 1 on a test ban treaty.
Four justices of the Domestic Relations Court were sworn in by Mayor Wagner at City Hall yesterday. Three were new appointees and one had been reappointed.

PARIS, Aug, 31 France found today material obstacles to prevent her participation in a proposed Western foreign ministers' meeting on Berlin. The prospect of a meeting was regarded here with a notable lack of enthusiasm.
LONDON, Aug. 31 Dr. Robert A. Soblen today lost his last legal appeal against the British Government's order deporting him to the United States.
The Bronx State Hospital, which was started in 1958, may receive its first patients next April, the state indicated yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) Natural gas producers were denied the right to plead rising costs to justify initial prices in a case from Texas District 4 yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 A New York art education professor told a Senate subcommittee today that he rejected the "sophomoric notion that America is in the midst of a cultural renaissance."
With the Labor Day week-end under way, travelers streamed in and out of the city last night to enjoy the last moments of summertime relaxation before returning to work and school.
Representative Samuel S. Stratton stepped up his efforts yesterday to deflate the drive to make Robert M. Morgenthau the Democratic nominee for Governor.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 President Kennedy signed today a bill creating a jo, it Government-industry corporation to operate an international communications system via earth satellites.
A highly competitive atmosphere has surrounded the United States market for nickel, key users of the metal reported last week.

The eccentric old clock in the Jefferson Market Courthouse tower was switched from handwinding to electrical operation at the stroke of noon yesterday. From now on it will probably be less interesting, but should be more reliable.
MOSCOW, Aug. 31 The Soviet Union has withheld from its people an appeal addressed to them by U Thant, Acting Secretary General of the United Nations, for better understanding of the Congo situation.

The flags of thirty-five nations passed in review in the Forest Hills Stadium of the West Side Tennis Club yesterday after Maria Bueno of Brazil and Roy Emerson of Australia had won early matches on the enclosure's turf courts.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The Department of Labor was accused today of poor administration of a law requiring government contractors to pay prevailing wage rates on construction projects.
The market for debt securities was firm yesterday in extremely limited trading.
RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 31 (UPI)--Ricky, a 5-year-old German Shepherd dog, will soon face his executioner. His conviction on a sheep-killing charge was upheld today by Virginia's highest court.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 The Midwest began to feel the economic pinch today from the shutdown of the Chicago and North Western Railway.
With traders preparing for the Labor Day week-end, the New York commodity markets were extremely quiet yesterday. All of the markets will remain closed until Tuesday morning.
A city-wide trucking strike was averted yesterday when employers and three locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters agreed to continue negotiations on a day-to-day basis.
CAIRO, Ill., Aug. 31 More than 100 Illinois state troopers moved into this city today to head off the possibility of any new racial disturbences. None developed.
No one has ever been laid off for lack of work at a modern five-story plant in Long Island City.

Nothing corrects Yankee tailspins like close-ups views of right handed pitchers wearing Kansas City flannels. And so it was last night at the Stadium, where once again it also was demonstrated that nothing distracts the Athletics like the sight of New York's pinstriped knickers.
The trend after Labor Day? As usual, the Wall Street, ananalysts offer a variety of opinions, ranging from pessimism to strong optimism.

IRKUTSK, U.S.S.R., Aug. 31 Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall arrived here today for a three-day tour of the Siberian industrial region. Mr. Udall, whose home state is Arizona, expressed admiration for the development of the rich natural resources of the area, which he likened to the western United States. He also inspected a hydroelectric station in Irkutsk.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 President Kennedy sent to the Senate today the nominations of Arthur J. Goldberg to be an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court and W. Willard Wirtz to be Secretary of Labor.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Aug. 31 Prime Minister Eric E. Williams, in his first address to the nation of TrinidadTobago, warned today that other new countries had been beset by "anarchy and civil war" and he appealed for unity and responsibility.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 31 Economic conditions improved in Venezuela during 1961 over those of the preceding year, but "recovery is not yet achieved," according to the annual Central Bank of Venezuela report, released here yesterday. The report is considered a kind of annual economic bible by economists here

The Sixty-ninth Street Brooklyn Ferry fleet carried more vehicular traffic last year than the larger city-owned ferry flotilla operating between St. George and Whitehall Street, according to a report of the Department of Marine and Aviation.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 31 (AP) The fourth Asian Games continued to be disrupted today by political disputes.
Sales of the Allied Stores Corporation climbed for the three, six and twelve months ended on July 31, the company reported yesterday.

BURAS, La., Aug. 31 Reporting threats of violence, Roman Catholic Church officials today closed Our Lady of Good Harbor School, desegregated two days ago. Less than three hours later, the Federal Bureau of Investigation began an inquiry.

SINGAPORE, Aug. 31 Peace Corps operations in Asia are "going almost too well to be believed," according to Sargent Shriver, director of the Corps, a United States volunteer program to assist developing countries. A year ago today the first contingent of the Corps was dispatched overseas.

American Export Lines will move its Baltimore terminal operations to the Western Maryland piers at Port Covington, Captain S. Blackedge, vice president for operations, announced yesterday. The company has been using the Baltimore Ohio Piers at Locust Point.
Local color was in more evidence than usual in Greenwich Village yesterday when the annual outdoor art exhibition opened for the sixty-second time.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Welfare officials of the District of Columbia proposed a program today to reduce the public relief rolls.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 31 Watching television does not tend to lower children's achievement in school, but children of lower intelligence watch television more than others, a psychologist said here today.
The stock market took Wall Street by surprise yesterday and staged a brisk advance in more active trading.
Phil Regan, the singer, who has been sought by the District Attorney's office since June, has been subpoenaed to appear before a grand jury next Friday.
The Owens-Illinois Glass Company is expanding its interest in a Brazilian glass container company, Companhia Industrial Sao Paulo e Rio, popularly known as Cisper.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Aug. 31 -It's a bit early in the game to get down to specifics about Army's remodeled football team. Still, Paul Dietzel, West Point's magnetic new head coach, obviously had been heartened by what he has seen in his squad's first week of two-a-day drills at near-by but isolated Camp Buckner.

RICHMOND, Va., Saturday, Sept. 1 (AP) Janet Crick, the 15-year-old Chicago girl who received a transplanted kidney from her mother, died early today at the Medical College of Virginia. Doctors at the hospital could not be reached immediately for comment or an explanation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Treasury Bill rates rose in today's sale of next week's regular issues of short-term bills. The increases carried the rates back almost to the levels of two weeks ago.

SINGAPORE, Aug. 31 The man who says he inspired the famous song, "Won't You Please Come Home, Bill Bailey?" holds court six nights a week in a once stately home that has been converted into a combination bar and boarding house in one of Singapore's residential districts. Now white-haired and past seventy, Bill Bailey says he

NEW CANAAN, Conn. ORIGINALLY named, with pious intentions, after the land of milk and honey, this corner of northern Fairfield County is more likely to be identified these days with the Bloody Mary and imported cheese.

SHTURA, Lebanon, Aug. 31 (Reuters) The Arab League Council voted overwhelmingly today to halt further discussion of Syrian charges against the United Arab Republic as a walkout by Cairo threatened to become permanent.
Seasoned air travelers as well as those who have never been aboard an airplane will have an opportunity tomorrow to examine what the airline industry is offering in modern flying equipment.
The Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute in Williamstown, Mass., will place on view today an acquisition of exceptional importance in fourteenthcentury Sienese painting.
ALGIERS, Aug. 31 Tens of thousands of Algerians, reacting to the prospect of civil war, demanded peace and unity in demonstrations here today.
PLACERVILLE, Calif., Aug. 30 Hybrid pine trees that promise to give forests immunity against devastating insects while accelerating timber growth are attracting international attention.

The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday gains in gross revenues and net income for July and for the seven months ended July 31. The report was filed with the Federal Communications Commission. The company does not issue comments on such required reports.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 31 The New York Mets, bewitched, bothered and beleaguered, will have to wait another day before starting their all-out drive to the forty-victory mark.
Dr. Fred Schwarz; leader of the Christian Anti-Communism Crusade, announced last night that the movement had lost $75,000 in New York since last April.

CORNING, Iowa, Aug. 31 (UPI) The National Farmers Organization announced today the signing of the first master contract with a processor. The announcement came a few hours before the start of a showdown battle for higher prices in the market place.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) Henry T. Adios, the 4-to-1 favorite, won the $70,976 American-National Maturity Pace to night at Sportsman's Park before 13,485.
Henry Colbert, New York concert manager, died in his home here yesterday. He was 63 years old and had been ill from cancer for the last six months.
MONTREAL, Aug. 31 (Canadian Press) A Finnish scientist has suggested that saliva and sweat may be effective against radiation hazards.
MADRID Aug. 31 The Roman Catholic hierarchy announced today the establishment of an agency to plan and coordinate church activities for workers throughout Spain.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm product prices increased nearly 2 per cent between midJuly and mid-August.

The sudden influx of Soviet bloc materials and technicians into Cuba has again brought thoughtless demands to send American Marines to take over the island or naval units to blockade it. Senator Tower of Texas has been clamoring for an invasion of Cuba for a long time.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 31--President Kennedy welcomed his wife Jacqueline and his daughter Caroline home tonight from their trip to Italy.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31--The Senate Antitrust and Monopoly subcommittee recommended today that four steel companies and nine of their principal officers be cited for contempt.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI)--Danny O'Connell's two-run pitch-single gave the Washington Senators a 4-2 victory tonight over the Los Angeles Angels in the second game of a double-header after the Angels had won the opener, 6--3.

HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 31 (AP) Two members of the New York City Ballet were seriously injured in a traffic accident here last night just after rehearsing for the troupe's first appearance in its tour of Europe.
Stocks eked out a small gain on average last month in moderately active trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
The 3-year-old set dominates today's thoroughbred racing action with features at Aqueduct, Arlington Park and Hazel Park.
Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish leaders called on both labor and management yesterday to show concern for the public welfare in their use of economic power.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 31 A woman has to be a good busi ness manager in order to buy well, a good psychologist to feed her family well and an efficiency expert to know how to shop, store and use foods properly.

DETROIT, Aug. 31 (AP) George Romney, Republican candidate for Governor of Michigan, told the National Fair Campaign Practices Committee today that he had never charged Communist infiltration of the Democratic party.
Eastern Air Lines said yesteday that by Sept. 13, when it plans to start operation of a full summer schedule, it would have about 700 certified flight engineers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The Billie Sol Estes investigation ended one of its most important weeks today in partisan debate.
FROM extreme frames with leopard spots, sequins, bells, buttons and bows, eyeglasses have turned back to the simple styles of forty years ago.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31--The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to clear the way for immediate admission of a Negro to the University of Mississippi.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman stated today that the narrow margin by which wheat farmers voted to continue controls indicated they want a more effective program for this grain.

WESTON, Conn., Aug. 31 Henrikas Rabinavicius, former Lithuanian Consul General in New York, died today, apparently of a heart attack, in his home on Beaverbrook Road. He was 70 years old and also lived at 45 East End Avenue, New York.

The story involves the late dean of Newport taxidrivers, a man who, for thirty years, had been taking sight-seers on tours without ever once, even by insinuation, breaking the barriers of good taste or, indeed, ever once stooping to any editorial comment at all.
Dutchess County Democrats hopped aboard the Morgenthaufor-Governor bandwagon yesterday, giving the United States Attorney nine more delegate votes for the democratic nomination convention this month.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 29 Swedes who view the winds of change in other parts of the world with concern are reacting to a zephyr of their own.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic. IN this lush Caribbean island country, discovered by Columbus, a shattered and bewildered society is searching for new ways of life. Memories of three decades of dictatorship are still raw; the ferment of radical revolution is still there; the chances for a well-meaning but ill-equipped government to achieve enough stability to establish a functioning democracy are still open to question.
KINGS POINT, L. L, Sept. 1 -Three bedraggled young men were arrested today after swimming three and a half miles from a disabled cabin cruiser they had allegedly stolen.

Pierre and Nicole Camard, young school teachers from Paris, returned to the city yesterday after hitchhiking 5,500 miles through twenty states and parts of eastern Canada. They had a record of many friendships and only one arrest.

Department store sales in the nation for the week ended Aug. 25 were 2 per cent below the level of a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board has reported. Volume in the preceding week was 3 per cent higher than a year ago. Of the twelve districts reporting, two showed gains Atlanta sales rose 4 per cent and San Francisco was up 3 per cent.
Governments of oil-producing countries in the Middle East have begun a drive to increase their revenues from petroleum operations within their borders by more than $500,000,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) The National Republican Citizens Committee, a pet project of former President Eisenhower, has stirred a battle among party leaders.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 1, (AP) The Indian Government announced last week it was shelving plans to build a $1,500 "people's car." A Communist leader immediately charged the Government had knuckled under to pressure from the domestic auto industry.

The chapel of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting here yesterday for the marriage of Miss Russell Underwood Weed, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jefferson Weed of Glen Ridge, N.J., to John Secrest Pyke Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Pyke of Cleveland.
How the food industry in this country under the free enterprise system has been able to make Americans the best-fed in the world will be dramatically demonstrated here for more than a week.
Moscow's Bolshoi Ballet troupe arrived here by air yesterday for its three-and-onehalf-month tour of the United States and Canada.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 1 Linguists from thirty nations were engaged here this week in the age-old problem of building a workable bridge between languages.

ANDORRA LA VELLA, Andorra, Sept. 1 (Reuters) Tension ran high today in this small principality high in the Pyrenees Mountains, where one of the ruling "coprinces" has refused to recognize the signature of the "very illustrious Syndic" the Prime Minister.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 The Government will ask the Supreme Court in a few days to review a lower court decision that the agency shop is unlawful.
MIAMI, Sept. 1 (UPI) The first group of Cuban refugees evacuated from Uruguay's Havana embassy arrived here today for a tearful reunion with friends and relatives.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall said this week that state-owned and stateoperated parks and recreation areas provided more outdoor vacation, recreation and camping in 1961 than in any previous year.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Ann Wood to Richard Myron Werkheiser took place here at noon yesterday in the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine. The Right Rev. J. Stuart Wetmore, Suffragan Bishop of the Diocese of New York, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Canon Harold R. Landon.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Sept. 1 The marriage of Miss Nancy Ellen Donovan, daughter of Leo F. Donovan of Millburn and the late Mrs. Caroline Donovan, to George Aaron Spaeth took place here this afternoon. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Spaeth of Evansville, Minn.

Now that the space communications bill is law, the Federal Communications Commission has properly begun preparations for energetic exercise of its vital regulatory functions. A working group made up of nineteen specialists from university faculties, other Government agencies and private industry is being added to the F.C.C. staff to plan enforcement of the new law's guarantees of protection for the public interest.
HYDRA, Greece. THE absence of ancient Greek ruins on this sunscorched Aegean island thirty nautical miles from the Acropolis has led to a Hollywood miracle with its own classic aspects.

IT is customary for a symphony orchestra's timpanist to stick to his kettledrums during a concert. Saul Goodman, the New York Philharmonic's head percussionist, has been doing just that with consummate skill for the last thirty-five years. Since 1958, however, he has also played a leading role in Leonard Bernstein's duties as the orchestra's conductor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) Bob Schmidt's home run with two out in the eleventh inning gave the Washington Senators a 3-2 victory over the Los Angeles Angels tonight. Leon Wagner had hit his thirty-third homer in the ninth for Los Angeles to tie the score.

If the Internal Revenue Service sends two agents to check your business tax return, don't panic. It no longer suggests that they suspect fraud. It is probably just a manifestation of the tax agency's new "quality audit" program. But ask about it anyway just in case.

After about a year's work, the deep-water port under construction at Ashdod, Israel, is beginning to take shape. The port is part of a new town and industrial development that has made Ashdod a major center in settlement of the Negev, Israel's desert southland.

WHEN Will Rogers died in a plane crash in Alaska twenty-seven years ago, his death seemed like a national calamity to millions of people. A few other professional entertainers and a few public figures were as famous; none was so dearly beloved.
