HEWLETT, L.I., Sept. 3 Miss Rona Silver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Silver, was married this evening to Martin M. Rutchik. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elias Rutchik of Norwich, Conn.

OPEN season for oysters started Sept. 1, but consumers probably will not find many of the luscious bivalves on the market before next month. When they do appear, oysters should be excellent because the plantain on which they feed have been particularly abundant in Long Island Sound this summer.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 3 Miss Felice Sunray Witztum, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harry Witztum of Madison, was married here this afternoin to David M. Gordis, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Robert Gordis of Belle Harbor, Queens, New York.
The largest crowd within memory to attend the national lawn tennis championships in an early round swarmed over the premises of the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 3 (AP) Jack Sanford scored his fourteenth straight victory and his twentieth of the season today as the San Francisco Giants moved up to two and a half games behind league-leading Los Angeles by defeating the Dodgers, 7-3.
MONTREAL, Sept. 3--McGill University's space project will be ready to send a vehicle aloft over the Caribbean next month, Dr. D. L. Mordell, dean of the Faculty of Engineering, has disclosed here.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 3-- President Kennedy urged boys and girls of high school age today to "return to school" this fall.
Desegregation of the Roman Catholic schools in the New Orleans Archdiocese is scheduled to go forward today, despite the threats of violence that forced the temporary closing of ...

Detective Donald Rolker's eye was caught yesterday by a green box on the sidewalk on West Fifty-fourth Street. He got out of his squad car and found the box to be a steel safe, securely closed by its combination lock.

MOSCOW, Sept. 3 MarxistLeninist scholars of twentythree countries, after meeting here for ten days to ponder the challenge of the European Economic Community, went home today without having decided what to do about it.
The new $5,000,000 Neptun, the world's largest-capacity cable ship is bound from West Germany for Newfoundland, where she is scheduled to begin her first job about Sept. 10.
The metropolitan area was described yesterday as heading for a new and costlier "spreadcity" pattern with people living farther and farther away from their jobs.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) This nation's astronauts and their spacecraft will be landed on earth, instead of water, before they try exploring the surface of the moon.
The American Press Institute of Columbia University announced yesterday its schedule of ten two-week seminars for newspaper men and newspaper women during 1962-63.

DARLINGTON, S.C., Sept. 3 (AP) Larry Frank of Greenville, S.C., and not Junior Johnson, won today's Southern 500mile stock car race, officials of the National Association of Stock Car Auto Racing said tonight.

WEDGEPORT, N.S., Sept. 3 This quaint maritime community of thatch-roofed cottages and country-like inns is about to be invaded by a band of students representing ten colleges in the United States and Canada prepared to troll or try for old Siwash.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 3 The Acting Secretary General, U Thant, opposed today any move to change the United Nations voting system to offset the growing influence of new member nations.
An increase in rents and a modernization program have been combined to place one of the city's older office buildings on a sound operating basis.
FARNBOROUGH, England, Sept. 3 Hovering a few yards above the ground, the Hawker P1127 jet fighter was shown in public here today for the first time.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission staff has drawn up detailed far-reaching reporting requirements for mutual funds.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 3 (UPI) The nine members of the Latin American free Trade Association (LAFTA) were reported ready today to reject Cuba's application for membership.
St. Louis, Sept. 3 (AP) Don Cardwell beat the St. Louis Cardinals on seven hits, 5 2, after Glen Hobbie had pitched the Chicago Cubs to a 6-2 victory in the first game of a double-header today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 3 Eddie Dooley Jr. with his Class S boat Kandahar, Howard McMichael with his International Kangaroo and David Gundy with Hugo in the 210 Class were among the series winners today as the Larchmont Yacht Club ended its week-end regatta for the Yaeht Racing Association.
The number of foreclosures in Manhattan real estate in the first six months of this year rose sharply, according to a report by the Real Estate Board of New York.
An impromptu concert of German folk music was played yesterday morning by a twelvepiece band from West Germany's Black Forest that had just arrived at New York International Airport.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 3 Argentina's military leaders are turning away from the idea of allowing President Jose Maria Guido to fulfill his pledge of national elections next year.

Fred Hooper's Crozier, a perennial runner-up in rich races on the thoroughbred calendar, shed himself of that status yesterday when he came through with an exciting victory in the $106,300 Aqueduct Stakes at Aqueduct.

Now that the Music Corporation of America has discovered that film production is more lucrative than representing personalities, there are indications that other talent agencies and public-relations firms may invade filmmaking.
ELMSFORD, N.Y., Sept. 3-- Two persons were killed and eleven others injured in an eight-car crash on the New York State Thruway near here tonight.

The astonishing Los Angeles Angels yesterday appeared to have reached the point of no return in their presumptuous American League pennant bid when, with an almost incredible effort, they elbowed their way right back into it again.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 3-- Chancellor Adenauer called on the West Germans tonight to welcome President de Gaulle "in the spirit of joy and satisfaction" that the foundation for a French-German accord had been achieved.

GROSSINGER, N.Y., Sept. 3 Eddie Fisher made a sentimental journey last night to the hotel where he got his first break in show business. He sang for seventy-five minutes to a capacity audience of 1,800 persons and walked off stage to one of the biggest ovations in his career.
CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (UPI) Run-scoring singles by Jerry Kindall in the opener and Tito Francona in the second game today carried the Cleveland Indians to 4-3 and 6-5 victories over the Chicago White Sox.

On Feb. 16, 1960, Capt. Edward L. Beach began an epic circumnavigation of the earth. He submerged his newly commissioned nuclear-powered submarine, the Triton, and began an eighty-four-day voyage under water, traveling 41,500 miles around the world.

PARIS, Sept. 3--The French Government moved today to stamp out subversive activity. An ordinance drastically modifying the rules of procedure in dealing with persons accused of crimes against the public peace was promulgated. Under the decree anyone accused of a flagrant crime of this kind can be brought to trial within forty eight hours of his arrest.

BLACKPOOL, England, Sept. 3 British plans for entering the European Common Market and Government proposals for a National Incomes Commission are expected to come under fierce attack here this week at the ninety-fourth Trades Union Congress.
GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 3 Capitalizing on three kick returns good for a total of 179 yards, the Green Bay Packers reasserted their superiority over the New York Giants tonight.

FARMVILLE, Va., Sept. 3 The shops on North Main street here are advertising "back-toschool" specials, but for at least half the residents of Prince Edward County these seasonal appeals are empty and ironic.
TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 3 Premier Assadollah Alam said tonight that at least 20,000 people had been killed on injured in the earthquake that struck western Iran Saturday night.
DETROIT, Sept. 3 (AP) Tomorrow is the day when 1963 model auto production begins in earnest.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 3 (AP)--Roman Catholic schools in New Orleans and six outlying parishes (counties) are scheduled to begin the first major parochial school desegregation in the South tomorrow. The police stand ready to prevent trouble.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 3 Prize winners in the Stamford Yacht Club's twentyeighth Vineyard race which ended last night, received their trophies at the annual postrace luncheon attended by about 150 skippers and crew members today. Commodore Frank Leeland made the presentations. Frank W. Tchitcherine, the regatta chairman, was toastmaster.

The new state-wide Family Court represents an effort to provide a single forum for the first time for almost all the problems of family life that require the attention of both the law and social services.

Parcels of clothing, jewelry, objects of art and other items suitable for resale at the Girls Club of New York Thrift Shop will be brought to the SheratonEast on Sept. 26 by guests attending a luncheon and fashion show there.
The three-day Labor Day week-end closed yesterday.
Hundreds of holiday motorists were surprised yesterday to pay their tolls at the Lincoln Tunnel to a woman toll collector.

LONDON, Sept. 3 A conference of more than 200 scientists that opened here today was urged by President Kennedy to "explore fully and objectively the basic reasons for our failure thus far to reach agreement" on a nuclear test ban.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 3 Merrie Duke, a rallying horse, and Howard Beissinger, a rallying driver, tonight collaborated flawlessly and won the $50,000 Roosevelt Trot before 26,168 fans at Roosevelt Raceway.
NORTH CONWAY, N.H., Sept. 3 E. E. Cummings, who made poetic art of commas and parentheses, died here early today after having suffered a stroke.
ALGIERS, Sept. 3--The power struggle that has carried Algeria to the brink of civil war is a clash of men, not of ideas or policies.

Edward Estlin Cummings was a magnificent poet. The terribly jocose waggery that his way of putting words on paper invited could never obscure the fact that those words burned with true fire. Capital letters and lower case are not valid distinctions of ability.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 3 (AP) --Pan American World Airways said today it was losing money on its twice-a-day flights to Havana. It indicated that the refugee airlift would be halted unless aid was received from the Government or other sources.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept. 3 (AP) The Southern Newspaper Publishers Association was told today that the racial "master-servant relationship" had been broken once and for all.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 3 --Finance Minister Walter Moreira Salles resigned tonight after returning from a mission to obtain postponement of scheduled payments to the United States and Western European countries.

WASHINGTON, Sept 3 (AP) Camilo Pascual pitched his seventeenth victory of the season and Bob Allison hit his twenty-second and twenty-third homers today as the Minnesota Twins twice rallied to beat the Washington Senators, 9 3 and 4 3.

Eight states in addition to New York are in the process of court reform or revision of judicial selection methods.

ACCRA, Ghana, Sept. 3-- President Kwame Nkrumah named Krobo Edusei Minister of Agriculture today. Mr. Edusei was dismissed from the Cabinet in April after his wife was severely criticized for having purchased an $8,400 bed.
The year covered by the present report has been a critical period in the life of the organization.
LONDON, Sept. 3--Dr. Robert A. Soblen made his final plea today against the British order directing him to be deported to the United States.

BILL VEECK, the eminent author, went sweeping into the press box at Comiskey Park in Chicago one day last week with all of his old buoyancy, verve, dynamism and zest for both life and mischief. The baseball writers swarmed around him in affectionate greeting. The fans spotted this unmistakable man and leaped to their feet in admiring salute.
Budget Director William F. Shea warned yesterday that the city must "review and recast" its vast schedules of public construction to conform to available funds.
John Marston, actor, died on Sunday at the Lambs Club, where he was a resident. He was 72 years old.
DENVER, Sept. 3 (AP) Fire raged out of control for more than four hours in the 300-room Albany Hotel yesterday, killing one person and injuring about fifty.

Friedrich Duerrenmatt's comedy "An Angel Comes to Babylon" will be presented in English Sept. 27 through Sept. 29 at the University of California's outdoor Hearst Greek Memorial Theatre in Berkeley. Plans to do the play here several years ago were abandoned because the production cost was considered too high.
A Democratic party primary has become a political training ground for Bronx teen-agers who do volunteer campaign work for the candidates.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI)--Congressional investigators predicted today that the cost of the Cambodian-American Friendship Highway might surpass $50,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 A review committee of the Alliance for Progress, the Administration's program for Latin America, has approved Columbia's ten-year plan for economic and social development.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 A loan of $2,500,000 was approved today by the Inter-American Development Bank to help raise agricultural productivity in Honduras. The loan will finance nearly 70 per cent of the cost of Honduras' rural credit program.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 3 Fairfield County's thirty garden clubs will hold their annual get-together exhibition on Sept. 12 and 13 at the Silvermine Guild of Artists, a scholarship fund benefit. Proceeds will enable a number of qualified students to attend the University of Connecticut or the SilverMine College of Art.

Propagating the rare Arabian oryx in captivity in Africa or the United States may preserve the species as a zoological curiosity and one can only hope the project succeeds. It is a sad thing, nevertheless, because an animal in the zoo is not the same as an animal in the wild. A better conservation ...
BERLIN, Tuesday, Sept. 4 An Allied order barring the Russians from using their customary crossing point into West Berlin was said to have gone into effect last midnight.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 3 Rutgers' football team is in the rare and difficult position of being able to improve slightly on its undefeated season of 1961. The Scarlet will play ten games this year. Last year's squad won all of its nine games.

Two agency changes involving cosmetics companies were disclosed over the week-end. Coty, Inc., which announced its departure from Dancer-Fitzgerald-Sample, Inc., on Thursday, named Ellington Co., Inc., as its new agency, effective Jan. 1, 1963. A spokesman for Coty said that billings on the account would total about $2,000,000 during 1963.
Formation of a Queens Transit Committee to seek "transit relief for Queens now" was announced yesterday by Borough President John T. Clancy.
The International Ladies Garment Workers Union has charged that the current House inquiry into New York's garment industry has "revenge and political blackmail" as its objectives.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 3 (UPI) Joey Jay scored his twentyfirst victory of the year tonight when he beat the Milwaukee Braves, 3 0, on a four-hitter for the Cincinnati Reds.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Sept. 3 (UPI) An epidemic of encephalitis, sleeping sickness, was increased over the week-end by seventeen cases, a health official reported today. An intensified campaign is under way against mosquitos suspected of carrying the disease.
ALBANY, Ga., Sept. 3 Ku Klux Klansmen massed in a pasture near here tonight, burned a cross, cheered racist oratory and swatted insects that swarmed about them by the millions.

Sky Shield III, an operation conducted Sunday to test the nation's air defenses, also resulted in tests of the patience of customs Service inspectors and travelers from overseas destinations, according to reports received from International Airport yesterday.
Angelo Granata, a short man with a loud voice, lifted a rattan cane on East 108th Street shortly after noon yesterday, jabbed it at 100 muscled ItalianAmericans and roared "Sotto! [Under!]."
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 3 (AP) Following is the text of President Kennedy's Labor Day message to the youth of the nation:

TEHERAN, Tuesday, Sept. 4 (AP) An announcement by an American broadcasting station here of impending new earthquakes spread panic through Teheran early today. Thousands of residents fled into the streets.
CHATHAM, N.Y.,Sept. 3 Governor Rockefeller spent Labor Day campaigning at the Columbia County Fair here.

DALLAS, Sept. 3 (AP) Billy Maxwell played down the middle with deadly approaches today and gained his first tournament victory in a year. He captured the $35,000 Dallas open with a one-over-par 71 for 277 and $5,300 first money.

GENEVA, Sept. 3 (AP) The neutralist states at the seventeen-nation disarmament conference supported today a Western proposal for continued three-power nuclear test ban talks during the coming recess of the main conference.
Although city schools will not open until next Monday, about 165,785 boys and girls will go to school for the first time tomorrow to register for kindergarten or first grade.

Zero Mostel, who lectured humorously, on the art of comedy at Harvard University's Loeb Drama Center last May, has obtained a booking for his monologue on an educational television station here. The Harvard lecture, with a few cuts to reduce the playing time, will be presented as part of the premiere program over WNDT (Channel 13) on Sept. 16.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 3 (AP) The Fourth Asian Games neared an end tonight after a riotous demonstration against India had cast a pall over the sportsmanship of the events.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 The Soviet Union's announcement yesterday that it would provide military aid to Cuba to meet threats of "imperialist" attack raises anew questions of the present meaning and effect of the Monroe Doctrine.
THE Knickerbocker Championships tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association at the StatlerHilton Hotel ended yesterday with a two-session contest for teams of four.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 Business plans for expansion this year have not changed, over-all, since last winter.
The Peace Corps will see action in underprivileged areas of Manhattan this fall, including East Harlem, Chelsea and the lower East Side.

Kurt Hans Volk, an expert in illuminated manuscripts and founder and chairman of Kurt H. Volk, Inc., typographers at 228 East Forty-fifth Street, died yesterday in his home in Hollywood, Fla. His age was 78.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (AP) Rex C. Ellsworth's Prove It, with 131 pounds, the most he has carried this season, won the $113,450 Washington Park Handicap today in a photo finish with Try Cash a 44-to-1 shot.

CONVENT, N.J., Sept. 3 Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. Froment have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jeanne Adelaide Froment, to Barrie Lewis Tiedemann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Tiedemann of Norfolk, Va.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 3 Prince Norodom Sihanouk threatened today to ask Communist China to send into Cambodia enough forces to "discourage aggression" if no one else would guarantee his country's frontiers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 Bolivia withdrew today from participation in all activities of the Organization of American States.
Richard H. Balch of Utica, former Democratic state chairman, publicly endorsed Representative Samuel S. Stratton last night for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

Court to Hear About Tactics Used to Control Diners The Waterfront Commission wild go into the State Supreme Court this week to seek support in its investigation of reports that hoodlums are using strong-arm tactics to take over mobile lunch-wagon operations on the Brooklyn waterfront.
The consolidation of the New York City court system has meant in many instances a change of venue for the courtrooms.
MANCHESTER, Eng., Sept. 3 The British Association for the Advancement of Science was urged today to press for the adoption of English as the most useful language for international communication.

THE fourth and last of the season's Naumburg Orchestral Concerts took place in the cool night air of the Central Park Mall last night. The conductor was 36-yearold Werner Torkanowsky, and the soloist for excerpts from Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunov" ...

WOODSTOCK, N.Y., Sept. 3 Miss Pamela Sturges, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hollister Sturges of New York and Woodstock, was married here this afternoon to Randal Loring Whitman, son of Mrs. Alain Whitman of New York and Dr. Loring Whitman of Chappaqua.
A contest has developed over who is the true conservative between two Republicans seeking the City Council seat of the late Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan.

SINGAPORE, Sept. 3 Leftist parties sympathetic to Communist China have opened a campaign to wreck plans for the integration of British territories in Borneo with proWestern Malaya. The integration plan envisages the formation by Aug. 31, 1963, of a new nation to be called Malaysia.
ALGIERS, Sept. 3 Troops supporting the Algerian Political Bureau were advancing on Algiers tonight from the south after skirmishes in which ten lives were reported lost.
TWENTY-TWO minutes to commute to New York is generally considered enviable, particularly when the green grass and trees at the residential end have not been overwhelmed by massive building.
A petition submitted by Governor Rockefeller to the Federal Maritime Commission has re ceived strong support within the regulatory agency.
ATHENS, Sept. 3 Vice President Johnson assured worried Greek leaders today that United States aid to Greece would be "even more effective in the future" than in the past.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 3 President Moise Tshombe of Katanga Province replied favorably today to the United Nations plan for ending his province's secession from the Congo.

Results of underground nuclear tests in Nevada and New Mexico have stirred consideration of the use of explosive release of nuclear energy for mine blasting, according to a Stanford Research Institute authority.

I COULDN'T stand going into my child's school," the mother said, "because I'd always hear teachers yelling. They seemed to spend more time on discipline than education. They didn't seem to enjoy teaching."
Morton L. Rubinow, a bridge teacher who attained international recognition as a tournament player, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 35 years old.
PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 3 --The mechanical eyes and brain of a spacecraft a million miles away can hardly be expected to distinguish whether it is "looking" at the earth or at the moon.

In a demonstration that a new era has dawned in Europe, President de Gaulle arrives in Bonn today on the first ceremonial state visit by a French head of state to Germany in recent times. The event is designed to put the final seal on the historic reconciliation between France and Germany that is the cornerstone of an ultimate United States of Europe.

ORANGE, Mass., Sept. 3 (UPI) A 23-year-old Yugoslavian parachutist sought asylum in the United States today, hours before his team 1eft for home from the sixth world sport parachuting championships here.

HAVANA, Sept. 3 Diplomatic sources said today the announcement in Moscow that Cuba had been granted further military aid from the Soviet Union marked the end rather than the beginning of an operation designed to bolster coastal and air defenses.
LONDON, Sept. 3 Simon M. Aisenstein, a pioneer in wireless telegraphy, died here today at the age of 78.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 3 The Mets lost twice to the Pirates today in a double-header that proved a little about overnight train rides and a great deal about the remarkable competitive nature of a man named Richie Ashburn. The scores were 2 0 and 5 4.

TOKYO, Sept. 3 (UPI)--Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor; newly appointed Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today that the United States was prepared to do more in South Vietnam if necessary to block the Communist threat to that country.
Two more television soap operas will go down the drain Sept. 28. They are "The Brighter Day" on the Columbia Broadcasting System and "Our Five Daughters" on the National Broadcasting Company network.
The city canceled its dedication ceremonies, scheduled for yesterday, for four rehabilitated buildings on West Ninety-fourth Street because it feared a possible outbreak of violence.
LONDON, Sept. 4--The reserves of gold and convertible currencies held by Britian as central banker for the sterling area fell last month by 24,000,000 ($67,200,000).
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4-- The Senate voted today to allow tax deductions for lobbying expenses by business concerns and individual business men.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4-- The Administration was accused today of failing to establish a clear policy on protecting the public against possible radiation dangers from nuclear testing.
Robert M. Morgenthau resigned yesterday as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York to seek the Democratic nomination for Governor.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 10 cents to $1.10 a bale yesterday.

The Florida Development Commission plans to offer on Sept. 24 road revenue bonds of three counties valued in the aggregate at $7,920,000. The largest is a $3,750,000 issue of Levy County. The other two are $3,170,000 of Orange County, and $1,000,000 of Santa Rosa County.
Montecatini, the big Italian chemical and mining concern, is staking a total of $25,000,000 of its own funds on the further development of a polypropylene industry in the United States.
ONE of the most popular fish dishes in French restaurants here is fillet of sole V ronique. The distinguishing feature of this dish is white seedless grapes in a sauce of dry white wine and cream.
ROME, Sept. 4--Rome gave Vice President Johnson a warm welcome today.

OTTAWA, Sept. 4 (AP)-- Despitee a major gain in exports to the United States, Canada rolled up a trade deficit of $126,300,000 during the first half of the year, more than 50 per cent higher than the $81,700,000 deficit in first-half of 1961.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 4--The United Nations reported today that its police force in the Middle East had been successful in maintaining "uninterrupted peace and quiet."
DARLINGTON, S.C., Sept. 4 (UPI)--Larry Frank held clear title to $21,100 in stock-car racing prize money today--money he was several hours late in collecting because of an error in scoring.
All Americans as well as all of our friends in this hemisphere have been concerned over the recent moves of the Soviet Union to bolster the military power of the Castro regime in Cuba.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 4--The St. Louis Art Museum has received a startling bonus.
OVIEDO, Spain, Sept. 4--The mood of the Asturias is as sullen as the grimy valleys of this northern region.
HOUSTON, Sept. 4 (AP)-- The Houston Colts, without benefit of hexers, witch doctors or black cats, beat the Philadephia Phillies, 4--1, tonight and avoided an unwanted major league record.

The acquisition of Piel Brothers, 79-year-old New York brewery concern, by Drewrys, Ltd., U.S.A., Inc., a brewery company of South Bend, Ind., was announced yesterday by Rudy A. Moritz, president of Drewrys.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4-- Telstar, the experimental communications satellite now in orbit, is not a single invention, but at least sixteen. Patents on the sixteen most important to its success have been obtained over a quarter of a century by the Bell Telephone Laboratories, Inc.

PARIS, Sept. 4--An expert testifying at the trial of five men accused of having tried to assassinate President de Gaulle said today that the bomb they planted by a roadside last September would certainly have killed the President if it had been detonated properly.

PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 4-- Scientists of the California Institute of Technology jubilantly announced tonight that they had successfully corrected the course of the Venus-bound spacecraft Mariner II with radio signals sent nearly 1,500,000 miles.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4-- President Kennedy led the applause today when the Schola Cantorum of the University of Arkansas sang for him in the rose garden of the White House.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 4--A human error, the possibility of which a missile director at Cape Canaveral had known, caused the failure of a $2,000,000 missile, it was reported here today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4-- President Kennedy's urban mass transit program has been quietly added to the list of the Administrations's election-year casualties.
MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 4-- Enrolled members of Nassau County's Republican and Democratic parties will vote Thursday in eight primary contests.

MOSCOW, Sept. 4 (UPI)-- Tass, the official Soviet press agency, criticized U Thant today. The agency said the Acting Secretary General of the United Nations had glossed over the situation in the Congo in his annual report on United Nations operations.
Prices of Government securities weakened yesterday. Corporates were a shade better; state and municipal obligations were quiet and firm.
Two rare white rhinoceroses, Malamba and Quagaza, arrived from Africa yesterday at the Bronx Zoo to help form an "animal bank" for creatures that might be facing extinction.

A crowd gathered around Sweet's Restaurant at 2 Fulton Street on the lower East Side eighty years ago last night. There were crowds around the offices of The New York Times, The New York Herald and the banking house of Drexel, Morgan Co. as well.
This summer has been unusually cool, the Weather Bureau said yesterday.

The head of Trans World Airlines has approached his counterparts at American and United Air Lines on the possibility of cutting the number of flights on major routes so as to ease the problem of too many unfilled seats.

A Brazilian was in custody here yesterday after he had been arrested Monday night with his pockets jingling from about fifty hotel room keys. Detectives had picked him up for questioning on a number of recent midtown jewel burglaries.
LONDON, Sept, 4--Prices of industrial shares slipped lower in the stock market today, in sharp contrast to the continued advance of British Government securities.

A British look at the late John Foster Dulles' record as an international diplomat will be issued Sept. 24 by AppletonCentury-Crofts. The author of "John Foster Dulles: A Reappraisal," is Richard GooldAdams, who was on the staff of The Economist (London) from 1947 to 1955. He examines Mr. Dulles' record with two questions in mind: did he handle ...

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Sept. 4 (AP)--Charles D. (Chic) Werner, the head track coach at Pennsylvania State University for twenty-nine years, today was named as the executive director of the new United States Track and Field Federation.

Business and industrial concerns that help make New York City the greatest trading center in the world also are going increasingly to distant lands to sell their products. The things they produce and the techniques they use to sell them are being demonstrated at various international trade fairs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4--Retail sales rose more in July than was originally reported, to a record level. The Commerce Department reported today that sales increased by 3 per cent in July, after making allowance for normal seasonal developments.

Sales of Dresser Industries; Inc., in the quarter and nine months ended with July showed a substantial increase over those of the periods last year. Earnings for the third quarter were lower as a result of the devaluation losses in the currencies of Argentina and Canada, the report disclosed yesterday.
Sterling eased somewhat yesterday in New York foreign-exchange trading. The pound closed at $2.8016 bid, against $2.8020 Friday.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 4-- Roman Catholic schools in New Orleans lowered racial barriers today for the first time in sixty-seven years. The desegregation was peaceful.

HAVANA, Sept. 4 (AP)-- The Cuban press praised today the military industrial aid being furnished by the Soviet Union as a step toward future socialist plenty and simultaneously reported that a plan for the rationing of shoes and clothes "is under study."
"Oliver!", the new musical by Lionel Bart, has been booked to open at the Imperial Theatre Dec. 27.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 4 (AP)--The Fourth Asian Games, a twelve-day mixture of sports and politics, ended tonight with thousands of Indonesians in Senajan Stadium booing Indian athletes and the Indian flag and national anthem.
PARIS, Sept. 4--Frenchmen returning from their summer holiday spending sprees were able to read some consoling news today: there will be no new taxes in 1963.
The Flight Engineers International Association, whose strike against Eastern Air Lines is now in its eleventh week, lost another round in the Federal courts yesterday.
Governor Rockefeller has increased the staff and operating funds of a team investigating irregularities in New York State road construction.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 4--Theodore W. Kheel, New York attorney and former president of the National Urban League, suggested today that employer's should seek out qualified Negroes in filling job openings.
Several seasoned performers and many rookies received the unhappiest cut of all yesterday as clubs in both pro football leagues pared their rosters to the limit.
New York's new court system took its first steps yesterday --a little uncertainly and with a fair measure of confusion.

The owners of radio station WMCA here have asked the Federal Communications Commission to rule on the possibility of changing an ultra-high-frequency television allocation from New Brunswick, N.J., to New York.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 4--Harvey Haddix, once "The Kitten" but now a wise old cat, kept the Mets in their place at Forbes Field tonight.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 4-- Dr. Juan Atilio Bramuglia, Foreign Minister during the first half the Peron era and a highly regarded international statesman, died after surgery this morning. He was 59 years old.
RACINE, Wis., Sept. 4 (UPI) --J.I. Case Company reported a net loss of $2,166,306 for the nine months ended July 31, down from a $7,121,308 deficit for the 1961 period.
International events produced sharp declines in coffee and cocoa futures yesterday. Other commodities traded on New York exchanges were quiet and mixed.

Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Sprout Clarke of 480 Park Avenue, a landscape architect known professionally as M. Betty Clarke, died Sunday in the Roosevelt Hospital after a two-month illness. She was 56 years old.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 4 --Mrs. Pat Hinman Duane of Delray Beach, Fla., the 1961 national champion in the Flying Dutchman Class, won easily with Hang Over today on Long Island Sound.
BLACKPOOL, England, Sept. 4--The growing influence of women and white-collar workers in trade-union affairs in Britain emerged today in a big way at the annual Trades Union Congress here.
ALBANY, Ga., Sept. 4 (UPI) --A group of Negroes attempting to integrate the city's schools today met police barricades and a crudely printed sign that read, "No Niggers, Please."

I.P.A. Associates, Inc., has sold the Oakdale-Sayville Shopping Center on Montauk Highway, Oakdale, L.I., to OakdaleSayville Associates. The price was more than $2,000,000. The development covers fifteen acres and has twenty-five stores and parking for 1,200 cars. Carl Davis and Alexander I. Oppenhelm of New York were the brokers.
The price of silver in New York yesterday reached $1.13 an ounce, the highest level since 1920.

BERLIN, Sept. 4--The Russians bowed tonight to an order barring the passage of their guards for the Soviet war memorial in West Berlin through the United States Army checkpoint on the border dividing East and West Berlin.

Roy Emerson of Australia and Darlene Hard of Long Beach, Calif., the defending men's and women's titleholders, were among the few players who completed their matches yesterday before rain forced a cancellation of most of the program in the national lawn tennis championships at Forest Hills.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4--Ben W. Heineman, chairman of the Chicago and North Western Railway, said today that the line would stay closed for months, if necessary, to win its point in the strike that has halted its operations.

Just before the art season gets under way, a few of the galleries are opening with print shows that may interest teenage viewers. The Kennedy Galleries, 13 East Fifty-eighth Street, offers a show designed to point out the differences among the various print media as well as variations within the same medium.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 4-- The Government of South Vietnam acted today to expel Francois Sully, correspondent here for the magazine Newsweek, on charges that he was "systematically hostile" to the country.

On the eve of tomorrow's primary elections, an unusual degree of ferment is apparent in both Democratic and Republican parties throughout the state. It is responsible for this year's exceptionally large number of contests for nomination to public office.

RAVENNA, Ohio, Sept. 4 (AP)--A twin-engine private plane believed to have been carrying two pilots and at least nine passengers--including executives from three oil companies--crashed and exploded in a farm field southeast of here tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4-- The United States admitted today that a U-2 reconnaissance plane might have "unintentionally" flown over the southern tip of Sakhalin Island in the Pacific.

THE brick and stone cottage was situated a little way out of the village of Ockentree only three or four feet from a busy national highway. More than 300 years old and looking its full age, it was half buried in a slope so that its front door opened into a room in its second story.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 4 --An autumn wedding is planned by Miss Barbara Bruce and George E. Hodge Jr. Announcement of their engagement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Gordon Bruce, parents of the prospective bride. Mr. Hodge is the son of Lieut. Col. Hodge, United States Army Air Corps, retired, and Mrs. Hodge of Vineyard Haven, Mass., formerly of New York.
BOSTON, Sept. 4--Sherman Adams, former Assistant to President Eisenhower, will be a guest lecturer at the College of Wooster in Wooster, Ohio, beginning Oct. 22.
HERSHEY, Pa., sept. 4-- With variations concocted by Coach John Stiegman, Pennsylvania has turned to threeteam football in an effort to improve its recent lowly status in the Ivy League.
Sales of the major department stores in the metropolitan area rose last month by 3 per cent from the 1961 level, according to survey made yesterday by The New York Times.
TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 4-- Help began pouring in today for victims of the earthquake in western Iran, which killed or injured at least 20,000 people.
UNITY HOUSE, Pa., Sept. --The International Ladies Gar ment Workers Union refused to day to bargain collectively with a union of its staff representatives.

Just as the President of the United States is constitutionally obligated to report to Congress on the State of the Union, so the Secretary General of the United Nations is called upon by the Charter "to make an annual report to the General Assembly on the work of the organization." Acting Secretary General Thant, like his predecessors, meets this obligation, but what he is really discussing is the state of mankind.

A FIELD of more than fifty is assured for the sixth 500-mile sports car race at Road America, in Elkhart Lake, Wis., on Sunday. Many of those on the starting grid will be "big bore" machines, some new, others old and proved.
MOSCOW, Sept. 4--The Soviet Union protested to the United States today against what it described as a "provocative flight" by a U-2 reconnaissance plane.
BERROUAGHIA, Algeria, Sept. 4--Two hostile, battleready Algerian Army groups of several thousand men each faced each other on a broad front just south of here today.

The building containing thirty apartments and occupying a plot 50 by 100 feet at 6125 Broadway, corner of West 257th Street, opposite Van Cortlandt Park in the Riverdale section of the Bronx has been bought by an investing client of Sol Victor, lawyer. It was sold through David Itzler of Nathan Rikelman, broker, for cash over existing mortgages amounting to $150,000.
CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (AP)--Al Smith's bases-filled pinch-single with two out in the thirteenth inning gave the Chicago White Sox a 3-2 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight.
FARMVILLE, Va., Sept. 4-- From the press box of the Little League softball field, a voice intoned a prayer over the loud speaker.

TRENTON, Sept. 4--Gov. Richard J. Hughes said today he was "very disappointed" at the continued opposition of the Port of New York Authority to a jetport in the pine belt of Burlington County in South Jersey.

RUMSON, N.J., Sept. 4-- Ten young Women from the Rumson-Middletown area were presented tonight at the third Rumson Debutante Ball. The event was given by their parents in the Sea Bright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Sept. 4 (AP)--Gov. John M. Dalton said today that he had received numerous reports of violence as a result of the National Farmers Organization's attempt to halt the movement of livestock to market.

THE death Monday of Morton L. Rubinow, after sev eral weeks in Mount Sinai Hospital following a heart attack, came as perhaps the greatest shock to the fraternity of expert bridge players since Louis Watson died in 1936 at the age of 29.
SOUTH SALEM, N.Y., Sept. 4--Ground was broken today for the first permanent home of the rural South Salem library.
Manhattan will have another unconventional film revival theatre next month, to complement the thriving New Yorker, the Bleecker Street Cinema and the Thalia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) --The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today a bill carrying $1,349,611,000 for construction of military installations and facilities in the fiscal year that started on July 1.
A default judgment for $12,551,232 was entered yesterday against the United States Trunk Company, Inc., of Fall River, Mass., because it had ignored a suit brought in Federal Court by an inventor.

Moorhead Wright of old Roaring Brook Road, Chappaqua, N.Y., for many years a leader in management training for the General Electric Company, died Monday night in Northern Westchester Hospital, Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 56 years old.

William A. Marsteller, the chairman of Marsteller, Inc., is engaged in an interesting crusade. He wants to abolish use of the term "billings"--a curious statistic that has always been a basic part of the advertising agency business.
The Los Angeles Angels apparently haven't run out of fantastic moves in their efforts to prove to a doubting world they still belong in the American League pennant struggle.
Changeovers in automobile plants--finishing with 1962 models and starting on 1963 cars--produced a mixed production picture in August.
After scattered interruptions yesterday, trucking operations in the city are expected to return to normal today.
Patrolman Robert J. Byrnes died in Coney Island Hospital late yesterday afternoon of wounds inflicted Friday night in Coney Island by a berserk gunman.
One of the biggest state primary elections in years will be run off tomorrow.
HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 4-- Although the football training schedule at Dartmouth has hardly begun, Bob Blackman, starting his eighth season as head coach, already is shoulderguard-high in problems.

VOLGOGRAD, U.S.S.R., Sept. 4--A delegation, of United States Government power officials, led by Stewart L. Udall, Secretary of Interior, completed an inspection of big Soviet dams today with a visit to the sparkling new Volgograd hydroelectric station on the Volga River.

Negotiations with the Castro regime concerning Cubans imprisoned in the 1961 invasion attempt are "proceeding favorably," James B. Donovan said yesterday following his return from Havana, where he saw Premier Fidel Castro.
Stocks sagged yesterday in slow trading. The post-Labor Day pick-up in the market that many had expected failed to develop.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4--The United States invoked international cotton trade controls today to stop imports of two products from Portugal.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 4-- The Delta Stables' Van Tat's Pride, with Del Insko driving, scored a nose victory over Sampson's Lady tonight in the Garden City, the feature mile pace at Roosevelt Raceway.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 4 (AP)--John J. Roe's Tilmar scored a front-running victory in today's feature at the Atlantic City race track before a crowd of 13,675.

A Chicago bail bondsman was held in $100,000 bail yesterday in Federal Court on charges of having swindled two New Jersey business men of $100,000 in a gold scheme while they awaited a rendezvous with him in Switzerland.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 4-- President de Gaulle arrived here today for a six-day state visit to West Germany designed to put the seal on a French-German reconciliation that is the keystone for construction of a united Europe.

THE young woman who dreams of marching to the altar in a bridal gown designed and executed by a famous Paris couturier can have her wish fulfilled (provided she can afford it) courtesy of Henri Bendel. Just unpacked at the store's Bridal Salon are six gowns by Givenchy, Dior, Fabiani and Simonetta, St. Laurent, Ricci and Heim.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4--For the next man-in-space shot, the, space agency plans to set up its press headquarters at a Florida motel partly owned by the seven Mercury astronauts.

OTTAWA, Sept. 4 (Canadian Press)--The Trade Department's biggest export push yet was announced today by George Hees, Minister of Trade--an operation that will see more than 700 foreign buyers airlifted to the doorstep of Canadian manufacturers.
The Government of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics deems it necessary to State the following to the Government of the United States of America.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 4 (UPI)--Daring base-running by Willie Davis and John Roseboro set the tempo tonight for a 5-4 victory by the Los Angeles Dodgers over the San Francisco Giants in the second game of their four game series.

BUFFALO, Sept. 4 (AP)-- Fran Striker, originator of the popular Western hero, the Lone Ranger, was killed today in an automobile collision on Route 16, about twelve miles southeast of here. He was 58 years old.

Bergdorf Goodman takes a very personal point of view about Paris. Under the discerning eye of Miss Ethel Frankau, director of the store's custom salon, good taste and the needs of her elegant, conservative clients always come first. Unlike most stores, where Paris copies are mass-produced on Seventh Avenue, Bergdorf Goodman copies its selections to order in its own workrooms. The workmanship and the prices match the original.
As a nation becomes more prosperous, its citizens spend more and more on services. ThiS fact of life has not been lost on the economists who have been watching and analyzing the trends.

Mutual funds and their trade association, the Investment Company Institute, complained yesterday that they have been unable to obtain copies of the 600-page study of the industry by the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Finance and Industry.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 4--Christopher Fry has returned to the theatre, after eight years of silence, with a historical play about Henry II that covers some of the same ground as Anouilh's "Becket."

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 4 --Billy Edwards of the Cherry Valley Club led the sectional qualifiers on Long Island today for the United States amateur championship. His thirty-sixhole score of 75, 68--143 over the Garden City Country Club course won the medal for the 31-year-old golfer by a twostroke margin.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4--A special Presidential board began an intensive effort today to settle a dispute between two unions and four key manufacturers of missiles and aircraft.
The sleek, new cargo-passenger ship African Comet steamed into port yesterday morning to receive the traditional welcome accorded by the port to new vessels.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 4-- Torchlight parades, rallies and radio speeches tonight increased the tempo of campaigning in one of the bitterest primary fights Westchester County has experienced in several years.

NEW YORKER of distinguished lineage in pub lic service, Robert Morris Morgenthau has lately and suddenly entered the political stage from deep in the wings. His name has helped him in this, but the solidity of his own record as a student, lawyer, naval officer.
CHEROKEE, N.C., Sept. 4--The Kennedy Administration is emphasizing economic development on the reservations in its policy toward American Indians.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 4-- Seven of the nine Members of the Latin American Free Trade Association vetoed Cuba's application for admission last night. Mexico and Brazil abstained.
The intestinal tumor removed from former President Herbert Hoover during a three-hour operation on Aug. 28 was reported yesterday to be malignant.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Sept. 4--Llewellyn E. Thompson Jr., former United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, suffered a kidney stone attack and collapsed this afternoon on the Air Force Academy golf course. Physicians at the Academy hospital said later his condition was "good."
YAPHANK, L.I., Sept. 4-- Primary contests are scheduled Thursday between Suffolk County Republicans seeking nominations for two Congressional seats and one State Assembly post.

LONDON, Sept. 4--Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies of Australia declared today that his country was neither "an enemy nor a prospective enemy" of Britain's membership in the European Economic Community, or Common Market.

Tomorrow's primary elections in this city lack the excitement that enveloped the Democratic primaries a year ago, when Mayor Wagner was fighting for his political life against the entrenched forces of "bossism." If the absence of comparable drama now results in a light vote, the beneficiaries will be the old-line Democratic regulars, who always find machine rule easiest to perpetuate when the mass of the electorate stays home.

The Board of Elections will make available on request of any law enforcement agency the names of candidates for public office and of campaign committee treasurers who fail to make public accountings of contributions and expenses. But the board will not initiate punitive action on its own against those on the lists.
Steel production last week gained 3.8 per cent over the preceding week's output, reaching the highest level since mid-May.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company had record sales in the three and nine months ended July 31, but earnings declined from those of the periods a year ago, the report of Harvey S. Firestone Jr., chairman, and Raymond C. Firestone, president, disclosed yesterday.
LONGMEADOW, Mass., Sept. 4--Robert A. Niemi of 409 Williams Street, a vice president of Combustion Engineering, Inc., died of a heart attack Saturday in North Adams Hospital. He was 46 years old.

James S. Lanigan resigned yesterday from the Village Independent Democrats, the club that backed him a year ago in his successful fight to unseat Carmine G. De Sapio as the Democratic leader in the Greenwich Village area.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4-- The Senate Post Office and Civil Service Committee tentatively approved today an increase in first-class and secondclass postal rates.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 4 --India has invited a representative of Communist China "to discuss essential preliminary measures" for further negotiations toward a peaceful settlement of their border dispute.
ALGIERS, Wednesday, Sept. 5--Algerian leaders announced today that a cease-fire agreement had been worked out to halt the fighting between rival Algerian troops.

PARIS, Sept. 4--The Twentysixth World Congress on Housing and Planning was told today that a population of 700,000 was the maximum for a city that would allow it to maintain reasonable traffic arrangements.
ALBANY, Sept. 4--The state has issued a new civil defense policy for school children. In effect, it says, "Stay where you are" instead of "Go home."

Mindful of the fact that Precocious Miss had been impeded in her previous race, Bobby Ussery steered her into the clear at the start of the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. The 4year-old daughter of Crafty miral remained at the head of the small field and won the sixfurlong sprint by a neck over First Dark of the Greentree Stable.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4-- Gov. Edmund G. Brown told his hometown neighbors tonight that he was ready for "the toughest scrap we have ever been in."

MANCHESTER, England, Sept. 4--A relatively simple explanation for one of the most perplexing problems of modern physics, superconductivity, or the frictionless flow of electricity, was propounded at today's sessions of the British Association for the Advancement of Science.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4-- President Kennedy said today that the United States would use "whatever means may be necessary" to prevent aggression by Cuba against any part of the Western Hemisphere.

A flurry of racial and ethnic issues erupted in the Bronx Democratic primary campaign yesterday, reflecting one of the most bitter contests among regular, reform and independent candidates in many years.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Sept. 4--The Huguenot Memorial Presbyterian Church was the setting here this evening for the marriage of Miss Judith Ros Henriques, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jeffrey Barlow Henriques of Pelham, to Paul Henry Dujardin. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul H. Dujardin, also of Pelham. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. William C. Schram. A reception was held at the Pelham Country Club.
LONDON, Sept. 4--Colin Jordan, the neo-Nazi leader who told a crowd in Trafalgar Square two months ago that "Hitler was right," was acquitted today of having violated the Public Order Act.
SPOKANE, Wash., Sept. 4 (UPI)--The American people are ready to invade Cuba and drive Premier Fidel Castro from the island, Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, said here today.
Steamship operators and longshoremen will begin daily negotiating sessions today to try to agree on a new contract. The present three-year contract expires Sept. 30.

Robert M. Morgenthau has now announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Governor of New York. For the past sixteen months he has served as United States Attorney here with ability and distinction.
More than half of the Democratic district leadership posts in Brooklyn and Queens will be contested in tomorrow's primary elections. Only a sprinkling of Republican leadership posts are at issue.
BERLIN, Sept. 4 (AP)--The two Berlins, East and West, are hewn from one city, but they are virtually separate countries as far as utilities are concerned.
Singapore's heavy vote in favor of merger with the Federation of Malaya was a defeat for the island state's pro-Communists.
Play was again at a complete standstill in the national lawn tennis championships at Forest Hills yesterday, with rails flooding the courts, and the finals now cannot be held until Monday.

Irving Dworman, a leading builder, died of a heart attack Tuesday evening while inspecting a construction site at 200 East Fifty-eighth Street. He was 73 years old and lived at 4000 Atlantic Avenue, Sea Gate, Brooklyn.

A new approach to adult education will be employed by the New School for Social Research this fall in a course designed to bridge the gap between the "two cultures" of the scientist and the non-scientist.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 4 (UPI)--Lee Grosscup, a quarterback whom the Minnesota Vikings put on waivers, said today he had received an offer from the New York Titans of the American Football League and was "very interested."
The men who sell food and newspapers, cut hair and shine shoes in the maze of lower Manhattan known as Wall Street sense a little more Optimism in their customers. They say this...
LONDON, Sept. 5--The stock market maintained its pattern of the last several days with Government securities advancing and industrial shares drift ing lower.

IN the vast archives of chess openings none has had a more checkered career than the Sicilian Defense. Breaking the symmetry with the first move--not to hold the center, but to start a counterattack on the queen's wing--the Sicilian is above all a fighting game.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5-- The Senate brought a greatly modified version of the Administration's tax revision bill near to passage today.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 5 (UPI)--A Federal grand jury indicted fifteen corporations, including five corporate giants, and twelve of their executives today for fixing prices of plastic hose and pipe.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 5--Thirty-one nations pledged today $86,000,000 in cash and commodities to the first cooperative assault on the hunger that grips half the world.
Bond prices weakened yesterday, but tended to recover in after-hours trading on news of the Treasury's advance refunding plans.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 5-- Josef Krips, conductor and musical director of the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra, has been chosen as the permanent conductor of the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra. He will succeed Enrique Jorda just after the start of the 1963-64 season.

Stocks declined again yesterday in quiet trading. Price changes were not large, but market observers were disappointed over the failure of stocks to regain the strength they had shown in the last few weeks.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 5 (AP)-- The Florida Legislature's reapportionment plan was approved today by a Federal court.

ROME, Thursday, Sept. 6-- Vice President Johnson signed an agreement with Foreign Minister Attilio Piccioni yesterday establishing United States Italian cooperation in space research that should culminate in 1964 with the launching of an Italian earth satellite.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 5-- When Gretel, Australia's challenger for the America's Cup, docked tonight after her first sailing exercises in almost a week, Sir Frank Packer, head of the owning syndicate, named fourteen men who will be her first team in the match against Weatherly. They were chosen from a squad of twenty-six. The rest will be kept busy, but not as principals.

A radio signal from an antenna in the Mojave Desert in California has reached America's Venus probe, Mariner II, and commanded it to correct its course. The result is that instead of missing Venus by 233,000 miles it will come within 9,000 miles of the planet, fully 1,000 miles nearer than had been originally planned.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 5-- Impish, the pride of the Eaton Ridge Farm at Norwich, N.Y., and rated by many the best of the 3-year-old trotting fillies, today drew the No. 2 post position for Saturday night's $27,723.25 Lady Suffolk Trot at Roosevelt Raceway.
The Columbia Broadcasting System announced yesterday that it would televise "A Tour of Monaco With Princess Grace" on Sunday, Feb. 17, from 8 to 9 P.M.

Hughes Aircraft Company scientists said yesterday that they had a new high-power amplifier tube that could eliminate spacecraft radio blackouts such as those experienced by astronauts during re-entry from orbit.
The Flight Engineers International Association accused the Federal Aviation Agency yesterday of reducing the training time required for flight engineers on Eastern Air Lines.

A work stoppage at the city's new educational television station, WNDT, was ordered yesterday by the union of professional television performers and announcers. The outlet is scheduled to go on the air Sept. 16 over Channel 13.

MOSCOW, Sept. 5--The Soviet Union has accused the United States, Britain and France of provocative incidents along the Berlin border. And it has once again refused to join in a four-power talk on ways to ease tension in the city, Tass, the official Soviet press service, reported tonight.

A suit to compel New York Typographical Union No. 6 to arbitrate grievances entered by the Publishers Association of New York City on behalf of one of its members. The New York Times Company, was filed yesterday in Federal Court.

RAVENNA, Ohio, Sept. 5 (AP)--Federal experts looked today for the cause of the nation's worst industrial airplane accident--the crash of a twinengined Lockheed Lodestar that killed a pilot, co-pilot and eleven oil company executives.

CHATTANOOGA, Sept. 5-- Public schools in this industrial Southern city were peacefully desegregated on a limited basis today when fifty-eight Negro children attended, without incident, six previously all-white elementary schools.

GRAND RAPIDS, 'Mich., Sept. 5--The executive director of the National Urban League called today for speedy action in remedying what he called the continued injustices under which Negro citizens live in both the North and the South.
ALBANY, Sept. 5--Governor Rockefeller said today his administration was trying to create the best state police force in the nation "in every way we know how.

ROME, Sept. 5--Pope John XXIII named ten Cardinals today, including Cardinal Spellman of New York, to a Presidency Council to help president over the Ecumenical Council of the Roman Catholic Church in October.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5-- President Kennedy will spend two days next week in surveying military and civilian space installations, the White House said today.
Robert M. Morgenthau last night offered New Yorkers "government with integrity, brains and a heart" if he is elected Governor. The Bronx Democrat, who resigned
MOSCOW, Sept. 5 (AP)-- Robert Frost recited his poem about a wall in New England tonight at a Moscow literary evening. Some members of his audience thought he was talking about the wall in Berlin.
Arbitration of an officer labor dispute affecting the nuclear ship Savannah will resume here today.
Three city agencies are investigating the possibility that a substantial amount of money is missing from funds of the Rikers Island Penitentiary.
ALGIERS, Sept. 5--Shooting between Algerian troops con tinued on three fronts today despite a cease-fire agreed to last night by political leaders here...
Grayson-Robinson Stores, Inc., big retail chain, has closed 30 of its stores and has taken other steps to cut operating expenses by a total annual rate of $2,100,000.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 5-- Maj. Gen. Pedro E. Aramburu, former President, said today that political apathy and partisan strife were inviting a military dictatorship in Argentina.
BERLIN, Sept. 5--Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin and the West German Government got into a public wrangle today over the Mayor's recent tactics in de-emphasizing the fourpower status of all Berlin.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5-- William Jackson Clothier, horseman and former national tennis champion, died last night at his home, Valley Hill Farm, in Valley Forge. He was 80 years old.
NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 5-- The election on Nov. 6 will decide the fate of the century-old Mathews mansion, which has housed city department offices here since 1941.
MOSCOW, Sept. 5--The Soviet Government newspaper, Izvestia, rejected tonight the explanation offered by the United States for the alleged flight of a U-2 reconnaissance

The New York Philharmonic will help celebrate its first season at Philharmonic Hall by presenting ten world premieres during the season. Last year, invitations were sent to internationally-known composers, and ten accepted the commissions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) --Billie Sol Estes did not originate and had "little to do" with administering the cotton allotment transfer deals that plunged him into major trouble with the Agriculture Department, his attorney said today.

The Emerson Electric Manufacturing Company increased the quarterly dividend on its common stock with the declaration yesterday of a 20-cent-ashare payment on Sept. 29 to stockholders of record on Sept. 14.

EXETER, N.H., Sept. 5-- The marriage of Miss Helen Lansing Gillespie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Ernest Gillespie, to Hendrik Willem van Loon took place here this afternoon. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Bowditch van Loon of Wilton, Conn.
WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 5 --"We've certainly had years in which we looked worse at this stage of our preparations."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5--A Russian intellectual said today that Marxism is not a dogma but a dynamic, developing concept.

HOLYOKE, Mass., Sept. 5-- State Attorney General Edward J. McCormack Jr. abandoned the rasp of a prosecuting attorney for the softer tones of a family lawyer tonight to plead his case for the Democratic nomination for Senator from Massachusetts.
The E.L. Bruce Company, already shaken by the Edward M. Gilbert scandal, may become the object of a battle for control by a West Coast lumber manufacturing concern.
CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (UPI)-- Telegraphers pressed for the continued support of eighteen other unions in their strike against the North Western Railroad today.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 5-- Demonstrations by an angry crowd outside a suburban school today marred the second day of parochial-school desegregation in the New Orleans area.

FARMVILLE, VVa., Sept. 5 --On a dirt and gravel road not far from the new high school building of the Prince Edward Academy stands the greenshingled, white bungalow where Mr. and Mrs. James Bolden and her eight children from a previous marriage live.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5--A physician warned today that syphilis was going undiagnosed all too often.
CHEROKEE, N.C., Sept. 5-- The National Congress of American Indians is planning a two-pronged attack on discrimination against Indians.

GENEVA, Sept. 5 (AP)-- The Soviet Union accepted today a United States proposal for direct negotiations for a nuclear test ban by the Big Three nuclear powers during the disarmament conference recess, which begins Saturday.
The U-2, despite its retirement two years ago from the skies of Russia, is once again haunting the wild blue yonder.

THE annual regional bridge tournament of the New York-New Jersey Bridge Conference, which comprises five sectional bridge associations, including the Greater New York Bridge Association, will begin today at Asbury Park, N.J., and continue through Sunday.
One of Manhattan's famous "holdout" corner properties--a tiny parcel of land in the midst of the Rockefeller Center area --was sold yesterday after being held by one family for 110 years.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 5-- Security officials believe that the Kenya Land Freedom Army, the Kikuyu terrorist organization that succeeded the Mau Mau, has started preparations for civil war after independence.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 5--A Federal Grand Jury indicted four Teamsters Union officials today on charges of embezzling nearly $40,000 in union funds in violation of the LandrumGriffin Law.
The New York and American stock exchanges made known yesterday the following changes in ownership of officers, directors and large stockholders of listed companies.

Former Deputy Chief Inspector Francis W. Lent, head of the Police Department's Hack Bureau until his retirement a year ago, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was stricken at the office of the Joint Defense Appeal, fund-raising agency of the American Jewish Committee and other Jewish philanthropic and cultural groups, at 300 West Forty-third Street.
It is surprising to many observers that the economy continues as strong as it is.

Apollo Industries, Inc., Pittsburgh, a diversified operating, and investment company, is expanding its activities through the acqusition of Taller Cooper, Inc., Brooklyn, N.Y. manufacturer of toll revenue control equipment.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 5 --The Luders-16 fleet of the In dian Harbor Yacht Club representing the United States, defeated the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club today in the opening race of their series for the Aberfeldy Trophy.

Dick Siderowf, a former New England amateur champion, and Bob Gardner, the current Metropolitan champion, led their respective fields yesterday in qualifying for the United States Amateur golf championship.

ALTHOUGH in certain scenarios custards are for throwing, they are, in many books, one of the most excellent of desserts. And custards are, for the amateur chef, at once among the simplest yet trickiest of dishes to make.

For one hour yesterday, a great Russian ballet master led sixty American children, some rigid with nervousness, through the classic movements of the dance.

SARASOTA, Fla., Sept. 6 (UPI) Christy Payne, retired vice president and treasurer of Standard Oil (New Jersey), died at his home here early today. He was 88 years old.

JAMES LAVER, curator emeritus of the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, was in the United States this week to accept an award "for distinguished service in the field of fashion" from Neiman-Marcus. He landed in New York and, before moving on to Dallas, where he received his award yesterday, the prolific author and fashion historian delivered himself of some thoughts about the plight of the male.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 6 (UPI) --The Korean joint truce observer team was called today to investigate a clash in which South Korean troops shot and killed three North Korean Communist soldiers in a half-hour clash in the demilitarized zone.

BRITISH television series on the part of the Royal Navy in World War II began last evening over Channel 11. Advance announcements suggested that the program might be the British equivalent of "Victory at Sea" and inevitably such a comparison is invited. But "Sea War,"
Grayson-Robinson Stores, Inc., retail chain, made known yesterday that it had obtained a warrant of attachment against Towers Marts International, Inc., discount operator, to recover $389,945,47.
Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines led by a wide margin in the first half of 1962 in the number of passengers flown on the North Atlantic route.
OLD LYME, Conn., Sept. 6 Mr. and Mrs. Francis Currie of New York and Lyme gave a small supper dance here tonight in the Old Lyme Country Club to introduce their daughter, Miss Mary Teresita Currie.
Thomas R. Jones, a Negro attorney, won a double victory yesterday as the Democratic reform group's candidate for district leader and for Assemblyman in the Bedford-Stuyvesant district of Brooklyn.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 6 Scores of thousands of dripping, rain-drenched Rhinelanders gave President de Gaulle a warmly enthusiastic welcome to the Ruhr, West Germany's industrial heartland, today.

The Senate Post Office Committee's approval of higher first-class postal rates brings the nickel letter a step closer to the mailbox. This is a cheerless prospect, especially with no indication that a 5-cent stamp will buy better service or even better-looking mailboxes.

BERLIN, Sept. 6 (UPI) Hanns Eisler, Hollwood songwriter who wrote the East German National Anthem after his return to Germany, died today in East Berlin, the East German press agency A.D.N. reported. He left the United States after having been ordered deported. His age was 64.
LONDON, Sept. 6 "The New Men," the second of three novels by Sir Charles Snow that are being adapted to the stage, opened tonight before an enthusiastic West End audience.

David Shaer's 4-year-old chestnut colt Commend closed powerfully on the outside at Aqueduct yesterday to take the $10,000 Croton Handicap by two and three-quarter lengths over George Zauderer's pace-setting Kisco Kid.

To prevent a recurrence of the stock thefts that plagued the financial district in July and August, brokerage houses have adopted a host of precautionary measures. These range from the use of camera equipment and badges to more frequent physical counts of securities.
After months of trying to find Howard R. Hughes, Trans World Airlines, Inc., may finally get to question the elusive financier on Sept. 24 in California.

Mayor Wagner promised early today that he would take up with the Board of Elections reports of widespread breakdowns of voting machines in yesterday's primary election.

ROME, Sept. 7 Giovanni Cardinal Urbani, Patriarch of Venice, in an address after a "mass of the cinema," severely criticized modern movie-making, adding "the day when the cinema world will mature, considering the productions up to the present time, seems far away. Furthermore, it is getting farther and farther away."
Production of lumber in the country totaled 217,913,000 board feet in the week ended Sept. 1, according to reports received yesterday from regional lumber associations.

CHEROKEE, N.C., Sept. 7 A Senate investigation has found that some states, having assumed civil and criminal jurisdiction over Indian reservations in recent years, are failing to provide equal protection of the law there.
SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Sept. 7 (AP) Edmund Lamy, former national outdoor speed skating champion, died last night in Saranac Lake General Hospital. He was 72 years old.
Despite record sales, earnings of the International Salt Company in the fiscal year ended June 30 declined from those of the year before, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
NEWARK, Sept. 7 (AP) Two North Jersey metropolitan areas rank among the ten highest in family income in the United States, according to statistics of the Federal Census Bureau.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 7 Government and financial circles here have greeted the tentative international coffee agreement with satisfaction if not elation. A meeting is scheduled Sept. 28 at the United Nations for a final vote on the accord, which sets export quotas for coffee producing nations and establishes a council of producing and consuming nations to adjustable for export and only 45,000,000 are wanted by purchasing nations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman replied tonight to a charge by Senator Jacob K. Javits that President Kennedy had shown inept leadership. He flung a similar charge at the New York Republican.
A bakers' union filed a $30,000,000 damage suit yesterday in Federal Court against the Ward Baking Company because the company transferred its bread-baking from its Bronx plant to Newark.
ARDMORE, Okla., Sept. 7 (AP) Opie Turner, the wife of the millionaire oilman who has sponsored several major, golf tournaments, died today at a hospital here.

Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' Affectionately, a winner of nine of her ten starts including six stakes races, was the overnight favorite at even money in a field of ten 2-year-old fillies entered for today's Matron Stakes at Aqueduct.
A SMALL, but excellent exhibition at the Kennedy Galleries, 13 East Fiftyeighth Street, demonstrates the various techniques used to reproduce prints.
Interoffice memorandums can have greater weight on a regulatory hearing than oral testimony offered by a steamship company's top officials, the Federal Maritime Commission has decided.
SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 7 (AP) Lenny Bruce, American comedian, opened at the Aarons Hotel last night and closed this morning.
Mohawk Airlines has reported a net profit of $44,772 for July, usually an unprofitable month for the regoinal carrier.

On the theory that one head man was better than two, the New York Rangers handed the coaching portfolio to Muzz Patrick yesterday. He has been the National Hockey League club's general manager for the past seven seasons and will continue in that capacity.
An upsurge in capital offerings is expected next week, ending the summer lull. Six major offerings totaling $164,600,000 are expected to reach the market.

Received courtesy call from former President of Colombia Alberto Lleras Camargo; asked Congress for authority to order up to 150,000 Ready Reservists to active duty; signed bill giving 2,000,000 disabled veterans an average 9.4 per cent increase in compensation; flew to Newport, R.I., for week-end.

New York City Democratic leaders began polling delegates to the party's forthcoming state convention yesterday on their preference for a candidate for Governor. The prospect was strong that the choice could turn on what the 185member Brooklyn delegation does.

HAMBURG, Germany, Sept. 7--President de Gaulle proposed today "organic cooperation" between the armies of France and West Germany as part of his program to make the two countries the nucleus for a larger European union.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 7 A Federal judge indicated today that he would issue an order declaring that Prince Edward County could not close its public schools to avoid integration while other public schools in the state were kept open.
GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 7 The Misses Gail Greenleaf, Suzanne Angevine Fox, Sara Hadley Devens and Elizabeth Mallory Hite were presented at parties here today.

BEDFORD, N.Y., Sept. 7 Mr. and Mrs. James E. Robison of Windmill Farm in Armonk, and Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Springs Jr. of Mount Kisco, gave a dance this evening at the Bedford Golf and Tennis Club in honor of Miss Martha Ann Robison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robison, and Miss Clare Harding Springs, daughter of Mr. Springs and the late Mrs. Clare Weber Springs.
Ramon Piedra, a former member of the Latin-American staff of United Press International here, died of a hear attack Thursday at his home. He was 61 years old.

Thirteen pre-election reports dealing with contests for Governorships, the House of Representatives and the United States Senate will be televised on the National Broadcasting Company's "Today" program, starting Wednesday morning.

DENVER, Sept. 7 (UPI) Frank Tripucka treated the largest crowd in Denver's professional football history to a dazzling passing display tonight as the Denver Broncos upset the San Diego Chargers, 30 21, in the first game of the 1962 American Football League season.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP) The butcher-hog market managed to equal its high of the year today with the sale of 20 head at $20 a hundred pounds.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 The Department of Health, Education and Welfare overruled the Public Health Service today and ordered a report on Government and private support of birthcontrol research made public.

The American Merchant Marine Conference, sponsored by the Propeller Club of the United States, will be held Oct. 3, 4 and 5 in Seattle, Wash., in conjunction with the club's thirtysixth annual convention.
ALBANY, Sept. 7 The State Education Department conceded today that summer-school Regents tests in five subjects had been unfairly difficult.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 Republican leaders proposed today that Congress authorize President Kennedy to use United States troops if necessary to defeat Cuban communism.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 7 "It looks as if we did the right thing with Gretel," said Alan Payne, the designer of Australia's America's Cup challenger, after routine practice on Rhode Island Sound today.

Church World Service appealed to the nation's Protestant and Eastern Orthodox churches yesterday for an initial $20,000 to speed aid to victims of last Saturday's earthquake in Iran. The dead and injured have been estimated at 20,000 persons.
A bank robber fled from a bank yesterday morning with what he thought was thousands of dollars. What he really had was an attache case full of bank forms worthless to him.
"PSYCOSISSIMO," which opened at the Norman die yesterday, bears witness to the fact that the Italians can make as cheap and poor a comedy as anyone.
