MONTICELLO, N.Y., Sept. 7 (AP) Mayor Wagner of New York, addressing a union convention tonight, called for a higher minimum wage and a "truly color-blind" economic opportunity for all people.

Now that there is hope for a solution of the Congo problem on the basis of a United Nations plan backed by the United States, Britain and Belgium, the Soviet Government is with some signs of panic attempting to throw a monkey wrench into the delicate operation. It denounces the plan as another "colonialist" conspiracy and advances a plan of its own to start the conflict all over main with United Nations troops.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 The rail industry reported today that last week's freight movements were down from the previous week and the corresponding week of 1961.

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 7 George Lawrence Smith, a retired Boston architect, died yesterday at Carolton Hospital in Fairfield at the age of 88. He had lived here with his son-inlaw and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. James Kinnear Gussow, since the death in 1956 of his wife, Mrs. Mary Blake Smith.
A passing train or construction work are sure to draw the attention of even the most hurried pedestrian. Combine the two and the effect is almost hypnotic on New Yorkers.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 7 (AP) Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy and the sponsors of a dinner for the Democratic candidate for Governor of Wisconsin differed sharply today over the stated purposes of the event.

The Public Service Company of Colorado announced yesterday that it is was issuing its stockholders rights to subscribe to 1,242,822 common shares at $23.50 each. The subscription will be on the basis of 1 new share for each 10 held of record of Sept. 6. The offer will expire on Sept. 24.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 7 Argentina's admirals and generals cannot agree on politics, but are trying to set a tough economic line for President Jose Maria Guido.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 That old, derisive exhortation "Get a horse" has become a most valuable bit of economic counsel now in the midst of the automotive age. For example tomorrow a 2-year-old horse can pick up $142,250 by winning one race the ArlingtonWashington Futurity at Arlington Park.
LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, Sept. 7 Premier Cyrille Adoula warned Portugal today that any violations of the Congo's frontiers or air space would be met by force.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 7--One day last week a motorist was giving a lift to a high-ranking diplomat when a Congolese traffic officer called their car to a halt for not stopping at a traffic light.
MOSCOW, Sept. 7 Stewart L. Udall, Secretary of the Interior, said today that Premier Khrushchev had challenged the United States to an "energy race."
CINCINNATI, Sept. 7 (AP) Vada Pinson doubled in the deciding run in the eleventh inning tonight, giving the Cincinnati Reds a 6-5 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

GLADWYNE, Pa., Sept. 7 Miss Rosemary Ranck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Richard Ranck, was married this afternoon to John Morton McIlvain, son of Mrs. George M. Cheston of Wynnewood and the late Edward M. McIlvain of New York.
DENVER, Sept. 7 (AP) Rex Baxter Jr. shot a par 70 today to preserve his lead in the $35,000 Denver open golf tournament with a two-round total of 134.

Stockholders of Skyline Homes, Inc., paved the way for a two-for-one stock split yesterday by voting an increase in authorized shares.

George Martin Hopkinson, retired assistant to the vice president in charge of operations of Rockefeller Center died yesterday in his home at 34-32 Thirtyfourth Street, Astoria, Queens. His age was 79.

Cotton futures were 50 cents up to a $1.65 a bale off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 The effects of the strike by the National Farmers Organization may be leveling off.

EASTON, Pa., Sept. 7 Lafayette didn't have a happy football season in 1981. The Leopards played more good good games than bad, getting their spots knocked off only by Delaware and Rutgers. But though they were highly competitive in other contests, they wound up their nine-game schedule with only two victories and a tie.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 7 John Motley Morehead, a 92-year-old engineering executive of the Union Carbide Corporation, will provide a $500,000 city hall of colonial design for this suburban community of 14,225 residents.
The Military Sea Transportation Service is offering the stern section of a burned-out tanker as partial payment for a long-term charter contract.
HAMILTON, N.Y., Sept. 7 Harold Lahar's return to the head football coaching job at Colgate means that the Red Raiders once again will stress defense.
TORRANYARD, Scotland, Sept. 7 The bulk of one of the biggest and most comprehensive collections of vintage cars in the world was sold at auction today in the Ayrshire countryside of Scotland.
THE American Ballet Theatre was in high spirits last night for the first of its two appearances in the Rebekah Harkness Foundation Dance Festival at the Delacorte Theatre in Central Park.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 7-- Britain recently sounded out the Soviet Union on an idea for clearing what the Russians have made the biggest hurdle to a Berlin settlement.

TWO more high-fashion models have recently been turned into actresses, a switch that is not rare in entertainment circles. Movie and theatrical moguls have a way of discovering what they hope will be talent to match the good looks they find in the pages of women's magazines or on the runways of fashion salons here and abroad.

A teamster strike that had cut off warehouse deliveries to A. P. and Gristede Bros. food stores since last Saturday was called off yesterday when the strikers voted to accept a temporary contract formula.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) A bill to appropriate $1,350,501,000 for construction of military facilities in the United States and abroad during the year that began July 1 was passed by the Senate today by voice vote.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UPI) The Eighth Armored Division Association honored Secretary of State Dean Rusk today as the American who "contributed the most toward the cause of peace" last year.
LONDON, Sept. 7 An attempt to bring the arts to Britain's masses will begin Sunday in the halls, schools and movies of Wellingborough, an industrial town seventy miles north of here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 Morris Louis Bernstein, an abstract expressionist painter, died here today of lung cancer in his home here. He was 49 years old.

The Alleghany Corporation, a large holding company controlled by the Murchison interests of Dallas, Tex., has taken its biggest investment action since the Murchisons won control of the company from Allan P. Kirby in May, 1961.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Sept. 7 (AP) Textile industry leaders were unanimous today in their criticism of a ruling by the Tariff Commission that eliminated any further restrictions on cotton imports.

The hundredth anniversary of the Jewish military chaplaincy will be marked tomorrow in a program at the post chapel of Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn.

The President's sudden and surprising request to Congress yesterday to authorize the call-up of 150,000 Reservists is apparently a considered though belated reflection of what the White House called "the critical nature of the international situation."

STONY BROOK, L.I. Sept. 7 Sutton Place, a 6-year-old gray gelding from the Annex, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas N. Lavery of Keswick, Va., won three blue ribbons today, the second day of the twenty-ninth annual North Shore horse show at the old Field Club.

Thousands of pets ranging from rare tropical fish to a nervous ocelot were on hand yesterday for the trade show opening of the National Association of the Pet Industry, Inc., at the New York Trade Building, Eighth Avenue and Thirtyfifth Street.
The construction of what is said to be the largest oceangoing barge for the transport of loaded truck trailers ever built in this country was announced here yesterday by McAllister Brothers, Inc.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Sept. 7 (AP) An overemphasis on cure rather than prevention is blocking a reduction in the number of alcoholics in the United States, the president of the National Women's Christian Temperance Union said today.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., Sept. 7 (UPI) An insurance company asked the United States District Court today to deny payment to the widow of a policyholder suspected of bombing a Continental Airlines 707 jetliner last May. Forty-five persons were killed.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 7 Nowadays and nights trotters race a mile a half minute or so faster than Lady Suffolk did more than 100 years ago.
Mayor Wagner swore in sixteen members of the New York City Council on Port Development and Promotion at a City Hall ceremony yesterday.
Directors of the Virginia Carolina Chemical Corporation yesterday sweetened a controversial recapitalization plan by declaring a dividend of $6 on its 6 per cent cumulative, $100 par preferred stock.

ON thirty-two occasions, a tall, bulky man with a mustache has entered the marble halls of the Supreme Court in quest of rulings to change the status of Negroes in the United States. Twentynine times he has come out with victories.
Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation is clearing the way for an entry into the European Common Market with plans for an aluminum fabricating plant in West Germany.
If it seemed nine degrees cooler than the normal mean temperature yesterday, don't blame faulty insulation. It was exactly that.
A burglary suspect who preyed upon churches was captured early yesterday after he tried to break into the St. Patrick's Cathedral rectory.

Eastern railroads asked the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday for a 10 per cent increase in passenger fares effective Nov. 15 to coincide with the expiration of the 10 per cent Federal transportation tax. The charge to customers, however, would be unchanged.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 7 (Reuters)--Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd's office announced tonight a Government decision to appoint a commission to investigate a five-year plan for the development of nonwhites in South-West Africa.
MOSCOW, Sept. 7--The Soviet Union announced today that its armed forces would be reduced by an undisclosed number of men.

The appointment of Rene Costa de Beauregard as manager of the eastern region of the North American, Central American and Caribbean division of Air France was announced yesterday by Henri J. Lesieur, general manager of the division.
Louisiana has announced that it will seek competitive bids Oct. 10 for a $20,000,000 bond offering. The issue, by the state's fiscal authority, will provide funds for teachers' salaries.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 7--The United States was reported today to be ready to counter with its own complaints it the Soviet Union moved to bring up in the United Nations its accusation that a U-2 plane flew over Sakhalin Island a week ago.

GENEVA, Sept. 7 (AP) The seventeen-nation disarmament conference adopted a "no progress" report to the United Nations General Assembly today and then recessed until Nov. 12. The United States and the Soviet Union are deadlocked ...
LONDON, Sept. 7 Dr. Robert A. Soblen lay unconscious in a hospital today as his wife arrived here in distress and physicians voiced concern that his heart showed signs of exhaustion.

The New York Yankees, their hand-to-hand conflicts with the Minnesota Twins and Los Angeles Angels behind them, set out last night on what they fervently hope will be a direct drive on the pennant at the expense of what's left of the American League. To the delight of a gathering of 24,855, the start was auspicious.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 The Senate Judiciary Committee today scheduled a public hearing next week for executives of four steel companies who refused to testify to its Antitrust and Monopoly subcommittee.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 7 (UPI) The International Chess Federation Congress ended yesterday with a decision aimed at preventing grand-master draws in international chess matches.

Mme. Vera Sukova, of CzechoSlovakia, a finalist at Wimbledon, and Roy Emerson of Australia and Darlene Hard of Long Beach, Calif., the defending singles titleholders, had to rally yesterday to reach the quarter-finals of the national lawn tennis championships at Forest Hills.

The missing rally was the subject of mind-searching by stock analysts late this week. Just before the long Labor Day week-end many of the market letter writers forecast a postholiday upturn at least a temporary one.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) A committee is beginning a two-month study of the education given the 180,000 children of military personnel who go to school overseas, the Defense Department announced today.
Aerospace Corporation has been awarded a $22,800,000 United States Air Force contract for continued work on missile and space programs.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 7 Jack Nicklaus and Gary Player turned in final rehearsal rounds of 66 over the 7,165-yard, par70 Firestone Country Club today. Arnold Palmer, the other member of a trio that will participate here in a two-day $75,000 World Series of Golf for television, carded a 68.
The E.L. Bruce Company, which was rocked last June by the Edward M. Gilbert scandals, turned over the presidency yesterday to its newest and largest stockholder.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) Government scientists said today that Comdr. Walter M. Schirra Jr. could undertake his planned Mercury orbital flight late this month without fear of harm from the radiation belt left in space by a hydrogen bomb.
PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 7 Gov. Richard J. Hughes outlined a series of changes today in New Jersey's drinking and driving laws designed to combat a rising toll of highway fatalities in the state.
SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Sept. 7 The prospect of a new crisis in Spain's relations with Morocco was believed to have been discussed in a Government meeting today.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 7--Fifty young women were presented tonight at the twenty-fourth Westchester Cotillion in the ballroom of the Shenorock Shore Club. Mrs. John Preston Edmondson, cotillion chairman, headed the receiving line.

Stocks showed more declines than advances although key averages showed a slight advance on average in dull trading. Oil issues and a small list of special situation stocks were strong. Volume, 2,889,560 shares.
PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 7 The New York Football Giants wind up their exhibition season tomorrow in a benefit game with the Philadelphia Eagles in Palmer Stadium on the Princeton University campus.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 7 The Netherlands Parliament approved tonight the Dutch-Indonesian agreement on the future of West New Guinea.

THERE is a veritable wonderland of gastronomy in Manhattan these days. It is the International Food Festival at the New York Coliseum and it opens to the public at 1 P.M. today. The exhibits range from the commonplace to the extraordinary, but a visit to the international supermarket alone would be worth the entrance fee.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 7 (AP) The appearance of Kelso in a prep race for next week's United Nations Handicap and the seventeenth running of the $114,910 World's Playground Stakes share the spotlight tomorrow at the Atlantic City Race Course.

VENICE, Sept. 7 "Bird Man of Alcatraz," the only United States entry at the Venice Film Festival, was awarded the San Gioirgio prize tonight, which is one of several unofficial sideline awards given at the event.
TRENTON, Sept. 7 New Jersey filed a $2,421,580 suit against the United States Government in Superior Court here today.
LONDON, Sept. 7 Prime Minister John Diefenbaker declared today that Canada would do all she could to retain the close ties of the Commonwealth and make certain its trade continued to grow.

A 20-year-old resident of the Bronx was held in $2,000 bail yesterday on charges of voting under another man's name and assaulting two policemen in a polling place. His case will be heard nn next Friday in Bronx Criminal Court.
The world series will open on Wednesday, Oct. 3, in the park of the National League champion, baseball officials agreed yesterday in a meeting here in the office of Commissioner Ford Frick.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP) Safe Mission, a colt who had been reported lame the last three weeks, captured the $37,517 Horseman Futurity for trotters in three heats last night at Washington Park. A.C.'s Viking, the winner of the Hambletonian and the Yonkers Futurity, finished third and seventh.

Shipments of aluminum sheet, plate and foil in July declined from June levels but exceeded July, 1961, shipments, according to the Aluminum Association. Seven-month shipments topped 1961-period totals.
President Kennedy inadvertently cut short a promising stock market rally yesterday.
The Tariff Commission's 3-to-2 vote against imposing new restrictions on cotton imports gives the Administration an opportunity to propose a new nonprotectionist solution to the cotton problem.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) The Army is awarding a contract for $42,500,000 to the Chrysler Corporation plant in Warren, Mich.
LONDON, Sept. 7 The Trades Union Congress, which represents more than 8,000,000 workers, called today for the withdrawal of United States Polaris submarines from their base in Scotland.
LONDON, Sept. 7 Sir Ernest Cooper, who retired in 1958 as chairman of Gillette Industries, Ltd., died at his home here today. He was 85 years old.
A three-month series tracing the history of Swedish films will open next month at the Museum of Modern Art.
General Electric Company scientists announced a new process today that they said might lead to a new way to make industrial diamonds.
Mayor Wagner turned thumbs down yesterday on an offer from Representative Charles A. Buckley of the Bronx to negotiate a truce in their political feud.
Recent economic changes by the Philippine Government are making the Philippines more attractive to foreign investors, according to a report issued by the Chase Manhattan Bank.

An authority on Far Eastern and pre-Columbian art, who also is the general sales manager of a distilling firm, and the chairman of a psychology department at Hofstra College are off Broadway's latest playwriting team.
Nine youths were rounded up by the police in the Bronx yesterday and charged with forging prescriptions on hundreds of physicians' blanks in order to purchase Doriden pills, or "goofballs."

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 7 (AP) Jack Sanford, aided by three San Francisco home runs and needing relief in the eighth, won his fifteenth straight victory tonight as the Giants edged the Chicago Cubs, 6 5.

Two youths were held without bail yesterday in Queens Criminal Court after they allegedly abused three younger boys for more than three hours last Wednesday night. One of the younger boys way in critical condition at Queens General Hospital with a skull fracture.
DETROIT, Sept. 7 (AP) The Minnesota Twins, surging ahead with a run on an obstruction play, continued their mastery of the Detroit Tigers with a 6 4 victory tonight.

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that more business enterprises and increased industrial investments were needed if New York State was to achieve full employment.

PEIPING, Sept. 10 (Reuters) --A leading official of Commu nist China was reported today to have told colleagues that the U-2 reconnaissance plane over China was "brought down by unconventional means."
The withdrawal of "My Fair Lady" was announced again yesterday. This time its departure from the Broadway. Theatre has been scheduled for Sept. 29.

An office-help service that used codes to designate the racial preferences of employers and the race or color of its employes has been barred from continuing the practice, the State Attorney General announced yesterday.
LONDON, Sept. 10--Both British Government securities and industrial shares were irregular in the stock market today.

DETROIT, Sept. 10 (AP)--Overtime work already is showing up as the automobile manufacturers begin their drive to furnish dealers with ample stocks for the 1963 model introductions starting late this month.
Educational television station WNDT (Channel 13) said yesterday its dispute with a TV performers union would not prevent the start of programing on Sunday at 8 P.M. as had been scheduled.

State Supreme Court Justice Francis X. Conlon approved settlement yesterday of a stockholder suit against the Universal American Corporation under which the company will add the Livingston Rock Gravel Company to its list of wholly owned subsidiaries.
Steel production in the Labor Day week declined 1.9 per cent from the levels of the preceding week, the best since mid-May.
An overwhelming majority of New York County's 118 delegates to the Democratic state convention refused to be committed yesterday to any candidate for Governor.

Rodney Laver of Australia achieved the first grand slam in men's tennis since 1938 when he won the national championship yesterday. For the first time, the women's title also went to an Australian player.

FINDING a home of one's own on Manhattan is, for many people, more than a search for shelter. There is the tricky business of balancing what the budget will allow against the going rate of rents and purchase prices of cooperative apartments. There is also the problem of a food address.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP)-- Ed Seltzer's El Bandido won the $57,400 Arlington Park Handicap today.

Guy Lombardo, the orchestra leader, has ended a thirty-three-year association with the Roosevelt Hotel's Grill Room. Mr. Lombardo and his Royal Canadians will open this winter in a new night club called the Port o' Call at a $4,500,000 resort in Tierra Verde, Fla.

Tenants at the Manhattanville housing project have set up a volunteer corps that has been on guard in the lobby of one building from 6 P.M. to 4 A.M. for six nights. A similar vigil started in a second building last night.

SPOKANE, Wash., Sept. 10 -An Air Force jet tanker with forty-four persons aboard crashed into a mountain near here today. Thirtyone bodies had been recovered by nightfall; and the others were presumed dead.

CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 10-- The wildest political scramble in the history of staid old New Hampshire ends tomorrow. In state-wide primaries its two parties will nominate candidates for Governor, both Senate seats and both House seats.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10-- Al Hartnett, secretary-treasurer of the International Union of Electrical Workers, today instructed the five banks at which the union has accounts not to honor union checks unless they bear his personal signature.
MOSCOW, Sept. 10--The Soviet newspaper Pravda expressed the hope today that Robert Frost would be successful in the defense of his ideals of "peaceful coexistence."

MEDFORD, Mass., Sept. 10-- Harry Arlanson, who has been dealing with high school and college football players for thirty years, appears quietly confident his 1962 Tufts University squad will one day be the source of some of his fondest memories.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10-- West Coast baseball fans now are virtually certain there will be a world series here next month.
GENEVA, Sept. 10--The United Arab Republic, Colombia and Nationalist China have applied for membership in an international accord for regulating trade in cotton goods.

Israel's Finance Minister appealed yesterday to the leadership of the United Jewish Appeal for intensified financial support. He said the funds were needed to alleviate the serious housing and social problems that had arisen with the heavy influx of immigration into his country.

ONE of the oldest and bitterest arguments in bridge --a matter of bridge mathematics--was discussed here recently, in the statement of a theory propounded by Stanley Slater, an actuary at the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, who sought to reccile the warring camps.
Does New York City have some things to learn from London about parks? Whitney North Seymour Jr., writing in The New York Times Magazine, thinks it does. So do many other observers.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 10--Foreign Ministers PaulHenri Spaak of Belgium and Joseph M.A.H. Luns of the Netherlands came to the conclusion at a meeting day that no acceptable formula had been found for establishing a European political union.
Protesting parents kept about 450 children out of two public schools yesterday in unrelated disputes over school policies.
Two capital issues of the Tennessee Gas Transmission Corporation totaling $72,500,000 will reach the public today.

Returned from week-end in New England; received Sir Garfield Barwick, Australian Minister of External Affairs; lunched with former President Eisenhower; conferred with Vice President Johnson on the Vice President's recent tour abroad.

ABRAHAM STRAUS has redesigned the third floor of its Brooklyn store to conform to what it hopes will be a smashingly chic image. The new floor, which houses such fashion merchandise as dresses, sportswear, suits and coats, furs, the bridal salon and the Rose Room, is airy, spacious and well-lighted.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10-- The Senate approved and sent to the White House today a bill authorizing $900,000,000 for employment-creating public works projects in depressed areas. The vote was 45 to 22.

Pat Rooney, the nimble softshoe dancer and songwriter, died after a cerebral hemorrhage Sunday night at his apartment in the Sherman Square Hotel. He was 82 years old. In his seventy-second year in show business he still played occasional television, banquet and club dates.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 10--Dr. Albert W. Miller's Sampson's Lady, a 5-year-old mare, scored a length-and-a-quarter victory over Rhythm Mite tonight in the Long Island Association Pace before 18,677 at Roosevelt Raceway.
NEWARK, Sept. 10.--The United States District Court here will hear all claims to the $2,421,580 hoard found in a Jersey City garage last July.
Protesting parents kept about 450 children out of two public schools yesterday in unrelated disputes over school policies.

LONDON, Sept. 11 (UPI)-- Ralph Dupas of New Orleans was disqualified in the sixth round tonight and booed by a sellout crowd of 12,000 for rough tactics against Brian Curvis of Wales at Wembley Arena.
Democratic leadership squabbles in Brooklyn and Queens threatened yesterday to delay Robert M. Morgenthau's nomination for the Governorship at the party's convention in Syracuse next week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- Provisions for "adjustment" benefits to workers injured by competitive imports came under attack today as the Senate Finance Committee resumed work on the Administration's foreign trade bill.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People charged employment discrimination against Negroes today to five concerns that do business with the Government and to two Army installations.
HAVANA, Sept. 11 (AP)-- A bristling defensive ring now surrounds Havana, following the bolstering of Cuba's military arm against what Government officials term "Yankee aggressive tactics."

Justice Arthur G. Klein of State Supreme Court refused yesterday to put the Bon Ami Company in the hands of a receiver while the court heard charges that its chairman and other officials had embezzled at least $500,000 in company funds.

WASHINGTON, Sept.11 (AP) --A 30-year-old Brooklyn salesman who has served as a Government informant within the Communist party pointed out William Albertson today as one who had a big voice in party affairs in New York.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- Rising wages and prices in most industrial, non-Communist nations outside the United States are giving this country a new and unsought advantage in this friendly but competitive world Community.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP)--The White House made public late today a fact-finding board report recommending the union shop for four major aerospace producers, subject to ratifying votes among the companies' 100,000 workers.

Communist-bloc periodicals have reported that a new international bank and genuine competition among Communist producers are two of the projects being worked on to further the economic integration of the members of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance, commonly known as Comecon.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- The Delaware Hudson Railroad lost its bid today for inclusion in the large Eastern railroad system formulated by the Norfolk Western Railway.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- The United States hopes to conclude nuclear testing in the atmosphere in sixty days. However, in the absence of a test ban treaty it plans to continue underground testing indefinitely.
Jack Soble, the brother of Dr. Robert A. Soblen, who died yesterday in London, was released from Federal Prison in Danbury, Conn., on Aug. 31.
DETROIT, Sept. 12--The Yankees cut some tall and fancy capers tonight before they finally beat the Tigers, 8--7, in a ten-inning struggle that ended the season series between the clubs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- Those who have wished the United States' refugee policy to be more liberal have publicly applauded the selection of Abba Philip Schwartz as chief of the State Department's Bureau of Security and Consular Affairs.

WARRENTON, Va., Sept. 11 --The board of the Fauquier Hospital Maternity Clinic, which performs sterilizations for Women who request it, reported unanimous support today by clinic members and medical personnel.

ALBANY, Sept. 11--Governor Rockefeller, who will be renominated for a second term at the Republican State Convention next week, left the door open today for debates with his Democratic opponent, Robert M. Morgenthau.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 11 --Top United States military authorities were said today to have described the campaign here against Communist guerrillas with "cautious optimism" to Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor.
SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 11 --Utah's voters today picked the least conservative Republicans to run against the most liberal Democrats in the slates offered to them in a primary election.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 11-- The Allies in West Berlin have been unable to get the Russians in East Berlin to accept a letter suggesting that the time has come to stop using armored vehicles to change the guard at the Soviet War Memorial.

BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Sept. 11 (AP)--Glenn Leasher, who drove a jet-powered racer to his death yesterday, probably was traveling at more than 400 miles per hour-- the goal he had hoped to achieve.

A year ago at this time Madison Avenue was treated to a curious spectacle. The once prim and reserved women's magazine field suddenly discarded its inhibitions and engaged in a lively hair-pulling contest.

A VISITOR from Pennsylvania was East in this deal, which he played at home, and was justly proud of the way he played the defense. The same layout of cards, or the equivalent, may be found in many bridge books, but this should not detract from interest in the deal because it occurs so often.
The television artists union denied yesterday that it was demanding money for teachers assigned to the new educational station by the Board of Education.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11 (AP)--Jack Sanford posted his sixteenth straight pitching victory and twenty-second for the season today by blanking Pittsburgh, 2--0. The triumph was the seventh straight for the pennant-contending San Francisco Giants.
THE Museum of Modern Art opens its 1962-63 sea son today with an exhibition of 135 paintings by the American artist Mark Tobey. As the master of a new linear,...

Supporters of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts expressed dismay yesterday upon learning that neither the President nor Mrs. Kennedy could attend the opening of Philharmonic Hall on Sept. 23.
PARIS, Sept. 11--The first step toward organizing possible European governmental participation in long-term development aid for Latin America will be taken here Thursday.
Operation of the Avnet Electronics Corporation in the fiscal year ended June 30 resulted in record sales and earnings, the report of Lester Avnet, president, disclosed yesterday.
The death of Dr. Robert A. Soblen ended a strange saga of betrayal.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 11-- Senator Carl Hayden, the dean of Capitol Hill, easily won the Democratic nomination today for his seventh term. His opponent in the November general election will be Evan Mecham, an ultra-conservative Republican.
CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 11-- Gov. Wesley J. Powell, who had hardly concealed his ambition for a place on a Republican national ticket, was upset today in the New Hampshire primary.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 11 (AP)--Two right-handers, Eli Grba and Don Lee, combined to pitch the Los Angeles Angels into second place today with a 9-0 victory over the Minnesota Twins. It was the Angels' second straight shutout over the Twins, who dropped into third place in the American League.
Cotton futures were unchanged to 55 cents a bale up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
"Bravo Giovanni," which resumed its stand at the Broadhurst on Friday night with Cesare Siepi starred, will be taken off after the eleventh performance on Saturday night.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 11-- The Australian America's Cup challenger Gretel had a boom sheared off at sea as though sliced by a buzz saw during her drill with Vim today. No one was injured in the mishap.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) --Per Jacobsson, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said today that it was time to worry less about the outflow of United States gold and worry more about possible world-wide deflation.
OTTAWA, Sept. 11 (Canadian Press)--Freedom for commercial bank lending rates was favored today by Dr. Marius W. Holtrop, governor of the Netherlands Central Bank.
Majestic Specialties, Inc., producer of sportswear apparel for women, is adding a junior line of sportswear through the purchase of a group of companies operating as Kelita, Inc.

One basic indicator of business conditions is the number of business failures. In any active economy, new businesses are always beginning, and old or tired businesses dropping out. Those where loss to creditors appears possible are called business failures.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Sept. 11 (UPI)--Unbeaten Eder Jofre of Sao Paulo retained his world bantamweight championship tonight by knocking out Jos Medel of Mexico in the sixth round of their scheduled fifteenround return bout at Ibirapuera Stadium.

The Maremont Corporation, which offered on Monday to acquire an additional 100,000 shares of the Gabriel Company at $23 a share, yesterday announced plans to support the Gabriel tender by selling more Maremont stock to the public.
LANSING, Mich., Sept. 11-- Oldsmobile has abdicated as the king of chrome. It has shifted to a sleek, sculptured, conservative look for 1963.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 11 --A general strike Friday was called today by the Leftist workers' leadership in support of a national plebiscite on Brazil's parliamentary system.
The chairman of the State Board of Social Welfare defended both the recipients of public welfare and the state's welfare system yesterday at a state inquiry.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- The Senate overwhelmingly confirmed today the nomination of Thurgood Marshall to a Federal judgeship on the Second Circuit Court of Appeals.

LONDON, Sept. 11--Dr. Robert A. Soblen died this morning in a suburban hospital from effects of the overdose of drugs he took five days ago. The convicted spy fled... the United States in June to avoid serving a life sentence for Soviet espionage.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 11 (AP)--Gov. John A. Notte Jr. was renominated tonight in a close Democratic primary.
Two museum exhibitions herald the opening of the art season as galleries begin unlocking their doors after the summer respite.
Stocks scored a small gain yesterday as trading quickened. There was no great rush to buy, however, and most individual gains were limited.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 11--At treasure-trove of ancient Celtic silverware was given to the Crown yesterday in a decision that extended the law of Scotland further into the realm of traditional Norse law in the Shetland Islands.
More than a half dozen prominent New Yorkers are under active consideration in high Democratic circles for the race against Senator Jacob K. Javits in this year's state election.
A seven-year experiment in air-conditioned subway riding has come to an unsuccessful end.
About 550 public school pupils were kept out of class yesterday by their parents to protest school policies. One boycott was in the Bronx, the other in Queens.

President Kennedy and his brother, Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy, are the subjects of profiles planned for publication four days apart. Little, Brown has scheduled for Sept. 27 "Portrait of a President: John F. Kennedy in Profile," by William Manchester, which discusses the President and his actions from April, 1961 to April, 1962.
Harlem Hospital's executive medical board was ousted yesterday after it had refused to approve the nomination of a Canadian physician to direct the hospital's Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology.

STRATFORD-ON-AVON, England, Sept. 11--The gap in the Royal Shakespeare Company's season at Stratford-on-Avon, caused by the postponement of Paul Schofield's "King Lear," has been filled by a production of "A Comedy of Errors" at the Shakespeare Theatre.

ALBANY, Sept. 11--The state Republican organization started its drive to retain control of the Legislature today with a strategy session attended by all but a few of the 208 candidates for the Senate and the Assembly.

DEL MAR, Calif., Sept, 11 (UPI)--Slipped Disc, the favorite, scored an easy victory today in the fifteenth running of the $84,615 Del Mar Futurity for 2-year-olds, taking the lead early in the backstretch and holding it to the finish.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 11 --Jewish leaders who regard the anti-Semitic wave that erupted in 1961 as the gravest in Argentina's history say the Roman Catholic Church, the military and the police must share the blame.

This year is the centennial of the death of Henry David Thoreau, and on a late summer afternoon his Walden Pond at Concord, Mass., lay quiet and peaceful. A hundred yards or so up a bank on the northeast shore...

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 11-- Maury Wills stole his 90th base, scored one run and drove in another tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Chicago Cubs, 3--1, and kept on top in the National League race.
KURDS' HEADQUARTERS, Somewhere in Northern Iraq, Aug. 24--Guerrilla fighting comes naturally to the Kurds.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- United States defense officials believe that too many industrial companies are trying to get into the glamorous space weapons business while neglecting less highlighted, but perhaps more immediate, weapons requirements.
AMHERST, Mass., Sept. 11-- When Vic Fusia became University of Massachusetts football coach last year, he was confident that his initial venture as head man would be successful.
SINCE coin-operated dry-cleaning centers opened in New York one year ago, many unexpected customers have been attracted to this new service.

The New Yorker Theatre, a leader among unconventional revival houses for more than two years, will introduce an unusual first-run policy early next month with the American premiere of Orson Welles' sevenyear-old film "Arkadin."

Five hundred residents of International House were vaccinated here early today after a student from East Africa was taken ill with what was feared to be smallpox. Later the illness was said to be "probably chicken pox."
SPOKANE, Wash., Sept. 11 (UPI)--The Air Force said today it had recovered the bodies of all forty-four men who died in the crash of a jet tanker near here Monday.

ALGIERS, Sept. 11--Ahmed Ben Bella, leader of the Political Bureau, which is the de facto Government of Algeria, asserted today that the bureau would continue to function after the establishment of a regular Government.

The Soviet Government has stated more than once that, carrying through a policy of peaceful coexistence with all countries irrespective of their socio-political order, it has exerted and does exert all efforts to safeguard peace for all the peoples of the world, to secure agreement on general and complete disarmament under strict international control.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- Taxpayers claiming refunds on their Federal income taxes next year will be offered a choice of savings bonds or cash.
WHAT is a great romance? To my mind it is a love story that can enthrall the imaginations of many people and that continues to do so for generations.
How the demands of the American housewife have revolutionized the preparation of foods by processors was described yesterday to more than 1,500 food industry leaders-- 600 of whom were from abroad.

HOUSTON, Sept. 11--The Protestant clergy of this predominantly Protestant and deeply conservative city report a fundamental change of feeling about the presence of a Roman Catholic in the White House.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI)--The Navy said today that it was investigating a case involving a former Navy official now employed by an organization that holds a $2,427,000 defense contract.
LONDON, Sept. 11--Visitors to the home of Abraham Lincoln's English ancestors have been paying homage at the wrong site, the National Trust said today.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Sept. 11-- A whistling southwesterly wind that blew in gusts of more than thirty knots provided a test of seamanship for contestants in the Middle Atlantic Star Class championships today on Long Island Sound.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 11 --A drastically revised model for the National Cultural Center in Washington was unveiled today by Mrs. John F. Kennedy.

NEWARK, Sept. 11--The representatives of three Newark building trade unions testified before the United States Commission on Civil Rights here today that there was almost a total absence of Negroes on their membership rolls.
ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 11-- When Cornell staged its first formal scrimmage of the year a week ago, coach Tom Harp was dismayed at the inexperience of his team.
E. Barry Ryan's 3-year-old filly Firm Policy is the evenmoney overnight favorite and the high weight under 125 pounds for today's mile-and-oneeighth Gazelle Handicap at Aqueduct.

Manufacturers of women's coats and suits here will be told by an industry association today that leading department and specialty stores across the nation are enjoying a banner fall season in coat and suit activity.

THE Ballet Folklorico of Mexico made its New York debut at the City Center last night. The company is not balletic, in the classical sense of the term, and some of its adaptations of folk dances come perilously close to music-hall type routines, but its big music-and-dance show offers much that is beautiful and interesting.

New York's organized labor movement reshuffled its top command yesterday.
ALBANY, Sept. 11 (AP)-- The State of New York made a claim today on the Finger Lakes race track for $354,201 in delinquent taxes and penalties.

MIAMI, Sept. 11 (UPI)-- Premier Fidel Castro declared early today that Congressional demands for energetic United States action against his regime were proof of "chaos" in the United States, which, he said, is "playing with fire and with war."
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 11-- A home-bred pacing colt with the unlikely name of Pocomoonshine won the $8,700 New York Sire Stakes No. 2 by a diminishing length at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP)--Arthur J. Goldberg was greeted by many bouquets and a single brickbat today as he pledged to serve fairly and without bias as a Supreme Court Justice.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- Higher profits, higher personal incomes and mixed trends in employment were reported today by Government agencies.

Bonds were mixed yesterday. The Treasury market was active and up slightly. Corporates moved slowly but showed a little better tone than on Monday. Dealers bid aggressively for new municipal issues but had poor experience in selling them.
With the complete National Hockey League schedule announced yesterday, the New York Rangers are wasting no time. They will open their training camp at Vancouver, B.C., today.
