World sugar and cocoa declined yesterday in moderately active trading. Other commodities traded on the New York exchanges were generally firm and quiet.

Data B, Inc., an electronic processing service, has leased a floor in the sixteen-story building at 404 Park Avenue South, northwest corner of Twenty-eighth Street, through Walter I. Lippman of GallantRoth Co., broker. Datatab will move from 200 Park Avenue South at Seventeenth Street in an expansion made necessary by an increase in system analysis and computer programming for commercial and industrial accounts.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall said today that he had found a "liberalization" of Soviet society.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 11 --The embattled National Farmers Organization opened a new campaign today to make it possible for members to withhold grain from the market.

MOSCOW, Sept. 11--The Soviet Union indicated today that it was prepared to wait until after the United States Congressional elections in November before entering a new round of talks on Berlin and Germany.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (AP)-- Wheat futures came under fairly still selling pressure in late dealings today on the Board of Trade and slumped sharply. Other commodities held within generally narrow ranges of previous closes.
LONDON, Sept. 11--Most industrial shares again were off slightly on the stock market today.
DUBLIN, Sept. 11 (UPI)-- Lord Brabazon, British aviation pioneer, charged today that there was "something rotten in Denmark" in the way the world's airlines were running their business.
An offering of $50,000,000 of Pacific Northwest Bell Telephone Company 40-year debentures will reach the market today through an investment banking group headed by Morgan Stanley Co.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11--Curtis, H. Bingham, president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, indorsed today efforts of the municipal bond sector of the industry to widen the market for municipals. But he urged the municipals dealers to be ready to meet and solve problems that would accompany such growth.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- The Administration and Congress seemed unimpressed today by the Soviet warning that an attack on Cuba could lead to a nuclear war.
Eastern Air Lines long dispute with the flight engineers union enters a new phase tomorrow when the airline begins operation of a full summer passenger schedule without the striking engineers.
PARIS, Sept. 11--Christian Fouchet, former French High Commissioner in Algeria, was brought into the Government today as a "coming man."
One of the most ticklish jobs in town yesterday was performed at the Bronx Zoo when a man manicured the claws of a 420-pound tigress.
Leading Manhattan Democrats predicted yesterday that Representative Charles A. Buckley of the Bronx would dominate the convention that will choose five candidates for the State Supreme Court.
The National Urban League called yesterday for a decade of discrimination in favor of Negro youth to help close the gap left by "300 years of deprivation."

Laboratory for Electronics, Inc., expects to show a profit in the fiscal year ending on April 30, 1963, Henry W. Harding, president, told shareholders yesterday at the annual meeting in Boston. The company is operating profitably in the current fiscal quarter, which ends Oct. 27, Mr. Harding said. In fiscal 1962, Laboratory for Electronics reported a gross income of $61,482,925, and earnings of $102,169, or 8 cents a share.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Sept. 11 --Gov. Edmund G. Brown is setting a fast pace for his challenger, Richard M. Nixon, as they open their big drives toward California's November election.

William Mayger Jr., who spent forty-one years in the international oil sales business, including more than two decades in the Far East, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Lincoln, Mont. He was 71 years old.

Most of the big men on campus at Fordham University yesterday were members of the New York Giants, beginning preparations for their National Football League opener against the Browns in Cleveland Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI)--The Agriculture Department reported today that dry, hot August weather was expected to cut the expected yields of such basic crops as corn, cotton and soybeans.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 11--Frederick Charles Wehman, an engineer who supervised construction of military bases in Africa during World War II, died today of cancer in his sister's home at 275 Winthrop Terrace. He was 64 years old.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Sept. 11 --News has reached here of the death in New Zealand of George Dibbern, who sailed a thirtytwo-foot home-made ketch from his native Germany to the South Seas and back across the Pacific to Vancouver. He was 76 years old.

A good many delegates to the state convention of the Democratic party, to be held next Monday and Tuesday at Syracuse, seem to be having difficulty making up their minds about whom to nominate for Governor.
HOUSTON, Sept. 11--President Kennedy stopped here tonight on his two-day tour of four space installations. He was greeted at International Airport by a crowd estimated at 10,000.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 11--A dinner dance and a supper dance tonight concluded the long list of parties given this "little season" on the North Shore for the young women who will make their formal debuts during the Thanksgiving and Christmas holidays.
Four Protestant Episcopal priests announced here yesterday that they had filed suit in Federal Court against police authorities in Jackson, Miss., for false arrest and deprivation of civil liberties.

According to a letter we print today from Stanley S. Surrey, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, the tax revision bills passed by the Senate and the House are not far removed from the original proposals made by President Kennedy. Mr. Surrey, moreover, denies that the Senate version is any weaker than the House bill.
The City Council passed yesterday Mayor Wagner's bill to establish a minimum wage of $1.25 an hour in private business and industry here. The vote was 24 to 1.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 11--Charlotte De Cozen shot 39, 38--77 today over the par-72 South Course at Westchester Country Club, her home club, and moved into a two-stroke lead for the twenty-ninth women's open golf championship of Fairfield and Westchester Counties.

The mutual funds scored a victory yesterday in Chancery Court at Wilmington, Del. Over the last year, there has been a rash of suits--estimated at about fifty--against the fees that the funds pay to management companies.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 11--The Soviet Union denounced today the United States decision to resume high-altitude nuclear tests over the Pacific.
LONDON, Sept. 11--Leaders of the major Commonwealth countries opened fire today on the terms under which Britain proposes to enter the European Economic Community.
BOSTON, Sept. 11--A team of surgeons spliced four major nerve trunks in the right arm of a teen-age baseball pitcher today at the Massachusetts General Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- A $1,000,000,000 cut in this year's foreign aid funds would constitute "a colossal breach of faith by the United States with the under-developed half of the free world," a high Administration official said today.

HAVANA, Sept. 11--Cuba said today that a "pirate vessel" entered a harbor in north-central Cuba early Monday and fired more than sixty shots into a British freighter and a Cuban ship. No casualties were reported.
HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., Sept. 11--The beacon atop High Tor is in jeopardy once again.

The atomic weapons race between the United States and the Soviet Union promises to reach a new peak of intensity in the weeks immediately ahead. The current Soviet test series is presumably continuing, and now the United States is resuming atmospheric and high altitude nuclear weapons experiments as well. This is a somber turn of events.
THE Bridgehampton (L.I.) course will present its first Double 400, with world championship points at stake for Grand Touring cars, on Saturday and Sunday.
The cornerstone of a building that will provide free facilities for voluntary social agencies here will be laid at noon today on the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and Fortieth Street.
MOSCOW, Sept. 11--The Soviet Union warned today that any attack by the United States on Cuba or upon Soviet ships bound for Cuba would mean war. Moscow implied that it would be a nuclear rocket war.

Pittsburgh, Pa., raised $4,320,000 yesterday on improvement bonds sold to a group headed by the First Boston Corporation. The group bid 100.6699 for a 2 7/8 per cent coupon, setting an interest cost to the city of 2.811 per cent. The bonds were reoffered scaled to yield 1.60 to 3 per cent.

CANNED tuna in recent years has become a staple in many American homes--and for good reason. The cost is relatively economical, A seven-ounce can, yielding two servings, is from 35 to 39 cents. The fish is an excellent source of protein and also contains iron, calcium and Vitamin A.

The only New Yorker in the Monumental Brass Society, William Bright Jones, journeyed with obvious bliss (and a bag of wax) to Brooklyn yesterday, where he heard there was a large chunk of brass worthy of his attention.

OVER the years an aura of inviolability wrapped itself around many baseball records until it had assumed the seem ingly impenetrable qualities of a protective shield. The one the old-timers viewed with the greatest pride, perhaps, was Ty Cobb's sacrosanct mark of ninety-six stolen bases in one season.
PATCHOGUE, L.I., Sept. 11 --Lawrence Delaney, leader of the Huntington Town Democratic organization, won the Suffolk County Democratic leadership last night when his opponent conceded.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 11 (Reuters)--Syria said today it had called for a pan-Arab conference to discuss the Palestine issue in isolation from inter Arab differences, and adopt decisive measures to meet dangers threatened by Israel.

A strike of longshoremen from Maine to Virginia on Sept. 30 was predicted yesterday unless the International Longshoremen's Association agreed to reduce the number of men in a pier gang. The prediction was made by Alexander P. Chopin, chairman of the New York Shipping Association.

LISBON, Portugal, Sept. 11 --Members of the liberal democratic opposition to Portugal's present regime have demanded the dismissal of Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar. He has been Premier since July 5, 1932.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 11--Thomas F. Brown of Sandusky, Ohio, a business executive and former assistant chief of the New York Ordnance District, died today in New Rochelle Hospital. Mr. Brown, who was 79 years old, had suffered a heart attack on Labor Day while visiting friends here.

ROME, Sept. 11--Pope John said tonight the ecumenical or universal council of the Roman Catholic Church would express and promote the yearning of peoples for "a peace that prevents armed conflicts and which should have its roots and its guarantee in the heart of each man."
TOKYO, Sept. 11 (AP)-- Communist China charged that two United States planes flew over its territory today, and issued what it called its 213th warning against such ":provocations."

MOSCOW, Sept. 12--Under such headlines as "Hands Off Cuba," Moscow newspapers published today the statement of the Soviet Government warning of the possibility of nuclear war if the United States molested the island.
Mayor Wagner and former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman formally declared their support of Robert M. Morgenthau yesterday for the Democratic nomination for Governor.
Plans are nearing completion for the eighth annual International Debutante Ball, to be held at the Astor on Dec. 27 for the benefit of the Kidney Disease Foundation of New York.
WHEREVER dog shows are held, one is apt to see Stanley Dangerfield.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Sept. 12-- William Gentzlinger's Vengeance III from the Huntington (L.I.) Bay fleet broke a tie for first place in the Mid-Atlantic Coast Star Class championships today with an easy victory.
Potato futures declined and cottonseed oil advanced in the wake of a Department of Agriculture crop report. Increased turnover produced a generally mixed market in other commodities traded here.

All admirers of orderly due process must respect the unruffled calm with which the New York Republicans are approaching their convention. Ignoring the question: "Is this trip necessary?" the 1,407 delegates and alternates will begin making their way to Buffalo over the week-end.
LET'S pretend it didn't happen. Let's wait until next week to declare the new season open.

Cuban exiles operating from secret Caribbean bases pledged more and bigger attacks yesterday on "belligerent" shipping in the Cuban sea lanes, United Press International reported. The Havana radio, meanwhile, blared new defiance of United States "warmakers."
IF BLACK adopts one of the hypermodern, restrained, temporizing openings, such as the Pirc or Benoni Defense, he must be careful to have the correct routine mapped out.
This is the time of year when the $300,000,000 antifreeze industry normally nails down its advertising plans for the winter months.
LONDON, Sept.12--The leaders of the smaller Commonwealth countries took a milder line today than the larger countries on the question of Britain's membership in the Common Market.
About 200 Master-drawings, many of them involving great names, have been reattributed by leading experts.
Organized labor yesterday denounced recent anti-Semitic outbreaks in Argentina and Uruguay.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 12-- While a single practice race could not possibly provide all the answers, it appeared today that the Australian. America's Cup challenger, Gretel, could beat her trial horse, Vim, any time to windward in moderate airs, but might be slower when the wind was light just off the quarter.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- The United States made strong rebuttal today to three widely discussed ideas for settling world money problems.

Senator Jacob K. Javits announoed yesterday that twelve prominent health authorities would make an independent study of the best way to provide medical care for the aged. He said the study would start with an analysis of objections that killed the Anderson-Javits bill in the Senate, 52 to 48, in July.
NEARLY 39,000,000, boys and girls are enrolled in the nation's public schools this fall, according to the National Education Association.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 11--A surprisingly chill wind, first foretaste of the impending fall, ruffled the trees along the Danube embankment. But up on Castle Hill, the sun shone warmly on the square in front of the Coronation Church.
On its way to Broadway, "The Interpreter," which was recently acquired by Laurence Feldman, will have been revamped at least fifteen times since the drama was first completed in 1958.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 12-- Desegregation of lunch counters at about fifteen drug, department and ten-cent stores here has been carried out with near-perfect efficiency.
Rhode Island borrowed $10,150,000 on six bond issues yesterday.

NEWARK, Sept. 12--"Subtle and sophisticated" discrimination against minorities has developed in New Jersey despite state laws that forbid it, the United States Commission on Civil Rights reported here today.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 12-- Carl Hayden, Arizona's very senior Democratic Senator, will meet Evan Mecham, an ultraconservative Republican less than half his age, in the November general election for United States Senator.
WARRENTON, Va., Sept. 12 --Mrs. M. is a Negro woman old before her years. She has eight children and she works five days a week as a maid to support them.
ATLANTA, Sept. 12--State Senator Carl E. Sanders won nomination today to the governorship by a surprisingly comfortable margin over former Gov. S. Marvin Griffin.

IT must sometimes be hard to be a foreiger being thoughtfully understood by Americans. Those Yankees can do an awful lot for you in the long run. But in the short run they do take up considerable quantities of time and privacy.
The business of selling stock market advice slipped during the market break earlier this year, but lately has shown signs of bouncing back.
Judges' private grumbling over the new, longer court day burst into the open yesterday when Justice Jacob Markowitz vowed to "raise hell" over the rule, imposed Sept. 1.
George B. Chenkin, a detective since 1949 with the Queens County District Attorney's office, died Tuesday of a heart attack at his home, 2665 Grand Concourse, The Bronx. He was 65 years old.

J.P. Stevens Co., Inc. almost doubled its earnings in the nine months ended Aug. 4 over the year-ago period as a result of substantially higher profits made in the first two quarters of the current fiscal year.
"You have built us a fine new stadium, now it's up to us to do the rest." That was Casey Stengel's message to the Borough of Queens yesterday.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 12-- Five designees for the nomination for justices of the State Supreme Court in the new Tenth Judicial District were recommended today by the executive committee of the Nassau County Republican committee.
WASHINGTON, Sept.12 (AP) --The Senate passed a bill to day to increase and clarify the authority of the Civil Aeronau tics Board in investigations of airplane crashes.
GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 12--George Simpson Armstrong, a consulting engineer, died today of a heart ailment in his home at Gilliam Lane, Riverside. His age was 76.
The Treasury's $26,800,000,000 advance refunding offer expired yesterday with indications that it would be a success.
The Board of Education reported yesterday that the city schools lacked about 400 teachers.
When the first American lands on the moon, there is a strong possibility that he will have found his way with the help of handicapped persons in metropolitan New York.
TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 12 (AP)--State Education Commissioner Frederick M. Raubinger named two fact-finding teams today to investigate school segregation issues in Englewood and Orange.

BERLIN, Sept. 12--Soviet sources in East Berlin have indicated that the Russians are ready to comply with the Western Allies' request to stop using armored convoys to take guards to the Soviet memorial in West Berlin.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 12 (UPI)--The Soviet Union's great distance runner, Pytor Bolotnikov, tonight won the 10,000-meter run on the first day of the European track and field championships.
KURDS' HEADQUARTERS, Somewhere in Northern Iraq, Aug. 23--A key question in the Kurdish rebellion against Iraqi rule may be: "How long can the Kurdish women and children stand the bombing?"
BONN, Germany, Sept. 12-- The Cabinet met tonight to try to settle what has become West Germany's major internal political issue--the 1963 budget.

A $10,000 prize for a published manuscript making "the most significant contribution to the advancement of knowledge" will be given annually by the Encyclopaedia Britannica Press, it was announced yesterday by Maurice B. Mitchell, president of Encyclopaedia Britannica, Inc.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 12--Two Katanga province soldiers were reported today to have been killed and others wounded in a clash with United Nations troops from India.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)--N. Battle Hales, Agriculture Department official, stuck to his testimony today that favored treatment helped Billie Sol Estes swing profitable farm aid deals.
The Loral Electronics Corporation will acquire Astrex, Inc., another electronics producer, in an $8,202,656 transaction, it was announced yesterday.
TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 12-- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi is striving to demonstrate to Iranians of Turkish and Kurdish origin his determination to improve their lot.
Dr. Bernard H. Eliasberg, a specialist in anesthesiology, died early yesterday in his sleep in his home at 1150 Park Avenue. He was 76 years old.
The Metropolitan Opera will participate in the world-wide celebration of the 400th birthday of William Shakespeare in 1964, with a two-week postseason series in April and May of that year.
PAMPLONA, Spain, Sept. 11 --A young university in this ancient capital of Navarre is underscoring the importance of Opus Dei in Spain today and its world-wide aspirations.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)--Democratic members of a Senate-House conference committee reached general agreement on a compromise omnibus farm bill today.
Stocks advanced again yesterday and showed the best gain of the month. Trading, however, continued comparatively light.

CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 12 --New Hampshire Republicans planted themselves in the middle of the road yesterday in their state-wide primary. Their colleagues in other states followed a somewhat more conservative path.

The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. decried last night the pace of civil rights progress in the United States. He also said that "no President can be great, or even fit for office, if he attempts to accommodate injustice to maintain his political balance."

PARIS, Sept. 12--The French Minister of Industry has stirred up concern among American business men in France by a sudden attack on two large American corporations that have recently laid off 1,000 workers because of changed business conditions.

Buddy De Franco, a clarinetist who, once seemed destined to take the role in postwar jazz that Benny Goodman held in the pre-war Swing Era, arrived at Basin Street East this week with a quartet he hopes will bring him the broad popular acceptance that has eluded him for the last decade.
IT is a cardinal rule that one does not double a slam simply because he has two aces.
A cry from the heart about police protection has gone to Mayor Wagner from Harry's Grocery and Delicatessen at 176 Albany Avenue in Brooklyn.
Hundreds of enthusiastic supporters greeted Governor Rockefeller and Senator Jacob K. Javits yesterday at the opening of Citizens for RockefellerJavits state headquarters at 60 Vanderbilt Avenue.

A lawyer insisted on being frisked by a patrolman in the criminal part of Supreme Court yesterday, and so confused the patrolman that he missed a halfinch roll of bills simulating twelve packets of heroin that had been found on the lawyer's client.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- The resumption of hearings by a House subcommittee into alleged racial discrimination and other improper practices in New York's garment industry was postponed today for the second time.

J.C. Penney Company realized a 15.7 per cent increase in earnings for the six months ended July 31 on a sales gain of 12.8 per cent over the preceding year's period. The company, which operates 1,684 departme stores, also reported yesterday that its half-year sales were the largest in its 60-year history.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 12--President Kennedy said today that "no nation which expects to be the leader of other nations" can afford to lag in the exploration of space.

ST. GEORGE'S, Grenada, Sept. 12--This small spice-producing island votes tomorrow for a new legislature in an election that probably will kill all hopes for formation of a proposed "Little Eight" federation of British-held Caribbean islands.
The cornerstone of Brotherhood House, which will provide free facilities for 100 voluntary social agencies here, was laid yesterday at the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and Fortieth Street.
PARIS, Sept. 12--The United States has let the leading Western European nations know that it is no longer prepared to "bail out" Latin-American countries so that their European creditors can be paid.

A new orchestra made its debut last night; not in a concert hall, but in a ballroombanquet hall called the Riviera Terrace. The orchestra is the Symphony of Musical Art, and judging from the way it played under its conductor, Vincent La Selva, it should be around for a while.

BALTIMORE, Sept.12 (UPI) --Tom Cheney, a baldish, muchtraveled 27-year-old righthander, set a record of twentyone strikesouts for a game of any duration in pitching the Washington Senators to a 2-1 victory in sixteen innings over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.
BOSTON, Sept. 12--A televised political debate between an older and a younger member of the Somerset Club in a sparsely filled auditorium here last night found opinion divided today as to the winner.

Friends of the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society will meet this fall at two theatre parties. The first will be on Oct. 18 when they will see "The Affair" at Henry Miller's Theatre. On Nov. 20 they will see "Lord Pengo" at the Royale.

Two major Japanese concerns borrowed $41,500,000 in the United States capital market yesterday. The Kokusai Denshin Denwa Company, Ltd., (K.D.D.) Japan's overseas radio and cable company, announced the private placement of $25,000,000 of 15year 6 , per cent notes with the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States and other institutional investors.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--Four steel companies apparently persuaded a majority of the Senate Judiciary Committee today that they should not be held in contempt of Congress for having declined to produce cost data subpoenaed by a subcommittee. The companies appeared before the full committee.

A contract to buy Le Havre in Queens, one of the largest privately constructed middleincome housing developments in the country, has been signed by the Realty Equities Corporation. The property is being sold by the Kay-Marq Consolidated Corporation for about $15,000,000.

JUST as a tea seems thoroughly British, a coffee, ac cording to Mrs. Marianne Gronwall van der Tuuk, is in the best Swedish tradition. The Swedes, she adds, are among the most enthusiastic of the world's coffee drinkers.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 12--Mexico will embark during the next few days into a three-year program of intensive exploration for additional deposits of iron ore and other metallic minerals to satisfy the rising demands of her expanding steel industry.
MIDLAND, Mich., Sept. 12 (AP)--The 40-year-old grandson of the founder of the Dow Chemical Company became president of the company today, succeeding his father, Dr. Leland I. Doan, 67.
Leaders of the world's food industry were urged yesterday to endeavor to make food cheaper and more abundant to all peoples.

WASHINGTON, Sept.12--The big news all over America this week is the outbreak of peace. After nearly three months of hostilities which took a fearful toll in human patience and broke many a mother's spirit, the kids are back in school.

PITTSBURGH, Sep. 12--The University of Pittsburgh will open another tough football schedule Saturday at Pitt Stadium against the University of Miami. It will be the first of this year's nationally televised college games of the week.
Union and industry spokesmen expressed little hope last night of averting a city-wide strike of truck drivers Monday morning.
The Superintendent of Banks approved merger plans of County Trust Company of White Plains and Gramatan National Bank and Trust Company of Bronxville yesterday.

The Savannah, the world's first nuclear-powered cargopassenger liner, which, was immobilized for nearly two weeks last month by union strikes, is scheduled to begin her first voyage to the West Coast today.

The wooing of the small saver is proving a costly flirtation, particularly for the nation's commercial banks. There are indications that many would be ready to drop the interest rate paid on savings accounts, except for the competition.

Three steel companies and two executives asked permission in Federal Court yesterday to plead no contest on Monday to an antitrust indictment charging a conspiracy to fix prices in the sale of open die steel forgings.
A pilot survey to see if the number of job vacancies in the nation may be determined statistically is being prepared by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor.
Following is President Kennedy's speech at Rice University in Houston yesterday, furnished by station KPRC, Houston, and recorded by The New York Times:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- President Kennedy appealed today for bipartisan support in the House of Representatives for legislation authorizing a $100,000,000 loan to the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- Three Republican Senators initiated a move in Congress today to write a military warning on Cuba into the Administration's reserve mobilization bill.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- A decline in reliance on Federal programs in the field of municipal finance and a consequent increase in public financing by states were foreseen today by a leading New York bond attorney.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 12-- Congress sent to President Adolfo Lopez Mateos today a Constitutional amendment giving the Government power to force both Mexican and foreign concerns to share their profits with workers. The President was expected to approve it.
BELTSVILLE, Md., Sept. 12 --Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman and his Soviet counterpart traded old sayings today in apparent agreement that farmers were underpaid for for their efforts.
Nearly every member of the New York Giants qualified as a man in motion yesterday during a workout at Jack Coffey Field on the Fordham University campus in the Bronx.
MOSCOW, Sept. 12--The Soviet Government announced today the rehabilitation of the reputation of a Czarist general of World War I whose record had been removed from Soviet history books under Stalin.

DONCASTER, England, Sept. 12 (UPI)--Hethersett, a colt that fell while running as the favorite in the Epsom Derby, romped home a fourlength winner today in the St. Leger Stakes, the fifth and last of Britain's racing classics.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 12 --The Doctors--of Philosophy and Medicine--again have complicated Coach John McLaughry's difficult task of mending Brown's shaggy football fortunes.
Reporters and correspondents of The New York Times will be heard three times a week in a new regular series on radio station WQXR starting Oct. 1.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 12-- Nationalist China indicated in its press today that it wanted to continue U-2 flights over the Chinese mainland and would ask the United States to approve the purchase of a new plane to replace the one downed Sunday by the Chinese Communists.

UMSASKIS LAKE, Me., Sept. 12--Zeke Dwelley, who has just retired as winter sports director of Edward Little High School in Auburn, has been leading a dozen devotees of the outdoors on a canoe trip through this remote Allagash country for the past week. And he has been disappointed.
Four boys firing rifles from the roof of a lower East Side tenement shot a man in the back yesterday afternoon as he approached the Manhattan end of the Williamsburg Bridge pedestrian walk.
LONDON, Sept. 12--Did William Shakespeare write all those plays?
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12 (UPI)--Orlando Pena, who shut out the Los Angeles Angels the last time he faced them, pitched the Kansas City Athletics to a 4-1 victory over them on four hits tonight.
For the second time young Cuban exiles have shot up chosen targets on the Cuban coast with reckless disregard of the consequences for the United States and for their own cause.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--For some time now, beginning with the indispensable United States support of the U.N. military offensive against Katanga as required to preserve international peace, a certain phrase has been reiterated by officials of the Kennedy Administration with an air of confidence that the words justify every foreign policy which has been under strong critical fire.

GENEVA, Sept. 12--All nineteen members of the Cotton Textiles Committee of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade are expected to join an international accord for regulating trade in cotton goods.

HARTFORD, Sept. 12--Eleven corporations and seven of their officials were indicted today by a special Federal grand jury on charges of conspiring to fix and stabilize prices in the sale of copper and brass tube and pipe throughout the United States from 1956 to 1961.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)--One of President Kennedy's closet advisers is urging that Vice Admiral H.G. Rickover be named Commissioner of Education. The admiral has sharply criticized American schools.

New York stores are introducing their collections of copies and adaptations of Paris fall fashions. A selection of the best copies will be illustrated when the majority of clothes are in the stores, later this month.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 12-- Spokesmen for the pesticide industry and the Government disputed today a book's contention that pesticides seriously threaten life on earth.

BUON ENAO, Vietnam, Sept. 12--Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, was given a glowing report today on the success of United States Special Forces in training and using the montagnards against the Vietcong.
Joseph McD. Mitchell, the City Manager of Newburgh, N.Y., told the state's Moreland Commission on Welfare here yesterday that home rule for localities was imperative.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 5.

CONCORD, N.H., Sept.12 --When the New Hampshire House of Representatives passed an anti-discrimination bill last year, representatives of resort interests set out to kill it in the Senate. They attached an amendment that would have made its provisions apply to private housing ...

Following are statements issued yesterday by Mayor Wagner and former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman in support of former United states Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau for the Democratic nomination for Governor:
VANCOUVER, B.C., Sept. 12 (Canadian Press)--Doug Harvey, Gump Worsley and Bert Olmstead were missing today when the New York Rangers opened training for the 1962-63 National Hockey League season.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 12--By some quirk of a queer seasonlong schedule, the Yankees arrived here to play a single game with the Indians tonight.

Representatives of the Bronx Democratic Reorganizing Committee gave a detailed report yesterday to the State Attorney General's office on alleged irregularities during the primary election campaign and the voting last Thursday.
OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 12 --Richard M. Nixon opened his big drive for the California governorship today by stressing communism, a subject that figured in his past campaigns.

A 12-year-old girl was found fatally stabbed yesterday about the same time that the Housing Authority agreed to post guards temporarily in the city project where she lived. The police believed the slayer was an intruder.
Vaudeville associates and friends from show business and private life attended a brief funeral service yesterday for Pat Rooney at the Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 West Seventy-second Street.

THE Bolshoi Ballet's muchheralded "Spartacus" was given its first American performance last night, and this reviewer feels it only fair to preface his remarks with the admission that he found the spectacle to be one of the most preposterous theatrical exercises he has ever seen.

Gasoline stocks in the United States increased to 178,749,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday from 175,059,000 a week earlier, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. Stocks a year ago were a shade lower at 178,478,000 barrels.
A Queens physician was being hunted yesterday in the abortion death here of a Florida heiress--the second fatal abortion of which the same doctor is accused.

DUBLIN, Sept. 12 (UPI)-- Airlines in at least three parts of the world are considering a series of loose mergers to save money and to simplify schedules and other services, some aviation authorities said today.

Jack Brause, realty investor, has bought the twelve-story showroom building at 76 Madison Avenue at the southwest corner of Twenty-eighth Street. He has insured title with the Home Title Guaranty Company.
WEST CHESTER, Pa., Sept. 12--Dr. Mary Jane Hogue, anatomist and zoologist, died yesterday afternoon at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. She was 78 years old.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 12 --Two Right-Wing Republicans failed to win nomination to national office in Utah's primary elections yesterday. But there was a hint of bad news for the Democrats in the way the votes fell.

A consecutive quadruple was registered by Braulio Baeza at Aqueduct yesterday, with his big score coming in the feature race. Riding the Darby Dan Farm's Bramalea, the steadygoing young jockey from Panama guided that daughter of Nashua to a clear triumph in the $28,750 Gazelle Handicap.
Edmund Duffy, who won three Pulitzer Prizes while an editorial cartoonist on The Baltimore Sun, died early today at his home, 253 East Sixtyfirst Street, after a long illness. He was 63 years old.

Britain's projected entry into the European Economic Community and a European political union has precipitated a heated debate at the Commonwealth conference in London. In effect the Commonwealth countries are staging a virtual "revolt" against the mother country.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- A Cuban Air Force pilot-instructor, who defected last week in a Czechoslovak-built training plane, reported today that more than 200 MIG jet fighters had been turned over to Cuba by the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is hurriedly preparing a special scientific satellite to investigate the unexpected radiation zone in space created by a United States high-altitude nuclear explosion last July.

Assistant Secretary of Labor James J. Reynolds will fly here today to try to avert a dockers' strike on Sept. 30 in Atlantic and Gulf Coast ports. Federal mediators who have been working with dockers and steamship leaders asked Mr. Reynolds to enter the dispute.

Arthur H. Thornhill Jr., executive vice-president and general manager of Little, Brown Co., has been elected president of the Boston book publishing concern, which is celebrating its 125th anniversary.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 12 --Britain and Canada supported today the United States request that the United Nations Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space concentrate for the present on international cooperation in space programs.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 12 --Safe Mission and Sprite Rodney, fresh from recent victories over the one-mile track at Washington Park in Chicago, were rated today as second choices behind A. C.'s Viking in Saturday night's $89,721.73 Dexter Cup trot for 3-year-olds at Roosevelt Raceway.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- The Senate voted today to let the Federal Government sell the $180,000,000 industrial empire of the General Aniline and Film Corporation to private investors.

Eight hundred guests at a tent party in Flushing Meadow Park were entertained by a fifteen-piece orchestra yesterday and were told that the 1964-65 New York World's Fair would be the "greatest single event in history."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)--A "Fruitful and constructive" meeting between House and Senate conferees bolstered chances today for a compromise college construction bill and student loan program.

WHEN Birdie Tebbetts was quoted in yesterday's column as saying that Maury Wills of the Dodgers was a bet ter base-stealer than the immortal Ty Cobb, it was innocently thought that the discussion had ended. But reactions were too sharp and furious for it to rest that quietly. The telephone-callers got in their licks first. The letters will flood in later.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 13--"The Perfect Setup," which is expected to open on Broadway in late October, may be the beginning of a new relationship between Hollywood and the legitimate theatre.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- The Department of State has disclosed that the United States has been supplying Israel with "significant amounts" of military equipment.

The amended title of the wilderness bill says it is "to provide for the preservation of wilderness areas," but the transparent purpose behind the substitute measure reported by the House Committee on Interior and Insular Affairs is to undermine the wilderness system that has long been established in the Forest Service.

The newest and smallest of the city's ten fireboats was commissioned yesterday afternoon and put into service last night. Its berth will be at 154th Place and the East River in Whitestone, Queens.

A Negro schoolteacher has decided to drop charges of bias against the owners of a new Bronx apartment house. The complaint had been carried to the courts by the City Commission on Human Rights.
MOSCOW, Sept. 13--Members of a United States Protestant delegation said today that they had been deeply impressed by the vitality of the Russian Orthodox Church under the Communist system.

ROME, Sept. 13--A document published today in the name of the Italian Communist party said a nuclear war "would be a war of extermination" and would destroy "every possibility of economic evolution and social progress" in Euorpe.

Mayor Wagner appointed Queens Borough Works Commissioner J. Wolfe Chassen yesterday as a judge of the Criminal Court at an annual salary of $25,000. Mr. Chassen will be sworn in by the Mayor at City Hall today at 11 A.M.
Cottonseed oil and world sugar futures weakened yesterday in moderately active trading. Other commodities traded on New York exchanges were dull and featureless.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- The Treasury announced today that it would try to sell a batch of long-term bonds by competitive bidding.
SEA CLIFF, L.I., Sept. 13-- Bill Gentzlinger of the Huntington (L.I.) Bay Fleet won the Atlantic Coast District I Star Class championship today with his third victory in the fiverace series.
MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 13-- Emile Zola German, a wellknown defense lawyer, was put forward for a prosecutor's role tonight.
Employers in the city's trucking industry came up yesterday with their first and "final" offer to settle a contract dispute with 12,500 truck drivers.

NORTH HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 13--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Lionel S. Jackson of North Haven and East Hampton, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sheila Woolsey Jackson, to Michael Francis Dorsey. He
LONDON, Sept. 13--A new phonetic alphabet commissioned in the will of George Bernard Shaw will be published for the first time in an edition of his "Androcles and the Lion."

UNHAPPINESS has always been the normal condition of most people. Those who are hungry, ill and fright ened, the majority of mankind, are unhappy with good cause. So are those with lesser but still burdensome afflictions: unrequited love, conviction of failure, debt and the pervasive anxiety of our time.

MOST food budgets are going to be in the red this week end, mainly because red meats are so much more expensive. The effects of livestock withholding by farmers, felt as a slight ripple at the retail level last week, have now assumed proportions more reminiscent of a stormy sea.
PARAMUS, N.J., Sept. 13-- Adam Shelfer led eleven metropolitan qualifiers for the United States Golf Association senior championship today, then withdrew.
SPRING LAKE, N.J., Sept. 13--John M. Bailey predicted tonight that President Kennedy would campaign in New York, Pennsylvania and Connecticut this year.
BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Sept. 13--The qualifying round of the Forest Hill Field Club's fifteenth annual invitation prowoman golf tournament ended in a tie today.
Earnings of Massey-Ferguson, Ltd., rose in the nine months ended July 31 on a sales increase of 15 per cent, the manufacturer of tractors, combines and diesel engines, reported yesterday.

Anti-Buckley Democrats in the Bronx registered formal protests with city and state authorities late yesterday that their watchers were being denied the opportunity to examine the faces of voting machines in the official canvass of the primary election vote.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13--The latest flare-up in the Congo, and President Kennedy's statement at his news conference today of United States policy toward Castro's Sovietized Cuba illustrated an interesting contrast in the strength and effects of two kinds of foreign policy-making. In trying to meet

Comdr. Walter M. Schirra Jr., who will make the next Mercury space flight, complained last night that Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. had been able to offer very limited help because of other calls on his time.
MOUNT GILEAD, N.C., Sept. 13--A Southern town's quest for Northern industry gets a good lampooning and a goodnatured ribbing by just that Southern town's hit musical comedy.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 13 --United States military forces will begin their official exodus from Laos tomorrow when two officers of the American Military Assistance Advisory Group depart by air for Bangkok, Thailand, from Vientiane.
The Mohole Project to drill a hole in the bottom of the sea has run into rough political weather and serious technical criticism.
DETOIT, Sept. 13--American Motors has forsaken sack cloth for silk. The company's most popular Classic series long the plain Jane of the automobile industry, will display sleek new garb for 1963.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13--Stanley Johnston, a former war correspondent for The Chicago Trib une and more recently the paper's editorial promotion assistant, died today at Cantigny Farm, near Wheaton. He was 62 years old.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- The United States is continuing its atmospheric test program to explore certain advances made in nuclear weapons during earlier tests, President Kennedy indicated today.
AN intercity match between New York and Chicago teams will be played tomorrow in Chicago with all the appurtenances of national and international tournaments.
Sales of the Pepperell Manufacturing Company, a Boston textile concern, are about 10 per cent below last year's levels, Homer M. Carter, president, told the annual meeting yesterday.
The Citizens Union announced yesterday it had given its "highly qualified" rating to eight candidates for legislative office, six of them incumbents.

DETROIT, Sept. 13 (UPI)-- The Detroit Tigers blasted four home runs and beat the Boston Red Sox, 14--6, in the opener of a double-header today as Jim Burning scored his seventeenth victory. The second game was postponed after two and a half scoreless innings because of rain.

ROADWAY and Seventh Avenue met in the neutral zone that is 21 West Fortysixth Street Wednesday night to settle the mutually absorbing question of who's going to wear what in "Seidman Son," a play about the trials and tribulations of a dress manufacturer. It was an issue of whose fashion philosophy would prevail.
The wholesale commodity price index remained unchanged Wednesday from 80.3 on Tuesday. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 85.1 on Sept. 7, 1961.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 13-- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor gave an optimistic report today on the military aspects of South Vietnam's fight against Communist guerrillas.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)--The Public Health Service said today that the Surgeon General had called an advisory committee to meet here on Sept. 27 for another review of oral polio vaccine.
MENLO PARK, N.J., Sept. 13--The J.J. Newberry Company, the variety and department store chain, took a major step into the restaurant field here today by opening an unusual six-part food operation.
LONDON, Sept. 13 (Reuters) --The largest exhibition ever of the work of Oskar Kokoschka, the 76-year-old expressionist, opened today at the Tate Gallery.

The conservation and modernization of existing sound structures well be emphasized in the redevelopment of downtown Stamford, Conn., according to James Felt Co. of New York, realty advisers for the project. Henry Hart Rice, vice president at Feit, will help negotiate leases and arrange financing.

ALBANY, Sept. 13--Harold C. Hanover, 63 years old, former president of the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O., was appointed today as assistant industrial commissioner in the State Labor Department by Commissioner Martin P. Catherwood.
Delegates to the United Nations were told yesterday that they could park their cars on a street marked with no-parking signs, but only during meetings of the General Assembly.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 13--The Kennedy Administration's role in collective bargaining was criticized here today by an executive of the United States Steel Corporation.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 13 (AP)--The Minnesota Twins kept their faint pennant hopes alive this afternoon by beating Chicago, 5--1, and snapping a four-game losing streak.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- The flight of the first nuclearpowered rocket has been delayed until at least 1967 by technical, administrative and budgetary problems, Congress was informed today.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 13 (AP) --Daniel Rhodes Hanna Jr., grandson of Marcus Alonzo Hanna, a political power early in this century, died today in Hanna House of University Hospitals. He was 68 years old.

Joseph Papp, founder-producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival, has selected "Macbeth" for the fifteen-week schedule of performances to be given at the city's schools, in upstate community theatres and at the Heckscher Theatre here.
Stanley Hoffman will give a concert of music for unaccompanied violin at Carnegie Recital Hall today at 6 P.M.

President Kennedy's Houston speech presented eloquently the case for the enormous and expensive effort now projected to put an American on the moon during this decade. This argument is, in its essence; that the pace and cost the Kennedy Administration has decided on are necessary because we cannot afford to permit the Soviet Union to enjoy a commanding lead in space. When Willie Shoemaker guided the Cain Hoy Stable's Battle Joined to victory in the seventh race at Aqueduct yesterday, the West Coast jockey received more than the usual applause tendered a winner.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- The tiny oil sheikdom of Kuwait, whose "average man" may be the world's richest, joined the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- President Kennedy urged four major aerospace manufacturers today to accept the terms proposed by a special Presidential board for settlement of their labor contract dispute with two unions.
Carl G. Lampl, a knitwear manufacturer by day and a songwriter by night, died Tuesday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Cleveland. He was 63 years old.

ATLANTA, Sept. 13--Under Georgia's countyunit election system, an urban politician needed courage, skill arid persistence to become a serious contender for the governorship. Carl E. Sanders, who was nominated to that office yesterday, has demonstrated all these qual ities, plus a sense of timing.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13--A House subcommittee investigating allegations of racial discrimination and other improper practices in New York's garment industry will resume hearings Wednesday in Washington.

NEWARK, Del., Sept. 13-- "If I had had this football squad four or five years ago, I'd say that the season would turn out fairly well. But this league [the Middle Atlantic Conference] is too well balanced now. The colleges are bigger and there are more and better football players."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- Department store sales in the week ended Sept. 8 were 13 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. All districts showed gains for the week.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13--A Department of Agriculture official who was demoted in the Billie Sol Estes investigation has been offered his old post. Secretary of
Directors of the National Newark and Essex Bank yesterday declared a 2 per cent stock dividend in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 35 cents. The dividends are pay
The Soviet warning Tuesday that a United States attack on Cuba or on Soviet ships bound for Cuba would mean war may have political and military as well as propaganda effects.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 13--A radar device, similar to the traffic speed-trap unit used by the police, is being tested here to measure the velocity of birds on the wing.
The acceptance of convenience foods by European housewives will come at a faster pace in the future, food industry leaders from abroad predicted here yesterday. Up to now, they

NEWARK, Sept. 13--Two major farm organizations in New Jersey recommended today that the state adopt a 3 per cent sales tax as a "realistic" way to meet the costs of new and expanding Government services.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)--President Kennedy leaves tomorrow to stay at Newport, R.I., until Wednesday.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 13-- Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson today withdrew his opposition to the appointment of three lawyers to carry an appeal to President Kennedy for a greater share of the former Mitchel Air Force Base.

DUBLIN, Sept. 13 (AP)-- Aircraft passengers are in no danger from radioactive fall-out from nuclear tests in the atmosphere, the medical committee of the International Air Transport Association said today.

The five-and-a-half-story apartment building at 1893-95 Andrews Avenue, corner of West Burnside Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Dobe Realty Corporation for cash over mortgages amounting to $247,000. The buyer was a
The Moreland Act Commission on Welfare heard widely divergent views yesterday on whether a State Welfare Commissioner should be appointed by the Governor or by the State Board of Social Welfare.
CHICO, Calif., Sept. 13-- Richard M. Nixon called today for a "three-pronged anti-subversive program that would make California a shining example to the nation.
Jonathan Logan, Inc., manufacturer of women's apparel, is expanding its children's wear operations with the acquisition of Trebor Knitting Mills of New York.
A half-hour tribute to the late Dag Hammarskjold, linking Sweden, Paris and United Nations headquarters in New York by means of Telstar, will be produced Monday morning by United Nations television.
Harlem Hospital's new sixmember executive medical board yesterday endorsed unanimously the nomination of a Canadian physician to direct the hospital's Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- An officer of the International Union of Electrical Workers today accused James B. Carey, the union's president of improperly financing the organization's activities.
Although it was not the first event of the fall season, the debut concert by the Silvermine String Quartet in Carnegie Recital Hall last night re-established the musical scene in a familiar setting.

A group of Elmhurst, Queens, parents kept their children out of school yesterday for the fourth day to protest their assignment to Junior High School 141 in Astoria. The parents, who are Negroes, charged that their children were being excluded from J.H.S. 145 in Jackson Heights.
The strategists at Young Rubicam, Inc., have been pondering a deep problem lately. The problem: How to bring back Bert and Harry Piel.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 13-- Gretel, Australia's challenger for the America's Cup, suffered another mishap today. She slipped off her supporting blocks while being hauled out for a final check before her match with the American defender, Weatherly, starting Saturday.

BRASILIA, Friday, Sept. 14 --Premier Francisco Brochado da Rocha and his Cabinet resigned early today, raising fears of military intervention in the Government of Brazil, Latin America's largest country.
Senator Jacob K. Javits, New York Republican, said last night that he was convinced "the American people will not tolerate a Communist military base on Cuba, no matter what it takes to eliminate it."

The stock market staged a thoroughly confused and confusing performance yesterday. Consideraly more issues declined than advanced yet key averages showed only a small loss. Meanwhile, trading activity was unchanged.
Supreme Court Justice Marcus G. Christ held a commanding lead last night in the race for the Republican nomination for the Court of Appeals bench.
TRENTON, Sept. 13--Gov. Richard J. Hughes predicted today that New Jersey would lead most states in civil rights legislation "within two years or sooner."

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 13-- Gov. Ross R. Barnett invoked the historic doctrine of interposition tonight in a move to block the enrollment of a Negro at the University of Mississippi. The university was under a Federal Court order to admit the Negro, James H. Meredith, next week.
ATLANTA, Sept. 13--Reaction to corruption in government and to racist demagoguery figured prominently in the nomination yesterday of State Senator Carl E. Sanders to the governorship.
NEWPORT, Calif., Sept. 13 (AP)--Jim Payton of the Mendota Yacht Club, Madison, Wis., today won the Clifford D. Mallory Trophy, symbolic of the men's North American sailing championship.

After fratricidal strife and a still precarious truce, the Algerian people are scheduled to go to the polls next week in their first national election as an independent nation. They will name the members of the first Algerian National Assembly, whose main task will be to appoint a regular government and draft a constitution.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 13 --A public frame of mind "bordering on hysteria" can be gen. erated by "one-sided" books such as that just written by Rachel Carson, it was charged today by Dr. C. Glen King, head of the Nutrition Foundation.

BERLIN, Sept. 13--The British took a new step today to inform the Russians of the Western Allies' request that they revert to the use of buses to transport guards for the Soviet war memorial in West Berlin instead of employing armored convoy's.

LONDON, Sept. 13--Britain prepared herself today for a drive to explain to leaders of the Commonwealth, in fullest detail, the agreements reached with the six members of the European Economic Community.
LONDON, Sept. 13--Direct investment overseas by British companies fell last year to 218,000,000 ($610,400,000), the Board of Trade Journal reported here. Oil and insurance investments were excluded.
A welfare recipient was found guilty in Bronx Criminal Court yesterday of having beaten a woman welfare worker so badly she has been unable to work for two and a half years.

The woes of West Germany's hard-pressed shipbuilding industry are being compounded by the actions of German creditors against a shipyard that has gone bankrupt, a major United States oil company charged yesterday.

A vast tropical rain forest in northwestern Colombia will be cleared and cultivated soon for scientific banana growing under the terms of a private technical assistance program announced jointly here yesterday by the United Fruit Company, a leading concern in the banana business, and the Corporation Financiera Colombiana de Desarrollo Industrial of Bogota, a private Colombian company that promotes industrial development.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 (AP)--John Callison's twentieth home run with one out in the ninth inning gave the Philadelphia Phillies a 2-1 victory over Milwaukee tonight.

LONDON, Sept. 13--A little selective buying gave the stock market here a better tone today. However, small losses outnumbered gains in the principal sections, and The Financial Times industrial index slipped 0.1, to 274.

WARRENTON, Va., Sept. 12 --The profound social and moral questions raised by voluntary sterilization for indigent mothers at Fauquier Hospital's free maternity clinic have had little impact in this rolling farm country.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- The Senate Finance Committee revised the Administration's foreign trade bill today to give President Kennedy broader powers than he is seeking.
BELGRADE, Sept. 13 (UPI) --Claude Piquemal gave France her first gold medal of the seventh European track and field championships today when he won the 100-meters dash in 10.4 seconds.

A relatively simple test for detecting cancer of the kidneys and the bladder early, while it is potentially curable, has been worked out by two researchers of the Harvard Medical School and the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital in Boston.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)--The Food and Drug Administration said today that it had reports indicating that at least ten deformed babies had been born in this country to women who took the sleepinducing drug thalidomide.

A Civil Aeronautics Board lawyer had charged the British Overseas Airways Corporation with illegally carrying passengers between here and San Francisco and between here and Lima, Peru, and Kingston, Jamaica.

Three teen-agers, including a girl, were killed last night when their car crashed into a wall in upper Manhattan as they were being pursued by Yonkers policemen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)--Senator Philip A. Hart, convinced that the Government does not pay its law makers enough, has set up a "Hart Michigan Fund" to help meet his expenses as a Senator.

Counsel for Hughes Tool Company, owned by Howard R. Hughes, denied yesterday, charges of forgery and fraud that had been leveled at Mr. Hughes earlier in the Federal Court battle here between Trans World Airlines, Inc., and Mr. Hughes and his tool company.

NAPLES, Italy, Sept. 13-- Many Italians have expressed doubts about whether the expenditures in the twelve-year effort to raise the economic level of poor and backward regions in the South have been worth while.

Although sales and earnings showed only moderate increases, they established new records for the Campbell Soup Company in the fiscal year ended July 29, the annual report of W.B. Murphy, president, disclosed yesterday.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 13-- The controversial Plan Organization governing Iran's economic development is undergoing a sharp curtailment. The net effect will be to clip the wings of the big bureau that has enjoyed virtual autonomy in pushing through urgently needed improvement projects.
Neither the heat nor the humidity is likely to bother the workers in part of a new jewelry plant that opened yesterday in Holbrook, in Islip Township, L.I.

Longshoremen and steamship operators, whose deadlock in contract negotiations point to a strike on Sept. 30, were told yesterday by James J. Reynolds, Assistant Secretary of Labor, to "get down to hard bargaining."
SEATTLE, Sept. 13 (UPI)-- Dave Hill took the openinground lead of the Seattle open golf tournament today with a six-under-par 64.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 13--"The Wonderful Adventures of Nils," an unusual color film in which King Gustaf VI Adolf has a walk-on part was acclaimed today as "magnificent propaganda" for Sweden.
LANE BRYANT, a store that specializes in clothes for large women, has assembled a travel collection that is fashionable, lightweight and easy to care for.
Chrysler Corporation announced yesterday that it would set up a nation-wide automotive leasing company. The new subsidiary will be known as the Chrysler Leasing Corporation.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Sept. 12 (AP)--A Cuban exile leader said tonight that the anti-Castro fighting group called Alpha 66 had a 300-man force scattered in small units throughout the Caribbean. He said they were ready to make five more strikes in the next sixty days.
One of the European central bankers, whose opinion of United Sates currency might be expected to bear weight in Washington, expressed strong confidence in the dollar yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 13 (AP)--Gino Cimoli's eighthinning single, his third hit of the game, brought in the winning run today as the Kansas City Athletics defeated the Los Angeles Angels, 5--4.
MOERBEKE, the Congo, Sept. 12--Premier Cyrille Adoula ventured into the lower Congo today, mixing politics with a largely sentimental journey to the huge Belgian sugar plantation here.
ISLE OF SARK, Sept. 13 (UPI)--The electric wheelchair of the Dame of Sark, Mrs. Sybil Hathaway, will continue to remain the only motorized vehicle on this peaceful English Channel island.

President Kennedy was criticized yesterday by a spokesman for industry for making "free collective bargaining a farce" in the aerospace industries. He was also accused of bypassing the national labor laws.

ALBANY, Sept. 13--An application for a temporary stay of pension payments from the State Employes Retirement System to former Supreme Court Justice J. Vincent Keogh was denied today in the Appellate Division, Third Department.

LONDON, Sept. 13--An inquest into the death of Dr. Robert A. Soblen was postponed today for three weeks at the request of the pathologist who performed the autopsy.

ON Monday the United States Constitution will be 175 years old.
SEAL BEACH, Calif., Sept. 13 (AP)--"It was an act of heroism. The pilot must have known he was turning toward almost certain death."
The New York Central Railroad reported an annual loss of $2,900,000 from its suburban passenger operations yesterday and asked for permission to raise commutation fares 8 cents a ride.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- Rail and truck loadings of freight were down last week from the preceding week, mainly due to the Labor Day holiday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)--President Kennedy signed today a bill creating a national seashore area at Point Reyes, Calif., thirtyfive miles northwest of San Francisco.
UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Sept. 13--The crystal-ball gazers predict a glorious season for Penn State's eleven, with an Eastern championship certain and national honors possible.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 13 --Premier Brochado da Rocha had asked the Cabinet this afternoon to authorize him to seek a vote of confidence from Congress on calling a national plebiscite at the time of the Congressional elections Oct. 7. The vote would concern the power allocated to the President. The Cabinet refused to let him seek the vote and decided to resign.

A defendant who contended in Supreme Court on Wednesday that he had been searched illegally by the police pleaded guilty yesterday to violation of the weapons law after a justice had denied his motion to invalidate the evidence.

OTTAWA, Sept. 13 (Canadian Press)--For the first time in twelve years, the Canadian Government has made a direct entry into the New York bond market and negotiated a twentyfive-year, 5-per-cent $250,000,000 issue to reinforce the country's exchange reserves.
CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP)-- Women with low incomes tend to be more plump than those who are well-to-do, a group of medical researchers reported today.

The following is a listing of restaurants that are recommended on the basis of varying merits. Such a listing is published every Friday in The New York Times. Unless otherwise indicated, the restaurants are open seven days a week.

Mayor Wagner sent a reassuring message yesterday to Harry Jaffe, the Brooklyn grocer and delicatessen owner who recently wrote him that the police had done little about the repeated robberies of his store at 176 Albany Avenue in the last eleven months.

Maj. Raul Castro, Cuba's Armed Forces Minister, has advised President Kennedy to convince "Pentagon generals" that an attack on Cuba "can mark the end of imperialism." This was reported in a Havana broadcast monitored yesterday by United Press International.

RENSSELAER, Ind., Sept. 13 --Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower opened his 1962 political campaigning tonight with a caustic attack on the "paradise for theorists" he said had been created in the Government.

A Queens physician awaiting extradition in France has confessed that he performed an abortion on a 19-year-old girl and then dismembered her body when she died, according to the Queens District Attorney's office.

The names of women working for the success of the annual luncheon of the Friends of the Philharmonic have been announced by Mrs. Sherman Ewing. She is chairman of the event scheduled for Nov. 27 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- The Senate approved today President Kennedy's request for special reserve mobilization authority. The action came after Administration leaders had disentangled the plan from Republican demands for a military warning on Cuba.

Anthony V.B. Geoghegan, executive vice president of Young Rubicam, Inc., and a figure of almost legendary renown in the advertising industry, died Wednesday of a heart attack at the Nassau Hospital in Mineola, L.I. He was 65 years old.
PARIS, Sept. 13--President de Gaulle's proposal to amend the Constitution by referendum provoked widespread opposition from party leaders today and presaged six weeks of sharp political struggle.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 13 (AP) --Jim Piersall, the Washington Senators' center fielder, was arrested and charged with disorderly conduct tonight when he went into the stand of Memorial Stadium after a fan who had been heckling him.

BOSTON, Sept. 13--Although Manager Ralph Houk is still striving to impress his Yankees that "this race isn't wrapped up yet," there is no ignoring the sudden feeling of relaxation that has come over the Bombers within the last twenty-four hours.
CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP)-- Except for another moderate rise in September soybean futures, all contracts on the Board of Trade declined today under persistent selling.
A one-year contract with a no-strike clause has been worked out between the Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers, the bargaining agent for 40,000 city teachers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- The burning of churches in Georgia, apparently to discourage voter-registration rallies, provoked President Kennedy today to one of his strongest denunciations.

Business men are attempting to defeat what they believe to be the most serious challenge to their pension and profit-sharing accumulations in many years. They are not confident of success because many of their colleagues seem unaware of the danger and time is short.
Cotton futures were 65 cents up to $1.10 a bale off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. New October and new December were weakest.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 13 --The Fay brothers from Houston, Ernest and Albert, were tied today at 89 points after four races in the national 5.5Meter Class sailing championship.
An autopsy yesterday showed "evidence of sexual assault" on 12-year-old Anna Ayala who was fatally stabbed on Wednesday, according to Dr. John F. Devlin, assistant medical examiner.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Sept. 13--The Central Synagogue was the setting here this evening for the marriage of Miss June Ellen Merahn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Ralph Merahn, to Arthur Michael Margolin. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Harry Margolin of Larchmont, N.Y.

FISH RIVER LAKE, Me., Sept. 13--Sportsmen are up in arms south of here over the possible fate of the Beaverkill River in New York and the Battenkill in Vermont. But, to quote Patrick Henry, "the firing already has begun in the North."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- Somewhat like Lazarus, Congress has come to life again, President Kennedy said today. He predicted that before it adjourned it would pass a number of bills that once seemed dead.

PENNS GROVE, N.J., Sept. 13--A group of students perched on stools, their eyes shielded by tinted goggles from flames spurting from narrow gas jets, and carefully fashioned delicate components of a glass condenser bulb assembly.

THE commodore is a colonel and the sailors are off-duty soldiers in New York's newest boating organization, the Willets Point Yacht Club. Begun this season by soldiers stationed at Fort Totten in Bayside, Queens, the club is headed by Lieut. Col. Lewis C. Miller.

Government securities prices held firm yesterday in limited trading. Corporates moved upward on better volume. Outstanding state and municipal obligations were traded actively, although new issues continued to move slowly out of syndicate.

The time had come for plain speaking on Cuba, and Americans, Cubans, Russians and the rest of the world heard it last evening from President Kennedy. The time has not come for a military invasion or any other drastic, unilateral action by the United States against Cuba, and this, too, has been made plain.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 13--President Moise Tshombe of Katanga accused the United Nations today of having airlifted 2,000 troops of the Central Congolese Government into Katanga to attack his secessionist province.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 14--The United States exhibited here today a fourteen pound steel object that dropped on Manitowoc, Wis., Sept. 5.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14--Gentlemen, the State Department has invited you to this seminar as part of our new program for assisting all diplomats from the newer nations toward a clearer understanding of the American way of life.
The possibility of earning $95,322 in the matter of a minute and seventeen seconds or so has prompted the owners of fourteen horses to enter their colts in today's Futurity at Aqueduct.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Sept. 14-- Bucknell's football team is the largest squad of Bisons Bob Odell has handled since he took the head coaching job here in 1958. The forty-six players make it easier in quantity, at least, for Odell to manage his twoteam system of play.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14-- The House of Representatives reversed its past position today and gave approval to a proposal for converting a large plutonium-producing reactor at Hanford, Wash., into the world's largest atomic power plant.
BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Sept. 14--The favorites advanced as two rounds were completed today in the fifteenth annual prowoman golf championship over the Forest Hill Field Club's 6,230-yard, par-71 course.

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 14 (AP)--State officials planned strategy in secret today for an expected showdown over conflicting orders from Gov. Ross R. Barnett and Federal District Judge Sidney Mize in the University of Mississippi desegregation dispute.

CHICAGO, Sept 14 (AP)-- Maury Wills continued his assault on Ty Cobb's record today with his ninety-first stolen base of the season as the Los Angeles Dodgers scored seven times in the first inning and beat the Chicago Cubs, 13-7.

MOSCOW, Sept. 14--The visits of two high officials from Saudi Arabia to the Soviet Union in the last ten days are regarded by some foreign observers as the beginning of closer relations between the two countries.
Stanley Hoffman, a young violinist from Kansas City who has been a member of the New York Philharmonic since last year, made his solo debut late yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall.

Talks were recessed indefinitely yesterday between WNDT and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, increasing the probability of a strike when the educational television station starts operation tomorrow evening.
The stock market shuffled around yesterday in desultory trading and ended with a minuscule gain.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 14-- An associate has said of Douglas Frank Hewson Packer, head of the Australian syndicate that hopes to win the America's Cup in the races starting tomororw, that "he is a man of iron whim."

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 14-- More than 2,700 school children in the New Orleans area qualified this week for state tuition grants under a program set up to provide an alternaive to integrated public schools.
BOSTON, Sept. 14--It is quite possible that from here on the Yankees will pay closer heed to the warnings of their skipper that "this pennant isn't wrapped up yet."

MOSCOW, Sept. 14--The Soviet Government accepted tonight with reservations President Kennedy's declaration that United States military intervention in Cuba was not required or justifiable at the present time.

USUALLY, bridge players with big reputations play very well, even in the most informal games, but there are times when they make enough mistakes to make glad the heart of any tyro.
PARIS, Sept. 14--Planning and direct financing by the Government were said today to have played a decisive role in the rapid and consistent economic growth of France.
PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 14 --The Mariner II, the United States' Venus-bound spacecraft continued to send radio signals today on the nineteenth day in space.
A large Brooklyn department store, in conjunction with the American National Theatre and Academy, is sponsoring a theatre appreciation series for high school students.
The Aeroquip Corporation said yesterday it was acquiring the Barco Manufacturing Company of Barrington, Ill., which makes swivel and ball joints for metal pipes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14-- Average prices in primary markets rose four-tenths of 1 per cent, to 101.2 per cent of their 1957-59 base during the week ended Sept. 11, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) announced yesterday the sale, entirely outside the United States, of a $100,000,000 issue of United States dollar bonds.
A 51-year-old woman was viciously beaten and her rescuer attacked at 3 P. M. yesterday in an elevator at 210 Fifth Avenue, at Twenty-fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP)--President Kennedy expressed confidence today that the American and German peoples would "one day witness the peaceful emergence of just and stable conditions in which the benefits of freedom can be developed in the fullest sense."
LONDON, Sept. 14--While industrial shares drifted lower in quiet trading, there was brisk demand for British Government securities in the stock market today.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 14-- The United States assured West Germany again today that it would use "whatever force is necessary" to defend the North Atlantic Treaty Organization "as an entity."

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 14 --President and Mrs. Kennedy were guests of honor tonight at a dinner given by the Australian Ambassador, Sir Howard Beale, on the eve of the international yacht race for the America's Cup.

ROME, Sept. 14 (AP)--Mrs. Sally Bragg Baker of Cambridge, Mass., wife of the second secretary at the United States Embassy, was found dead in the bathtub of their Rome apartment last night, apparently of natural causes.
