CORNPLANTER INDIAN RESERVATION, Pa., Sept. 15--Although he knows his cause is lost, Chief Corbett Sundown continues to fight with dedication and determination. He feels a sense of great responsibility as a chief of the Hawk clan of the Senaca Indians.
In an age of supersonic speeds, Clive Lewis, a 21-yearold Welshman, is a novelty. He is taking almost three years to circle the globe.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 16-- Steel men were a little more optimistic last week. But they still did not foresee evidence of a strong uptrend in orders.

COON RAPIDS, Iowa, Sept. 16--On this quiet Sunday, Konstantin G. Pysin, Soviet Minister of Agriculture, slogged through muddy fields, watched the newest farm machinery demonstrated and visited a commercial fertilizer warehouse and an experimental automatic airconditioned pig shed.

Richard A. Flink, the Queens lawyer credited by the Justice Department Saturday with having uncovered the intelligence activities of two Soviet employes of the United Nations, removed last night a little of the secrecy cloaking his role.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 16--The 17th session of the General Assembly opens here Tuesday. It is expected to be the busiest in United Nations history.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 16-- Most of the gossip you've been hearing lately about the remodeled Cleveland Browns is true, but they still needed the benefit of some bungling here and there on the part of the New York Giants today to score a 17-7 triumph in Municipal Stadium.

"We need a better Congress," Walter P. Reuther, vice president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., told a union convention out in Detroit. He urged labor to "get out and elect" such a Congress. These are praiseworthy sentiments, if taken at face value.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Sept. 16--Prime Minister Sir Edgar Whitehead issued a statement tonight accusing the Zimbabwe African People's Union, the African nationalist party led by Joshua Nkomo, of current violence in this country.
PARIS, Sept. 16--The economy of Western Europe moves out of the vacation season on a high plateau but with signs of weakening of the upward thrust of the three-year-old boom.
BOSTON, Sept. 16--Dramatic contests in both major parties are expected to attract close to 1,000,000 voters in Tuesday's primary. The record is 959,000, set in 1952.
Taking a leaf from Karl Marx, the central bankers of the non-Communist world, most of them ardent defenders of the capitalist system, have united in effective fashion.

Store space of 11,400 square feet has been leased by Mr. Richard, Inc., a chain of steak restaurants, in the office building being erected by Rose Associates and Charles B. Beneson at 1180 Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue), at the northeast corner of 46th Street. Raymond Babtkis of the Williams Real Estate Company was the broker.

Siam di Tella Ltda. of Buenos Aires, Argentina, reported a net profit in the fiscal year ended April 30 totaling 526,986,663 pesos ($5,323,101) on sales of 3,922,034,000 pesos ($39,622,566), the annual report disclosed over the weekend.
Members of three Teamsters Union locals will hold a combined vote today on whether to accept or reject terms of a new contract proposed last week by management.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16-- The International Monetary Fund said today that European restrictions on the outflow of private investment money were partly responsible for this country's balance-of-payments problem. It urged its European members to take "positive steps" to correct the situation.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 16--Following are items proposed for inclusion in the agenda of the 17th session of the United Nations General Assembly, which will convene here Tuesday (explanatory material within parentheses was compiled by the United Nations Office of Public Information

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 16--As far as size is concerned, the biggest sports arena of all is the one used for the America's Cup Races. It is known as the Atlantic Ocean. But it wasn't large enough yesterday. As least the corner of the ocean in which they raced wasn't roomy enough.
Vice President Johnson will speak at a dinner of the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation on Oct. 9 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
"The preaching of Jesus Christ is the most sublime of all the philosophies of life," the Rev. Francis X. Cronin said yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16-- The gross national product does not measure the gross national product.

"Peter Pan," starring Mary Martin, will be repeated by the National Broadcasting Company television network on Saturday, Feb. 5, from 7 to 9 P.M. The color tape production, which also stars Cyril Ritchard as Captain Hook, was first presented in 1960.

BONN, Sept. 16--The West German police asked the International Police (Interpol) for help today in the search for a missing West German rocket specialist amid speculation that he had been abducted by agents of a Middle Eastern country.
The proposed Republican state platform would pledge the party and its candidates for public office to provide "continued security, progress, happiness and prosperity" for the people of the state.
Almost 50 exponents of the ancient Oriental art of karate, representing eight states from Massachusetts to Florida, gave their version of fighting "emptyhanded" at the Manhattan Center yesterday.
JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 16-- University of Mississippi trustees will choose tomorrow between compliance with desegregation orders of a Federal court and the defiance urged by Gov. Ross R. Barnett.

At Syracuse and at Buffalo this week, Democrats and Republicans will be deeply en gaged in the ancient and tradi tional political practice of tick et balancing. Because many voters regard the practice as evil, leaders of both parties customarily deny that the matter of balance enters their considerations, even though it is often the ...

MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 16-- The leaders of the United Steelworkers of America chided President Kennedy today, holding that he had not acted forcefully enough to reduce unemployment and promote economic growth.
Two babies were christened yesterday each in the same ivory satin brocade christening robe that her descendants say was made by Martha Washington.

A quadruple assignment is likely to be Douglas Campbell's next Broadway chore. Mr. Campbell, who was seen here last season in the title role of "Gideon" and later as God when he succeeded Fredric March in Paddy Chayefsky's drama, is planning to affiliate himself with "Moby Dick."
MONZA, Italy, Sept. 16--Graham Hill of England, driving a sleek blue-black B.R.M., won the Italian Grand Prix today and virtually clinched the 1962 drivers' world championship.

PARIS, Sept. 16--Mohammed Boudiaf, a leading opponent of the dominant Political Bureau in Algeria, said here today that he was refusing to be a candidate in the National Assembly elections next Thursday.
BETHPAGE, L.I., Sept. 16 --Herb Pennell scored three of his four goals in the second half as Brookville rallied and defeated Long Island, 8--4, in a high-goal polo match at Bethpage State Park today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP)--The Interior Department plans to ask Congress for authorization to publish a new edition of the wall map of the United States.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 16--The executive board of the International Union of Electrical Workers voted tonight to recommend the suspension of Al Hartnett, secretary-treasurer of the union.
The agreement reached between the New York Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers is an important step to stable and peaceful operation of the city's schools.
A young Negro scientist voiced full support yesterday for the non-violent integration drive spearheaded in the South by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
LONDON, Sept. 16--Legislation that would make incitement to racial hatred a punishable offense in Britain was demanded today at a meeting of the World Jewish Congress.

BOSTON, Sept. 16 (UPI)-- The Boston Patriots cracked the two-season, 11-game victory streak of the two-time American Football League champion Houston Oilers today with a 34--21 victory before a crowd of 32,276 at Harvard Stadium.

The United Nations General Assembly should not adopt resolutions on matters it can do nothing about. Harlan Cleveland, Assistant Secretary of State for International Organization Affairs, said yesterday.
The fate of Lambert Feasley, Inc., a $20,000,000 agency controlled by the Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company, has been the subject of much speculation in recent weeks.

W. Adolphe Roberts, a suave, cane-swinging author and boulevardier who was a member of Greenwich Village's literary renaissance before World War I, died in London, after a brief illness, according to word re ceived Saturday night by the British Consulate here. He was 75 years old.
BUFFALO, Sept. 16--Governor Rockefeller flew to the state's Republican convention city today and began campaigning three days before his renomination is scheduled.
MOSCOW, Sept. 16 (UPI)-- Women in the Soviet Union from Vilna to Vladivostok re ceived comforting news today. It is not capricious, they were told, to crave black lingerie and fashionable hair-dos.
STOCKHOLM, Sept. 16-- Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, was honored today as the Swedish-American of 1962.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 16--A pastoral letter read today in all Roman Catholic Churches warned of Communist infiltration in this country.
Antonio Arraiz, MinisterCounselor of the Venezuelan delegation to the United Nations, died yesterday in his home at 17 Crooked Mile Road in Westport, Conn. He was 59 years old.

LONDON, Sept. 16--Prime Minister Macmillan completed preparations today for a final round of discussions with British Commonwealth leaders on Britain's prospective membership in the European Economic Community.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 16 (A.P.)--Camilo Pascual drove in the winning run with an eighth-inning single and gained his 19th victory today as the Minnesota Twins beat the Cleveland Indians, 4-3, for a sweep of their three-game series.
SEATTLE, Sept. 16 (UPI)-- Jack Nicklaus of Tucson, Ariz., shot a two-under par 68 today and won the $30,000 Seattle open with a 72-hole total of 265. It was his second tournament victory of the year.
"Boy, this is exciting!" exclaimed the youngster.

The jukebox, the gaudy and sometimes raucous fixture of taverns, bowling alleys, small restaurants and soda parlors, has been given a new look and some new sounds. The result, its leading manufacturer hopes, will be a host of new customers.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 16-- The most gala weekend of the season on the Eastern seaboard brought out the most conservative fashions.

IN the matter of style the two chess victories shown here are as far apart as the Muzio Gambit and the King's Indian Defense. They have, however, one thing in common; both bear the grandmasters touch.

FOR the woman who works, giving a dinner party on a weekday can be hectic if she must fix all the dishes when she gets home from the office. But if she plans a menu for which much of the preparation can be done in advance, she will be almost as calm, when her guests arrive, as if she had someone in the kitchen doing all the work for her.
If turn about is indeed fair play, then it is only fair to let the mutual funds show how well they have done since the market reached its low.

After a run of 10 years 4 months and 2 weeks at Jimmy Ryan's on 52d Street, Wilbur de Paris and his New Orleans Jazz Band, a seven-piece traditional group, have moved to Greenwich Village's Room at the Bottom.
A last-minute addition to the Senate version of the Revenue Act of 1962 is causing distress among some companies with foreign subsidiaries, which produce or ...
The Port of New York Authority has agreed to accept a $500,000 deferred-payment note from Northeast Airlines for overdue bills file carrier owes the bi-state agency.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 16-- You can drink at the Texas Bar here now, and if you don't like Texas you can always try the California, the Miami or the Hollywood Bars.
This week's meetings of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund in Washington should be happily free of a crisis atmosphere. Yet problems remain.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 16-- Gretel, Australia's first challenger for the America's Cup, was one down today in her match with the defender Weatherly and facing what most observers thought would be certain defeat in the four-of-sevenrace series.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 16 (UPI)--Gus Bell led off the last of the ninth with his sixth home run and gave the Milwaukee Braves a 5--4 victory over the Houston Colts today.

More than 2,500 members of the Salvation Army heard their international leader. Gen. Wilfred Kitching, declare yesterday that the "common life can be made uncommonly beautiful" by the "fragrance of sanctified living."
STOCKHOLM, Sept. 16--The Social Democratic party of Premier Tage Erlander appeared early today to be rolling up an impressive victory in yesterday's provincial and local elec- tions.

PERRYSBURG, Ohio, Sept. 16--Mr. and Mrs. Henry M. Dodge have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Quackenbush Dodge, to Brooks Whitney Stoddard. He is the son of Dr. Whitney S. Stoddard, professor of art at Williams College, and Mrs. Stoddard of Williamstown, Mass.
MOSCOW, Sept. 17-The Soviet Union rejected today the Western view that Moscow had no authority to abolish the office of the Soviet commandant in East Berlin.
Tempers and time grew shorter yesterday as steamship operators and longshoremen continued deadlocked in contract negotiations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP)--Legislation to permit self-employed persons to set up tax-deductible pension funds was cleared today for House and Senate action. However, it is still laden with controversy.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17-A conflict-of-interest rule on industry's role in competing for Government research contracts has been established by the Defense Department.
MOSCOW, Sept. 17--The Soviet Union revived today its demand for changes in the structure of the United Nations.

Camouflaged raincoats, carriage horns from Pakistan, machetes and motor parts are among the more than $10,000,000 worth of Government and industrial surplus now being offered at the 18th Trade Show of the Institute of Surplus Dealers.
Stocks posted a modest gain yesterday in more active trading.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Appropriations managers in the House of Representatives voted a $1,500,000,000 cut today in President Kennedy's foreign-aid program.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 17--R. H. Macy Co. gave a preview today of its newest branch store, in the Walt Whitman Shopping Center here, to about 500 persons. The store will by opened to the public tomorrow.
The Weyerhaeuser Company announced yesterday that is had reduced the list prices of some grades of bleached kraft papermaking pulp by $8 to $12 a ton.
Mrs. Eunice Kennedy Shriver has publicly discussed the heartbreak her Family underwent with a retarded older sister, who is in an institution.

CANNE DELLA BATTAGLIA, Italy, Sept. 17--Archeological excavations at the Cannae battlefield where Hannibal inflicted a disastrous defeat on the Romans on Aug. 2,216 B.C. have established that the tombs long revered as those of Roman and Carthaginian warriors formed part of a medieval Christian cemetery.

IF Bette Davis and Joan Crawford come to blows during the promotion of their joint film, "Whatever Happened to Baby Jane?", it is now possible to make book on the probable winner. Bette Davis. Each of these movie queens has a good right cross and left hook, and both are formidable in-fighters. But Bette Davis is the more aggressive. She can take out an opponent with one punch.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 17 (AP) --Home runs by Elmo Plaskett, a rookie, and Bob Clemente powered the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 5-2 victory over the San Francisco Giants tonight. The defeat for the second-place Giants was their sixth straight.

Robert Morris Morgenthau is basically a quiet and modest man. But at 43 years of age the Democratic nominee for Governor can look back at a career in which he has distinguished himself in the legal world, as a naval officer and as a skilled administrator.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 17--A friend of Al Hartnett said the other day that perhaps Mr. Hartnett's greatest fault, and at the same time his greatest strength, was a mixture of "Irish stubborness" and the courage to speak out for what he thinks is right, no matters what the consequences.

Leeds Northrup Company, Philadelphia manufacturer of measuring instruments and electronic controls, has formed an Italian subsidiary, I. Melville Stein, president, told shareholders yesterday at the annual meeting in Philadelphia.
David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, accused Herbert Hill, a consultant to the House Education and Labor Committee, of "contempt of Congress" yesterday.

The oil take-over fever has abruptly spread to Canada. Two large American companies, the Gulf Oil Corporation of Pittsburgh and the Superior Oil Company of Los Angeles, have taken steps toward control of smaller Canadian companies.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17-- The Washington Post published today the widely circulated rumor--and a denial--that President Kennedy was once secretly married.

FIFTY years ago yesterday, a squareshouldered blond with twinkling gray eyes made his major league debut with the Brooklyn Dodgers in old Washington Park. His name was--and is--Charles Dillon Stengel. His new teammates addressed him as "Charlie"--all except Zack Wheat, who knew him from Kansas City, where he had been called "Dutch." The more enduring and more famous nickname of "Casey" was to come later.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 17--The two feuding officers of the International Union of Electrical Workers stated their cases today before the membership.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17-- Treasury bill rates rose on today's sale of the regular weekly issues, continuing the zig-zag pattern that has prevailed for almost two months now.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17-- The Government said today there was no need to give way to panic when nuclear fallout doses exceeded the radiation protection levels set by the Federal Radiation Council.

Motilal Nehru, father of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, is the subject of a new biography by B.R. Nanda, which John Day plans for publication later this year. The elder Nehru, a self-made man, was a pre-eminent lawyer of fabulous wealth.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 17 (AP)--Watson Elliott's 5-yearold Tuscany Pomp scored by two lengths in the Drexelbrook Purse in the mud today.

HOUSTON, Sept. 17--Nine new astronauts, candidates for the lunar space flight, made their debuts here today. Two civilians were among the group, which also includes four Air Force officers and three Navy officers.
ATLANTA, Sept. 17-- A fourth Negro church burned to the ground today and a large-scale investigation by Federal and state agencies was begun.

Grace Filkins, whose auburn hair, alabaster skin and dark brown eyes captivated New York theater audiences in the eighteen-eighties and nineties, -died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. She was 97 years old and lived at the Dresden Madison Nursing Home, 36 East 67th Street.
SYRACUSE, Tuesday, Sept. 18 -With Robert M. Morgenthau nominated for Governor, New York Democrats today sought an Irish Catholic as his running mate for the United States Senate.

DURHAM, N.H., Sept. 17-- Dr. Carroll S. Towle, who taught English at the University of New Hampshire for 30 years and directed its Summer Writers Conference, died in Exeter Hospital last night. He was 61 years old.
"Natural Affection," William Inge's next drama, is to be staged by Tony Richardson, last represented here as co-director of "A Taste of Honey."

MOST women put rugs on the floor. The adventurous hang them on walls. If Michael Malce has his way, women will soon be wearing them on their backs. Mr. Malce's tiny shop at 35 West Eighth Street is currently displaying his latest brainchild, fashions made out of Spanish rugs and upholstery fabrics.
BRUSSELS, Sept. 17--More than 10 person were killed today when a four-story office rebuilding collapsed. The structure may have been weakened by the construction of a building close by.
BUFFALO, Sept. 17--Republican delegates and alternates gathered here today for what gave all signs of being the most smoothly run political convention in recent state history.
Special to The New York Times.

THE ghosts of a thousand American college novels march through "The Shortest Gladdest Years, " by Scott Sullivan. He conquers them all. Or joins them all, if you will--producing what one might think was at this late day unproducible: an unusual story of four maverick undergraduates in a conventional pattern of action.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The nomination of Irving Ben Cooper of New York as a judge of the United States District Court was approved by the full Judiciary Committee today and sent to the Senate.
PINEHURST, N.C., Sept. 17 --The United States Amateur golf championship opened today in a heavy morning downpour and an early shower of upsets.
APROPOS of a bridge hand reported here last week, remarking on a bad double of a slam contract, there is a quotable statement in a book called "Winning Duplicate." recently published in Texas:
JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 17Gov. Ross R. Barnett failed today to win a public pledge from trustees of the University of Mississippi that they would defy the desegregation orders of the Federal courts.
LONDON, Sept. 17--Prices of British Government securities rose by as much as 10 shillings ($1.40) in the stock market today.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Sept. 17--In 1959 Tom Nugent took over the head coaching post at the University of Maryland after guiding Virginia Military Institute and Florida State to intercollegiate gridiron recognition.
Cocoa and world-sugar prices tumbled in active trading here yesterday. Other commodities traded on New York exchanges were quiet and narrowly mixed.
The seventeenth United Nations Assembly opens today with enough excitement to prove that it is still alive.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 17--Mayor Wagner summoned the Democratic party today to a massive effort this fall to terminate Governor Rockefeller's political career.
WASHINGTON, Sept, 17-- The Trade Expansion Bill reached the Senate debate stage today, but for want of debaters there was no debate.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 17-- Behind Australia's challenge for the America's Cup were considerations of the country's position in the free world, her growth since World War II and a desire to attract foreign investments, particularly from the United States.
Ken Sears, a big but somewhat frail forward who last season had threatened to file a court suit against the New York Knickerbockers, yesterday signed a 1962-63 contract with them.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17-- Western collegiate football-- that mysterious Brand X--will get its first and perhaps stiffest test of the 1962 season this Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk spent more than four hours today in a joint session of two Senate committees as the Administration and Congress sought agreement on a policy on Cuba.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17-- Finance ministers from around the world met here today for a double dialogue.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 17--The Democratic State Convention opened its campaign against the Rockefeller administration today by shouting its approval of an amended 5,000-word platform.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17-- Former President Harry S. Truman declared today that this nation would never sacrifice freedom for survival.
Cotton futures were 20 cents off to 40 cents a bale up yesterday.

MILAN, Italy, Sept. 17--A prizefight here Friday night and a car race at nearby Monza yesterday had little in common except for the behavior of ticket-takers and the behavior of fans--both fans with tickets and fans without.

GENEVA, Sept. 17--Swiss designers and craftsmen have unveiled their latest creations at the annual Watches and Jewels Exhibition, Geneva's counterpart of a Paris fashion show. There are no parades of alluring models to capture attention, but, none are needed to set off the sparkle of the dazzling array in the showcases at the Museum of Art and History.
The Ford Foundation has issued a report on its aims, operations and finances that tends to reply to recent charges made against it and other large foundations.
DETROIT, Sept. 17 (AP)-- Automobile dealers may have slightly fewer leftover models in stock when the new cars go on sale this year than they did last September at the start of the 1962 model year.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 17-- No betting odds on the outcome of the America's Cup match have been circulated here, officially or unofficially.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 17An Executive order has been prepared for President Kennedy's signature enabling him to fulfill his 1960 campaign pledge to end racial discrimination in federally assisted housing.

A two-for-one split of the common stock of the Detroit Edison Company was proposed yesterday by company directors. The move is subject to the approval of shareholders at a special meeting to be held Nov. 19 and of the Michigan Public Service Commission.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17The Justice Department filed its first suit today to end racial segregation in public schools receiving Federal financial aid.

The American Society of Travel Agents offered free retraining, yesterday to "several thousand" airline sales and traffic personnel thrown out of work recently by strikes, automation of sales procedures or management changes.

THE 3-year-old was a bright, active child. Until the family moved into a new apartment, his parents had no idea that any thing was amiss. But in the new apartment, and in the playground downstairs, the child was continually bumping into things and "snubbing" the other children.

VALENCIA, Spain, Sept.17-- Generalissimo Francisco Franco described his regime today as an "authentic democracy" bent on solving the nation's development problems with the collaboration of all Spaniards.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 17-- President Kennedy swam, cruised and worked today, the third day of his extended weekend.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Sept. 17.--A company of paratroopers is expected to arrive here tomorrom from Northern Rhodesia and there is speculation that they may be used to help quell the upsurge of sabotage and violence in Southern Rhodesia.
Teamsters who deliver general goods in the city overwhelmingly rejected a management contract proposal last night and authorized their union executive board to call a strike.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 17 (UPI) --Jim Piersall of the Washington Senators was reduced to tears today when he won dismissal of a disorderly conduct charge lodged after he climbed into the stands at Memorial Stadium last Thursday night to challenge a heckling fan.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 17. Nine 2-year-old trotters will start in quest of the season's richest offering for standardbreds of this age and gait, $77,349.72, in the Westbury Futurity tomorrow night at Roosevelt Raceway. The distance will be one mile, twice around the half-mile oval.
LONDON, Sept. 17--Prime Minister Macmillan warned Commonwealth leaders today that it might not be possible for Britain to continue trade preferences if she did not join the Common Market.

The nine new United States astronauts who were introduced to the country yesterday are an impressive group in terms of the physical, mental and educational qualifications they have had to meet. Together with the Mercury astronauts who were selected in April, 1959, these new men will form the team on which this country is counting for advanced exploits in space.
Dr. Armitage Whitman, an orthopedic surgeon, died of cancer Friday at his home at 433 East 51st Street. He was 75 years old.
Articles by Chancellor Adenauer and the Earl of Avon, formerly Anthony Eden, highlight the 40th-anniversary issue of Foreign Affairs, which appears today.

JUDGING from manufacturers' reaction to the location of our new store on West 86th Street, just off Broadway, one would think we were opening in a jungle," Mrs. Malcolm Kandel remarked in a recent interview.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 17 (AP)--The International Amateur Athletic Federation indirectly branded the new United States Track and Field Federation today as an outlaw group.

Rose Net of the Foxcataher Farms won the $23,350 Roseben Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Rose Net's victory, however, was hardly as surprising as the performance turned in by Beau Purple, who was established as the strong favorite by his backers in the crowd of 28,045. Beau Purple, finished last among the eight contestants in the 20th running of the sevenfurlong race.

IF you want to see an exciting exhibition of some of the most dazzling ballet technique in the world, hurry down to the Metropolitan Opera House and watch the Bolshoi Ballet in "Ballet School." Even if you think you don't want to do it anyway, for you'll never regret it.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 17--Nations of the Middle East will have more to eat and more to export this year than they did last year.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 17 (AP)--The International Amateur Athletic Federation approved today, for the first time, a world pole vault record set with a fiber-glass pole. In effect, this meant acceptance of the pole itself.

The American Express Company has contracted to sell the 10-story office building at 61 Hudson Street that it has owned and occupied for more than 100 years. The property is being bought by Allan Haymes, realty investor and builder.
The competition among American agencies for international advertising accounts is fast picking up in intensity.

A Columbia University study says former President Dwight D. Eisenhower played "a much more active role" in originating various aspects of his Administration's defense policy than had generally been believed.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17--As if the Windy City weren't plagued enough by coattail-flapping breezes, irresistible currents of hot air today roared with hurricane velocity through the downtown offices of the Illinois State Athletic Commission.

THE Midtown Turf, Yachting and Polo Association, a bonded brigade of outdoor eccentrics, held its annual convulsion Saturday on the Winchester Gun Club ranch in Seymour, Conn. This is formally titled the annual George Fremault Memorial Shoot, It is held to raise money for Ducks Unlimited and have a good time in memory of deceased members.
Sales and earnings of Genesco, Inc., international manufacturer and retailer of apparel and footwear, established new highs in the fiscal year ended July 31, the company reported.
The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Reserve System announced yesterday a joint study of those bank loans in which stocks and bonds are used as collateral.

Mrs. Charles A. Dana Jr., executive chairman for the third annual Preview Party of the Decoration and Design Show, has announced the names of men and women who have joined the general and junior committees for the event.

BOSTON, Sept. 17--Edward J. McCormack and Edward M. Kennedy, two tired and nervous young men, moved doggedly through the traditional routines of Boston politics today as they ended their campaigns for the Democratic nomination to the United States Senate.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17-An all-Democratic farm bill was reported to Congress today by a Senate-House conference committee. It is certain to set off another major floor fight in the House.

A state inquiry into complaints of abuses in criminal courts opened its headquarters at 80 Centre Street yesterday, with a special counsel and an assistant busily scheduling appointments for experts and persons making complaints.
The Board of Education has been asked to approve the paymeat of $74,235 for architectural plans it will not use.
Steel production turned upward last week, gaining 2.5 per cent from the level of the preceding seven days.

The final fight is now being made to save the western end of the Rockaway Peninsula from a mammoth apartment house development. It is actually five minutes after midnight on this battle to outrace the bulldozer, because initial construction has already begun. But there is still a desperate hope that if public opinion became sufficiently aroused, this area could be saved and become one of the finest beach parks anywhere.

Following the abolition by the Soviet Union of the office of the commandant of the Soviet garrison in Berlin, the Governments of the United States. Britain and France, on Aug. 24, issued a statement, pretending that Berlin remains under the administration of the four powers and that the power's of the quadripartite allied Kommandatura remain in force there.
PARIS, Sept. 17--A French Air Force engineer has admitted to being the leader of the plot to assassinate President de Gaulle Aug. 22, the police announced tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- House-Senate conferees reached agreement today on a $2,350,000,000 college aid bill, a Kennedy "priority."
Discrimination in granting leases in an apartment house in the Riverdale section of the Bronx was permanently enjoined yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Gavagan.
The Union Pacific Railroad has joined the merger studies between the Southern Pacific Company and the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific railroads, it was announced yesterday.
PARIS, Sept. 17--Michel Siffre was removed today from the cave in southern France where the spent the last two months in isolation about 400 feet underground.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 17--Moise Tshombe, President of Katanga Province, said tonight that the Congolese Army had been ordered to make a "general attack" against Katangese troops.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept, 17-- President Kennedy asked the Chicago North Western Railway and the striking railway telegraphers tonight to submit the unresolved issues in their dispute to the binding arbitration of a special panel.
The American Federation of Television and Radio Artists said yesterday that educational television station WNDT had adopted "anti-labor tactics."

THE Hollywood reserve of journalists and lawyers has been called up for extended duty in the new television season. The initial flurry of network premieres in the elastic category of weekly filmed drama discloses expanded reliance on reporters and barristers to take care of problems not susceptible of instant brain surgery.

The Municipal Garage in Kew Gardens, Queens, the fourth in the Department of Traffic's offstreet parking program, is expected to be opened by the end of this month but without the planned parking meters.
Irwin Vincent Powell, a Wall Street stock salesman, was arrested yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation after an eight-month search.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP)-- Grain futures were under stiff selling pressure most of the time today with September soybeans losing abdut five cents a bushel. The feed grains showed a little rallying tendency in late dealings and closed narrowly mixed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17--Senator Humphrey of Minnesota, an established foreign affairs spokesman of the Administration in Congress, has for the first time put on the public record a candid admission that President Kennedy has set limits to the historic thrust of the Monroe Doctrine.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 17 (AP) --The Milwaukee Braves beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 2--1, tonight on Warren Spahn's five-hit pitching.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17--A shaky truce was reported today in the threatened Negro boycott of the Emancipation Proclamation centennial observance to be held next Saturday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 27--A Soviet source said today that the accusations of spying by the United States against two Russian employes of the United Nations secretariat was an attempt to shift attention from the latest incidents involving U-2 reconnaissance planes.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 17-U Thant, Acting Secretary General, said today that he would decide next month whether to make himself "available" for re-election.

SYRACUSE, Tuesday, Sept.18 --Robert M. Morgenthau won the nomination for Governor at 4 A.M. today on the second ballot at a turbulent Democratic State Convention that threatened to get out of control several times.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17-- An exhibition showing the cultural development of the American continent before the arrival of the Spaniards in the 15th and 16th centuries opened tonight at the Museum of Natural History of the Smithsonian Institution.
J. Truman Bidwell, who resigned as chairman of the board of the New York Stock Exchange when he was indicted for income-tax evasion last February, went on trial yesterday in Federal Court.

The Board of Education was the target yesterday of a sit-in by a group of Brooklyn parents and children who threatened to stay until they were promised that 16 students would be placed in better-integrated schools.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Sept. 17--President Francois Duvalier has assumed direct control of Haiti's economy.

Government securities prices moved up slightly yesterday in limited trading. Corporates were unchanged. Outstanding state and municipal obligations held firm in moderate trading, although recent issues continued to move slowly out of syndicate.

The Albemarle Paper Manufacturing Company, a relatively small paper company, surprised the business world yesterday by announcing that it was negotiating to acquire the Ethyl Corporation, a leading producer of anti-knock compounds for gasolines.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 17-- Clearing weather and northwest breezes of 15 to 25 knots were predicted today for tomorrow's second race of the America's Cup match between the United States defender Weatherly and the Australian challenger Gretel.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept 17--Diplomats and United Nations officials joined today in honoring Dag Hammarskjold, the Secretary General who was killed Sept. 18, 1961.
Growth stocks, are a twoway street--fast up, fast down. Lately Standard Poor's Corporation has been making a number of changes each month in its list of 200 rapid growth stocks.

TURNING the spotlight away from spectacular Russian achievements in space, William B. Murphy, president of the Campbell Soup Company, said yesterday that the Communist countries have failed to provide their people with adequate food.

The Democratic party in New York has chosen well in nominating former United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau for Governor to run against Nelson A. Rockefeller. He is an intelligent, well-informed, high-principled young man. He stood out among the several available candidates.

The International Development Association announced yesterday its first credit for an education project. The affiliate of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) advanced $5,000,000 to Tunisia for secondary and technical school construction.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 17--An increase in coronary thrombosig, arteriosclerosis and diabetes in Israel within the next twenty years was forecast here today by an authority on public health.
The curtain will rise this week on a new theater season in which the musical trend is up, theater parties are slightly down and the British influence is continuing.
IF William Snyder could sustain a play on the level of his best scenes in "The Days and Nights of Beebee Fenstermaker," he would be a new playwright to acclaim.

A compact radio transceiver, no larger than a pack of kingsize cigarettes, has been developed by the Communications Systems Division of ITT Kellogg, a division of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.
Monros H. Heyward, an international lawyer and a New Deal Democratic leader here, died of a heart attack Sunday in his home at 65 East 96th, Street. He was 52 years old.
RIO de JANEIRO, Sept. 17 --President Joao Goulart picked a moderate Socialist law professor today as Brazil's new Premier.

Camilo Egas, painter, and since 1932 director of the art workshops of the New School for Social Research, died yesterday of cancer in Montefiore Hospital, the Bronx. He was 62 years old and lived at 248 West 14th Street.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 18-- Four United States Air Force officers narrowly escaped injury today when a Vietnamese youth riding by on a bicycle threw a grenade hidden in a loaf of bread into their parked car.
Delaware borrowed $19,715,000 in the bond market yesterday on 2.80 per cent various purpose obligations due 1963-82.
MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 18-- The Government is expected to authorize a research project shortly to test what type of training best helps unemployed workers get and hold new jobs.
HALIFAX, N.S., Sept. 14--The apple orchards of Nova Scotia's Annapolis Valley, facing ruin in the early postwar years, have been revitalized by long-term tree renewal.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- Legislation to increase postal rates and Government pay has run into further delay because of the dispute over Communist propaganda.

Two ship officer unions have asked for assistance from the merged labor movement to combat what spokesmen for the unions yesterday called a raid by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters on inland waterway workers.

The M.A. Hanna Company, a huge industrial complex that George M. Humphrey, former Secretary of the Treasury, helped to build, has acquired 250,000 shares, or 6 per cent of the stock, of J. Ray McDermott Co., a large oil industry supplier, it was announced yesterday.

THE General Assembly of the United Nations chose yesterday as its president one of the outstanding prospects for the post--Muhammad Zafrulla Khan, a slender quietvoiced Pakistani of 69 years with a close-cropped light beard and an unshakable air of quiet courtesy.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 18 --Dr. Bertrand Klass of 285 Club Road, executive vice president of Forbes Research, Inc., of New York, died today in St. Joseph's Hospital after suffering a heart attack at his home. He was 38 years old.
BUFFALO, Sept. 18--The Republicans opened their state convention here today with a cast of familiar faces and a well-rehearsed script. At the first night session, after...
A ten-year campaign to raise $14,257,000 for a capital modernization and improvement program was announced yesterday by the Young Men's Christian Association of Greater New York.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 --The sixth Tiros meteorological satellite was shot to orbit today. Within a few hours it was transmitting unusually clear pictures that were incorporated into weather forecasts for the Northern Hemisphere.

Two groups of trial lawyers who practice in the criminal courts added their arguments yesterday to the growing protest against New York's longer court day. They asked for half an hour's relief from the new requirement.

The Brazilian genius for muddling through crises, postponing decisions, compromising and avoiding revolutions and civil wars has again been demonstrated. While the congressional elections will be held on Oct. 7, as scheduled, it is now agreed that the plebiscite over a return to strong presidential powers is to be put off to Jan. 6.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Eugene R. Black, president of the International Bank of Reconstruction and Development, made a farewell appeal today for countries to pool more of their foreign aid efforts.

An overnight sit-in by a group of Brooklyn Negro parents and children at the Board of Education ended at noon yesterday with the demonstrators claiming victory and the board denying that any concessions had been granted.

The tax-evasion trial of J. Truman Bidwell, former board chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, centered yesterday in United States District Court on the person who handled many of his daily affairs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18--Every year the Administration's foreign aid gets in more trouble. The House Appropriations Committee has now cut President Kennedy's request by over $1,124,000,000--the deepest slash in the 15 years of the program--and it is important to analyze why.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 18-- Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr., who had been letting George O'Day do the speaking for Weatherly, spoke for himself tonight.

PARIS, Sept. 18--Carry Back, the horse that receives as much man as a film star even thougn he still can't read without moving his lips, successfully invaded France this morning. His private Pan American cargo DC 7 landed at Orly Airport at 8:15 Paris time.

BERTOLT BRECHT wrote "Man Is Man" almost 40 years ago and made one of his many revisions less than 10 years ago. In the first or last version it remains a modern morality, shading from deceptive simplicity into a bitterly ironic commentary on how the name and character of a man can be reshaped.

Second-quarter net income of Rollins Broadcasting, Inc., will rise slightly, according to O. Wayne Rollins, president. Earnings in the period ended October, 1961, totaled $144,731, or 15 cents a share.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP)--Gemini, a two--seater spacecraft, is scheduled to carry two men into earth orbit for 14 days, maneuver, find and dock with another spacecraft, and train men for the critical stage of the trip to the moon.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The Administration is quietly seeking to head off a possible stalemate on legislation tightening up the drug laws.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 18 --Castleton Farm's consistent Speedy Scot gained the richest prize of his young career and one of his easiest victories before 18,545 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight in the third edition of the $77,349 Westbury Futurity.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP)--The Senate sent to President Kennedy today the long-debated authorization for constructing the world's largest atomic electric-power plant at Hanford, Wash.
A Polish immigrant who arrived penniless in the United States in 1939 and with less than a high school education gave $2,000,000 yesterday to Yeshiva University for its Graduate School of Science.
The following listing includes events that have been selected by New York Times critics. For children of all ages, unless otherwise noted.
JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 18-- Legislators cheered today as Gov. Ross R. Barnett pledged to remain "steadfast" in his efforts to block desegregation of the University of Mississippi.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 18--There was almost as much going on outside the United Nations today as inside.

ACCRA, Ghana, Sept. 18 -- The United States Ambassador, William P. Mahoney Jr., declared today that "unfounded charges and distortions" about the United States in the Ghanaian press should cease in the best interests of GhanaianAmerican relations.
BERLIN, Sept. 18--The West Berlin city government disclosed today that 29 East German men, women and children escaped to West Berlin through a tunnel Friday night.
A new process to make glass articles up to five times stronger than ever possible in the past was announced yesterday by the Corning Glass Works.

Into his legal career Mr. Donovan has crammed a variety of work, from straightening out involved legal tangles for big insurance companies to assignments tinged with adventure in international relations.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- A foreign aid cut of $1,124,400,000 was sent to the House of Representatives today by its Appropriations Committee.
The B.V.D. Company, Inc., manufacturer of men's and boys' attire since 1876, is entering the women's undergarment and bathing suit field through the acquisition of Flexees International, Inc.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 18 (UPI)--The Milwaukee Braves handed the Dodgers their third consecutive loss tonight in a 10-5 extra-base slugfest.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- Net working capital of United States corporations, excluding banks and insurance companies, rose by $2,200,000,000 in the second quarter of 1962, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

BUENOS AIRES, Wednesday, Sept. 19--The Cavalry Corps and Argentina's largest military garrison rebelled last night against the army high command. The rebels said early today that support for their cause was growing throughout the country.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18-- The Federal Government's antitrust suit against the Music Corporation of America ended today in a settlement of great significance to the nation's movie, television and record industries.

The bond markets showed new strength yesterday. Government issues were up slightly on moderate demand. Corporates benefited from good pension-fund buying of several recent issues still in syndicate. Municipals were active and firm despite strong bidding for new issues.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP)--The Surgeon General of the Public Health Service said today that "I don't believe there is any reason in the world for complete abandonment of plans for mass community immunizations of children with oral polio vaccine."
This year's Angels Ball, a dinner dance sponsored by the New York Section, National Council of Jewish Women, will take place at the Astor on Nov. 14.
Convictions and guilty pleas in narcotics cases have dropped nearly 40 per cent in New York County since a landmark decision of the United States Supreme Court in June, 1961.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 18-- Gretel, the Australian challlenger, defeated the United States defender, Weatherly, by 47 seconds today in the second race of the America's Cup yachting series. The victory was the first by a challenger in 14 cup races since 1934.

IT is clear that a classic Greek drama, such as Saphocles's "Antigone," staged and performed before the camera in a stiff, solemn classical style by a company of modern Greek actors speaking modern Greek is not likely to bring the American public stampeding into a theater; no matter how beautifully staged and acted and sonorously spoken it is. To most of us, this kind of drama and projection is so much Greek.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 18--Following is the acceptance speech delivered tonight to the Democratic State Convention by Robert M. Morgenthau, the nominee for Governor.
Last night was senior citizens' night at the Polo Grounds. Anyone 62 years of age or more was admitted for 50 cents, and he didn't have to prove his age, either.
The Symphony of the Air, led by Alfred Wallenstein, will give 10 subscription concerts at Carnegie Hall this season. Seven will be devoted to the music of Brahms.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- Mickey Mantle, apparently tired of the way the Yankees have been dawdling on the pennant trail of late, tonight took matters into his own hands. Exploding two homers, the Switcher drove in five runs as Ralph Houk's Bombers defeated the Senators, 7 to 1, before a crowd of 16,824.

PARIS, Sept. 18--As American tourists in Western Europe continued to scurry for home, the dollar rose "off the floor" this week against the Italian lira--the culminating symbol of the calm now reigning in the world's foreign exchange markets and the steadier situation of the dollar.
The Democratic voters of Massachusetts have evidently decided that if a man has the right connections, those are all the qualifications necessary for nomination to the United States Senate.
Federal mediators withdrew yesterday from the deadlocked negotiations between dockworkers and the steamship industry for a new contract to replace the one that expires Sept. 30.
Can art be advertised and mass-merchandised much as any other product?

Next Monday 92 of the world's airlines, most of them haunted by a financially disastrous 1961, will begin the grueling business of deciding whether fares and cargo rates should go up, down, or stay where they are.
The threat of a proxy fight for control of Fanny Farmer Candy Shops, Inc., moved a step closer to actuality yesterday. A group of four investors have filed form 14A's...

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 18 (AP)--Jim Bunning pitched the Detroit Tigers to a 2-1 victory over the Minnesota Twins today. The loss snapped a four-game Twins' winning streak and tightened the noose on Minnesota's pennant hopes.
CASSVILLE, N.J., Sept. 18 ---A massive, gilded Novgorod cupola was hoisted 110 feet to the peak of St. Vladimir's Church today.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18-- Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon called today for a quarantine of Cuba to halt the flow of Soviet arms.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 18-- The diggers have done it. For the first time since Sir Thomas Sopwith's first Endeavour won the first two races in 1934, an America's Cup challenger has won a race. Jock Sturrock, at the helm of the Royal Sydney Yacht Squadron's challenger, Gretel, beat Bus Mosbacher in the defender, Weatherly, by 47 seconds.
The arrival of "Banderol" on Oct. 9 at the Music Box was canceled yesterday.

BOSTON, Wednesday, Sept. 19 --Edward M. Kennedy, the 30year-old brother of the President, won a landslide victory over Edward J. McCormack Jr. yesterday in the Massachusetts Democratic Senatorial primary.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 18-- City and Westchester County officials asked the state today to speed the $100,000,000 redevelopment of downtown White Plains by building an eight-lane feeder road from the CrossWestchester Expressway into the center of the business area.
FOR some reason many people who like the outdoors feel an irresistible compulsion to write books about their erperiences, fish and animal life, and the paraphernalia connected with field sports.
Musical Courier, founded in 1880 and the oldest musical periodical in America, will go out of existence with the publication of its October issue.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The rate of new home construction, an indicator of economic activity to come, went up in August.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 18--Robert M. Morgenthau called on the Democratic party faithful tonight to join him in a "fighting campaign" to oust Governor Rockefeller from office.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- The Senate brought the Administration's foreign trade bill to the point of passage tonight after defeating a series of restrictive amendments.
Sales and earnings of Hayes Industries, Inc., in the fiscal year ended July 31 were the largest since World War II, the report disclosed yesterday.

THE Whitney Museum of American Art opens its season today with a doublebarreled show, one barrel discharging with a satisfactory bang in contrast with its partner's rather sugary fizzle. The exhibitions are respectively "American Prints Today" and "Arthur B. Davies (1862-1928), A Centennial Exhibition."
THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Sept. 18--Queen Juliana said today that the Netherlands Government "would welcome any improvement in relations with Indonesia."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP)--The first proceeding to require a member of the Communist party to register with the Attorney General ended today.
International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., announced yesterday in Toronto that it was cutting its nickel and copper production by about 15 per cent in the fourth quarter.

The directors of the Rochester Button Company declared yesterday a stock dividend of 5 per cent, in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock. Both are payable Oct. 16 to holders of record Oct. 5. Instead of fractional shares, a cash payment will be made, the. company announced.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 18-- Greater love hath no sailor than to leave an America's Cup race to go vote for his brother.

KONNERSREUTH, Germany, Sept. 18 (AP)--Therese Neumann, who was said to bear the wounds of the crucified Christ on her body and to have bled from them on many Fridays since 1926, died of a heart ailment today. She was 64 years old.
PARAMUS, N.J., Sept. 18-- The Playhouse on the Mall, the first year-round legitimate theater in a United States shopping center, opened tonight at the Bergen Mall here.
HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Sept. 18 --The National Lead Company officially opened its Hightsstown Laboratories today on a 250-acre site adjacent to the New Jersey Turnpike.

VARNA, Bulgaria, Sept. 18 --The Spanish team leads the Soviet team in Section A of the preliminaries of the Chess Olympits here, after the first two rounds of play. The score for Spain so far is 5 - , for the Soviet Union 5-1, for Belgium 5-2.
NEW bride club will open tonight, the Madi son Duplicate Bridge Club at 24 West 57th Street.

Superior Oil Company, which bears a very superior price as stocks go, caught some tapereaders' attention yesterday when it opened with a trade of 10 shares, followed by 20 shares and then by 200, at a price of 860. The stock has not been as active as that at the opening for about four years. By day's end the volume was 430 shares and the closing price was 862, up 4.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- Dr. William Weber Coblentz, a physicist who pioneered in the measurement of heat and light, died Saturday in George Washington Hospital after a long illness. He was 88 years old.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 18 --A military tribunal sentenced thirty-four persons to death today on charges that they had taken part in an attempt to overthrow the Lebanese Government last New Year's Eve.

LONDON, Sept. 18--The leaders of the Commonwealth countries failed to agree today on the form and content of a communique giving their positions on Britain's proposed membership in the European Economic Community.
CLVELAND, Sept. 18--James B. Carey won the first round today in his dispute with Al Hartnett at the convention of the International Union of Electrical Workers here.
The National Foundation re-- ported yesterday that "superior medical attention" was not yet available to most victims of birth defects and arthritis.
Mrs. John F. Kennedy will fly to New York tomorrow to make a pre-opening inspection of Philharmonic Hall, although she will be unable to attend its official opening on Sunday.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Sept. 18--Len Watters, who will be rounding out 40 years of high school and college football coaching this fall, thinks this could be one of his finest seasons.
The stock market followed a zigzag pattern yesterday and ended on the down side in active trading.
Although he had to go a little wide on the turn into the stretch, Black Beard of the Darby Dan Farm won the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday by a length.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 18-- Nationalist China emphasized today that it was determined to carry out an armed return to the mainland "no matter what people in foreign countries may think."

The Supreme Court of the State of New York is the highest trial court before which comes every conceivable type of action--from the determination of property rights to matrimonial relationships. NEW CITY, N.Y., Sept. 18 --Rockland County's Park Commission has agreed to buy 352 acres in Ramapo for the first large county park installation.

WHEN the San Francisco 49ers clobbered the New York Giants, 42-10, in an exhibition game a month ago, sympathetic words were offered by Allie Sherman, the young but prescient coach of the losers. He didn't waste them on his bat tered heroes. He tossed them in another direction.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 18--New York Democrats did bruising battle until 4 A.M. today before nominating Robert M. Morgenthau for Governor on the second ballot.

Leaders of the new Conservative party are "very confident" of gaining a place on the New York state ballot for the election Nov. 6, the party's state chairman, J. Daniel Mahoney, said yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 18--Three new nations took their places today in a chamber already packed from mural to mural. But delegates from a fourth nation failed to show up in time to claim their seats in the General Assembly.

WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., where American automo bile road racing was reborn in 1948, will conduct its 15th annual sports car Grand Prix on Friday and Saturday.

Charles L. Patterson, chairman of the Transit Authority, conceded yesterday that some of his high hopes for automated subway operations had been dashed by an eight-month experiment with a driverless shuttle train.

WESTAMPTON BEACH, L. I., Sept. 18--Col. Roy E. Ferguson, 45-year-old commander of the Suffolk County Air Force Base here, crashed into the Atlantic Ocean off Montauk Point today while piloting a supersonic jet interceptor on a training mission.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 18--The Democratic State Convention made political history tonight by nominating a Negro for Attorney General, a key policymaking and administrative office.
PINEHURST, N.C., Sept. 18 --Deane Beman, a pre-tourney favorite, made a successful 1962 debut today in the United States Amateur championship.
Unusually high fines totaling $2,000 were imposed in two cases in Criminal Court yesterday. One involved a going-outof-business sale and the other, misleading advertising.

MRS. ERWIN J. SMORGOR of South Bend, Ind., proved yesterday that winning the 14th Pillsbury Grand National BakeOff was as easy as apple pie. Her winning "Apple Pie '63" entry netted her a $25,000 check and a handshake from Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower. The former First Lady made the presentation at a luncheon held yesterday in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
A high-speed craft that will ride over land and water on a cushion of air will be tested, starting a year from now, as a means of access to all parts of the 4,900-acre Idlewild Airport.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept, 18 --The Rev. Dr. Robbins Wolcott Barstow, Congregational minster and former executive director of the Department of Overseas Union Churches, died yesterday in Stamford Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 13 Hamilton Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- The National Education Association called on Congress today to kill the Senate-House compromise on the higher education bill.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 18 --Hofstra's leading quarterback, Len Garille, is at his best when executing a pass play. But he hasn't satisfied his coaches on his selection of plays in the huddle.

Marrow, former chairman of New York City's Commission on Intergroup Relations, looks at today's racial religious and cultural tensions in his newest book, "Changing Patterns of Prejudice." BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 18--Thailand has not yet decided whether to bring the subject of worsening Thai-Cambodian relations before the United Nations General Assembly or the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization, Foreign Minister Thanat Khoman said today.

Harry Koler, "host" to the cigar smokers of the entertainment business since he retired from vaudeville and burlesque roles thirty years ago, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 80 years old.

The Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., issued an interim report yesterday showing it sustained a net loss of $818,348 in the first half of 1962. This compared with a net loss of $508,350 in the like 1961 period.

Railroad travel last year was 22 times as safe as travel by private automobile, participants at the annual presentation of the E. H, Harriman Memorial Awards for railroad safety were told here last night. The presentations were made at the Roosevelt Hotel.
ALGIERS, Sept. 19--Ahmed Ben Bella, leader of the de facto Government, appealed tonight to Algerians to go to polls "en masse" tomorrow for independent Algeria's first elections.
HAVANA, Sept. 19 (AP)-- The Armed Forces Ministry charged today that United States aircraft violated Cuban airspace yesterday, asserting it was the 163d time since July 1.
ADEN, Sept. 19--The ruler of Yemen, Imam Ahmad, a bearded feudal monarch, was reported dead today at the age of 71. The Imam died of natural causes hastened by old wounds and chronic ailments.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 19 (UPI) --Harmon Killebrew's 41st and 42d homers and Vic Power's grand-slam homer led the Minnesota Twins to a 12-5 victory over the Detroit Tigers today.
Electric power production in the country totaled 16,837,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended Sept. 15, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.

Next only to beating off the Soviet triumvirate plan for wrecking the United Nations, the most urgent task facing the General Assembly is to solve two related problems affecting the future capability of the United Nations to carry out the Charter. These problems are the Congo and the financial crisis caused by the refusal of Soviet Russia, France and other members to pay their assessments for the Congo and similar operations.

The fiftieth anniversary of the famous Armory Show of 1913 is to be commemorated in an exhibition at its original site, the 69th Regiment Armory at Lexington Avenue and 25th Street. The opening date of the exhibition has been tentatively set for April 12.

Servel, Inc., producers of dry cell batteries for flashlights, radios, hearing aids and other devices, is seeking control of the Sonotone Corporation, manufacturers of transistor hearing aids, nickel-cadmium batteries, and electronic components.
"The champ is back in form" was the essence of the crowd reaction at Aqueduct yesterday after Mrs. Richard du Pont's Kelso won the Stymie Handicap.

National Airlines and Pan American World Airways are negotiating for a re-exchange of large blocks of stock that the two airlines exchanged in 1958, Lewis B. Maytag Jr., president of National, said yesterday.
The American Hull Insurance Syndicate had a bad, if not unprofitable, year during 1961, the International Union of Marine Insurance was informed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19-- Caroline Kennedy's nursery school at the White House will be desegregated this fall.
The General Cable Corporation has elected Donald P. Kircher a director, it was announced yesterday.

The directors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company authorized yesterday the sale of $250,000,000 of 34year debentures. The company will use the proceeds for expansion of Bell System services.
The National Association of Manufacturers announced yesterday the election of Werner P. Gullander as its first fulltime president. He will assume his post on Nov. 1.

A Bronx man shot and killed his brother and then killed himself yesterday after being wounded twice by two patrolmen.
E. F. MacDonald Company, distributor of Plaid trading stamps, is negotiating to acquire Ross Products, Inc., a large smallware importing concern.

ALLEN DRURY won a Pulitzer Prize two years ago for his fiery and controversial novel, "Advise and Consent." The laurels should be shared by his sequel, "A Shade of Difference,"* since it continues the sweeping story of our country's entangled yet magnificent destiny.
PARIS, Sept. 19--President de Gaulle brought a more than hesitant Cabinet into line today behind his plan to strengthen the Presidency by popular election.

LONDON, Sept. 19--Despite their doubts and anxieties, the leaders of the Commonwealth agreed today that they would not stand in Britain's way if she chose to join the European Economic Community.
WIESBADEN, Germany. Sept. 19 (AP) -- The West German surplus of exports over imports continued to shrink last month, the Federal Statistics Office announced here today.

The city's 734 Civil Defense warning sirens will be tested today at 11 A. M. Robert E. Condon, director of city Civil Defense, said the public would not participate, but urged that everyone learn the meaning of the signals.
Union teamsters and their employers renewed negotiations yesterday in an effort to avert a threatened strike that would curtail deliveries of general merchandise in the city.
Directors of the Raytheon Company yesterday elected Thomas G. Lanphier Jr. to the newly created post of vice president for corporate planning of the country's largest electronics producer.

A leader of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People who has been a center of controversy in a House inquiry into the garment industry has resigned as a special Congressional consultant.

Dr. Ben-Henry Rose of Miami Beach, Fla., who retired five years ago as a general surgeon in the Bronx, died of a heart attack Sunday on a tour in Sligo, Ireland. His age was 65.

The educational beacon that station WNDT seeks to establish in television's "vast wasteland" has been blacked out by the strike of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists. The station's premiere on Channel 13 provided a tempting sample of the cultural contribution it can make. It also indicated how much development is still needed to assure full realization of WNDT's promise.

The Board of Education rejected the contention of a group of Negro parents in Queens yesterday that their children had been improperly excluded from a Jackson Heights junior high school.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19A French labor relations specialist offered steamship operators and longshoremen today a way to avert a threatened strike on Sept. 30 at this and other ports along the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts.

Chris Vames, owner of the Hamilton House and Colony House Restaurants in Brooklyn, died Tuesday at the Fall Kirk Hospital in Central Valley, N. Y. His age was 58. He lived at 9801 Shore Road, Brooklyn, and in Blooming Grove, N. Y.
The Ryan Aeronautical Company continued to purchase stock in the Continental Motors Corporation during August, the New York Stock Exchange "insider" reports showed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19--President Kennedy warned today that the $1,124,000,000 cut in his foreign aid program by the House Appropriations Committee posed "a threat to free world security." He demanded that the funds be restored.

The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, arrived here yesterday to address five church rallies on the fight for civil rights.

The short-interest position on the New York Stock Exchange declined to 5,358,450 shares as of Sept. 14, from 5,400,104 on Aug. 15, the highest level this year. This represents the first month's decline since a rising short-interest position began with 3,119,209 shares on March 15.

Frank V. Rigler, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Rigler of Annapolis, has been announced by the future bride's parents.

WASHINGTON, Sept.19 (AP) --The American Red Cross announced today that Communist China had given permission for Mrs. Ruth Redmond of Yonkers, N. Y., to make another visit to her son, held there as a prisoner.

FLORAL PARK, L.I., Sept. 20 Miss Nancy Lee Fletcher and Robert Alan Graham plan to be married in November.
