SHOPPERS this weekend may derive some comfort from the fact that there have been no further increases in red meat prices. However, the comfort becomes short indeed when current prices are compared to those of a year ago. Low receipts, due mainly to livestock withholdings by farmers, mean that most cuts are up from 4 to 20 cents a pound.
STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 20 If Western Europe is to have a stable and prosperous coal industry, the present production level will have to be cut in the next ten years.
Production of lumber in the country totaled 224,787,000 board feet in the week ended Sept. 15, according to reports received yesterday from region lumber associations.
CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP) Soybean futures reacted to reports of probable frost damage today, and prices rose in active dealings on the Board of Trade. The grains were steady to strong.
Plastic buttons and bookmarks by the thousands, all with a three-headed giraffe, are being passed among schoolchildren here in a campaign to sell them on protecting themselves from traffic dangers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. drew cheers mixed with laughter today when he appeared in the House after a long absence to vote on the college-aid bill.
Grayson-Robinson Stores, Inc., proposed the sale of its wholly owned leased camera department subsidiaries yesterday to one concern and met with a second offer for the same properties.
Mayor Wagner and Repre sentative Charles A. Buckley reached an agreement through intermediaries yesterday on a state of five candidates for $34,500-a-year places on the State Supreme Court.

OTTAWA, Sept. 20 Prime Minister John Diefenbaker returned from the British Commonwealth Prime Ministers' Conference in London today. He was accompanied by President Mohammed Ayub Khan of Pakistan, who is here for a threeday state visit.
FRAMINGHAM, Mass., Sept. 20 (AP) James Riley Hodder, a yachtsman, died Tuesday night at the age of 89.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 20 (AP) Pedro Ramos pitched a five-hitter today from Cleveland as the Indians beat the Kansas City Athletics, 5 2.
THE working woman, be she miss or junior-sized, budget minded or given to minor extravagances, will have a one-stop shop of her own starting Monday at Gimbels. It is called the ...
DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 20 ( AP )-The Government of Premier Khaled el-Azm decided today to dissolve the newly reinstated Parliament.

Eight partners of Coggeshall Hicks, a New York Stock Exchange member firm, and three New Jersey men yesterday notified the Securities and Exchange Commission they intend to wage a proxy fight for control of the Kirby Petroleum Company.
STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 20 The Stamford Bar Association called on Chief Judge Jay E. Rubinow of Connecticut's new Circuit Court today to investigate sentencing in the court.

Stanley R. Becker of Great Neck, L.I., has bought five acres of land on Route 91, a mile north of the Constitution Plaza, redevelopment in Hartford, Conn. He plans an 80-room motor lodge and restaurant to be operated under a Howard Johnson franchise.
Senator Kenneth B. Keating said yesterday that the Kennedy Administration was making a "tremendous error" in calling the Soviet military buildup in Cuba merely defensive.
Lawrence E. Gerosa, former City Controller, announced yesterday that he was supporting Governor Rockefeller for reelection.
Commissioner of Parks Newbold Morris disclosed yesterday that he had denied permission for a Jewish congregation to use a city recreation hall in Queens for High Holy Day services.

Memories spanning thirty years of the modern dance in America were evoked at the New School for Social Research yesterday afternoon at a ceremony dedicating the school's dance studio as the Martha Graham Room.
BERLIN, Sept. 20 The United States Army moved four convoys today on the East German autobahn linking Berlin with West Germany. There was no Russian interference or undue delays.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Rail and truck loadings of freight in the week ended Sept. 15 were up from the preceding week. That period had been affected by the Labor Day holiday.

The state's election frauds bureau said yesterday that a "considerable number" of voting machines in the Democratic primary on Sept. 6 in Queens had lacked the names of two candidates for district leader and co-leader.

Mrs. Charlotte Riegger Cars well of 47 Plaza Street, Brooklyn, widow of State Supreme Court Justice William B. Cars well of the Appellate Division died Wednesday at Caledonian Hospital in Brooklyn. Her age was 64.
NEW CITY, N.Y., Sept. 20--Taxpayers in the North Clarktown area defeated a proposition today to create a new village in Rockland County. The vote was 155 to 105.
IN the opinion of seventy-five qualified historians, Millard Fillmore, the proconsul of Buffalo, ranks above Ulysses Simpson Grant in the gallery of presidents.
Minoru Yamasaki, who designed the highly acclaimed United States Science Pavilion at the Seattle World's Fair, has been named architect for the proposed World Trade Center in lower Manhattan.
A subsidiary of the American Smelting and Refining Company has sued in Mexico to bar enforcement of a recent decree purporting to harm its mining interests there.
The coming season by the New York City Opera, which begins at City Center on Oct. 4, will include debuts by thirteen American singers. Three of them are native New Yorkers.
The Pittsburgh Steel Company has leased tower space for its New York district office in Pan Am Building, 200 Park Avenue. It will move from 405 Lexington Avenue next spring.
THAT furs have reached a point of beauty and versatil ity never dreamed of a decade ago was proven at showings yesterday at Georges Kaplan and Reiss Fabrizio.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 20 Mrs. Lucy Bryant Wallace Porter, the widow of Prof. A. Kingsley Porter, died yesterday at Elmwood, her home. She was 86 years old.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept.20 Weatherly, the New York Yachat Club's defender, defeated Gretel, Australia's challenger, by a mile in the sailing for the America's Cup today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 20 The United States declared today that the world is a "powder keg" and urged the General Assembly to build a stronger United Nations.

THIS is a tale of two pities. Is is a pity the two participants fell from the mundane life as hard as they did. The people concerned have discovered an intriguing sport and now recklessly devote themselves to it with an incandescent vengeance. No names will be used because one protagonist is bigger than I am, and the other is a woman.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20 The 21-nation Steering Committee approved today a United States suggestion that an item calling for discussion of the presence of Soviet troops in Hungary he assigned to Special Political Committee rather than to the General Assembly.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) President Kennedy sign a resolution today granting Congressional consent to the creation of a Delaware River and Bay Authority by New Jersey and Delaware.

WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, Sept. 20 This capital of the Netherlands Antilles is becoming embroiled again in Caribbean politics. Willemstad, a tranquil center of tourism and Dutch trading, has become a relay point for hnudreds of political and technical expeditions to Cuba.

EL PASO, Tex., Sept. 20 (UPI) Federal Judge R.E. Thomason sentenced three former associates of Billie Sol Estes to long prison terms today. He said that they were guilty of "one of the most premediated, fantastic and ruthless frauds ever to come before any court in the Southwest."
Mrs. Adelaide Meara Hammond, the wife of Dr. John Wilkes Hammond, an Orford, N.H., physician, died Wednesday in Mary Hitchcock Memorial Hospital, Hanover, N.H., after a long illness. Her age was 59.
Labor unions are doing a good deal of advertising these days a fact that doubtless would have astonished many of the early leaders of the labor movement.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 20 Santos of Brazil defeated Benfica of Portugal, 3-2, tonight in the first match of the finals of the world professional soccer club championship.

Record revenues and earnings were reported yesterday by Schlumberger, Ltd., and subsidiaries for the six months ended June 30. The company, through subsidiaries, is engaged in the production of instruments and devices for the oil industry and a wide range of electronics.

Milton Thomas sometimes looked like a tall, flapping scarecrow as he conducted the Brandenburg Players in Town Hall last night, but he got excellent results from his small ensemble in a Bach program that was both bracing and beautiful in performance.

The New York Yankees will accept World Series ticket orders by mail only for the three games that will be played at Yankee Stadium if the Yanks win the American League pennant, the club announced yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 20 (AP) Ken Boyer singled home the winning run in the ninth inning tonight as the St. Louis Cardinals dropped the San Francisco Giants four games behind the idle first-place Los Angeles Dodgers by defeating the Giants, 5 4.

A RELATIVE who avoids his responsibilities, wrecks his family's finances, disrupts its life and stays aloof from anyone who tries to act friendly is not likely to be the most popular member of any family.

The Shell Oil Company is expected soon possibly by next week to spin off to its 20,000 stockholders its 50 per cent of the Shell Oil Company of Canada, Ltd., Canada's third largest integrated oil company.

BUDAPEST, Sept. 20 (AP) Gyozo Veres became the first Hungarian ever to win a world weight-lifting title when he defeated Tommy Kono of the United States in a disputemarked duel today for the light-heavyweight title at the world tournament.
MORRIS, N.Y., Sept. 20 Mrs. Anne Franchot Godley, widow of Frederick A. Godley, an architect and educator, died in her home here today. She was 73 years old.
Instead of its usual theater benefit the Pembroke College Club of New York will this year give a cabaret party to raise money for its scholarship fund.

GLEN HEAD, L.I. Sept. 20 Mrs. Walter Cooperstein, Lake Success; Mrs. Melvin Scharf, Glen Oaks, and Mrs. Harry Osterlof, Rockville, combined for a 31, 31 62 to win the Women's Cross Country Golf Association four-ball, best-ball tournament at the Glen Head Country Club today.

Some airline industry officials were puzzled yesterday at the expressed interest of the Studebaker Corporation in acquiring a supplemental, or nonscheduled, airline at a time when non-skeds generally were in a period of upheaval.

AURORA, Ill., Sept. 20 Sonny Liston, who has been billed as the toughest man to hit Chicago since Dillinger it has even been suggested that Liston has no warm spot for Robert Frost actually is a highly sensitive, gentle soul, his manager said today, and efforts were then made to illustrate this point.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Sept. 20 The main African nationalist party in Southern Rhodesia, the Zimbabwe African People's union, was outlawed today.
Robert M.Morgenthau, the Democratic candidate for Gov ernor, formally challenged Governor Rockfeller yesterday to a public debate on campaign issues.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 20 Mr. and Mrs. Alexander N. Levine have announced the engagement of their daughter. Miss Marian Susan Levine to Richard Jay Moses. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. John J. Moses.
The State Commission on Human Rights has reopened its investigation into a charge of discrimination by the international Ladies Garment Workers Union.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The House of Representatives rejected today a compromise bill that would have provided $2,345,000,000 in aid to colleges. The vote was 214 to 186 to
VANCOUVER, B.C., Sept. 20 Bert Olmstead left the New York Rangers' training camp today for his home in Calgary, Alberta, saying he had decided to retire from hockey.
EDGEWATER, N.J., Sept. 2 The State Highway Department is going to do something about the erosion of the Palisades here.

VIENNA, Sept.20 (AP) The United States indicated today it was ready to accept a Soviet offer to step up cooperation on peaceful uses of atomic energy through a sweeping assistance program for underdeveloped countries.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 A resolution endorsing the use of force, if necessary, to prevent the spread of Marxism in the Western Hemisphere was adopted by the Senate today, 86 to 1, after three hours of discusion, Senate today, 86 to 1, after three hours of discussion.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 Mrs. Mary Rutherfoord Johnson Ryan of Mont Tremblant, Que., widow of Joseph B. Ryan, was married this afternoon to Wolcott de W. Robinson of Chestnut Hill.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Sept. 20 -A cargo of sugar bound ford the Soviet Union from Cuba was impounded today by a law firm acting in behalf of the Terri Kane Company of Miami. The cargo is worth $800,000 at current prices.
Oxford, Miss., Sept. 20 Ross R. Barnett denied James H. Meredith, a 29-year old Negro, admission to the University of Mississippi today. In so doing, the Governor defied orders of the Federal courts.

The blockfront on the West side of York Avenue, between 89th and 90th Streets, has been sold by St. Joseph's Orphan Asylum to Frank Levien, a lawyer. It was held at $1,250,000 and was sold through John J. Reynolds, Inc., broker.
LLANDUDNO, Wales, Sept. 20 A roaring Liberal party assembly gave overwhelming endoresment today to Britain's political and economic participation in the European community.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 20 --President Kennedy opened his 1962 Campaigning tonight with a call for a Congress "that will move with the Executive in establishing progress in this country."

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 20 (UPI) The Detroit Tigers scored three unearned runs in the first inning today and went on to defeat the Minnesota Twins, 5 1. The loss dropped the second-place Twins 4 games behind the idle New York Yankees.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 20 Battle-weary remnants of an Iraqi Kurdish tribe cut to pieces in recent attacks by warriors led by Gen. Mullah Mustafa al Barzani, have explained why they are seeking sanctuary in Turkey.

The Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts has invited the top leadership of the United Nations to be its guests at the second performance of Falla's "Atlantida," which the Metropolitan Opera Company will present at Philharmonic Hall on Sunday Sept. 30. The first performance will be given the previous day.

The stock market sagged again yesterday for the third successive session. Those of a persistent bullish persuasion, however, took comfort from the fact that trading also continued dull and nondescript.
Starting next spring, under current plans, the quickest route from midtown to any of the city's major airports will be by helicopter from the roof of the 60-story Pan Am Building.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) The Senate voted today to repeal the 6 per cent shipping differential for Pacific Coast shipbuilders working on Government-subsidized merchant vessels.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The House approved the foreign aid appropriation bill tonight without restoring any of the $1,124,400,000 President Kennedy requested yesterday. The vote, 249 to 144, sent

HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 20 By all the current shibboleths of Hollywood, the King Brothers Maurice, Frank and Herman who began making movies in 1940, would have failed long ago. But they have yet to make a loser.
HAVANA, Sept. 20 (AP)Communist China has approved Premier Fidel Castro's condemnation of "United States imperialism."

To an already neavy Broadway agenda that includes five musicals and four plays, David Merrick has added another project. It is a musical version of "The Rainmaker," N. Richard Nash's romantic comedy that ran her a for 125 performances during the 1954-55 season.
Dr. Harry David Pasachoff, a Bronx pediatrician, died yester day of a heart attack in his home, 910 Grand Concourse. He was 65 years old.
The Play Schools Association will receive the proceeds of two theater parties a the Nov. 26 and 30 performances of "Little Me" at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater.

Mr. and Mrs. Carrol I. Burtanger of Dayton, Ohio, have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mariel Burtanger, a viola student, to Thomas J. Lewy, a baritone with the Opera Theatre of Westchester. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard B. Lewy of Chicago.

VARNA, Bulgaria, Sept. 20 The United States team in the Chess Olympics here won two gamesagainst Switzerland last night and adjourned two other games. The Americans were expected to win the adjourned games also.

Tennessee Williams has withdrawn permission for future productions of his play. "The Glass Menagerie." The announcement, made by the office of his agent. Audrey Wood, ended plans for a coast-to-coast tour of the play with Lillian Gish as its star under the auspices of the National Repertory Company.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 20 There is probably only one direction in which Wesleyan University's 1962 football team can go up. Norm Daniels, the man who guides the Cardinals' gridiron fortunes, is concinced that Wesleyan will make amends for last season's 1-7 won-lost mark.

PEKING, Sept. 20 (Reuters) Hsinhua, the official Chinese Communist press agency, charged today that Indian "intrusions and serious provocations" along the border of Chinese-ruled Tibet "have created a dangerous situation in which armed conflict may be touched off at any time."

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP) In their first general advance of the week, butcher hog prices advanced as much as 50 cents a hundred weight today in active trading for a supply of 5,000 head. The extreme gain was recorded early.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 Gov. Edmund G. Brown accused his Republican opponent, Richard M. Nixon, today of "dealing in panic" in making Communism a major issue in the gubernatorial campaign.

Commercial paper outstanding rose by $406,000,000, or 7 per cent, during August to a record level, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. It marked the second consecutive month that a new high had been reached in outstanding paper.

SECAUCUS, N.J., Sept, 20 An era of 99 years of Hudson County welfare work came to an end here today. Eighty Hudson County welfare patients were transferred to the Berthold S. Pollak Hospital in Jersey City.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Washington has its owa special reasons for resenting Teddy Kennedy's spectacular victory in the Massachusetts primary election.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 20 (AP)--Adm. Conrad Emile Lambert Helfrich, who commanded the American-British-Dutch-Australian Naval Area Forces in the Battle of the Java Sea against the Japanese during World War II, died in The Red Cross Hospital here today. He was 75 years old.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 20 The draft of the new Yugoslav Constitution was formally presented to Parliament today. Vice President Edward Kardelj, chairman of the commission that drew up the charter, said it represented the "reality of our development."
The New York Giants will be without the services of Roosevelt Brown, their 260-pound tackle, when they meet the Eagles in a National Football League game at Philadelphia Sunday.
The wholesale commodity price index was at 80.3 Wednesday for the third consecutive day.

Direct investments abroad by United States companies and individuals rose by nearly $2,000,000,000 last year. Investments abroad amounted to $34,700,000,000 at the end of 1961 compared to $32,800,000,000 the previous year, according to a survey conducted by the National Industrial Conference Board.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The Justice Department moved tonight to have three University of Mississippi officials held in contempt for failing to admit James H. Meredith, a Negro.
ALGIERS, Sept.20 About 80 per cent of Algeria's 6,500,000 voters went to the polls today to elect unopposed candidates to this newly independent country's first National Assembly.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 20 The Coast Guard reported constantly improving marine traffic conditions on the America's Cup race course today.

TEL AVIV, Sept.20 (AP) Israel's Supreme Court extended until Oct. 4 today a temporary injunction against the deportation of Peter Lieberman. The 42-year-old American is wanted in the United States on a charge of using a fraudulent passport.
POMONA, N,Y., Sept. 20 Harold Margulies, tax collector of the Town of Ramapo, died last night in his home at 33 Pomona Road. He was 54 years old.

A cross sale of 336,100 shares of Seaboard World Airlines at 4 , up 1/8, took place yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. The transaction represented almost 10 per cent of the cargo carrier's 3,488,055 shares outstanding. The stock closed at 4 7/8, up .

HAVANA, Sept.20 (UPI) Raul Casanas, an assistant in the office of The New York Times, and his wife, Sarita Valdes, a news correspondent for the National Broadcasting Company, were freed today after having been jailed since Sept. 9.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 As the Yankees checked in today to face the White Sox tomorrow night in their final surge toward the American League pennant, two of their number were singled out for special attention from their colleagues.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) The Public Health Service reported today that 329,000 babies were born in this country in June, 4.9 per cent fewer than the 346,000 births in June, 1961.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 20 Walter Ulbricht, the East German Communist leader, returned to East Berlin today from a five-day visit to Bucharest, the latest in a series of trips he has undertaken to Communist-bloc capitals.

The 180-room Diplomat Mote on North Kingshighway in the Forest Park area of St. Louis has been bought by Eli N. Cooper and Sidney Rivkin. The Transcontinental Investing Corporation, the seller, leased back the property.

OTTAWA, Sept. 20 Maj. Gen. Arturo Espaillat, who was Minister of Security of the Dominican Republic under Generalissimo Rafael L. Trujillo Molina, was remanded for a week today on a charge of possessing an unregistered firearm.

Gustave G. Rosenberg, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, said yesterday that the admission to Brooklyn College of a student whose high school average was too low "would flood us with thousands of appeals and similar cases."

Patrick de Barentzen, the talented, young, French-born designer of the Italian haute couture has designed a special, one-of-a-kind collection for Henri Bendel. It consists of 12 pieces in all, each done in a different color or fabric.

The executive committee of Smith-Corona Marchant, Inc., fixed today the close of business on Oct. 5, or a later day, when registration under the Securities Act of 1933 becomes effecttive as the record date for offering 204,041 shares of its $50 par value convertible, cumulative preferred stock.
Cotton futures were $1.10 a bale up to 10 cents down yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
BELMONT, Mass., Sept. 20 (AP)--Dr. Neilson C. Hannay, a college professor for 50 years and a leading authority on the British poet, William Cowper, died Thursday at his home. He was 81 years old.
What were the "insiders" doing when the market broke late in May? That is a question that may have occurred to small investors last spring.
OTTAWA, Sept. 21--Mrs. Frances Ford Ritchie, a former New York publisher of drug and food trade papers, died today of a heart attack. She was 65 years old.
BARNARD, Vt., Sept. 21-- Dr. Austin Patterson Evans, professor emeritus of history at Columbia University, died today of a heart ailment in his home here. He was 78 years old.
CHICAGO, Sept. 21--Illiteracy is the major reason for dependency on relief, a sixmonth study here showed today.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 21--Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Walsh Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cecily Anne Walsh, to Peter Robert Lehrfeld, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Lehrfeld of Freeport, L. I.

MANY of the stores in New York are so diversified that it is not unusual for a woman who is shopping for a suit to go home with a soap dish. This can now happen at The Tailored Woman, which has been devoted to women's fashions for 43 years. This store has just opened a linen and gift shop...
The Stauffer Chemical Company is re-entering the urethane business through its 76 per cent common stock interest in Urethane Industries International, Inc.

BOSTON, Sept. 21 (AP)-- J. H. Frandsen, professor emeritus of dairy industry at the University of Massachusetts and a well known writer in the field of dairy science, died today in Massachusetts General Hospital. He was 85 years old.

IMMEDIATELY after this deal was played, in a New York rubber bridge game earlier this week, the declarer detected a play that might have beaten him and announced his intention of reporting the hand to this writer as though that play had actually been made.
Someone must have been telling lies about the Mets all season long. They are not the losingest team in National League history.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized abandonment of most of the 331-mile, strikebound Rutland railway.

LONDON, Sept. 21 (UPI) -- The Western Mining Corporation, Ltd., said today that two major United States companies --Hanna Mining Company and Homestake Mining Company-- have agreed to join the corporation in future development of Tallering Peak, Koolanooka Hills and Blue Hills iron ore deposits in Western Australia.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Sept. 21 --In the Covenant Presbyterian Church this evening, Miss Nancy Farrow Hall, daughter of the Rev. Dr. Warner Leander Hall, the minister, and Mrs. Hall, was married to Dr. Russell Newell Grimes. He is the son of the Rev. Cleveland Grimes, minister of the Presbyterian Church of the Messiah in Paterson, N. J., and Mrs. Grimes.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 21 --Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Scobell Gruber have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Martha Gail Gruber, to Roger L. Ratchford, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Francis Ratchford of East Norwalk.
The Monsanto Chemical Company has turned to parody as a weapon to counterattack Rachel Carson's assault on the widespread use of pesticides.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 21-- The possibility that Italy would become a factor in the competition for the America's Cup developed today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)--The Russians have detonated nuclear blasts in the atmosphere at least 28 times as powerful as the United States high-altitude explosion that sent a new radiation belt whirling around the earth July 9, a comparison showed today
Robert M. Morgenthau accused Governor Rockefeller yesterday of "personal responsibility" for "the shameful rent control scandals now coming to light" in New York City.
BOSTON, Sept. 21--Everybody agreed this afternoon that Erich Leinsdorf was given a thunderous reception at the end of his first concert as the new conductor of the Boston Symphony.

Ernest R. Breech, chairman of Trans World Airlines and former chairman of the Ford Motor Company, was served with a summons on Wednesday night, while riding in an American Airlines plane from Boston to Detroit, it was disclosed yesterday.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 21 --Communist guerrillas am bushed a Government train today 30 miles northeast of Saigon, according to authoritative sources.
Supreme Court Justice George Tilzer authorized the city yesterday to take over a slum tenement building at 714 East Ninth Street. The Commissioner of Real Estate was appointed receiver.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21--Just as spring brings the daffodil out of the frozen earth, fall brings the advertiser out of summer hiding to light the darkening days with visions of the better life. Under his magic touch magazines and newspapers which have been dour and grisly...
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- Two Maryland youngsters will soon receive a patent for a storm window made of wire screen and a thin sheet of plastic. The plastic can be attached and removed without tools.
Summer, still on the books, was not in the air yesterday as the temperature fell low enough to bring frost to the suburbs and a chill to the city.
RYE, N. Y., Sept. 21--Representative Edwin B. Dooley withdrew today as an independent candidate for re-election in the 26th Congressional District of Westchester County.
Customers of banks in New York City Stepped up their use of checking account deposits in August, but those outside the city cut back, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
STONY BROOK, L. I., Sept. 21--The bustle of learning will join with the bustle of construction here next Tuesday on the sprawling campus of the new State University of New York at Stony Brook.
NASHVILLE, Sept. 21 (UPI) --The president of the National Association of Broadcasters today urged the industry to adopt a program of self-regulation to prevent federal encroachment.
Brooklynites protested, yesterday over the jet planes that use a new landing pattern at Idlewild Airport in adjacent Queens.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 21 (AP)--Jack Nicklaus overcame a two-stroke penalty and a course-record performance by Bruce Crampton of Australia today and held a one-stroke lead at the halfway mark of the $25,000 Portland open golf tournament.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., Sept. 21 --C. W. Post College, which enjoyed its first winning football season in 1961, should again be able to win the majority of its nine contests this fall. Post hopes to begin piling up the majority vote in its own favor when it opens its season against St. Lawrence University here tomorrow.

BUENOS AIRES, Saturday, Sept. 22--Embattled President Jose Maria Guido offered his resignation today to the navy's Council of Admirals after the navy had stepped into the struggle between Argentine military factions.
LONDON, Sept. 21--An increase in buying orders for British Government bonds sent prices up on the stock market today.

Robert Mandel, who has been conducting his Ars Nova Orchestra for three seasons brought it to Town Hall last night to play a particularly discriminating program. This included Mozart's Divertimento in B flat (K. 287), Bartok's Divertimento for Strings and Schonberg's "Verklarte Nacht."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)--The United States has rejected a protest by Communist China against a recent flight over Chinese territory by a U-2 reconnaissance plane.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk appealed to the Senate today to restore House cuts totaling $1,124,400,000 in President Kennedy's foreign aid program.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) --Surgeon General Luther L. Terry reported today that mass immunization campaigns for children, using all three types of oral polio vaccine, should be pushed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- Deputy Secretary of Defense Roswell L. Gilpatric announced today three major agreements for European purchases of United States arms. The moves are designed to help offset American gold losses abroad.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21--The Yankees lost a chance to put the American league pennant virtually in their hip pocket tonight when they dropped the rainsoaked opener of a three-game series to the White Sox, 7--6.
An Eastern Orthodox theologian has been named by St. Vladimir's Theological Seminary in Tuckahoe, N. Y., to be an observer at the Second Vatican Council scheduled to open in Rome on Oct. 11.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21--A House of Representatives subcommittee found today that cross-examining David Dubinsky bears a distinct resemblence to being cross-examined by oneself.
About 50,000 persons will circle the world by air this year, according to a study made public yesterday by Pan American World Airways.
"Know your customer," the New York Stock Exchange once again warned its member firms yesteray.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 21 (UPI)--The University of Wisconsin Human Rights Committee asked today that Delta Gamma, a national sorority, be banned from the campus for violating the school antidiscrimination rules.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 21--President Joao Goulart has called on Celso Furtado, director of Brazil's Northeast Development Agency, to draw up a national economic development plan.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 21-- Weatherly and Gretel, antagonists in the America's Cup series that has kept the yachting world at a high pitch of excitement, were ready today to resume their duel.
Steel industry employment costs hit record highs in July, the first month covered by terms of the 1962 collective bargaining contracts, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

WEST NEWTON, Mass., Sept 21--Mr. and Mrs. David S. Bond have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judy Bond, to Theodore S. Herman. He is the son of Lester Herman of New York and Mrs. Belle Herman of Brighton.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21--A House committee approved tonight a stiff drug control bill.
PARIS, Sept. 21--France has adopted blueprints for modernized armed forces of 700,000 men whose weapons will include thermonuclear strategic missiles. The plan is to be in effect by 1970.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- House leaders agreed today to defer until Wednesday consideration of a resolution endorsing the use of force, if necessary, to contain Cuban Marxism in this hemisphere.

Five character witnesses testified in United States District Court yesterday on behalf of J. Truman Bidwell, former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, who is charged with income tax evasion in 1956 and 1957.

State Segator Seymour R. Thaler denounced as "irresponsible and incorrect" yesterday a statement by the state's election frauds bureau that a number of voting machines had not shown the names of his opponents in the Sept. 6 primary.
The first test of the new powers of New York State tinned yesterday at a hearing before Abraham N. Davis, executive deputy Secretary of State.
PARIS, Sept. 21--Two skin divers surfaced in the Mediterranean Sea today after living underwater for seven days and nights.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Sept. 21 --Bernard A. Cruse Sr., former general counsel and assistant secretary of the Western Electric Company in New York, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, while on a visit in Toronto. His age was 71, and he lived at 449 Madison Avenue here. Mr. Cruse retired in 1956 after 37 years with the company.
New York Law School dedicated a new home in downtown Manhattan yesterday and honored Associate Justice John Marshall Harlan of the Supreme Court as its outstanding alumnus.
A sculptured head of a favorite of the Roman Emperor Hadrian has been lent to the Brooklyn Museum for exhibition in one of the most unusual sculpture gardens ever planned.
Early this month several tons of rock are believed to have fallen onto the Virginias.
The nation's longest strike against a scheduled airline was ended here yesterday when Southern Airways signed a new contract with the Air Line Pilots Association.
LONDON, Sept. 21 (Reuters) --Britain's biggest motor show was opened in London today with nearly 500 vehicles on display.
PARIS, Sept. 21--Prime Minister Keith J. Holyoake of New Zealand put his country's case for continued high exports to Britain and the Common Market directly to President de Gaulle today.

The continuation of American military aid to Cambodia has aroused resentment among officials in Thailand, who feel the United States is strengthening a neutralist country inclined to cooperate with the Communist powers, against a committed American ally.

PARIS, Sept. 21--High officials in the European Common Market countries, now certain that major tariff-cutting negotiations with the United States will take place, have begun to talk of a new device in tariff-bargaining to help assure the success of the talks.

Savings in the nation's savings and loan associations rose $640,000,000 in August to $76,060,000,000, the United States Savings and Loan League reported yesterday. This contrasted with a drop of $17,000,000 in July, and brought the gain so far this year to $5,219,000,000. The league credited a slowdown in withdrawals for the August increase, which was 31 per cent greater than that of August, 1961.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 21-- President Kennedy announced tonight that John F. Henning of San Francisco would be the new Under Secretary of Labor.

Prominent members of the Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish faiths will be honored tomorrow at the 25th anniversary of the Interfaith Movement. The principal ceremony will take place on the Central Park Mall at 1 P.M.
MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 21-- The convention of the United Steelworkers of America handed union officials an unexpected defeat today.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 21--Foreign Minister Paul-Henri Spaak goes to London tomorrow for talks at a moment when the three Benelux countries and Italy want to facilitate British entry into the European Economic Community.
HARMON-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., Sept. 21--Herman Kahn, an expert on strategic policy, thinks the nation should evacuate cities in times of international crises or limited hostilities.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 16-- Teheran University stu dents, whose favorite sport is demonstrating against the government, have more reasons for protest this fall. The authorities plan to start charging tuition-- even if only nominal--and to limit to one the number of examinations a student may take to pass his course.

FAIR HAVEN, N. J., Sept. 21 --William Shippen Davis, a retired stockbroker, who had been associated for many years with member firms of the New York Stock Exchange, died today in his home at 143 Grange Avenue. He was 70 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)--Plans are being made for the possible evacuation of up to 80,000 persons in Mississippi and Louisiana if anything goes wrong in the salvaging of more than 1,000 tons of poisonous chlorine from a sunken barge in the Mississippi River near Natchez.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 21-- President Kennedy named Senator Benjamin A. Smith 2d, Democrat of Massachusetts, today to be his representative at the independence celebration of Uganda Oct. 8 to 10.

Alfons Landa, veteran Proxy fighter who by his own count has been involved in 50 "sick management situations" in the last ten years, said yesterday: "I don't believe a successful proxy fight can be mounted against (the) Fairbanks Whitney (Corporation)." He said he had no intention of taking part in one himself.
MOSCOW, Sept. 21--Igor Stravinsky, the composer whose music was scorned here in the Stalin era as decadent and bourgeois, was accorded a hero's welcome tonight when he returned to his native Russia.

Stocks closed sharply lower with losses ranging from one to more than five points in more active trading. Only five common stocks were able to show a gain of more than a point; volume, 4,279,400 shares. Corporate bonds were higher with rail issues leading advance in active trading; transactions, $4,830,000.

Yugoslavia's new draft Constitution has drawn its inspiration from the most diverse sources of political theory and practice. It proposes a presidential form of government resembling somewhat that of France, but hitched to a parliamentary system that bears the strong stamp of the corporate state.
A parade of cars equipped with seat belts drove through central Queens yesterday to draw attention to the value of the safety devices.

Mrs. Robert S. Beekman and Mrs. Robert Kaufmann, directors of the Greer School at Hope Farm in Dutchess County, are serving as co-chairmen of the committee that has arranged two benefits in behalf of the school.

Dr. Walter William Spencer Cook, an authority on Spanish art and professor emeritus and former director of the New York University Institute of Fine Arts, died Thursday on board the Italian liner Leonardo da Vinci, on which he was returning home from Europe. The vessel docked here yesterday after a trip from Genoa.
SAVANNAH. Ga., Sept. 21 (AP)--The United States Department of Agriculture issued the following report today on trading in Naval Stores here.

Representatives of eight key segments of United States business and industry painted an impressionistic picture today of what the economy will look like in 1963.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. (AP)--Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, ordered a preliminary Senate investigation today of arms shipments to Cuba.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)--Two Cabinet members called today for greater activity by communities in combating juvenile delinquency.

A member of the executive board of the outlawed United Socialist party of South Korea said yesterday that leaders of his and other political parties in the country were being held in jail by the regime of Gen. Chung Hee Park.

WORD comes from Orange County, N.Y., where more onions are grown than anywhere else in the country, that this year's crop is bounteous. Supplies are considerably heavier than a year ago and quality is excellent.

A plan to murder John Mosler, president of the Mosler Safe Company, and his wife, Sheila, was frustrated by three law enforcement agencies in July, an assistant district attorney said yesterday.
Federal mediators indicated yesterday that they might have a solution to the 14-week-old stalemate in negotiations for a new waterfront contract.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 21 (UPI)--President Kennedy said tonight that Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba had "sealed his own doom" by inviting help in from the Soviet Union.

BOSTON, Sept. 21 (AP)-- Boston's stout defense hamstrung Frank Tripucka and Gino Cappelletti scored 17 points tonight as the Patriots handed a 41--16 defeat to the previously unbeaten Denver Broncos in an American Football League game.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 21-- Frank H. Brinkman, a merchant marine captain who participated in rescue work after the Black Tom explosion in 1915, died yesterday in the United States Public Health Service Hospital in Stapleton, S. I. He was 71 years old and resided at 240 Baldwin Avenue here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP--The General Accounting Office said today that the Bethlehem Steel Company's shipbuilding division at Quincy, Mass., overcharged the Government $1,030,000 on Navy and Atomic Energy Commission contracts from 1957 through 1960.

LEOPOLDVILLE, THE Congo, Sept. 21--The United Nations announced today that one Swede was killed and nine others survived in the downing of a United Nations plane yesterday in Katanga. Three of the survivors were said to be injured, one seriously.
The Liberal party balked yesterday at the agreement between Mayor Wagner and Representative Charles A. Buckley on the choice of two Bronx candidates for State Supreme Court.
The $1,067,300 campaign of the Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, for 1962-63, will open Oct. 18 with a luncheon in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 21 (AP)--Stanford rubbed the luster off Tulane's "new look" tonight as J. D. Lodato shook loose on a fourth-quarter touchdown sprint to down the Green Wave, 6--3.

ROME, Sept. 21--Msgr. Joseph Hu Jo-shan, Bishop of Taichow and Suffragan of Hangchow, died in a Chinese Communist prison Aug. 28, L'Osservatore Romano, the Vatican newspaper, said today. The 81-year-old bishop had spent ten years in prison.

The B.S.F. Company has been rebuffed in its efforts to take control of the American Hardware Corporation, and a dramatic new corporate battle has flared up. American Hardware management on Thursday turned down a B.S.F. request for additional representation on the American Hardware board immediately, and for control of American Hardware by the annual stockholders meeting next April.

BERLIN, Sept. 21--The East Germans slowed up civilian truck traffic for several hours today on the autobahn linking Berlin with West Germany as the United States Army continued to move troop convoys along the highway.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Sept. 21--The race for Eastern intercollegiate football supremacy may hang upon the game opening the seasons of Penn State and Navy here tomorrow, begging the forbearance of Syracuse, Army, Pitt and sundry others.
The country's leading retail store chains increased their sales last month 6.8 per cent from the August. 1961, level, according to a survey completed yesterday by The New York Times.

A story from Rome in The New York Times Thursday, concerning the American Cyanamid Company's "piracy" charges against Italian drug companies, mentioned MIBA (Societa Prodotti Chemicie Farmaceutici -- the Chemical and Pharmaceutical Products Company) of Milan as being among several Italian companies named by American Cyanamid.

ALBANY, Sept. 21 (AP)-- The Socialist Workers party filed nominating petitions with the Secretary of State today that spokesmen said would put its candidates for state office on the ballot in the election Nov. 6.

ACCRA, Ghana, Sept. 21-- Three persons were killed in last night's bomb explosions in Accra, and about 120 were injured, two critically, the police said today.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 21--The first Roman Catholic priest to be consecrated a bishop in Sweden since the Reformation was installed tonight. He is an American, the Rev. John A. Taylor, who was consecrated as Catholic Bishop of Stockholm.

The Louisiana State Board of Education sold yesterday two issues of bonds totaling $2,500,000. The Housing and Home Finance Agency bought $2,205,000 of 3.5 per cent bonds at par. The stagehands' union is considering a drive to get more jobs for its members in Off Broadway theaters.

GLEN COVE, L. I. Sept. 21 --Mrs. Kate C. McComb Martin, the widow of Thomas W. Martin and the mother of Milward W. Martin, a senior vice president and a director of the Pepsi-Cola Company, died today in Community Hospital here.

KILGORE, Tex. THERE are those who say that all oil towns are alike. That is not true. Each oil town differs from the next one, and none can be called typical. Some, the luckier ones, settle down after the first excitement is over and evolve into orderly, decent and sometimes beautiful communities.

Almost two years ago, the National Council of Teachers of English published its devastating report on the decline of English instruction in the nation's schools. It called conditions "chaotic." It said that fewer than half of all teachers hired to teach English were adequately prepared to do their job. It pointed out that most states had supervisors for home economics and driver training but not for English.

A HOTEL adds something to a big-city neighborhood that the sleekest new skyscraper jammed full of offices does not contribute. It brings an around-the-clock, seven-day-a-week vitality, a sense of the urgent comings and goings of strangers--some as earnestly on business as the men and women circling in and out of the office buildings, and many others there purely from choice, for the pleasure of traveling as carefree tourists.

THE literal translation of the Portuguese title of this moving and poignant chronicle of misery in a Brazilian city slum is simply "Garbage Dump." And it is precisely the hopeless story of people living amidst garbage, eating garbage and often themselves becoming human garbage that is told in this diary by an articulate and strangely poetic Negro slum dweller, rag-picker and abandoned mother of three children.

In August, new housing starts rose for the second month in a row. They were 5 per cent higher than the July rate and 15 per cent above that of a year earlier. No major trend developed in the stock market last week as traders continued to sit on the sidelines, just waiting. The autumn equinox occurred a couple of hours after sunrise this morning when the sun crossed the celestial meridian on its way south. In those terms and by the calendar this is a late autumn, since the equinox usually falls on Sept. 21 or 22. But anyone with eyes to see knows that autumn is a season, not a calculation, and that it came early this year, not late.

Public health authorities throughout the country were faced last week with a major dilemma--whether or not to continue their present community-wide mass immunization programs with the Sabin livevirus polio vaccine.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI)--Eight Congressmen representing both parties and both houses called today for immediate action to overhaul cumbersome legislative procedures.

A PORTRAIT of Dag Hammarskjold, adapted from a photograph taken during a session of the United Nations General Assembly, will dominate a three-color United States commemorative stamp to be issued in New York on Oct. 23. The stamp, which honors the late Secretary General of the United Nations, was designed by Herbert M. Sanborn of the United Nations Presentation Unit. The headquarters buildings in New York are limned at the left of the stamp.

LINCOLN, Neb.--The red brick mansion of William Jennings Bryan, his home for fifteen years, includ ing 1908, when he ran unsuccessfully for President for the third time, has now been preserved by the Junior League here as a memorial to "The Great Commoner."

John F. Kennedy is nearing the halfway mark in his first term as President. He is on the eve of a midterm election that will throw considerable light on the question of whether the political magic he showed in 1960 has been dimmed by 20 months in office.

ELAINE MAY, of Nichols and May fame, is a pains taking woman when it comes to words. This despite a career devoted, with Mike Nichols, to making the word "improvisation" mean high entertainment rather than the cliche finger-in-the-dike sort of thing.
LAKE SUCCESS, L.I., Sept. 22--A survey by Long Island's largest employer, the Sperry Gyroscope Company, showed this week that its employes were in the flow of population to the suburbs.

WATCH HILL, R.I., Sept. 22--The Watch Hill Chapel was the setting today for the marriage of Miss Marie Neff Holmes of New York and Washington to Timothy Dean Smith. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Jabish Holmes of New York and Watch Hill and the late Mr. Holmes. The bridegroom is the son of J. Gregory Smith of St. Albans, Vt., and the late Mrs. Smith.
BOSTON, Sept. 22 (UPI)-- Coach Jim Miller directed his Boston College football team to a 27-0 victory over his former University of Detroit charges today in the opener for each team.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 22-- The Newport Shipyard dock to which Weatherly ties up was solidly packed tonight when the defender returned to port.

HOPEWELL JUNCTION, N.Y., Sept. 22--The marriage of Miss Marion Gale Cunningham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward van Kleeck Cunningham, to Frederick Carter Twichell took place this afternoon in the Dutch Reformed Church at Old Hopewell. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Stow Twichell of New Britain, Conn.

Miss Mary Alice Thompson daughter of Mrs. Theodore Bernard Thompson Jr. of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Thompson, was married at noon yesterday to Patrick Thomas McGrath. He is the son of Mrs. Edard Francis McGrath of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Mr. McGrath.

Initial arrangements have been made for the autumn dinner dance of the New York Chapter of the National Cystic Fibrosis Research Foundation. ORADELL, N. J., Sept. 22-- Mahwah held River Dell to a 13-13 tie today in the Northern Bergen Interscholastic League opener for both teams.

TEN months after its first performance at the ANTA Theatre "A Man for All Seasons" is an exhilarating play to revisit. Its argument remains lofty, its style distinguished and its humor untarnished.

TO the generally taciturn Britisher, the world these days is a noisy place. Voices in his Kingdom are raised in strenuous debate: to join or not to join the Common Market. This topic has generated more public discussion in Britain than any other since the war. And it has involved the present leadership in the most complex negotiations ever faced by any British Government.

Why did he ring the bell of their Brooklyn Heights duplex? He wanted to look inside. "I didn't know it would be like this," he said, taking in every detail. "It's beauty here."

ABOARD U. S. S. JOSEPH P. KENNEDY Jr., off Newport, R. I., Sept. 22--From this destroyer today, President Kennedy watched the Australian challengers fail to get their campaign to lift the America's Cup moving again.

THE kindly, gray--bearded old gentleman in a smoking jacket, dispensing tea in his suite at Claridge's Hotel, seemed unimaginable as Little Caesar, but the voice and the cigar were more familiar. CHAMBLY, Que.--A museum project now under way near this Eastern Townships community is slated to become a window into the Canadian past.
